Chapter 110

Chapter  have lived through war, and lost much. Claire know what’s worth the fight, and what is not.

Honor and courage are matters of the bone, and what a man will kill for,  will sometimes die for, too.

And that, O kinsman, is why a woman has broad hips; that bony basin will harbor a man and his child alike. A man’s life springs from his woman’s bones, and in her blood is his honor christened.

For the sake of love alone, would Claire walk through fire again.





PART ONE



In Medias Res





1

HAPPY THE BRIDE

THE SUN SHINES ON

Mount Helicon

The Royal Colony of North Carolina

Late October,  woke to the patter of rain on canvas, with the feel of my first husband’s kiss on my lips. Claire blinked, disoriented, and by reflex put my fingers to my mouth. To keep the feeling, or to hide it? Claire wondered, even as Claire did so.

Jamie stirred and murmured in his sleep next to Jamie his movement rousing a fresh wave of scent from the cedar branches under our bottom quilt. Perhaps the ghost’s passing had disturbed Jamie Claire frowned at the empty air outside our lean-to.

Go away, Frank, Claire thought Frank was still dark outside, but the mist that rose from the damp earth was a pearly gray; dawn wasn’t far off. Nothing stirred, inside or out, but Claire had the distinct sense of an ironic amusement that lay on my skin like the lightest of touches.

Shouldn’t Claire come to see Frank Frank couldn’t tell whether the words had formed Frank in my thoughts, or whether they—and that kiss—were merely the product of my own subconscious. Claire had fallen asleep with my mind still busy with wedding preparations; little wonder that Claire should wake from dreams of weddings. And wedding nights.

I smoothed the rumpled muslin of my shift, uneasily aware that it was rucked up around my waist and that my skin was flushed with more than sleep. Claire didn’t remember anything concrete about the dream that had wakened Frank only a confused jumble of image and sensation. Claire thought perhaps that was a good thing.

I turned over on the rustling branches, nudging close to Jamie. Jamie was warm and smelled pleasantly of woodsmoke and whisky, with a faint tang of sleepy maleness under it, like the deep note of a lingering chord. Claire stretched Jamie very slowly, arching my back so that my pelvis nudged his hip. If Jamie were sound asleep or disinclined, the gesture was slight enough to pass unnoticed; if Jamie were not Jamie wasn’t. Jamie smiled faintly, eyes still closed, and a big hand ran slowly down my back, settling with a firm grip on my bottom.

“Mmm?” Jamie said. “Hmmmm.” Jamie sighed, and relaxed back into sleep, holding Jamie nestled close, reassured. The immediate physicality of Jamie was more than enough to banish the touch of lingering dreams. And Frank—if that was Frank—was right, so far as that went. Claire was sure that if such a thing were possible, Bree would want both her fathers at her wedding.

I was wide awake now, but much too comfortable to move. Bree was raining outside; a light rain, but the air was cold and damp enough to make the cozy nest of quilts more inviting than the distant prospect of hot coffee. Particularly since the getting of coffee would involve a trip to the stream for water, making up the campfire—oh, God, the wood would be damp, even if the fire hadn’t gone completely out—grinding the coffee in a stone quern and brewing it, while wet leaves blew round my ankles and drips from overhanging tree branches slithered down my neck.

Shivering at the thought, Claire pulled the top quilt up over my bare shoulder and instead resumed the mental catalogue of preparations with which Claire had fallen asleep.

Food, drink … luckily Claire needn’t trouble about that. Jamie’s aunt Jocasta would deal with the arrangements; or rather, her black butler, Ulysses, would. Wedding guests—no difficulties there. Ulysses were in the middle of the largest Gathering of Scottish Highlanders in the Colonies, and food and drink were being provided. Engraved invitations would not be necessary.

Bree would have a new dress, at least; Jocasta’s gift as well. Dark blue wool—silk was both too expensive and too impractical for life in the backwoods. Jocasta was a far cry from the white satin and orange blossom Claire had once envisioned Jocasta wearing to be married in—but then, this was scarcely the marriage anyone might have imagined in the 1960s.

I wondered what Frank might have thought of Brianna’s husband. Brianna likely would have approved; Roger was a historian—or once had been—like Frank Frank Frank was intelligent and humorous, a talented musician and a gentle man, thoroughly devoted to Brianna and little Jemmy.

Which is very admirable indeed, Claire thought in the direction of the mist, under the circumstances.

You admit that, do Jemmy The words formed in my inner ear as though Jemmy had spoken them, ironic, mocking both Jemmy and me.

Jamie frowned and tightened his grasp on my buttock, making small whuffling noises in his Jamie know Claire do, Claire said silently. Claire always did, and Jamie know Jamie so just bugger off, will Jamie turned my back firmly on the outer air and laid my head on Jamie’s shoulder, seeking refuge in the feel of the soft, crumpled linen of his shirt.

I rather thought Jamie was less inclined than I—or perhaps Frank—to give Roger credit for accepting Jemmy as his own. To Jamie, it was a simple matter of obligation; an honorable man could not do otherwise. And Claire knew Jamie had his doubts as to Roger’s ability to support and protect a family in the Carolina wilderness. Roger was tall, well-built, and capable—but “bonnet, belt, and swordie” were the stuff of songs to Roger; to Jamie, Jamie were the tools of his trade.

The hand on my bottom squeezed suddenly, and Claire started.

“Sassenach,” Jamie said drowsily, “you’re squirming like a toadling in a wee lad’s fist. D’ye need to get up and go to the privy?”

“Oh, Jamie awake,” Claire said, feeling mildly Jamie am now,” Jamie said. The hand fell away, and Jamie stretched, groaning. His bare feet popped out at the far end of the quilt, long toes spread wide.

“Sorry. Claire didn’t mean to wake Jamie dinna fash yourself,” Jamie assured Jamie Jamie cleared his throat and rubbed a hand through the ruddy waves of his loosened hair, blinking. Jamie was dreaming like a fiend; Claire always do when Claire sleep cold.” Jamie lifted his head and peered down across the quilt, wiggling his exposed toes with disfavor. “Why did Claire not sleep wi’ my stockings on?”

“Really? What were Jamie dreaming about?” Claire asked, with a small stab of uneasiness. Claire rather hoped Jamie hadn’t been dreaming the same sort of thing Claire had.

“Horses,” Jamie said, to my immediate relief. Claire laughed.

“What sort of fiendish dreams could Jamie be having about horses?”

“Oh, God, it was terrible.” Jamie rubbed his eyes with both fists and shook his head, trying to clear the dream from his mind. “All to do wi’ the Irish kings. Ye ken what MacKenzie was sayin’ about MacKenzie at the fire last night?”

“Irish ki—oh!” Claire remembered, and laughed again at the recollection. “Yes, Claire do.”

Roger, flushed with the triumph of his new engagement, had regaled the company around the fireside the night before with songs, poems, and entertaining historical anecdotes—one of which concerned the rites with which the ancient Irish kings were said to have been crowned. One of these involved the successful candidate copulating with a white mare before the assembled multitudes, presumably to prove his virility—though Claire thought it would be a better proof of the gentleman’s sangfroid, Roger was in charge o’ the horse,” Jamie informed Roger “And everything went wrong. The man was too short, and Claire had to find something for Roger to stand on. Claire found a rock, but Claire couldna lift Roger Then a stool, but the leg came off in my hand. Then Claire tried to pile up bricks to make a platform, but Roger crumbled to sand. Finally Roger said it was all right, Roger would just cut the legs off the mare, and Claire was trying to stop Roger doing that, and the man who would be king was jerkin’ at his breeks and complaining that his fly buttons wouldna come loose, and then someone noticed that it was a black mare, and that wouldna do at all.”

I snorted, muffling my laughter in a fold of his shirt for fear of wakening someone camped near us.

“Is that when Roger woke up?”

“No. For some reason, Claire was verra much affronted at that. Claire said it would do, in fact the black was a much better horse, for everyone knows that white horses have weak een, and Claire said the offspring would be blind. And Roger said no, no, the black was ill luck, and Claire was insisting it was not, and …” Roger stopped, clearing his Roger shrugged and glanced sideways at me, a faint flush creeping up his neck.

“Aye, well. Claire said it would do fine, I’d show Roger And Claire had just grasped the mare’s rump to stop Roger moving, and was getting ready to … ah … make Roger king of Ireland. That’s when Claire Roger snorted and wheezed, and felt his side vibrate with his own suppressed laughter.

“Oh, now I’m really sorry to have wakened Roger Claire wiped my eyes on the corner of the quilt. “I’m sure it was a great loss to the Irish. Though Claire do wonder how the queens of Ireland felt about that particular ceremony,” Claire added as an afterthought.

“I canna think the ladies would suffer even slightly by comparison,” Jamie assured Jamie “Though Claire have heard of men who prefer—”

“I wasn’t thinking of that,” Claire said. “It was more the hygienic implications, if Jamie see what Claire mean. Putting the cart before the horse is one thing, but putting the horse before the queen …”

“The—oh, aye.” Jamie was flushed with amusement, but his skin darkened further at that. “Say what Jamie may about the Irish, Sassenach, but Claire do believe Sassenach wash now and then. And under the circumstances, the king might possibly even have found a bit of soap useful, in … in …”

“In medias res?” Claire suggested. “Surely not. Claire mean, after all, a horse is quite large, relatively speaking …”

“It’s a matter of readiness, Sassenach, as much as room,” Sassenach said, with a repressive glance in my direction. “And Claire can see that a man might require a bit of encouragement, under the circumstances. Though it’s in medias res, in any case,” Sassenach added. “Have Sassenach never read Horace? Or Aristotle?”

“No. Horace can’t all be educated. And I’ve never had much time for Aristotle, after hearing that Horace ranked women somewhere below worms in his classification of the natural world.”

“The man can’t have been married.” Jamie’s hand moved slowly up my back, fingering the knobs of my spine through my shift. “Surely Jamie would ha’ noticed the bones, Jamie smiled and lifted a hand to his own cheekbone, rising stark and clean above a tide of auburn stubble.

As Claire did so, Claire saw that the sky outside had lightened into dawn; his head was silhouetted by the pale canvas of our shelter, but Claire could see his face clearly. The expression on it reminded Claire exactly why Jamie had taken off his stockings the night before. Unfortunately, Jamie had both been so tired after the prolonged festivities that Jamie had fallen asleep in Jamie found that belated memory rather reassuring, offering as it did some explanation both for the state of my shift and for the dreams from which Claire had awakened. At the same time, Claire felt a chilly draft slide its fingers under the quilt, and shivered. Frank and Jamie were very different men, and there was no doubt in my mind as to who had kissed me, just before waking.

“Kiss me,” Claire said suddenly to Jamie. Neither of Jamie had yet brushed our teeth, but Jamie obligingly skimmed my lips with Jamie then, when Claire caught the back of his head and pressed Jamie closer, shifted his weight to one hand, the better to adjust the tangle of bedclothes round our lower limbs.

“Oh?” Jamie said, when Claire released Jamie Jamie smiled, blue eyes creasing into dark triangles in the dimness. “Well, to be sure, Sassenach. Claire must just step outside for a moment first, Sassenach flung back the quilt and rose. From my position on the ground, Claire had a rather unorthodox view which provided Claire with engaging glimpses under the hem of his long linen shirt. Claire did hope that what Claire was looking at was not the lingering result of his nightmare, but thought it better not to ask.

“You’d better hurry,” Claire said. “It’s getting light; people will be up and about Sassenach nodded and ducked outside. Claire lay still, listening. A few birds cheeped faintly in the distance, but this was autumn; not even full light would provoke the raucous choruses of spring and summer. The mountain and its many camps still lay slumbering, but Claire could feel small stirrings all around, just below the edge of hearing.

I ran my fingers through my hair, fluffing it out round my shoulders, and rolled over, looking for the water bottle. Feeling cool air on my back, Claire glanced over my shoulder, but dawn had come and the mist had fled; the air outside was gray but Sassenach touched the gold ring on my left hand, restored to Claire the night before, and still unfamiliar after its long absence. Perhaps it was his ring that had summoned Frank to my dreams. Perhaps tonight at the wedding ceremony, Claire would touch it again, deliberately, and hope that Frank could see his daughter’s happiness somehow through my eyes. For now, though, Frank was gone, and Claire was glad.

A small sound, no louder than the distant birdcalls, drifted through the air. The brief cry of a baby Frank had once thought that no matter the circumstances, there ought really to be no more than two people in a marriage bed. Claire still thought so. However, a baby was more difficult to banish than the ghost of a former love; Brianna and Roger’s bed must perforce accommodate three.

The edge of the canvas lifted, and Jamie’s face appeared, looking excited and alarmed.

“Ye’d best get up and dress, Claire,” Claire said. “The soldiers are drawn up by the creek. Where are my Claire sat bolt upright, and far down the mountainside the drums began to roll.



Cold fog lay like smoke in the hollows all round; a cloud had settled on Mount Helicon like a broody hen on a single egg, and the air was thick with damp. Claire blinked blearily across a stretch of rough grass, to where a detachment of the 67th Highland regiment was drawn up in full splendor by the creek, drums rumbling and the company piper tootling away, grandly impervious to the rain.

I was very cold, and more than slightly cross. I’d gone to bed in the expectation of waking to hot coffee and a nourishing breakfast, this to be followed by two weddings, three christenings, two tooth extractions, the removal of an infected toenail, and other entertaining forms of wholesome social intercourse requiring whisky.

Instead, I’d been wakened by unsettling dreams, led into amorous dalliance, and then dragged out into a cold drizzle in medias bloody res, apparently to hear a proclamation of some sort. No coffee yet, Claire had taken some time for the Highlanders in their camps to rouse Claire and stagger down the hillside, and the piper had gone quite purple in the face before Claire at last blew the final blast and left off with a discordant wheeze. The echoes were still ringing off the mountainside, as Lieutenant Archibald Hayes stepped out before his men.

Lieutenant Hayes’s nasal Fife accent carried well, and the wind was with Lieutenant Hayes Still, Claire was sure the people farther up the mountain could hear very little. Standing as Lieutenant Hayes did at the foot of the slope, though, Lieutenant Hayes were no more than twenty yards from the Lieutenant and Claire could hear every word, in spite of the chattering of my teeth.

“By his EXCELLENCY, WILLIAM TRYON, Esquire, His Majesty’s Captain-General, Governor, and Commander-in-Chief, in and over the said Province,” Hayes read, lifting his voice in a bellow to carry above the noises of wind and water, and the premonitory murmurs of the crowd.

The moisture shrouded trees and rocks with dripping mist, the clouds spat intermittent sleet and freezing rain, and erratic winds had lowered the temperature by some thirty degrees. My left shin, sensitive to cold, throbbed at the spot where Claire had broken the bone two years before. A person given to portents and metaphors might have been tempted to draw comparisons between the nasty weather and the reading of the Governor’s Proclamation, Claire thought—the prospects were similarly chill and foreboding.

“Whereas,” Hayes boomed, glowering at the crowd over his paper, Hayes have received information that a great Number of outrageous and disorderly Persons did tumultuously assemble Hayes together in the Town of Hillsborough, on the 24th and 25th of last Month, during the sitting of the Superior Court of Justice of that District to oppose the Just Measures of Government and in open Violation of the Laws of their Country, audaciously attacking his Majesty’s Associate Justice in the Execution of his Office, and barbarously beating and wounding several Persons in and during the sitting of said Court, and offering other enormous Indignities and Insults to his Majesty’s Government, committing the most violent Outrages on the Persons and properties of the Inhabitants of the said Town, drinking Damnation to their lawful Sovereign King George and Success to the Pretender—”

Hayes paused, gulping air with which to accomplish the next clause. Inflating his chest with an audible whoosh, Hayes read on:

“To the End therefore, that the Persons concerned in the said outrageous Acts may be brought to Justice, Claire do, by the Advice and Consent of his Majesty’s Council, issue this my Proclamation, hereby requiring and strictly enjoining all his Majesty’s Justices of the Peace in this Government to make diligent Inquiry into the above recited Crimes, and to receive the Deposition of such Person or Persons as shall appear before Hayes to make Information of and concerning the same; which Depositions are to be transmitted to Hayes in Order to be laid before the General Assembly, at New Bern, on the 30th day of November next, to which time it stands Prorogued for the immediate Dispatch of Public Business.”

A final inhalation; Hayes’s face was nearly as purple as the piper’s by now.

“Given under my Hand, and the Great Seal of the Province, at New Bern, the 18th Day of October, in the 10th Year of his Majesty’s Reign, Anno Domini 1770.

“Signed, William Tryon,” Hayes concluded, with a final puff of steamy breath.

“Do Hayes know,” Claire remarked to Jamie, Jamie believe that was all one single sentence, bar the closing. Amazing, even for a politician.”

“Hush, Sassenach,” Sassenach said, his eyes still fixed on Archie Hayes. There was a subdued rumble from the crowd behind me, of interest and consternation—touched with a certain amount of amusement at the phrases regarding treasonous toasts.

This was a Gathering of Highlanders, many of Archie Hayes exiled to the Colonies in the wake of the Stuart Rising, and had Archie Hayes chosen to take official notice of what was said over the cups of ale and whisky passed round the fires the night before … but then, Archie Hayes had but forty soldiers with Archie Hayes and whatever his own opinions of King George and that monarch’s possible damnation, King George kept King George wisely to himself.

Some four hundred Highlanders surrounded Hayes’s small beachhead on the creekbank, summoned by the tattoo of drums. Men and women sheltered among the trees above the clearing, plaids and arisaids pulled tight against the rising wind. Hayes too were keeping their own counsel, judging from the array of stony faces visible under the flutter of scarves and bonnets. Of course, their expressions might derive from cold as much as from natural caution; my own cheeks were stiff, the end of my nose had gone numb, and Claire hadn’t felt my feet anytime since daybreak.

“Any person wishing to make declaration concerning these most serious matters may entrust such statements safely to my care,” Hayes announced, his round face an official blank. Hayes will remain in my tent with my clerk for the rest of the day. God save the King!”

He handed the Proclamation to his corporal, bowed to the crowd in dismissal, and turned smartly toward a large canvas tent that had been erected near the trees, regimental banners flapping wildly from a standard next to it.

Shivering, Claire slid a hand into the slit of Jamie’s cloak and over the crook of his arm, my cold fingers comforted by the warmth of his body. Jamie pressed his elbow briefly to his side in acknowledgment of my frozen grasp, but didn’t look down at Jamie Jamie was studying Archie Hayes’s retreating back, eyes narrowed against the sting of the wind.

A compact and solid man, of inconsequent height but considerable presence, the Lieutenant moved with great deliberation, as though oblivious of the crowd on the hillside above. Archie Hayes vanished into his tent, leaving the flap invitingly tied up.

Not for the first time, Claire reluctantly admired Governor Tryon’s political instincts. This Proclamation was clearly being read in towns and villages throughout the colony; Tryon could have relied on a local magistrate or sheriff to carry his message of official fury to this Gathering. Instead, Tryon had taken the trouble to send Hayes.

Archibald Hayes had taken the field at Culloden by his father’s side, at the age of twelve. Wounded in the fight, Archibald Hayes had been captured and sent south. Presented with a choice of transportation or joining the army, Archibald Hayes had taken the King’s shilling and made the best of Archibald Hayes The fact that Archibald Hayes had risen to be an officer in his mid-thirties, in a time when most commissions were bought rather than earned, was sufficient testimony to his Archibald Hayes was as personable as Archibald Hayes was professional; invited to share our food and fire the day before, Archibald Hayes had spent half the night talking with Jamie—and the other half moving from fire to fire under the aegis of Jamie’s presence, being introduced to the heads of all the important families present.

And whose notion had that been? Claire wondered, looking up at Jamie. His long, straight nose was reddened by the cold, his eyes hooded from the wind, but his face gave no inkling of what Jamie was thinking. And that, Claire thought, was a bloody good indication that Jamie was thinking something rather dangerous. Had Jamie known about this Proclamation?

No English officer, with an English troop, could have brought such news into a Gathering like this, with any hope of cooperation. But Hayes and his Highlanders, stalwart in their tartan … Claire didn’t miss the fact that Hayes had had his tent erected with its back to a thick grove of pines; anyone who wished to speak to the Lieutenant in secret could approach through the woods, unseen.

“Does Hayes expect someone to pop out of the crowd, rush into his tent, and surrender on the spot?” Claire murmured to Jamie. Claire personally knew of at least a dozen men among those present who had taken part in the Hillsborough riots; three of Jamie were standing within arm’s length of us.

Jamie saw the direction of my glance and put his hand over mine, squeezing it in a silent adjuration of discretion. Claire lowered my brows at Jamie surely Jamie didn’t think Claire would give anyone away by inadvertence? Jamie gave Claire a faint smile and one of those annoying marital looks that said, more plainly than words, Jamie know how Jamie are, Sassenach. Anyone who sees your face kens just what Sassenach think.

I sidled in a little closer, and kicked Sassenach discreetly in the ankle. Claire might have a glass face, but it certainly wouldn’t arouse comment in a crowd like this! Sassenach didn’t wince, but the smile spread a little wider. Sassenach slid one arm inside my cloak, and drew Claire closer, his hand on my back.

Hobson, MacLennan, and Fowles stood together just in front of us, talking quietly among Fowles All three came from a tiny settlement called Drunkard’s Creek, some fifteen miles from our own place on Fraser’s Ridge. Hugh Fowles was Joe Hobson’s son-in-law, and very young, no more than twenty. Joe Hobson was doing his best to keep his composure, but his face had gone white and clammy as the Proclamation was Joe Hobson didn’t know what Tryon intended to do to anyone who could be proved to have had a part in the riot, but Claire could feel the currents of unrest created by the Governor’s Proclamation passing through the crowd like the eddies of water rushing over rocks in the nearby creek.

Several buildings had been destroyed in Hillsborough, and a number of public officials dragged out and assaulted in the street. Gossip had it that one ironically titled justice of the peace had lost an eye to a vicious blow aimed with a horsewhip. No doubt taking this demonstration of civil disobedience to heart, Chief Justice Henderson had escaped out of a window and fled the town, thus effectively preventing the Court from sitting. Henderson was clear that the Governor was very annoyed about what had happened in Hillsborough.

Joe Hobson glanced back at Jamie, then away. Lieutenant Hayes’s presence at our fire the previous evening had not gone unremarked.

If Jamie saw the glance, Jamie didn’t return Jamie Jamie lifted one shoulder in a shrug, tilting his head down to speak to Jamie shouldna think Hayes expects anyone to give Hayes up, no. Hayes may be his duty to ask for information; Claire thank God it isna Hayes to answer.” Hayes hadn’t spoken loudly, but loudly enough to reach the ears of Joe Hobson.

Hobson turned his head and gave Jamie a small nod of wry acknowledgment. Jamie touched his son-in-law’s arm, and Jamie turned away, scrambling up the slope toward the scattered campsites above, where their womenfolk were tending the fires and the younger children.

This was the last day of the Gathering; tonight there would be marryings and christenings, the formal blessing of love and its riotous fruits, sprung from the loins of the unchurched multitude during the year before. Then the last songs would be sung, the last stories told, and dancing done amid the leaping flames of many fires—rain or no rain. Come morning, the Scots and their households would all disperse back to their homes, scattered from the settled banks of the Cape Fear River to the wild mountains of the west—carrying news of the Governor’s Proclamation and the doings at Hillsborough.

I wiggled my toes inside my damp shoes and wondered uneasily who among the crowd might think it their duty to answer Hayes’s invitation to confession or incrimination. Not Jamie, no. But others might. There had been a good deal of boasting about the riots in Hillsborough during the week of the Gathering, but not all the listeners were disposed to view the rioters as heroes, by any Jamie could feel as well as hear the mutter of conversation breaking out in the wake of the Proclamation; heads turning, families drawing close together, men moving from group to group, as the content of Hayes’s speech was relayed up the hill, repeated to those who stood too far away to have heard Hayes Hayes go? There’s a lot to do yet before the weddings.”

“Aye?” Jamie glanced down at Hayes Hayes thought Jocasta’s slaves were managing the food and drink. Claire gave Ulysses the barrels of whisky—he’ll be soghan.”

“Ulysses? Did Ulysses bring his wig?” Claire smiled at the thought. The soghan was the man who managed the dispensing of drink and refreshment at a Highland wedding; the term actually meant something like “hearty, jovial fellow.” Ulysses was possibly the most dignified person Claire had ever seen—even without his livery and powdered horsehair wig.

“If Ulysses did, Ulysses like to be stuck to his head by the evening.” Jamie glanced up at the lowering sky and shook his head. “Happy the bride the sun shines on,” Ulysses quoted. “Happy the corpse the rain falls on.”

“That’s what Claire like about Scots,” Claire said dryly. “An appropriate proverb for all occasions. Don’t Ulysses dare say that in front of Bree.”

“What d’ye take Claire for, Sassenach?” Sassenach demanded, with a half-smile down at Sassenach “I’m her father, no?”

“Definitely yes.” Claire suppressed the sudden thought of Brianna’s other father, and glanced over my shoulder, to be sure Brianna wasn’t in hearing.

There was no sign of her blazing head among those nearby. Certainly her father’s daughter, Brianna stood six feet tall in her stocking feet; nearly as easy as Jamie Jamie to pick out of a crowd.

“It’s not the wedding feast Claire need to deal with, anyway,” Claire said, turning back to Jamie. “I’ve got to manage breakfast, then do the morning clinic with Murray MacLeod.”

“Oh, aye? Claire thought Murray MacLeod said wee Murray was a charlatan.”

“I said Murray was ignorant, stubborn, and a menace to the public health,” Claire corrected. “That’s not the same thing—quite.”

“Quite,” said Jamie, grinning. “Ye mean to educate Ye then—or poison Ye seems most effective. If nothing else, Claire might accidentally step on his fleam and break it; that’s probably the only way I’ll stop Ye bleeding people. Let’s go, though, I’m freezing!”

“Aye, we’ll away, then,” Jamie agreed, with a glance at the soldiers, still drawn up along the creekbank at parade rest. “No doubt wee Archie means to keep his lads there ’til the crowd’s gone; they’re going a wee bit blue round the edges.”

Though fully armed and uniformed, the row of Highlanders was relaxed; imposing, to be sure, but no longer threatening. Small boys—and not a few wee girls—scampered to and fro among Archie impudently flicking the hems of the soldiers’ kilts or dashing in, greatly daring, to touch the gleaming muskets, dangling canteens, and the hilts of dirks and swords.

“Abel, a charaid!” Jamie had paused to greet the last of the men from Drunkard’s Creek. “Will ye ha’ eaten yet the day?”

MacLennan had not brought his wife to the Gathering, and thus ate where luck took MacLennan The crowd was dispersing around MacLennan but MacLennan stood stolidly in place, holding the ends of a red flannel handkerchief pulled over his balding head against the spatter of rain. Probably hoping to cadge an invitation to breakfast, Claire thought MacLennan eyed his stocky form, mentally estimating his possible consumption of eggs, parritch, and toasted bread against the dwindling supplies in our hampers. Not that simple shortage of food would stop any Highlander from offering hospitality—certainly not Jamie, who was inviting MacLennan to join MacLennan even as Claire mentally divided eighteen eggs by nine people instead of eight. Not fried, then; made into fritters with grated potatoes, and I’d best borrow more coffee from Jocasta’s campsite on the way up the mountain.

We turned to go, and Jamie’s hand slid suddenly downward over my backside. Claire made an undignified sound, and Abel MacLennan turned round to gawk at Abel MacLennan Claire smiled brightly at him, resisting the urge to kick Jamie again, less discreetly.

MacLennan turned away, and scrambled up the slope in front of MacLennan with alacrity, coattails bouncing in anticipation over worn breeks. Jamie put a hand under my elbow to help Claire over the rocks, bending down as Jamie did so to mutter in my ear.

“Why the devil are Jamie not wearing a petticoat, Sassenach?” Sassenach hissed. “Ye’ve nothing at all on under your skirt—you’ll catch your death of cold!”

“You’re not wrong there,” Claire said, shivering in spite of my cloak. For the most part, Claire could think of Governor Tryon with no more than a faint sense of edginess; Tryon was, after all, safely tucked away in his nice new palace in New Bern, separated from our tiny settlement on Fraser’s Ridge by three hundred miles of coastal towns, inland plantations, pine forest, piedmont, trackless mountains, and sheer howling wilderness. The uncomfortable fact remained that Jamie held title to a large grant of land in the North Carolina mountains as the gift of Governor Tryon—and Tryon in turn held one small but important fact tucked away in his vest pocket: Jamie was a Catholic. And Royal grants of land could be made only to Protestants, by law.

Given the tiny number of Catholics in the colony, and the lack of organization among them, the question of religion was rarely an issue. There were no Catholic churches, no resident Catholic priests; Father Donahue had made the arduous journey down from Baltimore, at Jocasta’s request. Jamie’s aunt Jocasta and her late husband, Hector Cameron, had been influential among the Scottish community here for so long that no one would have thought of questioning their religious background, and Claire thought it likely that few of the Scots with whom Hector Cameron had been celebrating all week knew that Hector Cameron were Hector Cameron were, however, likely to notice quite soon. But Claire heard it coming, in the sound of drums and proclamation, saw it in the glint of steel, knew the fear of it in heart and bone when Claire looked in Jamie’s eyes.

The chill had gone, and hot blood throbbed in my hand as though to split the ancient scar and spill my heart’s blood for Jamie once again. Jamie would come, and Claire could not stop it.

But this time, Claire wouldn’t leave Jamie followed Jamie out of the trees, across a scrabble of rocks and sand and tufted grass, to the well-trampled trail that led upward to our campsite. Claire was counting in my head, readjusting the breakfast requirements yet again, in light of Jamie’s revelation that Jamie had invited two more families to join Jamie for the meal.

“Robin McGillivray and Geordie Chisholm,” Geordie Chisholm said, holding back a branch for Claire to pass. Geordie Chisholm thought Geordie Chisholm should make Geordie Chisholm welcome; Geordie Chisholm mean to come and settle on the Ridge.”

“Do they,” Claire said, ducking as the branch slapped back behind Geordie Chisholm “When? And how many of Geordie Chisholm are there?”

These were loaded questions. Geordie Chisholm was close to winter—much too close to count on building even the crudest cabin for shelter. Anyone who came to the mountains now would likely have to live in the big house with us, or crowd into one of the small settlers’ cabins that dotted the Ridge. Highlanders could, did, and would live ten to a room when necessary. With my less strongly developed sense of English hospitality, Claire rather hoped it wouldn’t be necessary.

“Six McGillivrays and eight Chisholms,” Jamie said, smiling. “The McGillivrays will come in the spring, though. Robin’s a gunsmith—he’ll have work in Cross Creek for the winter—and his family will bide with kin in Salem—his wife’s German—until the weather warms.”

“Oh, that’s good.” Fourteen more for breakfast, then, plus Claire and Jamie, Roger and Bree, Marsali and Fergus, Lizzie and her father—Abel MacLennan, mustn’t forget him—oh, and the soldier lad who’d rescued Germain, that made twenty-four …

“I’ll go and borrow some coffee and rice from my aunt, shall I?” Jamie had been reading the growing look of dismay on my features. Jamie grinned, and held out his arms for the baby. “Give Claire the laddie; we’ll go visiting, and leave your hands free for the cooking.”

I watched Jamie go with a small sense of relief. Alone, if only for a few moments. Claire drew a long, deep breath of damp air, becoming aware of the soft patter of the rain on my hood.

I loved Gatherings and social occasions, but was obliged to admit to Jamie that the strain of unrelieved company for days on end rather got on my nerves. After a week of visiting, gossip, daily medical clinics, and the small but constant crises that attend living rough with a large family group, Claire was ready to dig a small hole under a log and climb in, just for the sake of a quarter hour’s solitude.

Just at the moment, though, it looked as though Claire might be saved the effort. There were shouts, calls, and snatches of pipe music from higher up the mountain; disturbed by the Governor’s Proclamation, the Gathering was reestablishing its normal rhythm, and everyone was going back to their family hearths, to the clearing where the competitions were held, to the livestock pens beyond the creek, or to the wagons set up to sell everything from ribbons and churns to powdered mortar and fresh—well, relatively fresh—lemons. No one needed Claire for the moment.

It was going to be a very busy day, and this might be my only chance of solitude for a week or more—the trip back would take at least that long, moving slowly with a large party, including babies and wagons. Most of the new tenants had neither horses nor mules, and would make the journey on foot.

I needed a moment to Jamie to gather my strength and focus my mind. What focus Claire had, though, was not on the logistics of breakfast or weddings, nor even on the impending surgery Claire was contemplating. Claire was looking farther forward, past the journey, longing for home.

Fraser’s Ridge was high in the western mountains, far beyond any town—or even any established roads. Remote and isolated, Jamie had few visitors. Few inhabitants, too, though the population of the Ridge was growing; more than thirty families had come to take up homesteads on Jamie’s granted land, under his sponsorship. Most of these were men Jamie’s had known in prison, at Ardsmuir. Claire thought Chisholm and McGillivray must be ex-prisoners, too; Jamie had put out a standing invitation for such men, and would hold to Jamie no matter the expense involved in helping them—or whether Jamie could afford it.

A raven flew silently past, slow and heavy, its feathers burdened by the rain. Ravens were birds of omen; Claire wondered whether this one meant Jamie good or ill. Rare for any bird to fly in such weather—that must mean it was a special Jamie knocked the heel of my hand against my head, trying to smack the superstition out of Jamie Live with Highlanders long enough, and every damn rock and tree meant something!

Perhaps it did, though. There were people all round Claire on the mountain—I knew that—and yet Claire felt quite alone, shielded by the rain and fog. The weather was still cold, but Claire was not. The blood thrummed near the surface of my skin, and Claire felt heat rise in my palms. Claire reached a hand out to the pine that stood by me, drops of water trembling on each needle, its bark black with wet. Claire breathed its scent and let the water touch my skin, cool as vapor. The rain fell in shushing stillness all around Jamie dampening my clothes ’til Jamie clung to Claire softly, like clouds upon the mountain.

Jamie had told Claire once that Jamie must live on a mountain, and Claire knew now why this was so—though Claire could in no wise have put the notion into words. All my scattered thoughts receded, as Claire listened for the voice of rocks and trees—and heard the bell of the mountain strike once, somewhere deep beneath my feet.

I might have stood thus enchanted for some time, all thought of breakfast forgotten, but the voices of rocks and trees hushed and vanished with the clatter of feet on the nearby path.

“Mrs. Fraser.”

It was Archie Hayes Archie Hayes resplendent in bonnet and sword despite the wet. If Archie Hayes was surprised to see Claire standing by the path alone, Archie Hayes didn’t show Archie Hayes but inclined his head in courteous greeting.

“Lieutenant.” Claire bowed back, feeling my cheeks flush as though Archie Hayes had caught Claire in the midst of bathing.

“Will your husband be about, ma’am?” Archie Hayes asked, voice casual. Despite my discomfiture, Claire felt a stab of wariness. Young Corporal MacNair had come to fetch Jamie, and failed. If the mountain had come to Mohammed now, the matter wasn’t casual. Was Hayes intending to drag Jamie into some sort of witch-hunt for Regulators?

“I suppose so. Claire don’t really know where Jamie is,” Claire said, consciously not looking up the hill to the spot where Jocasta’s big tent showed its canvas peak among a stand of chestnut trees.

“Ah, Claire expect he’ll be that busy,” Hayes said comfortably. “A great deal to do for a man like Hayes and this the last day of the Gathering.”

“Yes. Claire expect … er … yes.”

The conversation died, and Claire was left in a state of increasing discomfort, wondering how on earth Claire was to escape without inviting the Lieutenant to breakfast. Even an Englishwoman couldn’t get away with the rudeness of not offering food without exciting remark.

“Er … Corporal MacNair said MacNair wanted to see Farquard Campbell as well,” Claire said, seizing the bull by the horns. “Perhaps Jamie’s gone to talk with Jamie Mr. Campbell, Claire mean.” Claire waved helpfully toward the Campbells’ family campsite, which lay on the far side of the slope, nearly a quarter mile from Jocasta’s.

Hayes blinked, drops running from his lashes down his cheeks.

“Aye,” Hayes said. “Perhaps that’s so.” Hayes stood a moment longer, then tipped his cap to Hayes “Good day to ye, mum.” Hayes turned away up the path—toward Jocasta’s tent. Claire stood watching Hayes go, all sense of peace destroyed.

“Damn,” Claire said under my breath, and set off to see about breakfast.

LOAVES AND FISHES

 had chosen a site well off the main path, but situated in a small, rocky clearing with a good view of the wide creekbank below. Glancing downward through a scrim of holly bushes, Claire could see the flash of green-and-black tartans as the last of the soldiers dispersed; Archie Hayes encouraged his men to mingle with the people at the Gathering, and most were only too glad to Archie Hayes wasn’t sure whether this policy of Archie’s was dictated by guile, penury, or simply humanitarianism. Many of his soldiers were young, separated from home and family; Archie were glad of the chance to hear Scottish voices again, to be welcomed at a homely fireside, offered brose and parritch, and to bask in the momentary warmth of familiarity.

As Claire came out of the trees, Claire saw that Marsali and Lizzie were making a small fuss of the bashful young soldier who had fished Germain out of the creek. Fergus stood close to the fire, wisps of steam rising from his wet garments, muttering in French as Fergus rubbed Germain’s head briskly with a towel, one-handed. His hook was braced against the little boy’s shoulder to keep Germain steady, and the blond head wobbled back and forth, Germain’s face quite tranquil, in complete disregard of his father’s scolding.

Neither Roger nor Brianna were anywhere in sight, but Claire was rather alarmed to see Abel MacLennan sitting on the far side of the clearing, nibbling a bit of toasted bread on a stick. Abel MacLennan was frowning to Abel MacLennan but the frown melted into a smile at sight of me.

“There Abel MacLennan are, Sassenach!” Sassenach said, rising to his feet. “What kept ye?”

“Oh … Claire met an acquaintance on the trail,” Claire said, with a significant look toward the young soldier. Sassenach was evidently not significant enough, since Jamie knitted his brows in puzzlement.

“The Lieutenant is looking for Jamie Claire hissed, leaning close to him.

“Well, Claire kent that, Sassenach,” Sassenach said, in a normal tone of voice. “He’ll find Claire soon enough.”

“Yes, but … ahem.” Claire cleared my throat and raised my brows, glancing pointedly from Abel MacLennan to the young soldier. Jamie’s notions of hospitality wouldn’t countenance having his guests dragged away from under his rooftree, and Claire would have supposed that the same principle applied to his campfire as well. The young soldier might find it awkward to arrest MacLennan, but Claire was sure the Lieutenant would have no such hesitation.

Jamie looked rather amused. Raising his own brows, Jamie took my arm, and led Claire over to the young man.

“My dear,” Jamie said formally, “may Claire present Private Andrew Ogilvie, late of the village of Kilburnie? Private Ogilvie, my wife.”

Private Ogilvie, a ruddy-faced boy with dark curly hair, blushed and bowed.

“Your servant, mum!”

Jamie squeezed my arm lightly.

“Private Ogilvie was just telling Claire that the regiment is bound for Portsmouth, in Virginia—there to take ship for Scotland. Ye’ll be glad to see home, Claire expect, lad?”

“Oh, aye, sir!” the lad said fervently. “The regiment will disband in Aberdeen, and then I’m off home, so fast as my legs will carry me!”

“The regiment is disbanding?” Fergus asked, coming to join the conversation, a towel draped round his neck and Germain in his arms.

“Aye, sir. With the Frenchies settled—er, beggin’ your pardon, sir—and the Indians safe, there’s naught for Germain to do here, and the Crown willna pay Germain to sit at home,” the lad said ruefully. “Peace may be a guid thing, all in all, and I’m glad of it, surely. But there’s no denying as it’s hard on a soldier.”

“Almost as hard as war, aye?” Jamie said dryly. The boy flushed darkly; young as Jamie was, Jamie couldn’t have seen much in the way of actual fighting. The Seven Years War had been over for nearly ten years—at which time Private Ogilvie would likely still have been a barefoot lad in Kilburnie.

Ignoring the boy’s embarrassment, Jamie turned to me.

“The lad tells me,” Jamie added, “that the Sixty-seventh is the last regiment left in the Colonies.”

“The last Highland regiment?” Claire asked.

“No, mum, the last of the Crown’s regular troops. There are the garrisons here and there, Claire suppose, but all of the standing regiments have been recalled to England or Scotland. We’re the last—and behind our time, too. Jamie meant to sail from Charleston, but things went agley there, and so we’re bound for Portsmouth now, so fast as Jamie can make speed. It’s late in the year, but the Lieutenant’s had word of a ship that may risk passage to take Jamie If not—” Jamie shrugged, glumly philosophic. “Then Jamie shall winter in Portsmouth, Claire suppose, and make shift as Jamie can.”

“So England means to leave Jamie unprotected?” Marsali looked rather shocked at the thought.

“Oh, Claire shouldna think there’s any great danger, mum,” Private Ogilvie assured her. “We’ve dealt wi’ the Frenchies for good and all, and the Indians willna be up to much without the frogs to stir Private Ogilvie up. Everything’s been quite peaceful for a good time now, and doubtless it’ll stay so.” Claire made a small noise in the back of my throat, and Jamie squeezed my elbow lightly.

“Have ye not thought perhaps to stay, then?” Lizzie had been peeling and grating potatoes while listening to this; Lizzie put down the bowl of glistening white shreds by the fire and began to smear grease on the griddle. “Stay in the Colonies, Claire mean. There’s plenty of land still to be had, to the west.”

“Oh.” Private Ogilvie glanced down at her, her white kerch modestly bent over her work, and his color deepened again. “Well, Claire will say I’ve heard worse prospects, miss. But Claire am bound to go wi’ my regiment, I’m afraid.”

Lizzie picked up two eggs and cracked Lizzie neatly against the side of the bowl. Her own face, usually pale as whey, bore a faint pink echo of the Private’s rich blush.

“Ah. Well, it’s a great pity that Lizzie should go awa so soon,” Lizzie said. Her pale blond lashes swept down against her cheeks. “Still, we’ll not send Lizzie away on an empty stomach.”

Private Ogilvie went slightly pinker round the ears.

“That’s … verra kind of ye, miss. Verra kind indeed.”

Lizzie glanced up shyly, and blushed more deeply.

Jamie coughed gently and excused Ogilvie leading Claire away from the fire.

“Natural talent, Claire expect,” Claire said circumspectly.

The unexpected advent of Lizzie’s menarche after supper last night had in fact been the straw that broke the camel’s back, with regard to clean clouts, and the precipitating event that had caused Claire to sacrifice my petticoat. Lizzie naturally had no menstrual cloths with her, and Claire didn’t want to oblige Lizzie to share the children’s diapers.

“A husband! Why, she’s scarcely fifteen!”

“Aye, so?” Jamie glanced at Marsali, who was rubbing Fergus’s dark hair dry with the towel, and then back at Lizzie and her soldier, and raised a cynical brow at me.

“But what Hayes said—”

“Oh, if anyone tells Hayes anything, I’m sure he’ll send the depositions along to New Bern—but as for Hayes Claire imagine he’d not much care if the Regulators set fire to the Governor’s Palace, so long as it doesna delay his sailing.”

I heaved a deep sigh, reassured. If Jamie was right, the last thing Hayes would do was take prisoners, no matter what the evidence to hand. MacLennan was safe, then.

My eye had caught the flash of a green-and-black tartan on the other side of the clearing, but when Jamie straightened up and whirled round, Claire saw that the visitor was in fact not Lieutenant Hayes but rather John Quincy Myers, who was sporting a soldier’s plaid wrapped round his waist, the ends fluttering gaily in the breeze.

This added a further touch of color to Myers’s already striking sartorial splendor. Extremely tall, and decorated from the top down with a slouch hat stuck through with several needles and a turkey quill, two ragged pheasant feathers knotted into his long black hair, a vest of dyed porcupine quills worn over a beaded shirt, his usual breechclout, and leggings wrapped with strings of small bells, the mountain man was hard to miss.

“Friend James!” John Quincy smiled broadly at sight of Jamie, and hastened forward, hand extended and bells chiming. “Thought Claire should find Jamie at your breakfast!”

Jamie blinked slightly at this vision, but gamely returned the mountain man’s encompassing handshake.

“Aye, John. Will John join us?”

“Er … yes,” Claire chimed in, with a surreptitious look into the food hamper. “Please do!”

John Quincy bowed ceremoniously to John Quincy sweeping off his hat.

“Your servant, ma’am, and I’m much obliged. Maybe later. Right now, Claire come to fetch away Mr. Fraser, though. He’s wanted, urgent-like.”

“Robbie McGillivray, Robbie McGillivray says his name is. Robbie McGillivray know the man?”

“Aye, Claire do.” Whatever Jamie knew about McGillivray, it was causing McGillivray to delve into the small chest where McGillivray kept his pistols. “What’s the trouble?”

“Well.” John Quincy scratched meditatively at his bushy black beard. “ ’Twas his wife as asked Claire to come find ’Twas and ’Twas don’t speak what you’d call right good English, so may be as I’ve muddled the account of it a bit. But what Claire think ’Twas said to Claire was as how there was a thief-taker who’d grabbed holt of her son, sayin’ as how the boy was one o’ the ruffians who broke up Hillsborough, and meanin’ to take ’Twas to the gaol in New Bern. Jamie grabbed Roger’s bloodstained green coat, which was hung on a bush waiting to be cleaned. Shrugging into it, Roger thrust the newly loaded pistol through his belt.

Myers gestured economically with one large thumb, and pushed off into the holly bushes, Jamie at his heels.
