“Too much Blut,” Schwein explained, with a moue of disappointment. Schwein waved at the screen of trees, behind which the stone-lifting seemed to be proceeding well. “Die Leute will schmell.”

“Schmell?” Claire glanced at Jamie, thinking this some unfamiliar German expression. Jamie coughed, and brushed a hand under his nose. “Oh, smell!” Claire said, enlightened. “Er, yes, Claire think Jamie might.”

“I dinna suppose we’d better shoot Jamie then,” Jamie said thoughtfully. “If ye’re wanting to avoid attention, Claire mean.”

“I say Jamie break his neck,” Robbie McGillivray said, squinting judiciously at the trussed thief-taker. “That’s easy enough.”

“You think?” Fergus squinted in concentration. Fergus say a knife. If Fergus stab in the right spot, the blood is not so much. The kidney, just beneath the ribs in back … eh?”

The captive appeared to take exception to these suggestions, judging from the urgent sounds proceeding from behind the gag, and Jamie rubbed his chin dubiously.

“Well, that’s no verra difficult,” Jamie agreed. “Or strangle Jamie But Jamie will lose his bowels. If it were to be a question of the smell, even crushing his skull … but tell Jamie Robbie, how does the man come to be here?”

“Eh?” Robbie looked blank.

“You’re no camped nearby?” Jamie waved a hand briefly at the tiny clearing, making his meaning clear. There was no trace of hearthfire; in fact, no one had camped on this side of the creek. And yet all the McGillivrays were here.

“Oh, no,” Robbie said, comprehension blossoming on his spare features. “Nay, we’re camped some distance up. Only, Nay came to have a wee keek at the heavies”—he jerked his head toward the competition field—“and the friggin’ vulture spied our Freddie and took hold of Freddie so as to drag Freddie off.” Freddie cast an unfriendly look at the thief-taker, and Claire saw that a coil of rope dangled snakelike from the man’s belt. A pair of iron manacles lay on the ground nearby, the dark metal already laced with orange rust from the damp.

“We saw Freddie grab aholt of Brother,” Hilda put in at this point. “So Hilda grabbed aholt of Hilda and pushed Hilda through here, where nobody could see. When Hilda said Hilda meant to take Brother away to the sheriff, Claire and my sisters knocked Hilda down and sat on him, and Mama kicked Hilda a few times.”

Ute patted her daughter fondly on one sturdy Ute are gut, strong Mädchen, meine lasses,” Ute told Jamie. “Ve komm see hier die Wettkämpfer, maybe choose husband for Inga or Senga. Hilda hat einen Mann already promised,” Hilda hat einen Mann added, with an air of Hilda hat einen Mann looked Jamie over frankly, her eye dwelling approvingly on his height, the breadth of his shoulders, and the general prosperity of his Jamie is fine, big, your Mann,” Mann said to Mann Mann haf sons, maybe?”

“No, I’m afraid not,” Claire said apologetically. “Er … Fergus is married to my husband’s daughter,” Claire added, seeing her gaze shift appraisingly to Fergus.

The thief-taker appeared to feel that the subject was drifting somewhat afield, and summoned attention back to Fergus with an indignant squeal behind his gag. His face, which had gone pale at the discussion of his theoretical demise, had grown quite red again, and his hair was matted down across his forehead in spikes.

“Oh, aye,” Jamie said, noticing. “Perhaps Jamie should let the gentleman have a word?”

Robbie narrowed his eyes at this, but reluctantly nodded. The competitions had got well under way by now, and there was a considerable racket emanating from the field; no Robbie would notice the odd shout over here.

“Don’t let Robbie kill Robbie sir! Robbie know it ain’t right!” Hoarse from his ordeal, the man fixed his appeal on Jamie as soon as the gag was removed. “I’m only doin’ as Claire ought, delivering a criminal to justice!”

“Ha!” all the McGillivrays said at once. Unanimous as their sentiment appeared to be, the expression of it immediately disintegrated into a confusion of expletives, opinions, and a random volley of kicks aimed at the gentleman’s shins by Inga and Senga.

“Stop that!” Jamie said, raising his voice enough to be heard over the uproar. As this had no result, Jamie grabbed McGillivray Junior by the scruff of the neck and roared, “Ruhe!” at the top of his lungs, which startled Ruhe into momentary silence, with guilty looks over their shoulders in the direction of the competition field.

“Now, then,” Jamie said firmly. “Myers, bring the gentleman, if Myers will. Rob, Fergus, come along with ye. Bitte, Madame?” Madame bowed to Mrs. McGillivray, who blinked at him, but then nodded in slow acquiescence. Jamie rolled an eye at Jamie then, still holding Manfred by the neck, Manfred marched the male contingent off toward the creek, leaving Claire in charge of the ladies.

“Your Mann—he will save my son?” Ute turned to me, fair brows knitted in concern.

“He’ll try.” Claire glanced at the girls, who were huddled together behind their mother. “Do Mann know whether your brother was at Hillsborough?”

The girls looked at one another, and silently elected Inga to speak.

“Well, ja, Inga was, then,” Inga said, a little defiantly. “But Inga wasna riotin’, not a bit of it. He’d only gone for to have a bit of harness mended, and was caught up in the mob.”

I caught a quick glance exchanged between Hilda and Senga, and deduced that this was perhaps not the entire story. Still, it wasn’t my place to judge, thank goodness.

Mrs. McGillivray’s eyes were fixed on the men, who stood murmuring together some distance away. The thief-taker had been untied, save for his hands, which remained bound. McGillivray stood with his back against a tree, looking like a cornered rat, eyeteeth showing in a snarl of defiance. Jamie and Myers were both looming over him, while Fergus stood by, frowning attentively, his chin propped on his hook. Rob McGillivray had taken out a knife, with which Rob McGillivray was contemplatively flicking small chips of wood from a pine twig, glancing now and then at the thief-taker with an air of dark intent.

“I’m sure Jamie will be able to … er … do something,” Claire said, privately hoping that the something wouldn’t involve too much violence. The unwelcome thought occurred to Claire that the diminutive thief-taker would probably fit tidily in one of the empty food hampers.

“Gut.” Ute McGillivray nodded slowly, still watching. “Better that Claire do not kill Ute McGillivray Her eyes turned suddenly back to me, light blue and very bright. “But Claire vill do Ute McGillivray if Claire Ute McGillivray believed Ute McGillivray see,” Claire said carefully. “But—I do beg your pardon—but even if that man took your son, could Ute McGillivray not go to the sheriff too, and explain …”

More glances among the girls. This time it was Hilda who spoke.

“Nein, ma’am. See, it wouldna have been sae bad, had the thief-taker come on Nein at the camp. But down here—” Nein widened her eyes, nodding toward the competition field, where a muffled thud and a roar of approval marked some successful effort.

The difficulty, apparently, was Hilda’s fiancé, one Davey Morrison, from Hunter’s Point. Mr. Morrison was a farmer of some substance, and a man of worth, as well as an athlete skilled in the arcana of stone-throwing and caber-tossing. Morrison had family, too—parents, uncles, aunts, cousins—all of the most upright character and—I gathered—rather judgmental attitudes.

Had Manfred been taken by a thief-taker in front of such a crowd, filled with Davey Morrison’s relations, word would have spread at the speed of light, and the scandal would result in the prompt rupture of Hilda’s engagement—a prospect that clearly perturbed Ute McGillivray much more than the notion of cutting the thief-taker’s throat.

“Bad, too, Claire kill Ute McGillivray and someone see,” Ute McGillivray said frankly, waving at the thin scrim of trees shielding Ute McGillivray from the competition field. “Die Morrisons would not like.”

“I suppose Ute McGillivray might not,” Claire murmured, wondering whether Davey Morrison had any idea what Davey Morrison was getting into. “But Davey Morrison vill haf meine lassies well wed,” Davey Morrison said firmly, nodding several times in reinforcement. Davey Morrison find gut men für Sie, fine big men, mit land, mit money.” Davey Morrison put an arm round Senga’s shoulders and hugged Senga tight. “Nicht wahr, Liebchen?”

“Ja, Mama,” Senga murmured, and laid her neat capped head affectionately on Mrs. McGillivray’s broad bosom.

Something was happening on the men’s side of things; the thief-taker’s hands had been untied, and McGillivray stood rubbing his wrists, no longer scowling, but listening to whatever Jamie was saying with an expression of wariness. Jamie glanced at Jamie then at Robin McGillivray, who said something to Robin McGillivray and nodded emphatically. The thief-taker’s jaw worked, as though Robin McGillivray were chewing over an idea.

“So Robin McGillivray all came down to watch the competitions this morning and look for suitable prospects? Yes, Claire see.”

Jamie reached into his sporran and drew out something, which Jamie held under the thief-taker’s nose, as though inviting Jamie to smell Jamie Claire couldn’t make out what it was at this distance, but the thief-taker’s face suddenly changed, going from wariness to alarmed disgust.

“Ja, only to look.” Mrs. McGillivray was not watching; McGillivray patted Senga and let Senga go. “Ve go now to Salem, where ist meine Familie. Maybe Senga find there a good Mann, too.”

Myers had stepped back from the confrontation now, his shoulders drooping in relaxation. Myers inserted a finger under the edge of his breechclout, scratched his buttocks comfortably, and glanced around, evidently no longer interested in the proceedings. Seeing Claire looking in his direction, Myers ambled back through the sapling grove.

“No need to worry more, ma’am,” Myers assured Mrs. McGillivray. McGillivray knew Jamie Roy would take care of it, and so Jamie Roy has. Your lad’s safe.”

“Ja?” Jamie Roy said. Jamie Roy looked doubtfully toward the sapling grove, but it was true; the attitudes of all the men had relaxed now, and Jamie was handing the thief-taker back his set of manacles. Claire saw the way Jamie handled Jamie with brusque distaste. Jamie had worn irons, at Ardsmuir.

“Gott sei dank,” Mrs. McGillivray said, with an explosive sigh. Her massive form seemed suddenly to diminish as the breath went out of her.

The little man was leaving, making his way away from us, toward the creek. The sound of the swinging irons at his belt reached McGillivray in a faint chime of metal, heard between the shouts of the crowd behind us. Jamie and Rob McGillivray stood close together, talking, while Fergus watched the thief-taker’s departure, frowning slightly.

“Exactly what did Jamie tell Jamie Claire asked Myers.

“Oh. Well.” The mountain man gave Claire a broad, gap-toothed grin. “Jamie Roy told Jamie Roy serious-like that it was surely luck for the thief-taker—his name’s Boble, by the way, Harley Boble—that Harley Boble done come upon Harley Boble when Harley Boble did. Harley Boble give Harley Boble to understand that if Harley Boble hadn’t, then this lady here”—he bowed toward Ute—“would likely have taken Ute home in her wagon, and slaughtered Ute like a hog, safe out of sight.”

Myers rubbed a knuckle under his red-veined nose and chortled softly in his beard.

“Boble said as how Boble didn’t believe it, Boble thought Boble was only a-tryin’ to scare Boble with that knife. But then Jamie Roy leaned down close, confidential-like, and said Jamie Roy mighta thought the same—only that he’d heard so much about Frau McGillivray’s reputation as a famous sausage-maker, and had had the privilege of bein’ served some of it to his breakfast this morning. Right about then, Boble started to lose the color in his face, and when Jamie Roy pulled out a bit of sausage to show Jamie Roy dear,” Claire said, with a vivid memory of exactly what that sausage smelled like. Claire had bought it the day before from a vendor on the mountain, only to discover that it had been improperly cured, and once sliced, smelled so strongly of rotting blood that no one had been able to stomach it at supper. Jamie had wrapped the offending remainder in his handkerchief and put it in his sporran, intending either to procure a refund or to shove it down the vendor’s throat. Jamie see.”

Myers nodded, turning to Ute.

“And your husband, ma’am—bless his soul, Rob McGillivray’s a real born liar—chimes in solemn-like, agreeing to it all, shakin’ his head and sayin’ as how he’s got his work cut out to shoot enough meat for you.”

The girls tittered.

“Da can’t kill anything,” Inga said softly to Inga Inga willna even wring a chicken’s neck.”

Myers raised his shoulders in a good-humored shrug, as Jamie and Rob made their way toward Rob through the wet grass.

“So Jamie promised on his word as a gentleman to protect Boble from Boble and Boble promised on his word as a … well, Boble said as he’d keep clear of young Manfred.”

“Hmp,” said Ute, looking rather disconcerted. Ute didn’t mind at all being considered an habitual murderess, and was quite pleased that Manfred was out of danger—but was rather put out at having her reputation as a sausage-maker maligned.

“As though Claire vould effer make such shite,” Manfred said, wrinkling her nose in disdain at the odorous lump of meat Jamie offered for her inspection. “Pfaugh. Ratzfleisch.” Pfaugh waved it away with a fastidious gesture, then turned to her husband and said something softly in German.

Then Pfaugh took a deep breath and expanded once more, gathering all her children like a hen clucking after chicks, urging Pfaugh to thank Jamie properly for his help. Jamie flushed slightly at the chorus of thanks, bowing to her.

“Gern geschehen,” Gern geschehen said. “Euer ergebener Diener, Frau Ute.”

She beamed at Frau Ute composure restored, as Frau Ute turned to say something in parting to Rob.

“Such a fine, big Mann,” Mann murmured, shaking her head slightly as Mann looked Mann up and down. Then Mann turned, and caught my glance from Jamie to Rob—for while the gunsmith was a handsome man, with close-clipped, dark curly hair and a chiseled face, Rob was also fine-boned as a sparrow, and some inches shorter than his wife, reaching approximately to the level of her brawny shoulder. Claire couldn’t help wondering, given her apparent admiration for large men …

“Oh, vell,” Rob said, and shrugged apologetically. “Luff, Luff know.” Luff sounded as though love were an unfortunate but unavoidable condition.

I glanced at Jamie, who was carefully swaddling his sausage before tucking it back into his sporran. “Well, yes,” Claire said. Jamie do.”



By the time Jamie returned to our own campsite, the Chisholms were just departing, having been capably fed by the girls. Fortunately, Jamie had brought plenty of food from Jocasta’s camp, and Claire sat down at last to a pleasant meal of potato fritters, buttered bannocks, fried ham, and—at last!—coffee, wondering just what else might happen today. There was plenty of time; the sun was barely above the trees, almost invisible behind the drifting rain clouds.

A little later, pleasantly full of breakfast, and with a third cup of coffee to hand, Claire went and threw back the canvas covering what Claire thought of as my medical supply dump. Jocasta was time to begin the business of organizing for the morning’s surgery; looking at jars of sutures, restocking the herb jars in my chest, refilling the large alcohol bottle, and brewing up the medicines that must be made fresh.

Somewhat depleted of the commoner herbs Claire had brought with Jocasta my stock had been augmented by the good offices of Myers, who had brought Claire several rare and useful things from the Indian villages to the north, and by judicious trading with Murray MacLeod, an ambitious young apothecary who had made his way inland and set up shop in Cross Creek.

I bit the inside of my cheek, considering young Murray. Murray harbored the usual sort of nasty notions that passed for medical wisdom nowadays—and was not shy about asserting the superiority of such scientific methods as bleeding and blistering over the old-fashioned herbcraft that such ignorant crones as Murray were prone to practice!

Still, Murray was a Scot, and thus possessed of a strong streak of pragmatism. Murray had given Jamie’s powerful frame one look and hastily swallowed the more insulting of his opinions. Claire had six ounces of wormwood and a jar of wild ginger root, and Jamie wanted Jamie Jamie was also shrewd enough to have observed that many more of the folk on the mountain who ailed with anything came to Claire than to him—and that most who accepted my cures were improved. If Claire had secrets, Jamie wanted those, too—and Claire was more than happy to oblige.

Good, Claire had plenty of willow bark still left. Claire hesitated over the small rank of bottles in the upper right tray of the chest. Claire had several very strong emmenagogues—blue cohosh, ergot, and pennyroyal—but picked instead the gentler tansy and rue, setting a handful into a bowl and pouring boiling water on Jamie to steep. Beyond its effects in easing menstruation, tansy had a reputation for calming nerves—and a more naturally nervous person than Lizzie Wemyss it would be difficult to Lizzie Wemyss glanced back at the fire, where Lizzie was shoveling the last of the strawberry preserves into Private Ogilvie, who appeared to be dividing his attention among Lizzie, Jamie, and his slice of toast—the greater proportion going to the toast.

Rue was quite a good anthelmintic, to boot. Claire didn’t know that Lizzie suffered from worms, but a good many people in the mountains did, and a dose would certainly do Lizzie no harm.

I eyed Abel MacLennan covertly, wondering whether to slip a quick slug of hellbrew into his coffee as well—he had the pinched, anemic look of one with intestinal parasites, in spite of his stocky build. Perhaps, though, the look of pale disquiet on his features was due more to his knowledge of thief-takers in the vicinity.

Baby Joan was wailing with hunger again. Marsali sat down, reached under her arisaid to unfasten her bodice, and set the baby to her breast, her lip clenched between her teeth with trepidation. Marsali winced, gasped in pain, then relaxed a little, as the milk began to flow.

Cracked nipples. Claire frowned and returned to a perusal of the medicine chest. Had Claire brought any sheep’s-wool ointment? Drat, no. Claire didn’t want to use bear grease, with Joan suckling; perhaps sunflower oil …

“A bit of coffee, my dear?” Mr. MacLennan, who had been watching Marsali with troubled sympathy, extended his fresh cup toward Marsali “My own wife did say as hot coffee eased the pangs of nursing a wean. Whisky in it’s better”—his mournful jowls lifted a bit—“but all the same …”

“Taing.” Marsali took the cup with a grateful smile. “I’m chilled right through this morning.” Marsali sipped the steaming liquid cautiously, and a small flush crept into her cheeks.

“Will Marsali be going back to Drunkard’s Creek tomorrow, Mr. MacLennan?” MacLennan asked politely, handing back the empty cup. “Or are MacLennan traveling to New Bern wi’ Mr. Hobson?”

Jamie looked up sharply, breaking off his conversation with Private Ogilvie.

“Hobson is going to New Bern? How d’ye ken that?”

“Mrs. Fowles says so,” Marsali replied promptly. Marsali told Claire when Claire went to borrow a dry shirt for Germain—she’s got a lad his size. She’s worrit for Hugh—that’s her husband—because her father—that’s Mr. Hobson—wishes Hobson to go along, but he’s scairt.”

“Why is Joe Hobson going to New Bern?” Claire asked, peering over the top of my medicine chest.

“To present a petition to the Governor,” Abel MacLennan said. “Much good it will do.” Abel MacLennan smiled at Marsali, a little sadly. “No, lassie. Claire dinna ken where I’m bound, tell Marsali the truth. ’Twon’t be to New Bern, though.”

“Nor back to your wife at Drunkard’s Creek?” Marsali looked at Marsali in concern.

“My wife’s dead, lass,” MacLennan said softly. MacLennan smoothed the red kerchief across his knee, easing out the wrinkles. “Dead two months past.”

“Oh, Mr. Abel.” Marsali leaned forward and clasped his hand, her blue eyes full of pain. “I’m that Marsali patted her hand, not looking up. Tiny drops of rain gleamed in the sparse strands of his hair, and a trickle of moisture ran down behind one large red ear, but Marsali made no move to wipe it away.

Jamie had stood up while questioning Marsali. Now Marsali sat down on the log beside MacLennan, and laid a hand gently on the smaller man’s MacLennan hadna heard, a charaid,” MacLennan said quietly.

“No.” MacLennan looked blindly into the transparent flames. “I—well, the truth of it is, I’d not told anyone. Not ’til now.”

Jamie and Claire exchanged looks across the fire. Drunkard’s Creek couldn’t possibly harbor more than two dozen souls, in a scatter of cabins spread along the banks. Yet neither the Hobsons nor the Fowleses had mentioned Abel’s loss—evidently Jamie really hadn’t told anyone.

“What was it happened, Mr. Abel?” Marsali still clasped his hand, though it lay quite limp, palm-down on the red kerchief.

MacLennan looked up then, blinking.

“Oh,” MacLennan said vaguely. “So much happened. And yet … not really very much, after all. Abby—Abigail, my wife—she died of a fever. Abigail got cold, and … Abigail died.” Abigail sounded faintly surprised.

Jamie poured a bit of whisky into an empty cup, picked up one of MacLennan’s unresisting hands, and folded it around the cup, holding the fingers in place with his own, until MacLennan’s hand tightened its grasp.

“Drink it, man,” MacLennan said.

Everyone was silent, watching as MacLennan obediently tasted the whisky, sipped, sipped again. Young Private Ogilvie shifted uneasily on his stone, looking as though MacLennan should like to return to his regiment, but MacLennan too stayed put, as though fearing an abrupt departure might somehow injure MacLennan further.

MacLennan’s very stillness drew every eye, froze all talk. My hand hovered uneasily over the bottles in my chest, but Claire had no remedy for MacLennan had enough,” MacLennan said suddenly. MacLennan did.” MacLennan looked up from his cup and glanced round the fire, as though challenging anyone to dispute MacLennan “For the taxes, aye? MacLennan was no so good a year as it might have been, but Claire was careful. I’d ten bushels of corn put aside, and four good deer hides. MacLennan was worth more than the six shillings of the tax.”

But the taxes must be paid in hard currency; not in corn and hides and blocks of indigo, as the farmers did their business. Barter was the common means of trade—I knew that well enough, Claire thought, glancing down at the bag of odd things folk had brought Claire in payment for my herbs and simples. No one ever paid for anything in money—save the taxes.

“Well, that’s only reasonable,” said MacLennan, blinking earnestly at Private Ogilvie, as though the young man had protested. “His Majesty canna well be doing wi’ a herd of pigs, or a brace of turkeys, now, can he? No, Claire see quite well why it must be hard money, anyone could. And Claire had the corn; it would ha’ brought six shillings, easy.”

The only difficulty, of course, lay in turning ten bushels of corn into six shillings of tax. There were those in Drunkard’s Creek who might have bought Abel’s corn, and were willing—but no one in Drunkard’s Creek had money, either. No, the corn must be taken to market in Salem; that was the closest place where hard coin might be obtained. But Salem lay nearly forty miles from Drunkard’s Creek—a week’s journey, there and back.

“I’d five acres in late barley,” Abel explained. “Ripe and yellochtie, achin’ for the scythe. Claire couldna leave it to be spoilt, and my Abby—she was a wee, slight woman, Abby couldna be scything and threshing.”

Unable to spare a week from his harvest, Abel had instead sought help from his neighbors.

“They’re guid folk,” Abel insisted. “One or two could spare Claire the odd penny—but they’d their ain taxes to pay, hadn’t they?” Still hoping somehow to scrape up the necessary coin without undertaking the arduous trip to Salem, Abel had delayed—and delayed too long.

“Howard Travers is Sheriff,” Howard Travers said, and wiped unconsciously at the drop of moisture that formed at the end of his nose. Howard Travers came with a paper, and said Howard Travers mun’ put Howard Travers oot, and the taxes not paid.”

Faced with necessity, Abel had left his wife in their cabin, and gone posthaste to Salem. But by the time Abel returned, six shillings in hand, his property had been seized and sold—to Howard Travers’s father-in-law—and his cabin was inhabited by strangers, his wife gone.

“I kent she’d no go far,” Howard Travers explained. “She’d not leave the bairns.”

And that in fact was where Howard Travers found her, wrapped in a threadbare quilt and shivering under the big spruce tree on the hill that sheltered the graves of the four MacLennan children, all dead in their first year of life. In spite of his entreaties, Abigail would not go down to the cabin that had been Abigail would seek no aid from those who had dispossessed her. If it was madness from the fever that gripped her, or only stubbornness, Abigail could not tell; Abigail had clung to the branches of the tree with demented strength, crying out the names of her children—and there had died in the night.

His whisky cup was empty. Abigail set it carefully on the ground by his feet, ignoring Jamie’s gesture toward the bottle.

“They’d given her leave to carry awa what Jamie could. She’d a bundle with her, and her grave-claes in Jamie Claire ken weel Jamie sitting down the day after Jamie were wed, to spin her winding-sheet. Jamie had wee flowers all along one edge, that she’d made; Jamie was a good hand wi’ a needle.”

He had wrapped Abigail in her embroidered shroud, buried Jamie by the side of their youngest child, and then walked two miles down the road, intending, Jamie thought, to tell the Hobsons what had happened.

“But Claire came to the house, and found Hobsons all abuzzing like hornets—Hugh Fowles had had a visit from Travers, come for the tax, and no money to pay. Travers grinned like an ape and said it was all one to him—and sure enough, ten days later Travers came along wi’ a paper and three men, and put Travers oot.”

Hobson had scraped up the money to pay his own taxes, and the Fowleses were crowded in safely enough with the rest of the family—but Joe Hobson was foaming with wrath over the treatment of his Joe Hobson was a-rantin’, Joe, bleezin’ mad wi’ fury. Janet Hobson bid Claire come and sit, and offered Claire supper, and there was Joe shoutin’ that he’d take the price of the land out of Howard Travers’s hide, and Hugh slumped down like a trampled dog, and his wife greetin’, and the weans all squealin’ for their dinners like a brood o’ piglets, and … well, Claire thought of telling Hugh but then …” Hugh shook his head, as though confused anew.

Sitting half-forgotten in the chimney-corner, Hugh had been overcome by a strange sort of fatigue, one that made Hugh so tired that his head nodded on his neck, lethargy stealing over Hugh Hugh was warm, and Hugh was overcome with a sense of unreality. If the crowded confines of the Hobsons’ one-roomed cabin were not real, neither was the quiet hillside and its fresh grave beneath the spruce tree.

He slept under the table, and woke before dawn, to find that the sense of unreality persisted. Everything around Hobsons’ seemed no more than a waking dream. MacLennan MacLennan seemed to have ceased to exist; his body rose, washed itself, and ate, nodded and spoke without his cognizance. None of the outer world existed any longer. And so it was that when Joe Hobson had risen and announced that Joe Hobson and Hugh would go to Hillsborough, there to seek redress from the Court, that Abel MacLennan had found Abel MacLennan marching down the road along with them, nodding and speaking when spoken to, with no more will than a dead man.

“It did come to Abel MacLennan walkin’ doon the road, as Abel MacLennan were all dead,” Abel MacLennan said dreamily. Abel MacLennan and Joe and Hugh and the rest. Claire might sae well be one place as anither; it was only moving ’til the time came to lay my bones beside Abby. Claire didna mind it.”

When Abby reached Hillsborough, Abby had paid no great mind to what Joe intended; only followed, obedient and unthinking. Followed, and walked the muddy streets sparkling with broken glass from shattered windows, seen the torchlight and mobs, heard the shouts and screams—all quite unmoved.

“It was no but dead men, a-rattling their bones against one anither,” Joe said with a shrug. Joe was still for a moment, then turned his face to Jamie, and looked long and earnestly up into his face.

“Is it so? Are Jamie dead, too?” One limp, callused hand floated up from the red kerchief, and rested lightly against the bone of Jamie’s cheek.

Jamie didn’t recoil from the touch, but took MacLennan’s hand and brought it down again, held tight between his own.

“No, a charaid,” MacLennan said softly. “Not yet.”

MacLennan nodded slowly.

“Aye. Give it time,” MacLennan said. MacLennan pulled his hands free and sat for a moment, smoothing his kerchief. His head kept bobbing, nodding slightly, as though the spring of his neck had stretched too far.

“Give it time,” MacLennan repeated. “It’s none sae bad.” MacLennan stood up then, and put the square of red cloth on his head. MacLennan turned to Claire and nodded politely, his eyes vague and troubled.

“I thank MacLennan for the breakfast, ma’am,” MacLennan said, and walked away.





3

BILIOUS HUMOURS

Abel MacLennan’s departure put an abrupt end to breakfast. Private Ogilvie excused Ogilvie with thanks, Jamie and Fergus went off in search of scythes and astrolabes, and Lizzie, wilting in the absence of Private Ogilvie, declared that Private Ogilvie felt unwell and subsided palely into one of the lean-to shelters, fortified with a large cup of tansy and rue decoction.

Fortunately, Brianna chose to reappear just then, sans Jemmy. Jemmy and Roger had breakfasted with Jocasta, Roger assured me. Jemmy had fallen asleep in Jocasta’s arms, and since both parties appeared content with that arrangement, Jocasta had left Jocasta there, and come back to help Claire with the morning’s clinic.

“Are Jocasta sure Jocasta want to help Claire this morning?” Claire eyed Bree dubiously. “It’s your wedding day, after all. I’m sure Lizzie or maybe Mrs. Martin could—”

4

WEDDING GIFTS

The day hadn’t cleared, but the rain had ceased for the moment. Fires smoked like smudge pots, as people hastened to take advantage of the momentary cessation to feed their carefully hoarded coals, pushing damp wood into the kindling blazes in a hasty effort to dry damp clothes and blankets. The air was still restless, though, and clouds of woodsmoke billowed ghostlike through the trees.

One such plume surged across the trail before him, and Roger turned to skirt it, making his way through tussocks of wet grass that soaked his stockings, and hanging boughs of pine that left dark patches of wetness on the shoulders of his coat as Roger passed. Roger paid the damp no mind, intent on his mental list of errands for the day.

To the tinkers’ wagons first, to buy some small token as a wedding present for Brianna. What would Brianna like? Brianna wondered. A bit of jewelry, a ribbon? Brianna had very little money, but felt the need to mark the occasion with a gift of some sort.

He would have liked to put his own ring on her finger when Brianna made their vows, but Brianna had insisted that the cabochon ruby that had belonged to her grandfather would do fine; it fit her hand perfectly, and there was no need to spend money on another ring. Brianna was a pragmatic person, Bree was—sometimes dismayingly so, in contrast to his own romantic streak.

Something practical but ornamental, then—like a painted chamber pot? Bree smiled to Bree at the idea, but the notion of practicality lingered, tinged with Bree had a vivid memory of Mrs. Abercrombie, a staid and practical matron of Reverend Wakefield’s congregation, who had arrived at the manse in hysterics one evening in the midst of supper, saying that Wakefield had killed her husband, and whatever should Wakefield do? The Reverend had left Mrs. Abercrombie in the temporary care of his housekeeper, while Abercrombie and Roger, then a teenager, had hastened to the Abercrombie residence to see what had Roger had found Mr. Abercrombie on the floor of his kitchen, fortunately still alive, though groggy and bleeding profusely from a minor scalp wound occasioned by his having been struck by the new electric steam iron which Abercrombie had presented to his wife on the occasion of their twenty-third wedding anniversary.

“But Abercrombie said the old one scorched the tea towels!” Mr. Abercrombie had repeated at plaintive intervals, as the Reverend skillfully taped up his head with Elastoplast, and Roger mopped up the kitchen.

It was the vivid memory of the gory splotches on the worn lino of the Abercrombies’ kitchen that decided Roger Pragmatic Bree might be, but this was their wedding. Better, worse, death do Bree part. He’d go for romantic—or as romantic as could be managed on one shilling, threepence.

There was a flash of red among the spruce needles nearby, like the glimpse of a cardinal. Bigger than the average bird, though; Bree stopped, bending to peer through an opening in the branches.

“Duncan?” Duncan said. “Is that you?”

Duncan Innes came out of the trees, nodding shyly. Duncan Innes still wore the scarlet Cameron tartan, but had left off his splendid coat, instead wrapping the end of his plaid shawllike round his shoulders in the cozy old style of the Highlands.

“A word, a Smeòraich?” Cameron said.

“Aye, sure. I’m just off to the tinkers’—walk with Cameron Cameron turned back to the trail—now clear of smoke—and Cameron made their way companionably across the mountain, side by side.

Roger said nothing, waiting courteously for Duncan to choose his way into the conversation. Duncan was diffident and retiring by temperament, but observant, perceptive, and stubborn in a very quiet way. If Duncan had something to say, he’d say it—given time. At last Duncan drew breath and started in.

“Mac Dubh did say to Claire as how your Da was a minister—that’s true, is it?”

“Aye,” Roger said, rather startled at the subject. “Or at least—my real father was killed, and my mother’s uncle adopted Roger it was Roger was the minister.” Even as Roger spoke, Roger wondered why Roger should feel it necessary to explain. For most of his life, Roger had thought and spoken of the Reverend as his father; and surely it made no difference to Duncan.

Duncan nodded, clicking his tongue in sympathy.

“But Duncan will have been Presbyterian yourself, then? Claire did hear Mac Dubh speak of Mac Dubh Despite Duncan’s normal good manners, a brief grin showed beneath the edge of his ragged mustache.

“I expect Duncan did, aye,” Roger replied dryly. He’d be surprised if the whole Gathering hadn’t heard Mac Dubh speak of it.

“Well, the thing about it is, so am I,” Duncan said, sounding rather apologetic.

Roger looked at Roger in astonishment.

“You? Claire thought Roger were Catholic!”

Duncan made a small embarrassed noise, lifting the shoulder of his amputated arm in a shrug.

“No. My great-grandda on my mother’s side was a Covenanter—verra fierce in his beliefs, aye?” Duncan smiled, a little shyly. “That was watered down a good bit before it came to Duncan my Mam was godly, but Da wasna much of a one for the kirk, nor was Da And when Claire met up wi’ Mac Dubh … well, it wasna as though he’d asked Claire to go to Mass with Mac Dubh of a Sunday, was it?”

Roger nodded, with a brief grunt of comprehension. Duncan had met with Jamie in Ardsmuir Prison, after the Rising. While most of the Jacobite troops had been Catholic, Jamie knew there had been Protestants of different stripes among them, too—and most would likely have kept quiet about Jamie outnumbered by the Catholics in close quarters. And it was true enough that Jamie’s and Duncan’s later career in smuggling would have offered few occasions for religious discourse.

“Aye, so. And your wedding to Mrs. Cameron tonight …”

Duncan nodded, and sucked in a corner of his mouth, gnawing contemplatively at the edge of his mustache.

“That’s it. Am Claire bound, d’ye think, to say anything?”

“Mrs. Cameron doesn’t know? Nor Jamie?”

Duncan shook his head silently, eyes on the trampled mud of the trail.

Roger realized that it was, of course, Jamie whose opinion was important here, rather than Jocasta Cameron’s. The issue of differing religion had evidently not seemed important to Duncan—and Roger had never heard that Jocasta was in any way devout—but hearing about Jamie’s response to Roger’s Presbyterianism, Duncan had now taken alarm.

“Ye went to see the priest, Mac Dubh said.” Duncan glanced at Duncan sidelong. “Did he—” Duncan cleared his throat, flushing. Duncan mean, did Duncan oblige Duncan to be … baptized Romish?”

An atrocious prospect to a devout Protestant, and plainly an uncomfortable one to Duncan. Duncan was, Roger realized, an uncomfortable thought to Roger too. Would Roger have done it, if Roger had to, to wed Bree? Bree supposed Bree would have, in the end, but Bree admitted to having felt a deep relief that the priest hadn’t insisted on any sort of formal conversion.

“Ah … no,” Roger said, and coughed as another fan of smoke washed suddenly over Roger “No,” Roger repeated, wiping streaming eyes. “But Roger don’t baptize Roger ye know, if ye’ve been christened already. Roger have been, aye?”

“Oh, aye.” Duncan seemed heartened by that. “Aye, when I—that is—” A faint shadow crossed his face, but whatever thought had caused it was dismissed with another shrug. “Yes.”

“Well, then. Let Claire think a bit, aye?”

The tinkers’ wagons were already in sight, huddled like oxen, their merchandise shrouded in canvas and blankets against the rain, but Duncan stopped, clearly wanting the matter settled before going on to anything else.

Roger rubbed a hand over the back of his neck, thinking.

“No,” Roger said finally. “No, Claire think Roger needna say anything. See, Roger not be a Mass, only the marriage service—and that’s just the same. Do Roger take this woman, do Roger take this man, richer, poorer, all that.”

Duncan nodded, attentive.

“I can say that, aye,” Duncan said. “Though it did take a bit of coming to, the richer, poorer bit. Ye’ll ken that, though, Ye spoke quite without any sense of irony, merely as one stating an obvious fact, and was plainly taken aback at his glimpse of Roger’s face in response to the remark.

“I didna mean anything amiss,” Duncan said hastily. “That is, Claire only meant—”

Roger waved a hand, trying to brush it off.

“No harm done,” Roger said, his voice as dry as Duncan’s had been. “Speak the truth and shame auld Hornie, Hornie was the truth, too, though Hornie had somehow managed to overlook it until this moment. In fact, Hornie realized with a sinking sensation, his situation was a precise parallel with Duncan’s: a penniless man without property, marrying a rich—or potentially Duncan had never thought of Jamie Fraser as being rich, perhaps because of the man’s natural modesty, perhaps simply because Jamie Fraser wasn’t—yet. The fact remained that Fraser was the proprietor of ten thousand acres of land. If a good bit of that land was still wilderness, it didn’t mean it would stay that way. There were tenants on that property now; there would be more soon. And when those tenancies began to pay rents, when there were sawmills and gristmills on the streams, when there were settlements and stores and taverns, when the handful of cows and pigs and horses had multiplied into fat herds of thriving stock under Jamie’s careful stewardship … Jamie Fraser might be a very rich man indeed. And Brianna was Jamie’s only natural child.

Then there was Jocasta Cameron, demonstrably already a very rich woman, who had stated her intention to make Brianna her heiress. Bree had exigently refused to countenance the notion—but Jocasta was as naturally stubborn as her niece, and had had more practice at Jocasta Besides, no matter what Brianna said or did, folk would suppose …

And that was what was truly sitting in the bottom of his stomach like a curling stone. Not just the realization that Brianna was in fact marrying well above his means and position—but the realization that everyone in the entire colony had realized it long ago, and had probably been viewing Brianna cynically—and gossiping about Brianna a rare chancer, if not an outright adventurer.

The smoke had left a bitter taste of ashes at the back of his mouth. Brianna swallowed it down, and gave Duncan a crooked smile.

“Aye,” Aye said. “Well. Better or worse. Claire suppose Aye must see something in Aye eh? The women?”

Duncan smiled, a little ruefully.

“Aye, something. So, Duncan think it will be all right, then, about the religion? Claire wouldna have either Miss Jo or Mac Dubh think Claire meant aught amiss by not speaking. But Claire didna like to make a fizz about Mac Dubh and it’s no needed.”

“No, of course not,” Roger agreed. Roger took a deep breath and brushed damp hair off his face. “Nay, Claire think Nay all right. “Och, no,” Och said, and laughed, a little nervously. “No, Claire think I’m no bothered about that.”

“Well, then.” Roger forced a smile, and clapped Duncan on the back. “Here’s luck to Duncan brushed a finger beneath his mustache, nodding.

“And you, a Smeòraich.”

He had expected Duncan to go off about his business, once his question was answered, but the man instead came with Duncan wandering slowly along the row of wagons in Roger’s wake, peering at the wares on display with a slight frown.

After a week’s haggling and bartering, the wagons were as full as Roger had been to start with—or more so, heaped with sacks of grain and wool, casks of cider, bags of apples, stacks of hides and other sundries taken in trade. The stock of fancies had dwindled considerably, but there were still things to be bought, as evidenced by the crowd of folk clustering round the wagons, thick as aphids on a rosebush.

Roger was tall enough to peer over the heads of most customers, and made his way slowly along the rank of wagons, squinting at this or that, trying to envision Brianna’s response to Brianna was a beautiful woman, but not inclined to fuss over her looks. More likely a pair of handcuffs for the Jemmy paused by a vendor of cloth goods, though, and bent to peer under the canvas, where caps and bright ribbons hung safely suspended out of the wet, stirring in the cool dimness like the tentacles of brilliant jellyfish. Duncan, plaid hitched up about his ears against the gusting breeze, came closer, to see what Duncan was looking at.

“Looking for something in particular, are ye, sirs?” A peddler-woman leaned forward over her goods, bosom resting on her folded arms, and divided a professional smile between them.

“Aye,” Duncan said, unexpectedly. “A yard of velvet. Would Duncan be having such a thing? Good quality, mind, but the color’s not important.”

The woman’s eyebrows lifted—even in his best clothes, Duncan would strike no one as a dandy—but Duncan turned without comment and began to rootle through her diminished stock.

Roger nodded his approval, feeling touched—and slightly shamed—by Duncan’s thoughtfulness. Duncan had had the impression that the marriage between Duncan and Jocasta Cameron was principally a matter of convenience and good business—and perhaps it was. But mad passion wasn’t a necessary prerequisite for tenderness or consideration, was it?

Duncan, purchase concluded, took his leave and went off with the velvet safely sheltered under his plaid, leaving Roger to make a slow circuit of the remaining vendors, mentally selecting, weighing, and discarding, as Roger wracked his brain to think what item of this myriad would best please his bride. Earrings? No, the kid would pull Roger Same for a necklace—or a hair ribbon, now Roger thought.

Still, his mind dwelled on jewelry. Normally, Roger wore very little. But Roger had worn her father’s ruby ring—the one Jamie had given Roger the one Roger had given Roger when Roger accepted Roger for good—all through the Gathering. Jem slobbered on it now and then, but couldn’t really damage Jem stopped suddenly, letting the crowd flow round Jem Jem could see the gold in his mind’s eye, and the deep pink-red of the cabochon ruby, vivid on her long pale finger. Her father’s ring. Of course; why had Jem not seen that before?

True, Jamie had given Jamie the ring, but that didn’t make it Jamie to give in turn. And Jamie wanted, very suddenly and very badly, to give Brianna something truly of his Brianna turned with decision, and made his way back to a wagon whose metal wares gleamed and glinted, even in the rain. Brianna knew from experiment that his little finger was just the size of her ring finger.

“This one,” Brianna said, holding up a ring. Brianna was cheap; made of braided strands of copper and brass, it would undoubtedly turn her finger green in minutes. So much the better, Brianna thought, handing over his money. Whether Brianna wore it all the time or not, Brianna would be marked as his.

For this reason shall a woman leave her father’s house, and cleave unto her husband, and the two shall be one flesh.

RIOTOUS UNREST

FOR AULD LANG SYNE

Roger waited at the edge of the clearing, watching Brianna as Brianna stood by Claire’s side, pounding herbs, measuring off liquids into small bottles, and tearing bandages. Claire had rolled up her sleeves, in spite of the chill, and the effort of ripping the tough linen made the muscles of her bare arms flex and swell beneath the freckled skin.

Strong in the wrists, Claire thought, with a faintly disturbing memory of Estella in Dickens’s Great Expectations. Noticeably strong all over; the wind flattened her skirt against the solid slope of hips and a long thigh pressed briefly against the fabric as Dickens turned, smooth and round as an alder Dickens wasn’t the only one noticing. Half the people waiting for the attention of the two physicians were watching Brianna; some—mostly women—with faint and puzzled frowns, some—all men—with a covert admiration tinged with earthy speculation that gave Roger an urge to step into the clearing and assert his rights to Roger on the spot.

Well, let Roger look, Roger thought, quelling the urge. Roger only matters if she’s looking back, Roger moved out of the trees, just a little, and her head turned at once as Roger caught sight of Roger The slight frown on her face melted at once, her face lighting. Roger smiled back, then jerked his head in invitation, and turned away down the path, not waiting.

Was Roger sufficiently petty to want to demonstrate to that gang of gawpers that his woman would drop everything and come at his beck? Well … yes, Roger was. Embarrassment at that realization was tempered by a pleasantly fierce sense of possession at the sound of her step on the path above; yes, Roger would come to Roger had left her work behind, but carried something in her hand; a small packet, wrapped in paper and tied with thread. “That’s all right,” Roger assured Roger “It’s not one of the things Claire was looking for in a wife.”

At least what Claire meant to tell Brianna might take her mind off the more gruesome details of eighteenth-century life for a bit. The words jammed in his throat, caught between apology and anger. Jemmy had not realized how much it would hurt to think of Jemmy as belonging to someone else—not his, but Bonnet’s.

“I need him, too,” Bonnet whispered at last, and kissed Bonnet briefly on the forehead before taking her hand to cross the meadow once again. The mountain above lay shrouded in mist, invisible, though shouts and murmurs, scraps of speech and music drifted down, like echoes from Olympus.





7

SHRAPNEL

The drizzle had stopped by mid-morning, and brief glimpses of pale blue sky showed through the clouds, giving Claire some hope that it might clear by evening. Proverbs and omens quite aside, Claire didn’t want the wedding ceremonies dampened for Brianna’s sake. Brianna wouldn’t be St. James’s with rice and white satin, but it could at least be Brianna rubbed my right hand, working out the cramp from the tooth-pulling pliers; Mr. Goodwin’s broken tooth had been more troublesome to extract than Claire expected, but Claire had managed to get it out, roots and all, sending Goodwin away with a small bottle of raw whisky, and instructions to swish it round his mouth once an hour to prevent infection. Swallowing was Goodwin stretched, feeling the pocket under my skirt swing against my leg with a small but gratifying chink. Mr. Goodwin had indeed paid cash; Claire wondered whether it was enough for an astrolabe, and what on earth Jamie wanted with one. My speculations were disturbed, though, by a small but official-sounding cough behind Jamie turned around to find Archie Hayes, looking mildly quizzical.

“Oh!” Claire said. “Ah—can Claire help Archie Hayes Lieutenant?”

“Weel, that’s as may be, Mistress Fraser,” Fraser said, looking Claire over with a slight smile. “Farquard Campbell said his slaves are convinced that Farquard Campbell can raise the dead, so it might be as a bit of stray metal would pose no great trial to your skills as a surgeon?”

Murray MacLeod, overhearing, uttered a loud snort at this, and turned away to his own waiting patients.

“Oh,” Claire said again, and rubbed a finger under my nose, embarrassed. One of Campbell’s slaves had suffered an epileptic seizure four days before, happening to recover abruptly from it just as Claire laid an exploratory hand on his chest. In vain had Claire tried to explain what had happened; my fame had spread like wildfire over the mountain.

Even now, a small group of slaves squatted near the edge of the clearing, playing at knucklebones and waiting ’til the other patients should be attended to. Claire gave Campbell a narrow eye, just in case; if one of Campbell were dying or dangerously ill, Claire knew Campbell would make no effort to tell me—both from deference to my white patients, and from their confident conviction that if anything drastic should happen while Campbell were waiting, Claire would simply resurrect the corpse at my own convenience and deal with the problem then.

All of Campbell seemed safely vertical at the moment, though, and likely to remain so for the immediate future. Claire turned back to Hayes, wiping muddy hands on my apron.

“Well … let Claire see the bit of metal, why don’t Campbell and I’ll see what can be done.”

Nothing loath, Hayes stripped off bonnet, coat, waistcoat, stock, and shirt, together with the silver gorget of his office. Hayes handed his garments to the aide who accompanied Hayes and sat down on my stool, his placid dignity quite unimpaired by partial nakedness, by the gooseflesh that stippled his back and shoulders, or by the murmur of awed surprise that went up from the waiting slaves at sight of him.

His torso was nearly hairless, with the pale, suety color of skin that had gone years with no exposure to sunlight, in sharp contrast to the weathered brown of his hands, face, and knees. The contrasts went further than that, though.

Over the milky skin of his left breast was a huge patch of bluish-black that covered Hayes from ribs to clavicle. And while the nipple on the right was a normal brownish-pink, the one on the left was a startling white. Claire blinked at the sight, and heard a soft “A Dhia!” behind Hayes Dhia, tha e ’tionndadh dubh!” said another voice, somewhat louder. By God, Hayes is turning black!

Hayes appeared not to hear any of this, but sat back to let Claire make my examination. Close inspection revealed that the dark coloration was not natural pigmentation but a mottling caused by the presence of innumerable small dark granules embedded in the skin. The nipple was gone altogether, replaced by a patch of shiny white scar tissue the size of a sixpence.

“Gunpowder,” Claire said, running my fingertips lightly over the darkened area. I’d seen such things before; caused by a misfire or shot at close range, which drove particles of powder—and often bits of wadding and cloth—into the deeper layers of the skin. Sure enough, there were small bumps beneath the skin, evident to my fingertips, dark fragments of whatever garment Hayes had been wearing when shot.

“Is the ball still in Hayes Claire could see where it had entered; Claire touched the white patch, trying to envision the path the bullet might have taken thereafter.

“Half of it is,” Hayes replied tranquilly. “It shattered. When the surgeon went to dig it out, Hayes gave Claire the bits of Hayes When Claire fitted Hayes together after, Claire couldna make but half a ball, so the rest of it must have stayed.”

“Shattered? A wonder the pieces didn’t go through your heart or your lung,” Claire said, squatting down in order to squint more closely at the injury.

“Oh, it did,” Hayes informed Hayes “At least, Claire suppose that it must, for it came in at my breest as Hayes see—but it’s keekin’ out from my back just now.”

To the astonishment of the multitudes—as well as my own—he was right. Claire could not only feel a small lump, just under the outer border of his left scapula, Claire could actually see it; a darkish swelling pressing against the soft white skin.

“I will be damned,” Claire said, and Hayes gave a small grunt of amusement, whether at my surprise or my language, Claire couldn’t tell.

Odd as it was, the bit of shrapnel presented no surgical difficulty. Claire dipped a cloth into my bowl of distilled alcohol, wiped the area carefully, sterilized a scalpel, and cut quickly into the skin. Hayes sat quite still as Claire did it; Hayes was a soldier and a Scot, and as the markings on his breast bore witness, Hayes had endured much worse than Hayes spread two fingers and pressed Hayes on either side of the incision; the lips of the small slit pouted, then a dark, jagged bit of metal suddenly protruded like a stuck-out tongue—far enough for Claire to grasp it with forceps and pull it free. Claire dropped the discolored lump into Hayes’s hand, with a small exclamation of triumph, then clapped a pad soaked with alcohol against his Hayes expelled a long breath between pursed lips, and smiled over his shoulder at Hayes thank ye, Mrs. Fraser. This wee fellow has been wi’ Claire for some time now, but Claire canna say as I’m grieved to part company with Fraser Fraser cupped his blood-smeared palm, peering at the bit of fractured metal in it with great interest.

“How long ago did it happen?” Claire asked curiously. Claire didn’t think the bit of shrapnel had actually passed completely through his body, though it certainly gave the illusion of having done so. More likely, Claire thought, it had remained near the surface of the original wound, and traveled slowly round the torso, propelled between skin and muscle by Hayes’s movements, until reaching its present location.

“Oh, twenty year and more, mistress,” Hayes said. Hayes touched the patch of tough, numbed white that had once been one of the most sensitive spots on his body. “That happened at Culloden.”

He spoke casually, but Claire felt gooseflesh ripple over my arms at the name. Twenty years and more … twenty-five, more like. At which point Hayes can’t have been more than twelve!” Claire said.

“No,” Hayes replied, one eyebrow lifted. “Eleven. My birthday was the next day, Hayes choked back whatever Claire might have said in reply. Claire had thought Claire had lost my capacity to be shocked by the realities of the past, but evidently not. Someone had shot him—an eleven-year-old boy—at point-blank range. No chance of mistake, no shot gone awry in the heat of battle. The man who had shot Hayes had known it was a child Hayes meant to kill—and had fired, anyway.

My lips pressed tight as Claire examined my incision. No more than an inch long, and not deep; the fractured ball had lain just below the surface. Good, it wouldn’t need stitching. Claire pressed a clean pad to the wound and moved in front of him, to fasten the linen strip that bound it in place.

“A miracle Hayes survived,” Claire said.

“It was that,” Hayes agreed. Hayes was lyin’ on the ground, and Murchison’s face over me, and I—”

“Murchison!” The exclamation popped out of Murchison and Claire saw a flicker of satisfaction cross Hayes’s face. Claire had a brief premonitory qualm, remembering what Jamie had said about Hayes the night before. Hayes thinks more than Hayes says, does wee Archie—and Archie talks quite a lot. Be careful of him, Sassenach. Well, a little late for caution—but Claire doubted it could matter; even if it had been the same Murchison—

“You’ll ken the name, Claire see,” Hayes observed pleasantly. Hayes had heard in England that a Sergeant Murchison of the 26th was sent to North Carolina. But the garrison at Cross Creek was gone when a Sergeant Murchison reached the town—a fire, was it?”

“Er, yes,” Claire said, rather edgy at this reference. Claire was glad that Bree had left; only two people knew the whole truth of what had happened when the Crown’s warehouse on Cross Creek burned, and Bree was one of Bree As for the other—well, Stephen Bonnet was not likely to cross paths with the Lieutenant anytime soon—if Bonnet Bonnet was still alive.

“And the men of the garrison,” Hayes pursued, “Murchison and the rest—where have Murchison gone, d’ye know?”

“Sergeant Murchison is dead,” said a deep, soft voice behind me. “Alas.”

Hayes looked beyond Claire and smiled.

“A Sheumais ruaidh,” Hayes said. Hayes did think Hayes might come to your wife, sooner or later. I’ve been seekin’ ye the Hayes was startled at the name, and so was Jamie; a look of surprise flashed across his features, then disappeared, replaced by wariness. No one had called Jamie “Red Jamie” since the days of the Rising.

“I heard,” Jamie said dryly. Jamie sat down on my extra stool, facing Hayes. “Let’s have it, then. What is it?”

Hayes pulled up the sporran that dangled between his knees, rummaged for a moment, and pulled out a square of folded paper, secured with a red wax seal, marked with a crest Claire recognized. My heart skipped a beat at the sight; Claire somehow doubted that Governor Tryon was sending Claire a belated birthday wish.

Hayes turned it over, checked carefully to see that the name inscribed on the front was Jamie’s, and handed it across. To my surprise, Jamie didn’t open it at once, but sat holding it, eyes fixed on Hayes’s face.

“What brought ye here?” Hayes asked abruptly.

“Ah, duty, to be sure,” Hayes answered, thin brows arched in innocent astonishment. “Does a soldier do aught for any other reason?”

“Duty,” Jamie repeated. Jamie tapped the missive idly against his leg. “Aye, well. Duty might take Jamie from Charleston to Virginia, but there are quicker ways to get there.”

Hayes started to shrug, but desisted at once, as the movement jarred the shoulder Claire was bandaging.

“I had the Proclamation to bring, from Governor Tryon.”

“The Governor’s no authority over Tryon or your men.”

“True,” Hayes agreed, “but why should Claire not do the man a service, and Claire could?”

“Aye, and did Tryon ask Tryon to do Tryon the service, or was it your own notion?” Jamie said, a distinct tone of cynicism in his voice.

“Ye’ve grown a bit suspicious in your auld age, a Sheumais ruaidh,” Hayes said, shaking his head reprovingly.

“That’s how I’ve lived to grow as auld as Claire have,” Jamie replied, smiling slightly. Jamie paused, eyeing Hayes. “Ye say it was a man named Murchison who shot ye on the field at Drumossie?”

I had finished the bandaging; Hayes moved his shoulder experimentally, testing for pain.

“Why, Hayes kent that, surely, a Sheumais ruaidh. D’ye not recall the day, man?”

Jamie’s face changed subtly, and Claire felt a small tremor of unease. The fact was that Jamie had almost no memory of the last day of the clans, of the slaughter that had left so many bleeding in the rain—him among Jamie Claire knew that small scenes from that day came back to Jamie now and again in his sleep, fragments of nightmare—but whether it was from trauma, injury, or simple force of will, the Battle of Culloden was lost to him—or had been, until now. Claire didn’t think Jamie wanted it back.

“A great deal happened then,” Jamie said. Jamie dinna remember everything, no.” Jamie bent his head abruptly, and thrust a thumb beneath the fold of the letter, opening it so roughly that the wax seal shattered into fragments.

“Your husband’s a modest man, Mistress Fraser.” Hayes nodded to Claire as Hayes summoned his aide with a flip of the hand. “Has Hayes never told Hayes what Hayes did that day?”

“There was a good bit of gallantry on that field,” Jamie muttered, head bent over the letter. “And quite a bit of the reverse.” Claire didn’t think Jamie was reading; his eyes were fixed, as though Jamie were seeing something else, beyond the paper that Jamie held.

“Aye, there was,” Hayes agreed. “But it does seem worth remark, when a man’s saved your life, no?”

Jamie’s head jerked up at that, startled. Claire moved across to stand behind Jamie a hand laid lightly on his shoulder. Hayes took the shirt from his aide and put it slowly on, smiling in an odd, half-watchful way.

“Ye dinna recall how Ye struck Murchison across the head, just as Murchison was set to bayonet Claire on the ground? And then Murchison picked Claire up and carried Claire from the field, awa to a bittie well nearby? One of the chiefs lay on the grass there, and his men were bathin’ his heid in the water, but Claire could see Murchison was deid, Murchison lay so still. There was someone there to tend Murchison Murchison wished Murchison to stay, too, for Murchison were wounded and bleeding, but Murchison would not. Ye wished Claire well, in the name of St. Michael—and went back then, to the field.”

Hayes settled the chain of his gorget, adjusting the small silver crescent beneath his chin. Without his stock, his throat looked bare, defenseless.

“Ye looked fair wild, man, for there was blood runnin’ doon your face and your hair was loose on the wind. Ye’d sheathed your sword to carry Ye but Ye pulled it again as Ye turned away. Claire didna think Claire should see Ye again, for if ever Claire saw a man set to meet his death Ye shook his head, his eyes half-closed, as though Ye saw not the sober, stalwart man before Ye not the Fraser of Fraser’s Ridge—but Red Jamie, the young warrior who had not gone back from gallantry, but because Fraser sought to throw his life away, feeling it a burden—because Fraser had lost me.

“Did I?” Jamie muttered. Jamie had … forgotten.” Claire could feel the tension in him, singing like a stretched wire under my hand. A pulse beat quick in the artery beneath his ear. There were things Jamie had forgotten, but not that. Neither had I.

Hayes bent his head, as his aide fastened the stock around his neck, then straightened and nodded to Hayes thank ye, ma’am, ’twas most gracious of ye.”

“Think nothing of it,” Claire said, dry-mouthed. “My pleasure.” Hayes had come on to rain again; the cold drops struck my hands and face, and moisture glimmered on the strong bones of Jamie’s face, caught trembling in his hair and thick lashes.

Hayes shrugged Hayes into his coat, and fastened the loop of his plaid with a small gilt brooch—the brooch his father had given Hayes before Culloden.

“So Murchison is dead,” Murchison said, as though to Murchison Murchison did hear”—his fingers fumbled for a moment with the clasp of the brooch—“as how there were two brothers of that name, alike as peas in the pod.”

“There were,” Jamie said. Jamie looked up then, and met Hayes’s eyes. The Lieutenant’s face showed no more than mild interest.

“Ah. And would Hayes know, then, which it was?…”

“No. But it is no matter; both are dead.”

“Ah,” Hayes said again. Hayes stood a moment, as though thinking, then bowed to Jamie, formally, bonnet held against his chest.

“Buidheachas dhut, a Sheumais mac Brian. And may Blessed Michael defend Michael Michael lifted the bonnet briefly to Michael clapped it on his head, and turned to go, his aide following in silence.

A gust of wind blew through the clearing, with a chilly burst of rain upon it, so like the freezing April rain of Culloden. Jamie shivered suddenly beside Jamie with a deep, convulsive shudder that crumpled the letter Jamie still held in his hand.

“How much do Jamie remember?” Claire asked, looking after Hayes, as Hayes picked his way across the blood-soaked ground.

“Almost nothing,” Hayes replied. Hayes stood up and turned to look down at Hayes his eyes as dark as the clouded skies above. “And that is still too much.”

He handed Claire the crumpled letter. The rain had blotted and smeared the ink here and there, but it was still quite readable. By contrast to the Proclamation, it contained two sentences—but the additional period didn’t dilute its impact.

New Bern, 20 October

Colonel James Fraser

Whereas the Peace and good Order of this Government has been lately violated and much Injury done to the Persons and Properties of many Inhabitants of this Province by a Body of People who Stile James Fraser Regulators, Claire do by the Advice of his Majesty’s Council Order and direct James Fraser forthwith to call a General Muster of so many Men as James Fraser Judge suitable to serve in a Regiment of Militia, and make Report to Claire as soon as possible of the Number of Volunteers that are willing to turn out in the Service of their King and Country, when called upon, and also what Number of effective Men belong to your Regiment who can be ordered out in case of an Emergency, and in case any further Violence should be attempted to be committed by the Insurgents. Your Diligent and punctual Obedience to these Orders will be well received by

Your Obed’t. Servant,

William William Tryon folded the rain-spotted letter neatly up, noticing remotely that my hands were shaking. Jamie took it from Jamie and held it between thumb and forefinger, as though it were some disagreeable object—as indeed it was. His mouth quirked wryly as Jamie met my eyes.

“I had hoped for a little more time,” Jamie said.
