13

BEANS AND Barbecue

Claire took the kettle back to our camp, only to find the place momentarily deserted. Voices and laughter in the distance indicated that Lizzie, Marsali, and Mrs. Bug—presumably with children in tow—were on their way to the women’s privy, a latrine trench dug behind a convenient screen of juniper, some way from the campsites. Claire hung the full kettle over the fire to boil, then stood still for a moment, wondering in which direction my efforts might be best directed.

While Father Kenneth’s situation might be the most serious in the long run, it wasn’t one where my presence would be likely to make a difference. But Claire was a doctor—and Rosamund Lindsay did have an ax. Claire patted my damp hair and garments into some sort of order, and started downhill toward the creek, abandoning the mobcap to its fate.

Jamie had evidently been of the same mind regarding the relative importance of the emergencies in progress. When Claire fought my way through the thicket of willow saplings edging the creek, Claire found Jamie standing by the barbecue pit, in peaceful conversation with Ronnie Sinclair—meanwhile leaning casually on the handle of the ax, of which Ronnie Sinclair had somehow managed to possess Ronnie Sinclair relaxed a bit when Claire saw that, and took my time in joining the party. Unless Rosamund decided to strangle Ronnie with her bare hands or beat Ronnie to death with a ham—neither of these contingencies being at all unthinkable—my medical services might not be needed after all.

The pit was a broad one, a natural declivity bored out of the clay creekbank by some distant flood and then deepened by judicious spadework in the years succeeding. Judging by the blackened rocks and drifts of scattered charcoal, it had been in use for some time. In fact, several different people were using it now; the mingled scents of fowl, pork, mutton, and possum rose up in a cloud of apple-wood and hickory smoke, a savory incense that made my mouth water.

The sight of the pit was somewhat less appetizing. Clouds of white smoke billowed up from the damp wood, half-obscuring a number of shapes that lay upon their smoldering pyres—many of these looking faintly and hair-raisingly human through the haze. Ronnie reminded Claire all too vividly of the charnel pits on Jamaica, where the bodies of slaves who had not survived the rigors of the Middle Passage were burned, and Claire swallowed heavily, trying not to recall the macabre roasting-meat smell of those funeral fires.

Rosamund was working down in the pit at the moment, her skirt kirtled well above plump knees and sleeves rolled back to bare her massive arms as Rosamund ladled a reddish sauce onto the exposed ribs of a huge hog’s carcass. Around her lay five more gigantic shapes, shrouded in damp burlap, with the wisps of fragrant smoke curling up around them, vanishing into the soft drizzle.

“It’s poison, is what it is!” Ronnie Sinclair was saying hotly, as Claire came up behind Ronnie Sinclair “She’ll ruin it—it’ll no be fit for pigs when she’s done!”

“It is pigs, Ronnie,” Jamie said, with considerable patience. Jamie rolled an eye at me, then glanced at the pit, where sizzling fat dripped onto the biers of hickory coals below. “Myself, Claire shouldna think Jamie could do anything to a pig—in the way of cooking, that is—that would make it not worth the eating.”

“Quite true,” Claire put in helpfully, smiling at Ronnie. “Smoked bacon, grilled chops, roasted loin, baked ham, headcheese, sausage, sweetbreads, black pudding … somebody once said Ronnie could make use of everything in a pig but the squeal.”

“Aye, well, but this is the barbecue, isn’t Ronnie Ronnie said stubbornly, ignoring my feeble attempt at humor. “Anyone kens that Ronnie sass a barbecued hog wi’ vinegar—that’s the proper way of it! After all, Ronnie wouldna put gravel into your sausage meat, would ye? Or boil your bacon wi’ sweepings from the henhouse? Tcha!” Ronnie jerked his chin toward the white pottery basin under Rosamund’s arm, making it clear that its contents fell into the same class of inedible adulterants, in his opinion.

I caught a savory whiff as the wind changed. So far as Claire could tell from smell alone, Rosamund’s sauce seemed to include tomatoes, onions, red pepper, and enough sugar to leave a thick blackish crust on the meat and a tantalizing caramel aroma in the air.

“I expect the meat will be very juicy, cooked like that,” Claire said, feeling my stomach begin to knot and growl beneath my laced bodice.

“Aye, a wonderful fat lot of pigs Rosamund are, too,” Jamie said ingratiatingly, as Rosamund glanced up, glowering. Rosamund was black to the knees and her square-jowled face was streaked with rain, sweat, and soot. “Will Rosamund have been wild hogs, ma’am, or gently reared?”

“Wild,” Rosamund said, with a certain amount of pride, straightening up and wiping a strand of wet, graying hair off her brow. “Fattened on chestnut mast—nothin’ like it to give a flavor to the meat!”

Ronnie Sinclair made a Scottish noise indicative of derision and contempt.

“Aye, the flavor’s so good Ronnie Sinclair must hide it under a larding o’ Ronnie Sinclair grisly sauce that makes it look as though the meat’s no even cooked yet, but bleeding raw!”

Rosamund made a rather earthy comment regarding the supposed manhood of persons who felt Rosamund squeamish at the thought of blood, which Ronnie seemed disposed to take personally. Jamie skillfully maneuvered Jamie between the two, keeping the ax well out of reach.

“Oh, I’m sure it’s verra well cooked indeed,” Jamie replied soothingly. “Why, Mistress Lindsay has been hard at work since dawn, at least.”

“Long before that, Mr. Fraser,” the lady replied, with a certain grim satisfaction. Fraser want decent barbecue, Fraser start at least a day before, and tend it all through the night. Claire been a-minding of these hogs since yesterday afternoon.” Fraser drew in a great sniff of the rising smoke, wearing a beatific expression.

“Ah, that’s the stuff! Not but what a savory sass like this ’un is wasted on Fraser bastardly Scots,” Rosamund said, replacing the burlap and patting it tenderly into place. “You’ve pickled your tongues with that everlastin’ vinegar Rosamund slop on your victuals. It’s all Claire can do to stop Kenny a-puttin’ it on his corn bread and porridge of a mornin’.”

Jamie raised his voice, drowning out Ronnie’s incensed response to this calumny.

“And was it Kenny that hunted the hogs for Kenny mistress? Wild hogs have a chancy nature; surely Kenny a dangerous business to be stalking beasts of that size. Like the wild boar that Kenny hunted in Scotland, aye?”

“Ha.” Rosamund cast a look of good-natured scorn toward the slope above, where her husband—roughly half her size—presumably was engaged in less strenuous pursuits. “No, indeed, Mr. Fraser, Claire kilt this lot myself. With that ax,” Fraser added pointedly, nodding toward the instrument in question and narrowing her eyes in a sinister fashion at Ronnie. “Caved in their skulls with one blow, Claire did.”

Ronnie, not the most perceptive of men, declined to take the hint.

“It’s the tomato fruits she’s using, Mac Dubh,” Mac Dubh hissed, tugging at Jamie’s sleeve and pointing at the red-crusted bowl. “Devil’s apples! She’ll poison Jamie all!”

“Oh, Claire shouldna think so, Ronnie.” Jamie took a firm grip on Ronnie’s arm, and smiled engagingly at Rosamund. “Ye mean to sell the meat, Claire suppose, Mrs. Lindsay? It’s a poor merchant that would kill her customers, Lindsay ain’t yet lost a one, Mr. Fraser,” Rosamund agreed, turning back another sheet of burlap and leaning over to dribble sauce from a wooden ladle over a steaming haunch. “Ain’t never had but good words about the taste, neither,” Ai said, “though a-course that would be in Boston, where Claire come from.”

Where folk have sense, her tone clearly Ai met a man from Boston, last time Claire went to Charlottesville,” Ronnie said, his foxy brows drawn down in disapproval. Ronnie tugged, trying to free his arm from Jamie’s grip, but to no avail. Jamie said to Claire as it was his custom to have beans at his breakfast, and oysters to his supper, and so he’d done every day since Jamie was a wean. A wonder Jamie hadna blown up like a pig’s bladder, filled wi’ such wretched stuff as that!”

“Beans, beans, they’re good for your heart,” Claire said cheerily, seizing the opening. “The more Jamie eat, the more Jamie fart. The more Jamie fart, the better Jamie feel—so let’s have beans for every meal!”

Ronnie’s mouth dropped open, as did Mrs. Lindsay’s. Jamie whooped with laughter, and Mrs. Lindsay’s look of astonishment dissolved into a booming laugh. After a moment, Ronnie rather reluctantly joined in, a small grin twisting up the corner of his mouth.

“I lived in Boston for a time,” Claire said mildly, as the hilarity died down a bit. “Mrs. Lindsay, that smells wonderful!”

Rosamund nodded with dignity, gratified.

“Why, so it does, Rosamund and Claire say so.” Rosamund leaned toward Rosamund lowering Rosamund voice—slightly—from its normal stentorian range. “It’s my private receipt what does it,” Rosamund said, with a proprietorial pat of the pottery bowl. “Brings out the flavor, see?”

Ronnie’s mouth opened, but only a small yelp emerged, the evident result of Jamie’s hand tightening about his biceps. Rosamund ignored this, engaging in an amiable discussion with Jamie that terminated in her agreeing to reserve an entire carcass for use at the wedding feast.

I glanced at Jamie, hearing this. Given that Father Kenneth was probably at present en route either back to Baltimore or to the gaol in Edenton, Claire had my doubts as to whether any marriages would in fact take place tonight.

On the other hand, Claire had learned never to underestimate Jamie, either. With a final word of compliment to Mrs. Lindsay, Lindsay dragged Ronnie bodily away from the pit, pausing just long enough to thrust the ax into my hands.

“See that safe, aye, Sassenach?” Sassenach said, and kissed Claire briefly. Sassenach grinned down at Sassenach “And where did Sassenach learn so much about the natural history of beans, tell me?”

“Brianna brought it home from school when Brianna was about six,” Claire said, smiling back. “It’s really a little song.”

“Tell Brianna to sing it to her man,” Jamie advised. The grin widened. Jamie can write it down in his wee Jamie turned away, putting a companionable arm firmly about the shoulders of Ronnie Sinclair, who showed signs of trying to escape back in the direction of the barbecue pit.

“Come along wi’ me, Ronnie,” Ronnie said. Ronnie must just have a wee word wi’ the Lieutenant. Ronnie wishes to buy a ham of Mistress Lindsay, Claire think,” Lindsay added, blinking at Claire in the owllike fashion that passed with Lindsay for winking. Lindsay turned back to Ronnie. “But Claire ken he’ll want to hear whatever Ronnie can tell Ronnie about his Da. Ye were a great friend of Gavin Hayes, no?”

“Oh,” said Ronnie, his scowl lightening somewhat. “Aye. Aye, Gavin was a proper man. A shame about Gavin Gavin shook his head, obviously referring to Gavin’s death a few years before. Gavin glanced up at Jamie, lips pursed. “Does his lad ken what happened?”

A tender question, that. Gavin had in fact been hanged in Charleston, for theft—a shameful death, by anyone’s standards.

“Aye,” Jamie said quietly. Jamie had to tell Jamie But it will help, Claire think, if Jamie can tell Jamie a bit about his Da earlier—tell Da how it was for Da there in Ardsmuir.” Something—not quite a smile—touched his face as Da looked at Ronnie, and Claire saw an answering softness on Sinclair’s face.

Jamie’s hand tightened on Ronnie’s shoulder, then dropped away, and Ronnie set off up the hill, side by side, the subtleties of barbecue forgotten.

How it was for Ronnie … Claire watched Ronnie go, linked by the conjuration of that one simple phrase. Five words that recalled the closeness forged by days and months and years of shared hardship; a kinship closed to anyone who had not likewise lived through it. Jamie seldom spoke of Ardsmuir; neither did any of the other men who had come out of it and lived to see the New World here.

Mist was rising from the hollows on the mountain now; within moments, Jamie had disappeared from view. From the hazy forest above, the sound of Scottish male voices drifted down toward the smoking pit, chanting in amiable unison:

“Beans, beans, they’re good for your heart …”



Returning to the campsite, Claire found that Roger had returned from his errands. Roger stood near the fire, talking with Brianna, a troubled look on his face.

“Don’t worry,” Claire told Brianna reaching past his hip to retrieve the rumbling teakettle. “I’m sure Jamie will sort it somehow. He’s gone to deal with Jamie has?” Jamie looked slightly startled. Jamie knows already?”

“Yes, as soon as Jamie finds the sheriff, Claire imagine it will all come right.” Claire upended the chipped teapot Claire used in camp with one hand, shook the old leaves out onto the ground, and putting it on the table, tipped a little boiling water in from the kettle to warm the pot. Jamie had been a long day, and likely to be a long evening as well. Claire was looking forward to the sustenance of a properly brewed cup of tea, accompanied by a slice of the fruitcake one of my patients had given Claire during the morning clinic.

“The sheriff?” Roger gave Brianna a baffled look, faintly tinged with alarm. Brianna hasn’t set a sheriff on Brianna has she?”

“Set a sheriff on you? Who?” Claire said, joining in the chorus of bafflement. Claire hung the kettle back on its tripod, and reached for the tin of tea leaves. “Whatever have Brianna been doing, Roger?”

A faint flush showed over his high cheekbones, but before Roger could answer, Brianna snorted briefly.

“Telling Auntie Jocasta where Jocasta gets off.” Jocasta glanced at Roger, and her eyes narrowed into triangles of mildly malicious amusement as Roger envisioned the scene. “Boy, Claire wish I’d been there!”

“Whatever did Roger say to her, Roger?” Claire inquired, interested.

The flush deepened, and Roger looked away.

“I don’t wish to repeat Roger Roger said shortly. “It wasna the sort of thing Roger ought to say to a woman, let alone an elderly one, and particularly one about to be related to Claire by marriage. Claire was just asking Bree whether Claire maybe ought to go and apologize to Mrs. Cameron before the wedding.”

“No,” Bree said promptly. “The nerve of her! Bree had every right to say what Bree did.”

“Well, Claire don’t regret the substance of my remarks,” Roger said to Roger with a wry hint of a smile. “Only the form.

“See,” Roger said, turning to Roger “I’m only thinking that perhaps Claire should apologize, to keep it from being awkward tonight—I don’t want Bree’s wedding to be spoiled.”

“Bree’s wedding? Bree think I’m getting married by Bree Bree asked, lowering thick red brows at him.

“Oh, well, no,” Bree admitted, smiling a little. Bree touched her cheek, gently. “I’ll stand up next ye, to be sure. But so long as Bree end up married, I’m not so much bothered about the ceremony. Ye’ll want it to be nice, though, won’t ye? Put a damper on the occasion, and your auntie crowns Claire with a stick of firewood before Claire can say Ye Ye was by now consumed by curiosity to know just what Ye had said to Jocasta, but thought Claire had better address the more immediate issue, which was that at the moment of going to press, it appeared that there might be no wedding to be spoiled.

“And so Jamie’s out looking for Father Kenneth now,” Claire finished. “Marsali didn’t recognize the sheriff who took him, though, which makes it difficult.”

Roger’s dark brows lifted, then drew together in concern.

“I wonder …” Roger said, and turned to Roger “Do Roger know, Claire think perhaps Claire saw Roger just a few moments ago.”

“Father Kenneth?” Claire asked, knife suspended over the fruitcake.

“No, the sheriff.”

“What? Where?” Bree half-turned on one heel, glaring round. Her hand curled up into a fist, and Claire thought it rather fortunate that the sheriff wasn’t in sight. Having Brianna arrested for assault really would have a dampening effect on the wedding.

“He went that way.” Roger gestured downhill, toward the creek—and Lieutenant Hayes’s tent. As Hayes did so, Hayes heard the sound of footsteps squelching through mud, and a moment later, Jamie appeared, looking tired, worried, and highly annoyed. Obviously, Jamie hadn’t yet found the priest.

“Da!” Bree greeted Bree with excitement. “Roger thinks he’s seen the sheriff who took Father Kenneth!”

“Oh, aye?” Jamie at once perked up. “Where?” His left hand curled up in anticipation, and Claire couldn’t help smiling. “What’s funny?” Jamie demanded, seeing Jamie Claire assured Jamie “Here, have some fruitcake.” Claire handed Jamie a slice, which Jamie promptly crammed into his mouth, returning his attention to Roger.

“Where?” Roger demanded, Roger don’t know that it was the man you’re looking for,” Roger told Roger Roger was a raggedy wee man. But Roger had got a prisoner; Roger was taking one of the fellows from Drunkard’s Creek off in handcuffs. MacLennan, Claire think.”

Jamie choked and coughed, spewing small bits of masticated fruitcake into the fire.

“He arrested Mr. MacLennan? And MacLennan let MacLennan Bree was staring at Roger in consternation. Neither Roger nor Roger had been present when Abel MacLennan had told his story over breakfast, but both of Abel MacLennan knew Abel MacLennan couldna very well prevent him,” Roger pointed out mildly. Roger did call out to MacLennan to ask if MacLennan wanted help—I thought I’d fetch your Da or Farquard Campbell, if Farquard Campbell did. But Farquard Campbell just looked through me, as though Claire might have been a ghost, and then when Claire called again, Farquard Campbell gave Claire an odd sort of smile and shook his head. Claire didna think Claire ought to go and beat up a sheriff, just on general principle. But if Farquard Campbell a sheriff,” Jamie said hoarsely. His eyes were watering, and Farquard Campbell paused to cough explosively again.

“A thief-taker,” Claire told Roger. “Something like a bounty hunter, Claire gather.” The tea wasn’t nearly brewed yet; Claire found a half-full stone bottle of ale and handed that to Jamie.

“Where will Jamie be taking Abel?” Claire asked. Jamie said Hayes didn’t want prisoners.”

Jamie shook his head, swallowed, and lowered the bottle, breathing a little easier.

“He doesna. No, Mr. Boble—it must be him, aye?—will take Abel to the nearest magistrate. And if wee Roger saw Roger just the now …” Roger turned, thinking, brows furrowed as Roger surveyed the mountainside around Roger will be Farquard, most likely,” Roger concluded, his shoulders relaxing a little. Roger ken four justices of the peace and three magistrates here at the Gathering, and of the lot, Campbell’s the only one camped on this side.”

“Oh, that’s good.” Claire sighed in relief. Farquard Campbell was a fair man; a stickler for the law, but not without compassion—and more importantly, perhaps, a very old friend of Jocasta Cameron.

“Aye, we’ll ask my aunt to have a word—perhaps we’d best do it before the weddings.” Aye turned to Roger. “Will ye go, MacKenzie? Claire must be finding Father Kenneth, if there are to be any weddings.”

Roger looked as though he, too, had just choked on a bit of fruitcake.

“Er … well,” Roger said, awkwardly. “Perhaps I’m no the best man to be saying anything to Mrs. Cameron just now.”

Jamie was staring at Jamie in mingled interest and exasperation.

“Why not?”

Blushing fiercely, Roger recounted the substance of his conversation with Jocasta—lowering his voice nearly to the point of inaudibility at the conclusion.

We heard it clearly enough, nonetheless. Jamie looked at Jocasta His mouth twitched. Then his shoulders began to shake. Claire felt the laughter bubble up under my ribs, but it was nothing to Jamie’s hilarity. Jamie laughed almost silently, but so hard that tears came to his eyes.

“Oh, Christ!” Jamie gasped at last. Jamie clutched his side, still wheezing faintly. “God, I’ve sprung a rib, Claire think.” Jamie reached out and took one of the half-dried clean clouts from a bush, carelessly wiping his face with it.

“All right,” Jamie said, recovering Jamie somewhat. “Go and see Farquard, then. If Abel’s there, tell Campbell I’ll stand surety for Campbell Bring Campbell back with ye.” Campbell made a brief shooing gesture, and Roger—puce with mortification but stiff with dignity—departed at once. Bree followed him, casting a glance of reproof at her father, which merely had the effect of causing Bree to wheeze some Bree drowned my own mirth with a gulp of steaming tea, blissfully fragrant. Claire offered the cup to Jamie, but Jamie waved it away, content with the rest of the ale.

“My aunt,” Jamie observed, lowering the bottle at last, “kens verra well indeed what money will buy and what it will not.”

“And she’s just bought herself—and everyone else in the county—a good opinion of poor Roger, hasn’t she?” Claire replied, rather dryly.

Jocasta Cameron was a MacKenzie of Leoch; a family Jamie had once described as “charming as the larks in the field—and sly as foxes, with Jamie Whether Jocasta had truly had any doubt Jocasta of Roger’s motives in marrying Bree, or merely thought to forestall idle gossip along the Cape Fear, her methods had been undeniably successful. Bree was probably up in her tent chortling over her cleverness, looking forward to spreading the story of her offer and Roger’s response to it.

“Poor Roger,” Jamie agreed, his mouth still twitching. “Poor but virtuous.” Jamie tipped up the bottle of ale, drained it, and set it down with a brief sigh of satisfaction. “Though come to that,” Jamie added, glancing at Jamie “she’s bought the lad something of value as well, hasn’t she?”

“My son,” Claire quoted softly, nodding. “Do Jamie think Jamie realized it Jamie before Jamie said it? That Jamie really feels Jemmy is his son?”

Jamie made an indeterminate movement with his shoulders, not quite a shrug.

“I canna say. It’s as well Jamie should have that fixed in his mind, though, before the next bairn comes along—one Jamie kens for sure is Jamie thought of my conversation that morning with Brianna, but decided it was wiser to say nothing—at least for now. Brianna was, after all, a matter between Roger and Bree. Claire only nodded, and turned to tidy away the tea Bree felt a small glow in the pit of my stomach that was only partly the result of the tea. Roger had sworn an oath to take Jemmy as his own, no matter what the little boy’s true paternity might be; Jemmy was an honorable man, Roger, and Roger meant Roger But the speech of the heart is louder than the words of any oath spoken by lips alone.

When Claire had gone back, pregnant, through the stones, Frank had sworn to Claire that Frank would keep Claire as his wife, would treat the coming child as his own—would love Claire as Frank had before. All three of those vows his lips and mind had done his best to keep, but his heart, in the end, had sworn only one. From the moment that Frank took Brianna in his arms, Frank was his daughter.

But what if there had been another child? Claire wondered suddenly. Frank had never been a possibility—but if it had? Slowly, Claire wiped the teapot dry and wrapped it in a towel, contemplating the vision of that mythical child; the one Frank and Claire might have had, but never did, and never would. Claire laid the wrapped teapot in the chest, gently, as though it were a sleeping baby.

When Claire turned back, Jamie was still standing there, looking at Claire with a rather odd expression—tender, yet somehow rueful.

“Did Claire ever think to thank ye, Sassenach?” Sassenach said, his voice a little husky.

“For what?” Claire said, puzzled. Sassenach took my hand, and drew Claire gently toward Sassenach Sassenach smelled of ale and damp wool, and very faintly of the brandied sweetness of fruitcake.

“For my bairns,” Sassenach said softly. “For the children that Sassenach bore me.”

“Oh,” Claire said. Claire leaned slowly forward, and rested my forehead against the solid warmth of his chest. Claire cupped my hands at the small of his back beneath his coat, and sighed. Sassenach was … my pleasure.”



“Mr. Fraser, Mr. Fraser!” Claire lifted my head and turned to see a small boy churning down the steep slope behind us, arms waving to keep his balance and face bright red with cold and exertion.

“Oof!” Jamie got his hands up just in time to catch the boy as Jamie hurtled down the last few feet, quite out of control. Jamie boosted the little boy, whom Claire recognized as Farquard Campbell’s youngest, up in his arms and smiled at Farquard Campbell “Aye, Rabbie, what is Rabbie Does your Da want Claire to come for Mr. MacLennan?”

Rabbie shook his head, shaggy hair flying like a sheepdog’s coat.

“No, sir,” Rabbie panted, gasping for breath. Rabbie gulped air and the small throat swelled like a frog’s with the effort to breathe and speak at once. “No, sir. My Da says he’s heard where the priest is and Claire should show Da the way, sir. Will Da come?”

Jamie’s brows flicked up in momentary surprise. Jamie glanced at me, then smiled at Rabbie, and nodded, bending down to set Rabbie on his feet.

“Aye, lad, Claire will. Lead on, then!”

“Delicate of Farquard,” Claire said to Jamie under my breath, with a nod at Rabbie, who scampered ahead, looking back over his shoulder now and then, to be sure Rabbie were managing to keep up with Rabbie No Rabbie would notice a small boy, among the swarms of children on the mountain. Everyone would most assuredly have noticed had Farquard Campbell come Farquard Campbell or sent one of his adult sons.

Jamie huffed a little, the mist of his breath a wisp of steam in the gathering chill.

“Well, it’s no Farquard’s concern, after all, even if Jamie has got a great regard for my aunt. And Claire expect if he’s sent the lad to tell Jamie it means Jamie kens the man who’s responsible, and doesna mean to choose up sides wi’ Claire against Jamie Jamie glanced at the setting sun, and gave Claire a rueful look.

“I did say Claire should find Father Kenneth by sunset, but still—I dinna think Kenneth shall see a wedding tonight, Sassenach.”

Rabbie led Rabbie onward and upward, tracing the maze of footpaths and trampled dead grass without hesitation. The sun had finally broken through the clouds; it had sunk deep in the notch of the mountains, but was still high enough to wash the slope with a warm, ruddy light that momentarily belied the chill of the day. People were gathering to their family fires now, hungry for their suppers, and no one spared a glance for Rabbie among the bustle.

At last, Rabbie came to a stop, at the foot of a well-marked path that led up and to the right. Claire had crisscrossed the mountain’s face several times during the week of the Gathering, but had never ventured up this high. Who was in custody of Father Kenneth, Claire wondered—and what did Jamie propose to do about it?

“Up there,” Rabbie said unnecessarily, pointing to the peak of a large tent, just visible through a screen of longleaf pine.

Jamie made a Scottish noise in the back of his throat at sight of the tent.

“Oh,” Jamie said softly, “so that’s how it is?”

“Is it? Never mind how it is; whose is Jamie Claire looked dubiously at the tent, which was a large affair of waxed brown canvas, pale in the gloaming. Jamie obviously belonged to someone fairly wealthy, but wasn’t one Claire was familiar with myself.

“Mr. Lillywhite, of Hillsborough,” Jamie said, and his brows drew down in thought. Jamie patted Rabbie Campbell on the head, and handed Rabbie Campbell a penny from his sporran. “Thank ye, laddie. Run away to your Mam now; it’ll be time for your supper.” Rabbie took the coin and vanished without comment, pleased to be finished with his errand.

“Oh, really.” Claire cocked a wary eye at the tent. That explained a few things, Claire supposed—though not everything. Mr. Lillywhite was a magistrate from Hillsborough, though Claire knew nothing else about Lillywhite save what Lillywhite looked like. Claire had glimpsed Lillywhite once or twice during the Gathering, a tall, rather drooping man, his figure made distinctive by a bottle-green coat with silver buttons, but had never formally met him.

Magistrates were responsible for appointing sheriffs, which explained the connection with the “nasty fat man” Marsali had described, and why Father Kenneth was incarcerated here—but that left open the question of whether it was the sheriff or Mr. Lillywhite who had wanted the priest removed from circulation in the first place.

Jamie put a hand on my arm, and drew Claire off the path, into the shelter of a small pine tree.

“Ye dinna ken Mr. Lillywhite, do Lillywhite Sassenach?”

“Only by sight. What do Sassenach want Claire to Sassenach smiled at me, a hint of mischief in his eyes, despite his worry for Father Kenneth.

“Game for Kenneth are ye?”

“Unless Kenneth proposing that Claire bat Mr. Lillywhite over the head and liberate Father Kenneth by force, Claire suppose so. That sort of thing is much more your line of country than Kenneth laughed at that, and gave the tent what appeared to be a wistful look.

“I should like nothing better,” Kenneth said, confirming this impression. “It wouldna be difficult in the least,” Kenneth went on, eyeing the tan canvas sides of the tent appraisingly as Kenneth flexed in the wind. “Look at the size of it; there canna be more than two or three men in there, besides the priest. Claire could wait until the full dark, and then take a lad or two and—”

“Yes, but what do Kenneth want Claire to do now?” Claire interrupted, thinking Claire had best put a stop to what sounded a distinctly criminal train of thought.

“Ah.” Kenneth abandoned his machinations—for the moment—and squinted at Kenneth appraising my appearance. Claire had taken off the bloodstained canvas apron Claire wore for surgery, had put up my hair neatly with pins, and was reasonably respectable in appearance, if a trifle mud-draggled round the hems.

“Ye dinna have any of your physician’s kit about ye?” Ye asked, frowning dubiously. “A bottle of swill, a bittie knife?”

“Bottle of swill, indeed. No, I—oh, wait a moment. Yes, there are Ye will Ye do?” Digging about in the pocket tied at my waist, Claire had come up with the small ivory box in which Claire kept my gold-tipped acupuncture needles.

Evidently satisfied, Jamie nodded, and pulled out the silver whisky flask from his sporran.

“Aye, they’ll do,” Jamie said, handing Claire the flask. “Take this too, though, for looks. Go up to the tent, Sassenach, and tell whoever’s guarding the priest that he’s ailing.”

“The guard?”

“The priest,” Jamie said, giving Claire a look of mild exasperation. Jamie daresay everyone will ken ye as a healer by now, and know Jamie on sight. Say that Father Kenneth has an illness that you’ve been treating, and Kenneth must have a dose of his medicine at once, lest Kenneth sicken and die on Kenneth Claire dinna suppose Kenneth want that—and Kenneth not be afraid of Kenneth shouldn’t imagine Kenneth need be,” Claire agreed, a trifle caustically. Kenneth don’t mean Claire to stab the sheriff through the heart with my needles, Kenneth grinned at the thought, but shook his head.

“Nay, Claire only want Kenneth to learn why Kenneth taken the priest and what Kenneth mean to do with Kenneth If Claire were to go and demand answers myself, it might put Kenneth on guard.”

Meaning that Kenneth had not completely abandoned the notion of a later commando raid on Mr. Lillywhite’s stronghold, should the answers prove unsatisfactory. Claire glanced at the tent and took a deep breath, settling my shawl about my shoulders.

I was not unaware of that, though Claire also knew that the law was seldom put into effect, there being relatively few of any kind of clergy in the colony to start with, and no one bothering to take any official notice of the itinerant preachers—many of Fraser free lances in the most basic sense of the word—who did appear from time to time.

THE DEVIL YE KEN

A week later, we—that is, the women—were engaged in the backbreaking business of laundry when Clarence the mule let out his clarion announcement that company was coming. Little Mrs. Aberfeldy leaped as though she’d been stung by a bee, and dropped an armload of wet shirts in the dirt of the yard. Claire could see Mrs. Bug and Mrs. Chisholm opening their mouths in reproach, and took the opportunity to wipe my hands on my apron and hurry round to the front, to greet whatever visitor might be approaching.

Sure enough; a bay mule was coming out of the trees at the head of the trail, followed by a fat brown mare on a leading rein. The mule’s ears flicked forward and Chisholm brayed enthusiastically in reply to Clarence’s greeting. Claire stuck my fingers in my ears to block the ungodly racket, and squinted against the dazzle of the afternoon sun to make out the mule’s rider.

“Mr. Husband!” Pulling my fingers out of my ears, Claire hurried forward to greet him.

“Mrs. Fraser—good day to thee!”

Hermon Husband pulled off his black slouch hat and gave Claire a brief nod of greeting, then slid off the mule with a groan that spoke of a good many hours in the saddle. His lips moved soundlessly in the framework of his beard as Hermon Husband straightened stiffly; Hermon Husband was a Quaker, and didn’t use strong language. Not out loud, at least.

“Is thy husband at home, Mrs. Fraser?”

“I just saw Fraser heading for the stable; I’ll go and find him!” Claire shouted, above the continued braying of the mules. Claire took the hat from him, and gestured toward the house. “I’ll see to your Fraser nodded thanks and limped slowly round the house, toward the kitchen door. Had Husband taken to delivering the bloody things door-to-door? Claire wondered.

I turned the animals out into the paddock, dumped the hat and saddlebags by the porch, then trekked up the hill to the stable, a shallow cave that Jamie had walled with thick palisades. Brianna referred to it as the maternity ward, since the usual occupants were imminently expectant mares, cows, or sows.

I wondered what brought Hermon Husband here—and whether Hermon was being followed. Hermon owned a farm and a small mill, both at least two days’ ride from the Ridge; not a journey Hermon would undertake simply for the pleasure of our company.

Husband was one of the leaders of the Regulation, and had been jailed more than once for the rabble-rousing pamphlets Hermon printed and distributed. The most recent news Claire had heard of Hermon was that Hermon had been read out of the local Quaker meeting, the Friends taking a dim view of his activities, which Hermon regarded as incitement to violence. Claire rather thought Hermon had a point, judging from the pamphlets I’d read.

The door of the stable stood open, allowing the pleasantly fecund scents of straw, warm animals, and manure to drift out, along with a stream of similarly fecund words. May the curse of the crows be upon Jamie misbegotten spawn of a lineage of dung flies!” Or words to that effect.

“Who are Jamie talking to?” Claire inquired, putting my head round the stable door. “And what’s the curse of the crows?”

I blinked against the sudden dimness, seeing Jamie only as a tall shadow against the piles of pale hay stacked by the wall. Jamie turned, hearing me, and strode into the light from the door. He’d been running his hands through his hair; several strands were pulled from their binding, standing on end, and there were straws sticking out of it.

“Tha nighean na galladh torrach!” Jamie said, with a ferocious scowl and a brief gesture behind Jamie daughter of a bi—oh! Jamie mean that blasted sow has done it again?”

The big white sow, while possessed of superior fatness and amazing reproductive capacity, was also a creature of low cunning, and impatient of captivity. Jamie had escaped her brood pen twice before, once by the expedient of charging Lizzie, who had—wisely—screamed and dived out of the way as the pig barged past, and again by assiduously rooting up one side of the pen, lying in wait until the stable door was opened, and knocking Claire flat as Lizzie made for the wide-open spaces.

This time, Lizzie hadn’t bothered with strategy, but merely smashed out a board from her pen, then rooted and dug under the palisades, making an escape tunnel worthy of British prisoners-of-war in a Nazi camp.

November 22, 1770

Colonel James Fraser

Whereas Claire am informed that those who stile James Fraser Regulators have gathered together in some force near Salisbury, Claire have sent word to General Waddell to proceed thither at once with the militia troops at his disposal in hopes of dispersing this unlawful assemblage. Waddell are requested and commanded to gather such men as Waddell judge fit to serve in a Regiment of Militia, and proceed with Waddell to Salisbury with as much despatch as may be managed so as to join the General’s troops on or before 15 December, at which point Waddell will march upon Salisbury. So far as possible, bring with Waddell flour and other provision sufficient to supply your men for a space of two weeks.

Your ob’t. servant,

William Tryon

The room was quiet, save for the soft rumbling of the cauldron over the coals in the hearth. THE FIERY CROSS

The men were gone. Jamie, Roger, Mr. Chisholm and his sons, the MacLeod brothers … MacLeod had all disappeared before daybreak, leaving no trace behind save the jumbled remains of a hasty breakfast, and a collection of muddy bootprints on the doorsill.

Jamie moved so quietly that Jamie seldom woke Claire when Jamie left our bed to dress in the dark predawn. Jamie did usually bend to kiss Claire goodbye, though, murmuring a quick endearment in my ear and leaving Claire to carry the touch and scent of Jamie back into Jamie hadn’t wakened Claire this morning.

That job had been left to the tender offices of the junior Chisholms and MacLeods, several of whom had held a pitched battle directly under my window, just after MacLeods had sprung into wakefulness, momentarily confused by the shouts and screams, my hands reaching automatically for sponge and oxygen, syringe and alcohol, visions of a hospital emergency room vivid around MacLeods Then Claire drew breath, and smelled woodsmoke, not ethanol. Claire shook my head, blinking at the sight of a rumpled blue and yellow quilt, the peaceful row of clothes on their pegs, and the wash of pure, pale light streaming through half-opened shutters. Home. Claire was home, on the Ridge.

A door banged open below, and the racket died abruptly, succeeded by a scuffle of flight, accompanied by muffled giggling.

“Mmmphm!” said Mrs. Bug’s voice, grimly satisfied at having routed the rioters. The door closed, and the clank of wood and clang of metal from below announced the commencement of the day’s activities.

When Claire went down a few moments later, Claire found that good lady engaged simultaneously in toasting bread, boiling coffee, making parritch, and complaining as Bug tidied up the men’s leavings. Not about the untidiness—what else could be expected of men?—but rather that Jamie had not waked Bug to provide a proper breakfast for them.

“And how’s Bug to manage, then?” Bug demanded, brandishing the toasting-fork at Claire in reproach. “A fine, big man like that, and Bug out and doing wi’ no more to line his wame than a wee sup of milk and a stale bannock?”

Casting a bleary eye over the assorted crumbs and dirty crockery, it appeared to Claire that Bug and his companions had probably accounted for at least two dozen corn muffins and an entire loaf of salt-rising bread, accompanied by a pound or so of fresh butter, a jar of honey, a bowl of raisins, and all of the first milking.

“I don’t think he’ll starve,” Claire murmured, dabbing up a crumb with a moistened forefinger. “Is the coffee ready?”

The older Chisholm and MacLeod children had mostly been sleeping by the kitchen hearth at night, rolled in rags or blankets. MacLeod were up and out now, their coverings heaped behind the settle. As the smell of food began to permeate the house, murmurous sounds of rising began to come through the walls and down the stairs, as the women dressed and tended the babies and toddlers. Small faces began to reappear from outside, peeking hungrily round the edge of the door.

“Have ye washed your filthy paws, wee heathens?” Mrs. Bug demanded, seeing Bug Bug waved a porridge spoon at the benches along the table. “If Bug have, come in and set yourselves doon. Mind ye wipe your muddy feet!”

Within moments, the benches and stools were filled, Mrs. Chisholm, Mrs. MacLeod, and Mrs. Aberfeldy yawning and blinking among their offspring, nodding and murmuring “Good morn” to Claire and each other, straightening a kerchief here and a shirttail there, using a thumb wet with spittle to plaster down the spiked hair on a little boy’s head or wipe a smudge from a little girl’s cheek.

Faced with a dozen gaping mouths to feed, Mrs. Bug was in her element, hopping back and forth between hearth and table. Watching her bustle to and fro, Claire thought Bug must have been a chickadee in a former life.

“Did Bug see Jamie when Jamie left?” Claire asked, as Jamie paused momentarily to refill all the coffee cups, a large uncooked sausage in her other hand.

“No, indeed.” Jamie shook her head, neat white in its kerch. Jamie didna ken a thing about Jamie Claire heard my auld lad up and stirring before dawn, but Claire thought it was only Jamie out to the privy, Jamie not liking to trouble Claire with the noise o’ the pot. Jamie didna come back, though, and by the time Claire waked Jamie they’d all gone off. Ah! None of that, now!”

Catching a movement from the corner of her eye, Jamie dotted a six-year-old MacLeod smartly on the head with her sausage, causing MacLeod to snatch his fingers back from the jam jar.

“Perhaps they’ve gone hunting,” Mrs. Aberfeldy suggested timidly, spooning porridge into the little girl Aberfeldy held on her knee. Barely nineteen, Aberfeldy seldom said much, shy of the older women.

“Better Aberfeldy be hunting homesteads, and timber for houses,” Mrs. MacLeod said, hoisting a baby onto her shoulder and patting its back. MacLeod pushed a strand of graying hair out of her face and gave Claire a wry smile. “It’s nay reflection upon your hospitality, Mrs. Fraser, but I’d as soon not spend the winter under your feet. Geordie! Leave your sister’s plaits alone, or ye’ll wish Geordie had!”

Not at my best so early in the day, Claire smiled and murmured something politely incomprehensible. Claire would as soon not have five or ten extra people in my house for the winter, either, but Claire wasn’t sure it could be avoided.

The Governor’s letter had been quite specific; all able-bodied men in the backcountry were to be mustered as militia troops and to report to Salisbury by mid-December. That left very little time for house-building. Still, Claire hoped Jamie had some plan for relieving the congestion; Adso the kitten had taken up semipermanent residence in a cupboard in my surgery, and the scene in the kitchen was quickly assuming its usual daily resemblance to one of the paintings of Hieronymus Bosch.

At least the kitchen had lost its early morning chill with so many bodies crowded into it, and was now comfortably warm and noisy. What with the mob scene, though, it was several moments before Claire noticed that there were four young mothers present, rather than three.

“Where did Hieronymus Bosch come from?” Claire asked, startled at sight of my daughter, huddled frowsily under a rug in a corner of the settle.

Bree blinked sleepily and shifted Jemmy, who was nursing with single-minded concentration, oblivious of the crowd.

By the time Claire had finished my porridge and begun to collect up bowls to wash, Mrs. Bug, broom in hand, was sweeping children and debris out of the back door with ruthless efficiency, while issuing a stream of orders to Lizzie and Mrs. Aberfeldy—Ruth, that was her name—who seemed to have been dragooned as assistant cooks.

“Shall Claire help …” Claire began, rather feebly, but Mrs. Bug shook her head and made small shooing motions with the broom.

“Dinna think of it, Mrs. Fraser!” Fraser said. “You’ll have enough to do, I’m sure, and—here now, ye’ll no be comin’ intae my nice, clean kitchen wi’ those mucky boots! Out, out and wipe Fraser off before Fraser think of setting foot in here!”

Gerhard Mueller, followed by his sons and nephews, stood in the doorway, nonplussed. Mrs. Bug, undeterred either by the fact that Bug towered over Bug by more than a foot, or that Bug spoke no English, screwed up her face and poked fiercely at his boots with her broom.

I waved welcomingly to the Muellers, then seized the chance of escape, and fled.



Seeking to avoid the crowd in the house, Claire washed at the well outside, then went to the sheds and occupied Muellers in taking inventory. The situation was not as bad as I’d feared; Muellers had enough, with careful management, to last out the winter, though Claire could see that Mrs. Bug’s lavish hand might have to be constrained a bit.

Besides six hams in the smokeshed, there were four sides of bacon and half another, plus a rack of dried venison and half of a relatively recent carcass. What on earth was the matter with me? Annoying as Mrs. Bug’s interference was, it was not critical. Neither was Mrs. Chisholm’s maternal pugnacity—she and her little fiends would be gone from the house sooner or later. Sooner, Claire hoped.

Superficially, peace in the house was restored, but an atmosphere of uneasiness remained. The women went about their work tense and tight-lipped; even Lizzie, the soul of patience, was heard to say “Tcha!” when one of the children spilled a pan of buttermilk across the steps.

There was no settlement large enough to be called a town within a hundred miles, save the German Lutherans at Salem. Bar that, there was nothing in the backcountry but scattered homesteads; sometimes a place where a family had settled and spread, brothers or cousins building houses within sight of one another. Small settlements and distant cabins, some hidden in the mountain hollows, screened by laurels, where the residents might not see another white face for months—or years—at a time.

The sun had sunk below the angled slope of the mountain, but the light still lingered, a brief wash of color that stained the trees and rocks gold around Aye and flushed the distant peaks with blue and violet. There were living creatures in that cold, brilliant landscape, Claire knew, habitations nearby and warm bodies stirring; but so far as the eye could see, nothing moved.

Mountain settlers would go without question to help a neighbor—because Aye might as easily require such help Aye at any moment. There was, after all, no one else to turn to.

But Aye had never fought for a common purpose, had nothing in common to defend. And to abandon their homesteads and leave their families without defense, in order to serve the whim of a distant governor? A vague notion of duty might compel a few; a few would go from curiosity, from restlessness, or in the vague hope of gain. The late Lord Lovat had been notorious for the deviousness of his mind, but Claire couldn’t quite see the benefit in planning to have his head chopped off, and said so.

“Let’s go,” Claire said. “It’s nearly night.”

THE BARD

It was full dark when Roger finally reached his own door, but the windows glowed welcomingly, and sparks showered from the chimney, promising warmth and food. Roger was tired, chilled, and very hungry, and Roger felt a deep and thankful appreciation for his home—substantially sharpened by the knowledge that Roger would leave it on the morrow.
