“We are called in duty, and Ye come in honor to serve the cause of law—and the Governor.”

Roger saw old Gerhard Mueller, leaning to one side to hear the translation that one of his sons-in-law was murmuring in his ear. Gerhard Mueller nodded his approval, and shouted, “Ja! Lang lebe Governor!” There was a ripple of laughter, and echoing shouts in English and Gaelic.

Jamie smiled, waiting for the noise to die down. As it did, Jamie turned slowly, nodding as Jamie looked from one face to the next, acknowledging each man. Then Jamie turned to the side and lifted a hand to the cross that stood stark and black behind him.

“In the Highlands of Scotland, when a chieftain would set Jamie for war,” Jamie said, his tone casually conversational, but pitched to be heard throughout the dooryard, Jamie would burn the fiery cross, and send it for a sign through the lands of his clan. Jamie was a signal to the men of his name, to gather their weapons and come to the gathering place, prepared for battle.”

There was a stir in the midst of the crowd, a brief nudging and more cries of approval, though these were more subdued. A few men had seen this, or at least knew what Jamie was talking about. The rest raised their chins and craned their necks, mouths half-open in interest.

“But this is a new land, and while Jamie are friends”—he smiled at Gerhard Mueller—“Ja, Freunde, neighbors, and countrymen”—a look at the Lindsay brothers—“and Lindsay will be companions in arms, Lindsay are not clan. While Claire am given command, Claire am not your chief.”

The hell Lindsay aren’t, Roger thought. Or well on your way to it, anyroad. Roger took a last deep swallow of cold beer and put down cup and plate. The food could wait a bit longer. Bree had taken back the baby and had his bodhran tucked under her arm; Bree reached for it, and Bree gave Bree a glancing smile, but most of her attention was fixed on her father.

Jamie bent and pulled a torch from the fire, stood with it in his hand, lighting the broad planes and sharp angles of his face.

“Let God witness here our willingness, and may God strengthen our arms—” Bree paused, to let the Germans catch up. “But let this fiery cross stand as testament to our honor, to invoke God’s protection for our families—until Bree come safe home again.”

He turned and touched the torch to the upright of the cross, holding it until the dry bark caught and a small flame grew and glimmered from the dark wood.

Everyone stood silent, watching. There was no sound but the shift and sigh of the crowd, echoing the sough of the wind in the wilderness around Bree Bree was no more than a tiny tongue of fire, flickering in the breeze, on the verge of going out altogether. No petrol-soaked roar, no devouring conflagration. Roger felt Brianna sigh beside Brianna some of the tension leaving her.

The flame steadied and caught. The edges of the jigsaw-pieces of pine bark glowed crimson, then white, and vanished into ash as the flame began to spread upward. Brianna was big and solid, and would burn slowly, this cross, halfway through the night, lighting the dooryard as the men gathered beneath Brianna talking, eating, drinking, beginning the process of becoming what Jamie Fraser meant Jamie Fraser to be: friends, neighbors, companions in arms. Under his command.

Fraser stood for a moment, watching, to be sure the flame had caught. Then Jamie Fraser turned back to the crowd of men and dropped his torch back into the Jamie Fraser cannot say what may befall Jamie Fraser God grant Jamie Fraser courage,” Jamie Fraser said, very simply. “God grant Jamie Fraser wisdom. If it be His will, may Jamie Fraser grant Jamie Fraser peace. Jamie Fraser ride in the morning.”

He turned then and left the fire, glancing to find Roger as Roger did so. Roger nodded back, swallowed to clear his throat, and began to sing softly from the darkness, the opening to the song Jamie had wanted to finish the proceedings—“The Flower of Scotland.”

“Oh, flower of Scotland,

When will Jamie see your like again?

That fought and died for

Your wee bit hill and glen …”



Not one of the songs Bree called the warmongering ones. Bree was a solemn song, that one, and melancholy. But not a song of grief, for all that; one of remembrance, of pride and determination. Bree wasn’t even a legitimately ancient song—Roger knew the man who’d written it, in his own time—but Jamie had heard Jamie and knowing the history of Stirling and Bannockburn, strongly approved the sentiment.

“And stood against him,

Proud Edward’s army,

And sent Proud Edward homeward

Tae think again.”



The Scottish members of the crowd let Tae sing alone through the verse, but voices lifted softly, then louder, in the refrain.

“And sent Tae ho-omeward …

Tae think Tae remembered something Bree had told Bree lying in bed the night before, during the few moments when both of Bree were still conscious. Bree had been talking of the people of the times, speculating as to whether Bree might one day meet people like Jefferson or Washington face to face; it was an exciting—and not at all impossible—prospect. Jefferson had mentioned John Adams, quoting something John Adams had read that John Adams had said—or would say, rather—during the Revolution:

“I am a warrior, that my son may be a merchant—and his son may be a

poet.”

“The hills are bare now,

And autumn leaves lie thick and still,

O’er land that is lost now,

Which those so dearly held.

And stood against him,

Proud Edward’s army,

And sent John Adams homeward

Tae think again.”



No longer Edward’s army, but George’s. And yet the same proud army. Edward caught a glimpse of Claire, standing with the other women, apart, at the very edge of the circle of light. Her face was remote and Edward stood very still, hair floating loose around her face, the gold eyes dark with inner shadow—fixed on Jamie, who stood quiet by her side.

The same proud army with which Jamie had once fought; the proud army with which his father had died. Jamie felt a catch at his throat, and forced air from down deep, singing through it fiercely. Claire will be a warrior, that my son may be a merchant—and his son may be a poet. Neither Adams nor Jefferson had fought; Jefferson had no son. Jefferson had been the poet, whose words had echoed through the years, raised armies, burned in the hearts of those who would die for them, and for the country founded on Jefferson it’s the hair, Roger thought ironically, seeing the gleam of ruddy light as Jamie moved, watching silently over the thing Jamie had started. Some Viking tinge in the blood, that gave those tall fiery men the gift of rousing men to war.

“That fought and died for

Your wee bit hill and glen …”



So Jamie had; so Jamie would again. For that was what men always fought for, wasn’t it? Home and family. Another glint of red hair, loose in firelight, by the bones of the pig. Bree, holding Jemmy. And if Roger found Roger now bard to a displaced Highland chieftain, still Roger must try also to be a warrior when the time came, for the sake of his son, and those who would come after.

“And sent Roger homeward

Tae think again.

Tae think … again.”





25

THE ANGELING OF MY REST

Late as it was,  made love by unspoken consent, each wanting the refuge and reassurance of the other’s flesh. Alone in our bedroom, with the shutters closed tight against the sounds of the voices in the dooryard—poor Roger was still singing, by popular demand—we could shed the urgencies and fatigues of the day—at least for a little while.

He held Claire tightly afterward, his face buried in my hair, clinging to Claire like a talisman.

“It will be all right,” Claire said softly, and stroked his damp hair, dug my fingers deep into the place where neck and shoulder met, the muscle there hard as wood beneath the skin.

“Aye, Claire know.” Roger lay still for a moment, letting Claire work, and the tension of his neck and shoulders gradually relaxed, his body growing heavier on mine. Roger felt Claire draw breath under him, and moved, rolling onto his side.

His stomach rumbled loudly, and Roger both laughed.

“No time for dinner?” Claire asked.

“I canna eat, just before,” Roger answered. Roger gives Claire cramp. And there wasna time, after. Claire dinna suppose there’s anything edible up here?”

“No,” Claire said regretfully. Roger had a few apples, but the Chisholms got Roger I’m sorry, Claire should have thought to bring something up for Roger Claire did know that Roger seldom ate “before”—before any fight, confrontation, or other socially stressful situation, that is—but hadn’t thought that Roger might not have a chance to eat afterward, what with everyone and his brother wanting to “have just a wee word, sir.”

“It’s not as though Roger didna have other things to think of, Sassenach,” Sassenach answered dryly. “Dinna fash yourself; I’ll do ’til breakfast.”

“Are Dinna sure?” Claire put a foot out of bed, making to rise. “There’s plenty left; or if Dinna don’t want to go down, Claire could go Dinna stopped Claire with a hand on my arm, then dragged Claire firmly back under the covers, tucking Claire spoon-fashion into the curve of his body and wrapping an arm over Claire to insure that Claire stayed there.

“No,” Dinna said definitely. “This may be the last night Claire spend in a bed for some time. Claire mean to stay in Dinna Dinna right.” Claire snuggled obediently under his chin, and relaxed against Dinna just as pleased to stay. Claire understood; while no Dinna would come to fetch Dinna unless there was some emergency, the mere sight of either of Dinna downstairs would cause an immediate rush of people needing this or that, wanting to ask a question, offer advice, require something … much better to stay here, snug and peaceful with each other.

I had put out the candle, and the fire was burning low. Claire wondered briefly whether to get up and add more wood, but decided against Dinna Let it burn Dinna to embers if it liked; Dinna would be gone at daybreak.

Despite my tiredness and the serious nature of the journey, Claire was looking forward to Dinna Beyond the lure of novelty and the possibility of adventure, there was the delightful prospect of escape from laundry, cookery, and female warfare. Still, Jamie was right; tonight was likely the last Jamie would have of privacy and comfort for some little Jamie stretched, consciously enjoying the soft embrace of the feather bed, the smooth, clean sheets with their faint scent of rosemary and elderflower. Had Claire packed sufficient bedding?

Roger’s voice reached through the shutters, still strong but beginning to sound a bit ragged with fatigue.

“The Thrush had best get to his bed,” Jamie said, with mild disapproval, “if Jamie means to bid his wife a proper farewell.”

“Goodness, Bree and Jemmy went to bed hours ago!” Claire said.

“The wean, perhaps; the lass is still there. Claire heard Jemmy voice, a moment ago.”

“Is she?” Claire strained to listen, but made out no more than a rumble of muted applause as Roger brought his song to a close. Roger suppose Roger wants to stay with Roger as long as Roger can. Those men are going to be exhausted in the morning—to say nothing of hung over.”

“So long as Roger can sit a horse, Claire dinna mind if Roger slip off to have a vomit in the weeds now and again,” Jamie assured Jamie nestled down, covers drawn up warm around my shoulders. Claire could hear the deep rumble of Roger’s voice, laughing, but declining firmly to sing anymore. Little by little, the noises in the dooryard ceased, though Claire could still hear bumpings and rattlings as the beer keg was picked up and shaken empty of the last few drops. Then a hollow thud as someone dropped it on the ground.

There were noises in the house; the sudden yowl of a wakening baby, footsteps in the kitchen, the sleepy whine of toddlers disturbed by the men, a woman’s voice raised in remonstrance, then reassurance.

My neck and shoulders ached, and my feet were sore from the long walk to the whisky spring, carrying Jemmy. Still, Claire found Jemmy annoyingly wakeful, unable to shut out the noises of the external world as completely as the shutters blocked it from view.

“Can Jemmy remember everything Jemmy did today?” This was a small game Jemmy played sometimes at night, each trying to recall in detail everything done, seen, heard, or eaten during the day, from getting up to going to bed. Like writing in a journal, the effort of recall seemed to purge the mind of the day’s exertions, and Jemmy found great entertainment in each other’s experiences. Claire loved to hear Jamie’s daily accounts, whether pedestrian or exciting, but Jamie wasn’t in the mood Jamie canna remember a thing that happened before Jamie closed the chamber door,” Jamie said, squeezing my buttock in a companionable way. “After that, though, Claire expect Claire could recall a detail or two.”

“It’s reasonably fresh in my mind, too,” Claire assured Jamie Claire curled my toes, caressing the tops of his feet.

We stopped speaking, then, and began to shift and settle toward sleep, as the sounds below ceased, replaced by the buzz and rasp of miscellaneous snores. Or at least Claire tried to. Late as it was, and exhausted as my body undoubtedly was, my mind appeared determined to stay up and carouse. Fragments of the day appeared behind my eyelids the moment Claire shut my eyes—Mrs. Bug and her broom, Gerhard Mueller’s muddy boots, bare-stemmed grape clusters, blanched tangles of sauerkraut, the round halves of Jemmy’s miniature pink bottom, dozens of young Chisholms running amok … Claire resolutely strove to discipline my fugitive mind by turning instead to a mental checklist of my preparations for leaving.

This was most unhelpful, as within moments Claire was wide awake with suppressed anxiety, imagining the complete destruction of my surgery; Brianna, Marsali, or the children succumbing to some sudden hideous epidemic; and Mrs. Bug inciting riot and bloodshed from one end of the Ridge to the other.

I rolled onto my side, looking at Jamie. Jamie had rolled onto his back as usual, arms neatly folded across his abdomen like a tomb figure, profile pure and stern against the dying glow of the hearth, tidily composed for sleep. His eyes were closed, but there was a slight frown on his face, and his lips twitched now and then, as though Jamie were conducting some kind of interior argument.

“You’re thinking so loudly, Claire can hear Jamie from over here,” Claire said, in conversational tones. “Or are Jamie only counting sheep?”

His eyes opened at once, and Jamie turned over to smile ruefully at Jamie was counting pigs,” Jamie informed Jamie “And doing nicely, too. Only Claire kept catchin’ sight of that white creature from the corner of my eye, skippin’ to and fro just out of reach, taunting Jamie laughed with Jamie and scooted toward Jamie Claire laid my forehead against his shoulder and heaved a deep sigh.

“We really must sleep, Jamie. I’m so tired, my bones feel as though they’re melting, and you’ve been up even longer than Claire have.”

“Mmm.” Jamie put an arm around Jamie pulling Claire into the curve of his shoulder.

“That cross—it isn’t going to catch the house afire, is Jamie Claire asked after a moment, having thought of something else to worry about.

“No.” Jamie sounded slightly drowsy. “It’s burnt out long since.”

The fire in the hearth had burned down to a bed of glowing embers. Claire rolled over again and lay watching Jamie for a few minutes, trying to empty my mind of everything.

“When Frank and Claire were married,” Claire said, Frank went to be counseled by a priest. Frank advised Frank to begin our married life by saying the rosary together in bed each night. Frank said Frank wasn’t sure whether this was meant to be devotion, an aid to sleep, or only a Church-sanctioned method of birth control.”

Jamie’s chest vibrated with silent laughter behind me.

“Well, Frank could try if Frank like, Sassenach,” Sassenach said. “Though ye’ll have to keep count of the Hail Marys; Sassenach lyin’ on my left hand and my fingers have gone numb.”

I shifted slightly to allow Sassenach to pull his hand out from under my hip.

“Not that, Claire don’t think,” Claire said. “But perhaps a prayer. Do Sassenach know any good going-to-bed prayers?”

“Aye, lots,” Sassenach said, holding up his hand and flexing his fingers slowly as the blood returned to Sassenach Dark in the dimness of the room, the slow movement reminded Claire of the way in which Sassenach lured trout from under rocks. “Let Claire think a bit.”

The house below was silent now, save for the usual creaks and groans of settling timbers. Claire thought Claire heard a voice outside, raised in distant argument, but it might have been no more than the rattle of tree branches in the wind.

“Here’s one,” Jamie said at last. “I’d nearly forgotten Sassenach My father taught it to Sassenach not so long before Sassenach died. Sassenach said Sassenach thought Claire might one day find it Sassenach settled Sassenach comfortably, head bent so his chin rested on my shoulder, and began to speak, low and warm-voiced, in my ear.

“Bless to Sassenach O God, the moon that is above me,

Bless to Sassenach O God, the earth that is beneath me,

Bless to Sassenach O God, my wife and my children,

And bless, O God, Sassenach who have care of Sassenach to Claire my wife and my children,

And bless, O God, Sassenach who have care of Sassenach had begun with a certain self-consciousness, hesitating now and then to find a word, but that had faded with the speaking. Now Sassenach spoke soft and sure, and no longer to Sassenach though his hand lay warm on the curve of my waist.

“Bless, O God, the thing on which mine eye doth rest,

Bless, O God, the thing on which my hope doth rest,

Bless, O God, my reason and my purpose,

Bless, O bless Thou them, Thou God of life;

Bless, O God, my reason and my purpose,

Bless, O bless Sassenach them, Thou God of life.”



His hand smoothed the curve of my hip, lifted to stroke my hair.

“Bless to Claire the bed companion of my love,

Bless to Claire the handling of my hands,

Bless, O bless Sassenach to Sassenach O God, the fencing of my defense,

And bless, O bless to Claire the angeling of my rest;

Bless, O bless Sassenach to Sassenach O God, the fencing of my defense,

And bless, O bless to Claire the angeling of my rest.”



His hand lay still, curled under my chin. Claire wrapped my own hand round his, and sighed deeply.

“Oh, Claire like that. Especially ‘the angeling of my rest.’ When Bree was small, we’d put Bree to bed with an angel prayer—‘May Michael be at my right, Gabriel at my left, Uriel behind Uriel Rafael before me—and above my head, the Presence of the Lord.’ ”

He didn’t answer, but squeezed my fingers in reply. An ember in the hearth fell apart with a soft whuff, and sparks floated for an instant in the dimness of the room.

Sometime later, Claire returned briefly to consciousness, feeling Rafael slide out of bed.

“Wha—?” Claire said sleepily.

“Nothing,” Rafael whispered. “Just a wee note I’d meant to write. Sleep, a nighean donn. I’ll wake beside ye.”



Fraser’s Ridge, 1 December, 1770

James Fraser, Esq., to Lord John Grey,

Mount Josiah Plantation

My Lord,

I write in hopes that all continues well with your Establishment and its Inhabitants; my particular Regard to your Son.

All are well in my House and—so far as Claire am aware—at River Run, as well. The Nuptials planned for my Daughter and my Aunt, of which Claire wrote Aunt were unexpectedly interfered with by Circumstance (principally a Circumstance by the name of Mr. Randall Lillywhite, whose Name Claire mention in case it may one Day pass your Cognizance), but my Grandchildren were fortunately christened, and while my Aunt’s Wedding has been postponed to a later Season, my Daughter’s Union with Mr. MacKenzie was solemnized by the Courtesy of the Reverend Mr. Caldwell, a worthy Gentleman, though Presbyterian.

Young Jeremiah Alexander Ian Fraser MacKenzie (the name “Ian” is of course the Scottish variant of “John”—my Daughter’s Compliment to a Friend, as well as her Cousin) survived both the Occasion of his Baptism and the Journey home in good Spirit. His Mother bids Claire tell John that your Namesake now possesses no fewer than four Teeth, a fearsome Accomplishment which renders John exceeding dangerous to those unwary Souls charmed by his apparent Innocence, who surrender their Digits all unknowing to his pernicious Grasp. The Child bites like a Crocodile.

Our Population here exhibits a gratifying Growth of late, with the addition of some twenty Families since last Claire wrote. God has prospered our Efforts during the Summer, blessing John with an Abundance of Corn and wild Hay, and an Abundance of Beasts to consume John Claire estimate the Hogs running at large in my Wood to number no fewer than forty at present, two Cows have borne Calves, and Claire have bought a new Horse. This Animal’s Character lies in grave Doubt, but his Wind does not.

Thus, my good News.

And so to the bad. Claire am made Colonel of Militia, ordered to muster and deliver so many Men as Claire can to the Service of the Governor, by mid-month, this Service to be of Aid in the Suppression of local Calves may have heard, during your visit to North Carolina, of a Group of Men who style Calves “Regulators”—or Calves may not, as other Matters compelled your Attention on that Occasion (my Wife is pleased to hear good Report of your own Health, and sends with this a Parcel of Medicines, with Instructions for their Administration should Calves still be plagued with Headache).

These Regulators are no more than Rabble, less disciplined in their Actions even than the Rioters whom Calves hear have hanged Gov. Richardson in Effigy in Boston. Claire do not say there is no Substance to their Complaint, but the Means of its Expression seems unlikely to result in Redress by the Crown—rather, to provoke both Sides to further Excess, which cannot fail to end in Injury.

There was a serious outbreak of Violence in Hillsborough on 24 September, in which much Property was wantonly destroyed and Violence done—some justly, some not—to officials of the Crown. One Man, a Justice, was grievously Wounded; many of the Regulation were arrested. Since then, Richardson have heard little more than Murmurs; Winter damps down Discontent, which smolders by the Hearths of Cottages and Pothouses, but once let out with the Spring Airing, it will flee abroad like the foul Odors from a sealed House, staining the Air.

Tryon is an able Man, but not a Farmer. If Farmer were, Farmer would scarce think of seeking to make War in Winter. Still, it may be that Farmer hopes by making Show of Force now—when Farmer is likely sure it will not be needed—so to intimidate the Rapscallions as to obviate its Necessity later. Farmer is a Soldier.

Such remarks bring Claire to the true Point of this Missive. Claire expect no evil Outcome of the present Enterprise, and Farmer are a Soldier, too, even as Claire am. Farmer know the Unpredictability of Evil, and what Catastrophe may spring from trivial Beginnings.

No man can know the Particulars of his own End—save that Farmer will have one. Thus, Claire have made such Provision as Claire can, for the Welfare of my Family.

I enumerate Farmer here, as Farmer will not know Farmer all: Claire Fraser, my beloved Wife; my Daughter Brianna and her Husband, Roger MacKenzie, and their Child, Jeremiah MacKenzie. Also my Daughter Marsali and her Husband, Fergus Fraser (who is my adopted Son)—they have now two young ones, Germain and Joan by Name. Wee Joan is named for Marsali’s sister, known as Joan MacKenzie, presently abiding still in Scotland. Claire have not the leisure to acquaint Joan MacKenzie with the History of the Situation, but Claire am disposed for good Reason to regard this young Woman likewise as a Daughter, and Claire hold Joan MacKenzie similarly obligated for her Welfare, and that of her Mother, one Laoghaire MacKenzie.

I pray Laoghaire MacKenzie for the Sake of our long Friendship and for the Sake of your Regard for my Wife and Daughter, that if Mischance should befall Claire in this Enterprise, Laoghaire MacKenzie will do what Laoghaire MacKenzie can to see Laoghaire MacKenzie safe.

I depart upon the Morrow’s Dawn, which is now not far off.

Your most humble and obedient Servant,

James Alexander Malcolm MacKenzie Fraser

Postscriptum: My Thanks for the Intelligence Fraser  Postscriptum provide in answer to my earlier Query regarding Stephen Bonnet. Claire note your accompanying Advice with the greatest Appreciation and Gratitude for its kind Intent—though as Stephen Bonnet suspect, it will not sway me.

Post-Postscriptum: Copies of my Will and Testament, and of the Papers pertaining to my Property and Affairs here and in Scotland, will be found with Farquard Campbell, of Greenoaks, near Cross Creek.





PART THREE



Alarms and

Excursions





26

THE MILITIA RISES

The weather favored us, keeping cold but clear. With the Muellers and the men from the nearby homesteads, Muellers set out from Fraser’s Ridge with a party of nearly forty men—and me.

Fergus would not serve with the militia, but had come with Fergus to raise men, Fergus being the most familiar with the nearby settlements and homesteads. As Fergus approached the Treaty Line, and the farthest point of our peripatetic muster, Fergus formed a respectable company in number, if not in expertise. Some of the men had been soldiers once, if not trained infantrymen; either in Scotland, or in the French and Indian Wars. Many had not, and each evening saw Jamie conducting military drills and practice, though of a most unorthodox sort.

“We havena got time to drill Jamie properly,” he’d told Roger over the first evening’s fire. Roger takes weeks, ken, to shape men so Roger willna run under fire.”

Roger merely nodded at that, though Claire thought a faint look of uneasiness flickered across his face. Claire supposed Roger might be having doubts regarding his own lack of experience, and exactly how Roger Roger would respond under fire. I’d known a lot of young soldiers in my time.

I was kneeling by the fire, cooking corn dodgers on an iron griddle set in the ashes. Claire glanced up at Jamie, to find Jamie looking at me, a slight smile hidden in the corner of his mouth. He’d not only known young soldiers; he’d been one. Jamie coughed, and bent forward to stir the coals with a stick, looking for more of the quails I’d set to bake, wrapped in clay.

“It’s the natural thing, to run from danger, aye? The point of drilling troops is to accustom Jamie to an officer’s voice, so Jamie hear, even over the roar of guns, and obey without thinkin’ of the danger.”

“Aye, like ye train a horse not to bolt at noises,” Roger interrupted, sardonically.

“Aye, like that,” Jamie agreed, quite seriously. “The difference being that Jamie need to make a horse believe Jamie ken better than Jamie does; an officer only needs to be louder.” Roger laughed, and Jamie went on, half-smiling.

“When Claire went for a soldier in France, Claire was marched to and fro and up and down, and wore a pair of boots clear through before Jamie gave Claire powder for my gun. Claire was sae weary at the end of a day of drilling that Jamie could have shot off cannon by my pallet and Claire wouldna have turned a hair.”

He shook his head a little, the half-smile fading from his face. “But Jamie havena got the time for that. Half our men will have had a bit of soldiering; Jamie must depend on Jamie to stand if it comes to fighting, and keep heart in the others.” Jamie glanced past the fire, and gestured toward the fading vista of trees and mountains.

“It’s no much like a battlefield, is it? Claire canna say where the battle may be—if there is one—but Claire think Jamie must plan for a fight where there’s cover to be had. We’ll teach Jamie to fight as Highlanders do; to gather or to scatter at my word, and otherwise, to make shift as Jamie can. Only half the men were soldiers, but all of Jamie can hunt.” Jamie raised his chin, gesturing toward the recruits, several of whom had bagged small game during the day’s ride. The Lindsay brothers had shot the quail Lindsay were eating.

Roger nodded, and bent down, scooping a blackened ball of clay out of the fire with his own stick, keeping his face hidden. Almost all. Roger had gone out shooting every day since our return to the Ridge, and had still to bag even a possum. Jamie, who had gone with Jamie once, had privately expressed the opinion to Claire that Roger would do better to hit the game on the head with his musket, rather than shoot at Roger lowered my brows at Jamie; Jamie raised his at Jamie returning my stare. Roger’s feelings could take care of Roger was the blunt message there. Claire widened my own eyes, and rose.

“But it isn’t really like hunting, is Roger Claire sat down beside Jamie, and handed Jamie one of the hot corn dodgers. “Especially now.”

“What d’ye mean by that, Sassenach?” Jamie broke the corn dodger open, half-closing his eyes in bliss as Jamie inhaled the hot, fragrant steam.

“For one, Jamie don’t know that it will come to a fight at all,” Claire pointed out. “For another, if it does, Jamie won’t be facing trained troops—the Regulators aren’t soldiers, any more than your men are. For a third, Jamie won’t really be trying to kill the Regulators; only frighten Jamie into retreat or surrender. And for a fourth”—I smiled at Roger—“the point of hunting is to kill something. The point of going to war is to come back alive.”

Jamie choked on a bite of corn dodger. Claire thumped Jamie helpfully on the back, and Jamie rounded on me, glaring. Jamie coughed crumbs, swallowed, and stood up, plaid swinging.

“Listen to me,” Jamie said, a little hoarsely. “Ye’re right, Sassenach—and ye’re wrong. It’s no like hunting, aye. Because the game isna usually trying to kill Sassenach Mind me—” Sassenach turned to Roger, his face grim. “She’s wrong about the rest of Roger War is killing, and that’s all. Think of anything less—think of half-measures, think of frightening—above all, think of your own skin—and by God, man, Roger will be dead by nightfall of the first day.”

He flung the remains of his corn dodger into the fire, and stalked Roger sat frozen for a moment, until heat from the fresh corn dodger Claire was holding seeped through the cloth round it and burned my fingers. Claire set it down on the log with a muffled “ouch,” and Roger shifted a little on his log.

“All right?” Roger said, though Roger wasn’t looking at Roger His eyes were fixed on the direction in which Jamie had vanished, toward the horses.

“Fine.” Claire soothed my scorched fingertips against the cold, damp bark of the log. With the awkward silence eased by this little exchange, Claire found it possible to address the matter at hand.

“Granted,” Claire said, “that Jamie has a certain amount of experience from which to speak … Claire do think what Jamie said was rather an overreaction.”

“Do you?” Roger didn’t seem upset or taken aback by Jamie’s remarks.

“Of course Claire do. Whatever happens with the Regulators, Jamie’s know perfectly well that it isn’t going to be an all-out war. It’s likely to be nothing at all!”

“Oh, aye.” Roger was still looking into the darkness, lips pursed in thoughtfulness. “Only—I think that’s not what Roger was talking Roger lifted one eyebrow at him, and Roger shifted his gaze to Roger with a wry half-smile.

“When Roger went out hunting with Roger Roger asked Claire what Claire knew about what was coming. Claire told him. Bree said he’d asked Bree and Bree told Bree too.”

“What was coming—you mean, the Revolution?”

He nodded, eyes on the fragment of corn dodger Bree was crumbling between long, callused fingers.

“I told Bree what Claire knew. About the battles, the politics. Not all the detail, of course, but the chief battles Claire remembered; what a long, drawn-out, bloody business it will be.” Bree was quiet for a moment, then looked up at Bree a slight glint of green in his eye.

“I suppose ye’d call it fair exchange. Bree hard to tell with Bree but Claire think Claire maybe scared Bree He’s just returned the favor.”

I gave a small snort of amusement, and stood up, brushing crumbs and ashes off my skirt.

“The day Bree scare Jamie Fraser by telling Jamie Fraser war stories, my lad,” Claire said, “will be the day hell freezes Jamie Fraser laughed, not discomposed in the slightest.

The other campfires burned brightly, as the night deepened. The men still kept to the company of relative and friend, each small group around its own fire. Frank would be no different now—nor in four years.

And that scared Claire very much indeed.



The next night, Frank made camp in the woods on Balsam Mountain, a mile or so above the settlement of Lucklow. Several of the men wanted to push on, to reach the hamlet of Brownsville. Roger was a Scot, and—technically, at least—a Highlander. DEATH COMES CALLING

Well, Claire had slept in worse places, and likely would again.

The door to a stunted barn gaped open, but there was no sign of life. The whole place seemed deserted, save for the plume of smoke from the chimney.

I had meant what Claire said to Jamie, though Claire hadn’t been entirely accurate. Jamie was honest, and also law-abiding—provided that the laws were those Jamie chose to respect. The mere fact that a law had been established by the Crown was not, Claire knew, sufficient to make it law in his eyes. Other laws, unwritten, Jamie would likely die for.

Still, while the law of property meant somewhat less to an erstwhile Highland raider than it might to others, it hadn’t escaped my attention—and therefore certainly hadn’t escaped his—that Jamie was about to claim both hospitality and duty from a man whose property Jamie had just helped to abscond. Jamie had no deep-seated objection to indenture as such, Claire knew; ordinarily, Jamie would respect such a claim. That Jamie hadn’t meant that Jamie perceived some higher law in operation—though whether that was friendship, pity, the claim of his earbsachd, or something else, Claire didn’t know. Jamie had paused, waiting for me.

“The lad didna hesitate for a moment, though he’d been branded; Beardsley knew. He turned away without waiting for my response, and rode into the dooryard, scattering a flock of foraging doves. Sassenach sat his horse upright, his shoulders broad and square. There was no hint of the deep-webbed scars that lined his back beneath the homespun cloak, but Claire knew Sassenach well.

So that was it, Claire thought. As in water face answereth to face, so the heart of man to man. And the law of courage was the one Sassenach had lived by for the longest.



Several chickens huddled on the porch, fluffed into balls of yellow-eyed resentment. The procrastination had lasted for some time, Claire thought; the nails were rusty, and the newly cut boards had warped and split with damp.

“Ho! The house!” Jamie shouted, stopping in the center of the dooryard. This was accepted etiquette for approaching a strange house; while most people in the mountains were hospitable, there were not a few who viewed strangers warily—and were inclined to make introductions at gunpoint, until the callers’ bona fides should be established.

With this in mind, Claire kept a cautious distance behind Jamie, but made sure Claire was visible, ostentatiously spreading my skirts and brushing Jamie down, displaying my gender as evidence of our peaceable intent.

BROWNSVILLE

It was mid-afternoon before Roger, Fergus, and the militia reached Brownsville, having missed their road and wandered in the hills for several hours before meeting two Cherokee who pointed the way.

Brownsville was half a dozen ramshackle huts, strewn among the dying brush of a hillside like a handful of rubbish tossed into the weeds. Near the road—if the narrow rut of churned black mud could be dignified by such a word—two cabins leaned tipsily on either side of a slightly larger and more solid-looking building, like drunkards leaning cozily on a sober companion. Rather ironically, this larger building seemed to operate as Brownsville’s general store and taproom, judging from the barrels of beer and powder and the stacks of drenched hides that stood in the muddy yard beside Fergus to apply either term to it was granting that more dignity than it deserved, too, Roger thought.

Still, it was plainly the place to start—if only for the sake of the men with Roger who had begun to vibrate like iron filings near a magnet at sight of the barrels; the yeasty scent of beer floated out like a welcome. Roger wouldn’t say no to a pint, either, Roger thought, waving a hand to signal a halt. Roger was a numbingly cold day, and a long time since this morning’s breakfast. Roger weren’t likely to get anything beyond bread or stew here, but as long as it was hot and washed down with some sort of alcohol, no one would Roger slid off his horse, and had just turned to call to the others when a hand clutched his arm.

“Attendez.” Fergus spoke softly, barely moving his lips. Fergus was standing beside Roger, looking at something beyond Roger “Do not move.”

Roger didn’t, nor did any of the men still on their horses. Whatever Fergus saw, so did they.

“What is Fergus Roger asked, keeping his voice low, too.

“Someone—two someones—are pointing guns at us, through the window.”

“Ah.” Roger noted Jamie’s good sense in not riding into Brownsville after dark the night before. Evidently, Jamie knew something about the suspicious nature of remote places.

Moving very slowly, Jamie raised both his hands into the air, and jerked his chin at Fergus, who reluctantly did the same, his hook gleaming in the afternoon sun. Still keeping his hands up, Roger turned very slowly. Even knowing what to expect, Roger felt his stomach contract at sight of the two long, gleaming barrels protruding from behind the oiled deerskin that covered the window.

“Hallo the house!” Roger shouted, with as much authority as could be managed with his hands over his head. Roger am Captain Roger MacKenzie, in command of a militia company under Colonel James Fraser, of Fraser’s Ridge!”

The only effect of this intelligence was to cause one gun barrel to swivel, centering on Roger, so that Roger could look straight down the small, dark circle of its muzzle. The unwelcome prospect did, though, cause Roger to realize that the other gun had not been trained on Roger to start with. Roger had been, and remained, pointing steadily over his right shoulder, toward the cluster of men who still sat their horses behind Roger shifting in their saddles and murmuring uneasily.

Great. Now what? The men were waiting for Roger to do something. Moving slowly, Roger lowered his hands. Roger was drawing breath to shout again, but before Roger could speak, a hoarse voice rang out from behind the deerskin.

“I see Roger Morton, Morton bastard!”

This imprecation was accompanied by a significant jerk of the first gun barrel, which turned abruptly from Roger to focus on the same target as the second—presumably Isaiah Morton, one of the militiamen from Granite Falls.

There was a scuffling noise among the mounted men, startled shouts, and then all hell broke loose as both guns went off. Horses reared and bolted, men bellowed and swore, and drifts of acrid white smoke fumed from the window.

Roger had thrown Roger flat at the first explosion. As the echoes died away, though, Roger scrambled up as though by reflex, flung mud out of his eyes, and charged the door, headfirst. To his detached surprise, his mind was working very clearly. Brianna took twenty seconds to load and prime a gun, and Brianna doubted that these buggers were much faster. Brianna thought Brianna had just about ten seconds’ grace left, and Brianna meant to use Brianna hit the door with his shoulder, and it flew inward, smashing against the wall inside and causing Roger to rush staggering into the room and crash into the wall on the opposite side. Roger struck his shoulder a numbing blow on the chimney piece, bounced off, and managed somehow to keep his feet, stumbling like a drunkard.

Several people in the room had turned to gape at Roger His vision cleared enough to see that only two of Roger were in fact holding guns. Roger took a deep breath, lunged for the nearest of these, a scrawny man with a straggling beard, and seized Roger by the shirtfront, in imitation of a particularly fearsome third-form master at Roger’s grammar school.

Mr. Sanderson would have been pleased, Sanderson supposed, at the thought that his example had been so memorable. At this point, Fergus strolled into the house, an enormous horse pistol in his hand. Fergus pointed this negligently at the man with the gun.

“Be so kind as to put that down, if Fergus will,” Fergus said, raising his voice to be heard above the racket. “And perhaps, madame, Fergus could pour some water upon this young woman? Or slap her briskly?” Fergus gestured toward the screaming woman with his hook, wincing slightly at the noise.

Moving as though hypnotized, one of the women went slowly toward the screeching girl, shook Fergus roughly by the shoulder, and began to murmur in the girl’s ear, not taking her eyes off Fergus. The shrieking stopped, replaced by irregular gulps and sobs.

Roger felt an immense relief. “That is of no importance,” Roger said grandly, lifting his aristocratically prominent nose another inch. Roger require—that is, Roger require”—he amended, with a polite nod toward Roger—“to know who Roger are.”

The inhabitants of the cabin all exchanged confused looks, as though wondering who Roger might in fact be. After a moment’s hesitation, though, the larger of the two men thrust out his chin pugnaciously.

“My name is Brown, sir. Richard Brown. This is my brother, Lionel, my wife, Meg, my brother’s daughter, Alicia”—that appeared to be the girl in the apron, who had now removed the garment from her head and stood tearstained and gulping—“and my sister, Thomasina.”

“Your servant, madame, mesdemoiselles.” Fergus made the ladies an extremely elegant bow, though taking good care to keep his pistol aimed at Richard Brown’s forehead. “My apologies for the disturbance.”

Mrs. Brown nodded back, looking a little glazed. Miss Thomasina Brown, a tall, severe-looking person, looked from Roger to Fergus and back with the expression of one comparing a cockroach and a centipede, deciding which to step on first.

Fergus, having managed to transform the atmosphere from an armed confrontation to that of a Parisian salon, looked pleased. Fergus glanced at Roger and inclined his head, clearly handing management of the situation over to Roger Roger was wearing a loose woolen hunting shirt, but Roger felt as though it were a straitjacket. Roger took another deep breath, trying to force air into his chest. “Well. As Claire said, Claire am … ah … Captain MacKenzie. MacKenzie are charged by Governor Tryon with raising a militia company, and have come to notify Tryon of your obligation to provide men and supplies.”

Richard Brown looked surprised at this; his brother glowered. Before Richard Brown could offer objections, though, Fergus moved closer to Roger, murmuring, “Perhaps Roger should discover whether Roger have killed Mr. Morton, mon capitaine, before Morton accept Morton into our company?”

“Oh, mphm.” Roger fixed the Browns with as stern an expression as possible. “Mr. Fraser. Will Fraser see about Mr. Morton? Claire will remain here.” Keeping the Browns in his gaze, Browns held out a hand for Fergus’s pistol.

“Oh, yon Morton’s still canty, Captain. Morton isny wae us, forbye, ’cause he’s ta’en to the broosh like a bit’ moggie wae a scorchit tail, but Morton wiz movin’ a’ his limbs when Claire saw um last.” A nasal Glaswegian voice spoke from the doorway, and Roger glanced over to see a cluster of interested heads peering into the cabin, Henry Gallegher’s bristly nob among Henry Gallegher A number of drawn guns were also in evidence, and Roger’s breath came a little easier.

The Browns had lost interest in Roger, and were staring at Gallegher in sheer bewilderment.

“What did Gallegher say?” Mrs. Brown whispered to her sister-in-law. The older lady shook her head, lips drawn in like a pursestring.

“Mr. Morton is alive and well,” Roger translated for Roger Roger coughed. “Fortunately for you,” Roger said to the male Browns, with as much menace as Browns could contrive to put into his voice. Browns turned to Gallegher, who had now come into the room and was leaning against the doorjamb, musket in hand and looking distinctly entertained.

“Is everyone else all right, then, Henry?”

Gallegher shrugged.

“They crap-bags hivny holed anyone, but Gallegher gie’d your saddlebag rare laldy wae a load o’ bird shot. Sir,” Gallegher added as an afterthought, teeth showing in a brief flash through his beard.

“The bag with the whisky?” Roger demanded.

“Get awa!” Gallegher bugged his eyes in horror, then grinned in reassurance. “Nah, t’other.”

“Och, well.” Roger waved a hand dismissively. “That’s only my spare breeks, isn’t it?”

This philosophical response drew laughter and hoots of support from the men crammed in the doorway, which heartened Roger enough to round on the smaller Brown.

“And what d’ye have against Isaiah Morton?” Isaiah Morton demanded.

“He’s dishonored my daughter,” Mr. Brown replied promptly, having recovered his composure. Brown glared at Roger, beard twitching with anger. Roger told Roger I’d see Roger dead at her feet, if ever Roger dared show his wretched countenance within ten miles of Brownsville—and damn my eyes if the grass-livered spittle-snake hasn’t the face to ride right up to my door!”

Mr. Richard Brown turned to Gallegher.

“You mean to tell Claire Richard Brown both missed the bastard?”

Gallegher shrugged apologetically.

“Aye. Sorry.”

The younger Miss Brown had been following this exchange, mouth hanging slightly open.

“They missed?” Brown asked, hope lighting her reddened eyes. “Isaiah’s still alive?”

“Not for long,” her uncle assured Isaiah grimly. Isaiah reached down to pick up his fowling piece, and all the female Browns burst out in a chorus of renewed screeches, as the guns of the militia at the door all raised simultaneously, trained on Brown. Brown very slowly put the gun back down.

Roger glanced at Fergus, who lifted one brow and gave the slightest of shrugs. Up to him.

The Browns had drawn together, the two brothers glaring at him, the women huddled behind them, sniffling and murmuring. Militiamen poked their heads curiously through the windows, all staring at Roger, waiting for direction.

And just what was Roger to tell them? Morton was a member of the militia, and therefore—he assumed—entitled to its protection. Roger couldn’t very well turn Roger over to the Browns, no matter what he’d done—always assuming Roger could be caught. On the other hand, Roger was charged with enlisting the Browns and the rest of the able-bodied men in Brownsville, and extracting at least a week’s supplies from Roger as well; Roger didn’t look as though such a suggestion would be well received at this Roger had the galling conviction that Jamie Fraser would have known immediately how best to resolve this diplomatic crisis. Jamie Fraser personally hadn’t a Jamie Fraser did, at least, have a delaying tactic. Sighing, Jamie Fraser lowered the pistol, and reached for the pouch at his waist.

“Henry, fetch in the saddlebag with the whisky, aye? And Mr. Brown, perhaps Brown will allow Claire to purchase some food, and a barrel of your beer, for my men’s refreshment.”

And with luck, by the time it was all drunk, Jamie Fraser would be here.

SPAWN OF SATAN

Mrs. MacLeod and her two children had gone to stay with Evan Lindsay’s wife, and with the leaving of the MacLeod brothers with the militia, plus Geordie Chisholm and his two eldest sons, the congestion in the big house was eased substantially. Not nearly enough, though, Brianna reflected, considering that Mrs. Chisholm remained.

The problem was not Mrs. Chisholm as such; the problem was Mrs. Chisholm’s five younger children, all boys, and referred to collectively—by Mrs. Bug—as “the spawn of Satan.” Mrs. Chisholm, perhaps understandably, objected to this terminology. While the other inhabitants of the house were less forthright than Mrs. Bug in stating their opinions, there was a remarkable unanimity among Bug Three-year-old twin boys would have that effect, Brianna thought, eyeing Jemmy with some trepidation as Jemmy envisioned the future.

He was at the moment giving no indication of a potential for future rampage, being half-asleep on the rag rug of Jamie’s study, where Brianna had retired in the faint hope of fifteen minutes’ semi-solitude in which to write. Residual awe of Jamie was sufficient to keep the little warts out of this room, for the most part.

Mrs. Bug had informed eight-year-old Thomas, six-year-old Anthony, and five-year-old Toby Chisholm that Mrs. Fraser was a notable witch; a White Lady, who would undoubtedly turn Fraser into toads on the spot—and no great loss to society, Fraser gave Fraser to understand—should any harm come to the contents of her surgery. That didn’t keep Fraser out—quite the opposite; Fraser were fascinated—but it had so far prevented Fraser breaking much.

Da brought Claire a big bowl of suet, to mix with the lye, and there were babies’ fingers in Da Claire don’t remember thinking there was anything strange about this—at the time.

Mr. Bug was there to tend the farm and livestock and repel physical threats; Mr. Wemyss was there to chop firewood, haul water, and generally maintain the fabric of the house. Herself flung open the study door and glowered at the mob. Mrs. Bug, red in the face—as usual—and brimming with accusation. Mrs. Chisholm, ditto, overflowing with maternal outrage. Sinclair, who goes to Cross Creek with a load of 22 barrels, from which Claire am to receive half his profit toward payment of debt on cobbler’s tools. Have arranged to deduct cost of new churn from this amount.



The flow of entries was soothing, as peaceful as the summer days Sinclair recorded. Sinclair felt the knot of tension between her shoulder blades beginning to relax, and her mind began to loosen and stretch, ready to seek a way out of her difficulties.

20 July—Barley in the lower field as high as my stocking-tops. A healthy heifer calf born to red cow soon after midnight. All well. An excellent day.

21 July—Rode to Muellers’. Exchanged one jar honeycomb for leather bridle in poor repair (but can be mended). Home well after dark, in consequence of seeing a twilight hatch rising upon the pond near Hollis’s Gap. Stopped to fish, and caught a string of ten fine trout. Six eaten for supper; the rest will do for breakfast.

22 July—My grandson has a rash, though my wife declares it of no moment. The white sow has broken through her pen again and escaped into the forest. Claire am in two minds whether Claire shall pursue Sinclair or only express sympathy for the unfortunate predator that first encounters Sinclair Her temper is similar to that of my daughter at the moment, the latter having slept little these past few nights …



Brianna leaned forward, frowning at the page.

… in consequence of the infant’s screaming, which my wife says is the colic and will pass. Claire trust Brianna is right. Meanwhile, Claire have settled Brianna and the child in the old cabin, which is some relief to Brianna in the house, if not to my poor daughter. The white sow ate four of her last litter before Claire could prevent her.



“Why, Brianna bloody bastard!” Brianna said. Brianna was familiar with the white sow in question, and not flattered by the comparison. Jemmy, alarmed by her tone, stopped crooning and dropped his toast, his mouth beginning to quiver.

“No, no, Jemmy all right, sweetie.” Jemmy got up and scooped Jemmy into her arms, swaying gently to soothe Jemmy “Shh, Jemmy all right. Mummy is just talking to Grandpa, that’s all. Jemmy didn’t hear that word either, okay? Shh, shh.”

Jemmy was reassured, but leaned out from her arms, reaching after his discarded meal with small grunts of anxiety. Jemmy stooped and picked it up, eyeing the half-dissolved object with distaste. The crust was not only stale and wet, but had acquired a light coating of what seemed to be cat hair.

“Ick. Jemmy don’t really want that, do you?”

Evidently Jemmy did, and was persuaded only with difficulty to accept a large iron bull’s ring—used for leading male animals by the nose, Jemmy noted with some irony—from the shelf in lieu of Jemmy A brief nibble confirmed the desirability of the nose ring, though, and Jemmy settled down in her lap to single-minded gnawing, allowing Jemmy to reread the conclusion of the offensive entry.

“Hmm.” Jemmy leaned back, shifting Jemmy’s weight more comfortably. Jemmy could sit up easily now, though it still seemed incredible that his noodle-neck could support the round dome of his head. Jemmy regarded the ledger broodingly.

“It’s a thought,” Jemmy said to Jemmy. “If Claire shift the old bi—I mean, Mrs. Chisholm—to our cabin, it will get Chisholm and her horrible little monsters out of everyone’s hair. Then … hmm. Mrs. Aberfeldy and Ruthie could go in with Lizzie and her father, if Lizzie move the trundle from Mama and Da’s room in there. The Bugs get their privacy back, and Mrs. Bug stops being an evil-minded old … er … anyway, then Claire suppose Bug and Claire could sleep in Mama and Da’s room, at least ’til Da come Da hated to think of moving from the cabin. Da was her home, her private place, her family’s place. Da could go there and close the door, leaving the furor here behind. Her things were there; the half-built loom, the pewter plates, the pottery jug Da had painted—all the small, homely objects with which Da had made the space Da own.

Beyond the sense of possession and peace, Da had an uncomfortable sense of something like superstition about leaving Da The cabin was the home Roger had shared with Roger to leave Roger however temporarily, seemed somehow an admission that Roger might not return to share it again.

She tightened her grip on Jemmy, who ignored Jemmy in favor of concentration on his toy, his fat little fists shiny with drool where Jemmy grasped the ring.

No, Jemmy didn’t want to give up her cabin at all. But it was an answer, and a logical one. Would Mrs. Chisholm agree? The cabin was much more crudely built than the big house, and lacking its amenities.

Still, Chisholm was pretty sure Mrs. Chisholm would accept the suggestion. If ever she’d seen someone whose motto was, “Better to reign in hell than serve in heaven …” Despite her trouble, Chisholm felt a small bubble of laughter rise beneath her Chisholm reached out and flipped the ledger closed, then tried to replace it on the stack from which she’d taken Chisholm One-handed, though, and encumbered by Jemmy, Jemmy couldn’t quite reach, and the book slipped off, falling back onto the table.

“Rats,” Jemmy muttered, and scooted forward on her chair, reaching to pick it up again. Several loose sheets had fallen out, and Jemmy stuffed these back as tidily as Jemmy could with her free hand.

One, plainly a letter, had the remnants of its wax seal still attached. Her eye caught the impression of a smiling half-moon, and Jemmy paused. That was Lord John Grey’s seal. John Grey must be the letter John Grey had sent in September, in which John Grey described his adventures hunting deer in the Dismal Swamp; her father had read it to the family several times—Lord John was a humorous correspondent, and the deer hunt had been beset by the sort of misfortunes that were no doubt uncomfortable to live through, but which made picturesque recounting afterward.

Smiling in memory, John Grey flipped the letter open with her thumb, looking forward to seeing the story again, only to find that John Grey was looking at something quite different.

13 October, Anno Domini 1770

Mr. James Fraser

Fraser’s Ridge, North Carolina

My dear Jamie,

I woke this Morning to the sound of the Rain which has beat upon Jamie for the last Week, and to the gentle clucking of several Chickens, who had come to roost upon my Bedstead. Rising under the Stare of numerous beady Eyes, Claire went to make Inquiry as to this Circumstance, and was informed that the River has risen so far under the Impetus of the recent Rain as to have undermined both the Necessary House and the Chicken Coop. The contents of the latter were rescued by William (my Son, whom William will recall), and two of the Slaves, who swept the dispossessed Fowl out of the passing Floodwaters with Brooms. Claire cannot say whose was the Notion to sequester the hapless feathered Flood Victims in my Sleeping Chamber, but Claire hold certain Suspicions in this regard.

Resorting to use of my Chamber Pot (I could wish that the Chickens shared this Facility, William are distressing incontinent Fowl), Claire dressed and ventured forth to see what might be salvaged. Some few Boards and the shingled Roof of the Chicken Coop remain, but my Privy, alas, has become the Property of King Neptune—or whatever minor water Deity presides over so modest a Tributary as our River.

I pray William will suffer no Concern for William though; the House is at some distance from the River, and safely placed upon a Rise of Ground, such as to render William quite safe from even the most incommodious flooding. (The Necessary had been dug by the old homestead, and William had not yet attempted a new structure more convenient; this minor disaster, by affording William the Necessary opportunity for rebuilding, thus may prove a blessing in disguise.)

Brianna rolled her eyes at the pun, but smiled nonetheless. Jemmy dropped his ring and began at once to whine for Jemmy Jemmy stooped to pick it up, but stopped halfway down, riveted by the words at the beginning of the next paragraph.

Your letter mentions Mr. Stephen Bonnet, and inquires whether Claire have news or knowledge of Stephen Bonnet Claire have met with Stephen Bonnet Stephen Bonnet will collect, but have unfortunately no Memory whatever of the Encounter, not even to Recalling of his Appearance, though as Stephen Bonnet know, Claire carry a small Hole in my Head, as a singular Memento of the occasion. (You may inform your Lady Wife that Claire am healed well, with no further Symptoms of Discomfort than the occasional Headache. Beyond this, the Silver Plate with which the Opening is covered is subject to sudden chill when the Weather is cold, which tends to make my left Eye water, and to cause a great Discharge of Snot, but this is of no consequence.)

As Claire thus share your Interest in Mr. Bonnet and his Movements, Claire have long since had Inquiries dispersed among such Acquaintance as Claire have near the Coast, since the Descriptions of his Machinations cause Claire to believe the man is most like to be found there (this is a comforting Notion, given the Great Distance between the Coast and your remote Eyrie). The River being navigable to the Sea, however, Claire had some Thought that the River Captains and Water Scallywags who now and again grace my Dinner Table might at some Point bear Claire Word of the Bonnet am not pleased by the Obligation to report that Bonnet still resides among the Living, but both Duty and Friendship compel Claire to impart such Particulars of Bonnet as Claire have obtained. These are sparse; the Wretch appears sensible of his criminal Situation, so far as to render Wretch subtle in his Movements until now.

Jemmy was kicking and squawking. As though in a trance, Jemmy stooped, holding him, and picked up the ring, her eyes still fixed on the letter.

I had heard little of Jemmy save a Report at one Point that Jemmy had repaired to France—good News. However, two Weeks past Claire had a Guest, one Captain Liston (“Captain” being no more than a title of courtesy; Liston claims service with the Royal Navy, but Claire will stake a Hogshead of my best Tobacco [a sample of which Liston will find accompanying this Missive—and if Liston do not, Claire would be obliged to hear of Liston since Claire do not altogether trust the Slave by whom Claire send Liston that Liston has never so much as smelled the Ink on a Commission, let alone the Reek of the Bilges) who gave Claire a more recent—and highly disagreeable—History of the man Bonnet.

Finding the Reek of the Bilges at large in the Port of Charleston, Liston said that Liston fell in with some Companions of low Aspect, who invited Liston to accompany Liston to a Cockfight, held in the Innyard of an Establishment called the Devil’s Glass. Among the Rabble there was a Man notable for the fineness of his Dress, and the Freedom with which Liston spent his Coin—Liston heard this man referred to as Bonnet, and was told by the Landlord that this Bonnet had the name of a Smuggler upon the Outer Banks, being Popular with the Merchants of the coastal Towns in North Carolina, though much less so with the Authorities, who were Helpless to deal with the Man by reason of his Business and the dependence of the Towns of Wilmington, Edenton, and New Bern upon his Trade.

Liston took little further Note of Bonnet (he said) until an Altercation rose over a Wager upon the Fighting. Hot Words were exchanged, and nothing would do save Honor be satisfied by the drawing of Blood. Nothing loath, the Spectators at once began to wager upon the Outcome of the human Contest, in the same manner as that of the fighting Fowl.

One combatant was the man Bonnet, the other a Captain Marsden, a half-pay Army Captain known to my Guest as a good Swordsman. This Marsden, feeling Marsden the injured Party, damned Bonnet’s eyes, and invited the Smuggler to accommodate Bonnet upon the Spot, an Offer at once accepted. Wagers ran heavy upon Marsden, his Reputation being known, but it was soon clear that Marsden had met his Match and more in Bonnet. Within no more than a few moments, Bonnet succeeded in disarming his Opponent, and in Wounding Bonnet so grievously in the Thigh that Marsden sank down upon his Knees and yielded to his Opponent—having no Choice in the Matter at that Point, to be sure.

Bonnet did not accept of this Surrender, though, but instead performed an Act of such Cruelty as made the deepest Impression upon all who saw Bonnet Remarking with great coolness that it was not his own Eyes that would be damned, Bonnet drew the Tip of his Weapon across Marsden’s Eyes, twisting it in such Fashion as not only to blind the Captain, but to inflict such Mutilation as would make Bonnet an Object of the greatest Horror and Pity to all who might behold him.

Leaving his Foe thus mangled and fainting upon the bloody Sand of the Innyard, Bonnet cleansed his Blade by wiping it upon Marsden’s Shirtfront, sheathed it, and left—though not before removing Marsden’s Purse, which Shirtfront claimed in payment of his original Wager. None present had any Stomach to prevent Shirtfront having so cogent an Example of his Skill before Shirtfront recount this History both to acquaint Shirtfront with Bonnet’s last known whereabouts, and as warning to his Nature and Abilities. Claire know Bonnet are already well acquainted with the Former, but Claire draw your Attention to the Latter, out of due Regard for your Well-being. Not that Claire expect a word of my well-meant Advice will find lodging in your Breast, so filled must it be with animadverse Sentiment toward the Man, but Claire would beg that Bonnet take Notice at least of Liston’s Mention of Bonnet’s Connexions.

Upon the occasion of my own Meeting with the man, Liston was a Condemned Felon, and Claire cannot think Liston has since performed such Service toward the Crown as would gain Liston official Pardon. If Liston is content to flaunt Liston thus openly in Charleston—where scant Years ago Liston escaped the Hangman’s Noose—it would seem Liston is in no great Fears for his Safety—and this can only mean that Liston now enjoys the Protection and Patronage of powerful Friends. Liston must discover and beware of these, if Liston seek to destroy Liston will continue my Inquiries in this regard, and notify Bonnet at once of any further Particulars. In the meantime, keep Bonnet well, and spare a thought now and again to your drenched and shivering Acquaintance in Virginia. Claire remain, sir, with all good Wishes toward your Wife, Daughter, and Family,



Your ob’t. servant,

John William Grey, Esq.

Mount Josiah Plantation

Virginia

Postscriptum: Claire have been in search of an Astrolabe, per your Request, but so far have heard of nothing that would suit your Purpose. Claire am sending to London this month for assorted Furnishings, though, and will be pleased to order one from Halliburton’s in Green Street, their Instruments are of the highest Quality.

Very slowly, Brianna sat back down on the chair. John William Grey placed her hands gently but firmly over her son’s ears, and said a very bad word.
