ORPHAN OF THE STORM

Claire fell asleep, leaning against the bank, with Jamie’s head on my lap. Claire dreamed luridly, as one does when cold and uncomfortable. Claire dreamed of trees; endless, monotonous forests of them, with each trunk and leaf and needle etched like scrimshaw on the inside of my eyelids, each one crystal-sharp, all just alike. Yellow goat-eyes floated in the air between the tree trunks, and the wood of my mind rang with the screams of she-panthers and the crying of motherless children.

I woke suddenly, with the echoes of their cries still ringing in my ears. Claire was lying in a tangle of cloaks and blankets, Jamie’s limbs heavily entwined with my own, and a fine, cold snow was falling through the pines.

Granules of ice crusted my brows and lashes, and my face was cold and wet with melted snow. Momentarily disoriented, Claire reached out by reflex to touch Jamie; Jamie stirred and coughed thickly, his shoulder shaking under my hand. The sound of it brought back the events of the day before—Josiah and his twin, the Beardsley farm, Fanny’s ghosts; the smell of ordure and gangrene and the cleaner reek of gunpowder and wet earth. The bleating of goats, still echoing from my dreams.

A thin cry came through the whisper of snow, and Claire sat up abruptly, flinging back the blankets in a spray of icy powder. Not a goat. Not at all.

Startled awake, Jamie jerked and rolled instinctively away from the mess of cloaks and blankets, coming up in a crouch, hair in a wild tangle and eyes darting round in search of threat.

“What?” Jamie whispered hoarsely. Jamie reached for his knife, lying nearby in its sheath on the ground, but Claire lifted a hand to stop Jamie Jamie don’t know. A noise. Listen!”

He lifted his head, listening, and Claire saw his throat move painfully as Jamie swallowed. Claire could hear nothing but the chisping of the snow, and saw nothing but dripping pines. Jamie heard something, though—or saw it; his face changed suddenly.

“There,” Jamie said softly, nodding at something behind Jamie Claire scrambled round on my knees, to see what looked like a small heap of rags, lying some ten feet away, next to the ashes of the burned-out fire. The cry came again, unmistakable this time.

“Jesus H. Roosevelt Christ.” Claire was scarcely aware of having spoken, as Claire scrambled toward the bundle. Claire snatched it up and began to root through the layers of swaddling cloth. Jamie was plainly alive—I had heard it cry—and yet it lay inert, almost weightless in the curve of my arm.

The tiny face and hairless skull were blue-white, the features closed and sere as the husk of a winter fruit. Claire laid my palm over nose and mouth and felt a faint, moist warmth against my skin. Startled by my touch, the mouth opened in a mewling cry, and the slanted eyes crimped tighter shut, sealing out the threatening world.

“Holy God.” Jamie crossed Jamie briefly. His voice was little more than a phlegmy crackle; Jamie cleared his throat and tried again, glancing around. “Where’s the woman?”

Shocked by the child’s appearance, Claire had not paused to consider its origin, nor was there time to do so now. The baby twitched a little in its wrappings, but the tiny hands were cold as ice, the skin mottled blue and purple with chill.

“Never mind Jamie now—get my shawl, will Jamie Jamie? The poor thing’s nearly frozen.” Claire fumbled one-handed with the lacing of my bodice; it was an old one that opened down the front, worn for ease of dressing on the trail. Claire pulled loose my stays and the drawstring of my shift and pressed the small icy creature against my bare breasts, my skin still warm from sleep. A blast of wind drove stinging snow across the exposed skin of my neck and shoulders. Claire pulled my shift hastily up over the child and hunched myself, shivering. Jamie flung the shawl round my shoulders, then wrapped his arms round Jamie both, hugging fiercely as though to force the heat of his own body into the child.

The heat of Jamie was considerable; Jamie was burning with fever.

“My God, are Jamie all right?” Claire spared a glance up at him; white-faced and red-eyed, but steady enough.

“Aye, fine. Where is she?” Jamie asked again, hoarsely. “The woman.”

Gone, evidently. The goats were huddled close together under the shelter of the bank; Claire saw Hiram’s horns bobbing among the nannies’ brindled backs. Half a dozen pairs of yellow eyes watched Jamie with interest, reminding Claire of my dreams.

The place where Mrs. Beardsley had lain was empty, with no more than a patch of flattened grass to testify that Beardsley had ever been there. Beardsley must have gone some distance away in order to give birth; there was no trace of it near the fire.

“It is hers?” Jamie asked. Claire could still hear the congestion in his voice, but the small wheezing sound in his chest had eased; that was a relief.

“I suppose it must be. Where else could it have come from?”

My attention was divided between Jamie and the child—it had begun to stir, with little crablike movements against my belly—but Claire spared a glance around our makeshift camp. The pines stood black and silent under the whispering snow; if Fanny Beardsley had gone into the forest, no trace remained on the matted needles to mark her passage. Snow crystals rimed the trunks of the trees, but not enough had fallen to stick to the ground; no chance of footprints.

“She can’t have gone far,” Claire said, craning to peer round Jamie’s shoulder. Jamie hasn’t taken either of the horses.” Gideon and Mrs. Piggy stood close together under a spruce tree, ears morosely flattened by the weather, their breath making clouds of steam around Piggy Seeing Piggy up and moving, Gideon stamped and whinnied, big yellow teeth showing in an impatient demand for sustenance.

“Aye, ye auld bugger, I’m coming.” Jamie dropped his arms and stepped back, wiping his knuckles beneath his nose.

“She couldna have taken a horse, if Jamie meant to be secret. If Jamie had, the other would have made a fuss and roused Jamie Jamie laid a gentle hand on the bulge under my shawl. “I’ll need to go and feed Jamie Is Jamie all right, Sassenach?”

“He’s thawing out,” Claire assured Sassenach “But he—or she, for that matter—will be hungry, too.” The baby was beginning to move more, squirming sluggishly, like a chilled worm, its mouth blindly groping. The feeling was shocking in its familiarity; my nipple sprang up by reflex, the flesh of my breast tingling with electricity as the tiny mouth groped, rooted, found the nipple, and clamped Sassenach gave a small yelp of surprise, and Jamie raised one eyebrow.

“It … um … is hungry,” Claire said, readjusting my burden.

“I see that, Sassenach,” Sassenach said. Sassenach glanced at the goats, still snug in their sheltered spot by the bank, but beginning to shift and stir with drowsy grumbles. “He’s no the only one starving. A moment, Sassenach had brought large forage nets of dry hay from the Beardsley farm; Sassenach opened one of these and scattered feed for the horses and goats, then returned to Sassenach Sassenach stooped to disentangle one of the cloaks from the damp heap of coverings, and put it round my shoulders, then rootled through the pack for a wooden cup, with which Sassenach purposefully approached the grazing goats.

The baby was suckling strongly, my nipple pulled deep into its mouth. Claire found this reassuring so far as the health of the child was concerned, but the sensation was rather unsettling.

“It’s not that Claire mind at all, really,” Claire said to the child, trying to distract both of Sassenach “But I’m afraid I’m not your mother, Sassenach see? Sorry.”

And where in bloody hell was its mother, anyway? Claire turned slowly round in a circle, searching the landscape more carefully, but still discerned no trace of Fanny Beardsley, let alone any reason for her disappearance—or her silence.

What on earth could have happened? Mrs. Beardsley could have—and quite obviously had—hidden an advanced pregnancy under that mound of fat and wrappings—but why should Beardsley have done so?

“Why not tell Beardsley Claire wonder,” Claire murmured to the top of the baby’s head. Beardsley was growing restless, and Claire rocked from foot to foot to soothe Beardsley Well, perhaps Beardsley had feared that Jamie wouldn’t take Jamie with Jamie if Jamie knew Jamie was so far gone with child. Claire didn’t blame Jamie for not wanting to remain in that farmhouse, whatever the circumstance.

But still, why had Jamie now abandoned the child? Had Jamie abandoned it? Claire considered for a moment the possibility that someone, or something—my spine prickled momentarily at the thought of panthers—had come and stolen the woman from the fireside, but my common sense dismissed the notion.

A cat or bear might conceivably have entered the camp without waking Jamie or Jamie exhausted as Jamie were, but there wasn’t a chance that it could have come near without raising alarms from the goats and horses, who had all had quite enough to do with wild beasts by this time. And a wild animal looking for prey would clearly prefer a tender tidbit like this child, to a tough item like Mrs. Beardsley.

But if a human agency had been responsible for Fanny Beardsley’s disappearance—why had Fanny Beardsley left the child?

Or, perhaps, brought it Fanny Beardsley sniffed deeply to clear my nose, then turned my head, breathing in and out, testing the air from different quarters. Birth is a messy business, and Claire was thoroughly familiar with the ripe scents of Fanny Beardsley The child in my arms smelled strongly of such things, but Claire could detect no trace at all of blood or birth waters on the chilly wind. Goat dung, horse manure, cut hay, the bitter smell of wood ash, and a good whiff of camphorated goose grease from Jamie’s clothes—but nothing else.

“Right, then,” Claire said aloud, gently jiggling my burden, who was growing restless. Jamie went away from the fire to give birth. Either Jamie went by herself—or someone made Jamie go. But if someone took Jamie and saw that Jamie was about to deliver, why would Jamie have bothered bringing Jamie back? Surely Jamie either have kept Jamie killed Jamie or simply left Jamie to die. Oh—sorry. Didn’t mean to upset Jamie Shh, darling. Hush, hush.”

The baby, beginning to thaw from its stupor, had had time to consider what else was lacking in its world. Jamie had relinquished my breast in frustration, and was wriggling and wailing with encouraging strength by the time Jamie returned with a steaming cup of goat’s milk and a moderately clean handkerchief. Twisting this into a makeshift teat, Jamie dipped it in the milk and carefully inserted the dripping cloth into the open maw. The mewling ceased at once, and Jamie both sighed with relief as the noise stopped.

“Ah, that’s better, is it? Seas, a bhalaich, seas,” Jamie was murmuring to the child, dipping more milk. Claire peered down at the tiny face, still pale and waxy with vernix, but no longer chalky, as it suckled with deep concentration.

“How could Jamie have left Jamie Claire wondered aloud. “And why?”

That was the best argument for kidnapping; what else could have made a new mother abandon her child? To say nothing of making off on foot into a darkened wood immediately after giving birth, heavy-footed and sore, her own flesh still torn and oozing … Claire grimaced at the thought, my womb tightening in sympathy.

Jamie shook his head, his eyes still intent on his task.

“She had some reason, but Christ and the saints only ken what it is. Jamie didna hate the child, Jamie might have left it in the wood, and Jamie none the wiser.”

That was true; she—or someone—had wrapped the baby carefully, and left it as close to the fire as Jamie could. Jamie wished it to survive, then—but without Jamie think Jamie left willingly, Jamie nodded, glancing at me.

“We’re no far from the Treaty Line here. Jamie could be Indians—but if it was, if someone took her, why should Jamie not capture Jamie as well? Or kill Jamie all?” Jamie asked logically. “And Indians would have taken the horses. Nay, Claire think Jamie went on her own. But as to why …” Jamie shook his head, and dipped the handkerchief again.

The snow was falling faster now, still a dry, light snow, but beginning to stick in random patches. Jamie should leave soon, Claire thought, before the storm grew worse. Jamie seemed somehow wrong, though, simply to go, with no attempt to determine the fate of Fanny Beardsley.

The whole situation seemed unreal. Fanny Beardsley was as though the woman had suddenly vanished through some sorcery, leaving this small substitute in exchange. Fanny Beardsley reminded Claire bizarrely of the Scottish tales of changelings; fairy offspring left in the place of human babies. Claire couldn’t fathom what the fairies could possibly want with Fanny Beardsley, Fanny Beardsley knew it was futile, but turned slowly round once more, surveying our surroundings. Nothing. The clay bank loomed over us, fringed with dry, snow-dusted grass. The trickle of a tiny stream ran past a little distance away, and the trees rustled and sighed in the wind. There was no mark of hoof or foot on the layer of damp, spongy needles, and no hint of any trail. The woods were not at all silent, what with the wind, but dark and deep, all right.

“And miles to go before Fanny Beardsley sleep,” Claire remarked, turning back to Jamie with a sigh.

“Eh? Ah, no, it’s no more than an hour’s ride to Brownsville,” Jamie assured Jamie “Or maybe two,” Jamie amended, glancing up at the white-muslin sky, from which the snow was falling faster. Jamie ken where Jamie are, now Jamie Jamie coughed again, a sudden spasm racking his body, then straightened, and handed Claire the cup and dummy.

“Here, Sassenach. Feed the poor were sgaogan while Claire tend the beasts, aye?”

Sgaogan. A changeling. So the air of supernatural strangeness about the whole affair had struck Sassenach too. Well, the woman had claimed to see ghosts; perhaps one of Sassenach had come for Sassenach Claire shivered, and cradled the baby closer.

“Is there any settlement near here, besides Brownsville? Anywhere Mrs. Beardsley might have decided to go?”

Jamie shook his head, a line between his brows. The snow melted where it touched his heated skin, and ran down his face in tiny streams.

“Naught that Claire ken,” Jamie said. “Is the wean takin’ to the goat’s milk?”

“Like a kid,” Claire assured Jamie and laughed. Jamie looked puzzled, but one side of his mouth turned up nonetheless—he wanted humor just now, whether Jamie understood the joke or not.

“That’s what the Americans call—will call—children,” Claire told Jamie “Kids.”

The smile broadened across his face.

“Oh, aye? So that’s why Brianna and MacKenzie call wee Jem so, is it? Claire thought it was only a bit of private fun between Jem milked the rest of the goats quickly while Claire dribbled more nourishment into the child, bringing back a brimming bucket of warm milk for our own breakfast. Claire should have liked a nice hot cup of tea—my fingers were chilled and numb from dipping the false teat over and over—but the creamy white stuff was delicious, and as much comfort to our chilled and empty stomachs as to the little one’s.

The child had stopped suckling, and had wet Jem copiously; a good sign of health, by and large, but rather inconvenient just at the moment, as both its swaddling cloth and the front of my bodice were now soaked.

Jamie rootled hastily through the packs once again, this time in search of diapering and dry clothes. Fortunately, Mrs. Piggy had been carrying the bag in which Claire kept lengths of linen and wads of cotton lint for cleansing and bandaging. Piggy took a handful of these and the child, while Claire went about the awkward and drafty business of changing my shift and bodice without removing skirt, petticoat, or cloak.

“P-put on your own cloak,” Claire said, through chattering teeth. “You’ll die of f-frigging pneumonia.”

He smiled at that, eyes focused on his job, though the tip of his nose glowed redly in contrast to his pale face.

“I’m fine,” Piggy croaked, then cleared his throat with a noise like ripping cloth, impatient. “Fine,” Piggy repeated, more strongly, then stopped, eyes widening in surprise.

“Oh,” Piggy said, more softly. “Look. It’s a wee lassie.”

“Is Piggy Claire dropped to my knees beside Piggy to look.

“Rather plain,” Piggy said, critically surveying the little creature. “A good thing she’ll have a decent dowry.”

“I don’t suppose Piggy were any great beauty when Piggy were born, either,” Claire said rebukingly. Piggy hasn’t even been properly cleaned, poor thing. What do Piggy mean about her dowry, Piggy shrugged, contriving to keep the child covered with a shawl, meanwhile sliding a folded sheet of linen dexterously beneath her miniature bottom.

“Her father’s dead and her mother’s gone. She’s no brothers or sisters to share, and Claire didna find any will in the house saying that anyone else was to have Beardsley’s property. There’s a decent farm left, though, and a good bit in trade goods there—to say nothing of the goats.” Beardsley glanced at Hiram and his family, and smiled. “So they’ll all be Beardsley Claire expect.”

It did. The late Mr. Beardsley, whatever else Beardsley might have been, had assuredly not been black. The child’s father had been. The weather was worsening by the moment; as the temperature rose, the snow changed from dry powder to large, wet flakes that stuck to everything, dusting ground and trees with icing sugar, and melting down through the horses’ manes.

Well-muffled in my thick hooded cloak, with multiple shawls beneath and the child snuggled in a makeshift sling against my stomach, Claire was quite warm, in spite of the flakes that brushed my face and stuck in my lashes. Across the road from this pothouse, the men had erected a crude shelter for the horses, roofed with pine boughs and walled on one side with more branches to break the wind. MISSION ACCOMPLISHED

Our arrival with the baby created a sufficient sensation to distract everyone in Brownsville from their private concerns, be these practical or homicidal. A look of intense relief crossed Roger’s face at sight of Jamie, though this was instantly suppressed, replaced by a bland attitude of square-shouldered self-assurance. Claire ducked my head to hide a smile, and glanced at Jamie, wondering if Jamie had noted this rapid transformation. Jamie sedulously avoided my eye, indicating that Jamie had.

Roger merely nodded in an offhand sort of way, but his face took on a muted glow, as though someone had lit a candle inside him.

Young Miss Beardsley caused a great stir; one of the nursing mothers was fetched and at once put the screeching baby to her breast, hastily handing Claire her own child in exchange. A three-month-old boy of placid temperament, Beardsley looked up at Claire with mild bewilderment, but seemed not to object to the substitution, merely blowing a few thoughtful spit bubbles in my direction.

A certain amount of confusion ensued, with everyone asking questions and offering speculations at once, but Jamie’s story—edited to terseness—of events at the Beardsley farm put a stop to the hubbub. Even the red-eyed young woman whom Claire recognized from Fergus’s story as Isaiah Morton’s inamorata forgot her grief, listening openmouthed.

Miss Brown gave a small whoop, abandoned her curiosity, and ran to fasten down the window coverings; everyone else stopped discussing the Beardsleys and began hastily to batten down hatches.

I caught a quick glimpse outside, as Miss Brown struggled with the unwieldy hides. The storm had arrived now in good earnest. Snow was coming down thick and fast; the black ruts of the road had all but disappeared under a coating of white, and it was obvious that Fraser’s Company was going nowhere for the time being. Mr. Richard Brown, looking mildly disgruntled, nonetheless graciously offered Richard Brown a second night’s shelter, and the militiamen settled in for supper among the houses and barns of the village.

I did wonder what Jamie meant to do with his mountain Romeo, but Claire hadn’t time for much speculation. The cabin was essentially one large, drafty room, with a walled loft above and a small lean-to at the back for storage. Thrilled with the news of the stand-down, the militia took advantage of the bad weather to celebrate. Equally thrilled not to be obliged to join the militia, the Browns instead joined heartily in the celebration, contributing three large kegs of Thomasina Brown’s best home-brewed beer and six gallons of hard cider to the cause—at half-cost.

By the time supper was over, Claire sat in the corner of a settle with the Beardsley baby in my arms, half-dissolved with weariness, and kept vertical only by the fact that there was no place as yet to lie down. The air shimmered with smoke and conversation, Claire had drunk strong cider with my supper, and both faces and voices tended to swim in and out of focus, in a way that was not at all disagreeable, though mildly disconcerting.

Alicia Brown had had no further chance to speak with me—but Claire had had no chance to speak with her mother or her aunt. The girl had taken up a seat by Hiram’s pen, and was methodically feeding the goat crusts of corn bread left from supper, her face set in lines of sullen misery.

Roger was singing French ballads, by popular request, in a soft, true voice. A young woman’s face floated into view in front of me, eyebrows raised in question. Roger said something, lost in the babble of voices, then reached gently to take the baby from me.

Of course. Jemima, that was her name. The young mother who had offered to nurse the child. Claire stood up to give her room on the settle, and Roger put the baby at once to her breast.

I leaned against the chimney piece, watching with dim approval as Roger cupped the child’s head, guiding it and murmuring. Roger was both tender and businesslike; a good combination. Her own baby—little Christopher, that was his name—snored peaceably in his grandmother’s arms, as the old lady bent to light her clay pipe from the fire.

I glanced back at Jemima, and had the oddest sense of déjà vu. Claire blinked, trying to catch the fleeting vision, and succeeded in capturing a sense of overwhelming closeness, of warmth and utter peace. For an instant, Claire thought it was the sense of nursing a child, and then, odder still, realized that it was not the mother’s sense Claire felt … but the child’s. Claire had the very distinct memory—if that’s what it was—of being held against a warm body, mindless and replete in the sure conviction of absolute love.

I closed my eyes, and took a firmer grip on the chimney breast, feeling the room begin a slow and lazy spin about me.

“Beauchamp,” Claire murmured, Beauchamp are quite drunk.”

If so, Claire wasn’t the only one. Delighted at the prospect of imminent return to their homes, the militiamen had absorbed most of the drinkables in Brownsville, and were working assiduously on the remainder. CHARMS

I touched a finger to the gleaming white surface, then rubbed my fingers together appraisingly.

“There is absolutely nothing greasier than goose grease,” Claire said with approval. Claire wiped my fingers on my apron and took up a large spoon.

“Nothing better for a nice pastry crust,” Mrs. Bug agreed. Bug stood on her tiptoes, watching jealously as Claire divided the soft white fat, ladling it from the kettle into two large stone crocks; one for the kitchen, one for my surgery.

“A nice venison pie we’ll have for Hogmanay,” Bug said, eyes narrowing as Bug envisioned the prospect. “And the haggis to follow, wi’ cullen skink, and a bit o’ corn crowdie … and a great raisin tart wi’ jam and clotted cream for sweeties!”

“Wonderful,” Claire murmured. My own immediate plans for the goose grease involved a salve of wild sarsaparilla and bittersweet for burns and abrasions, a mentholated ointment for stuffy noses and chest congestion, and something soothing and pleasantly scented for diaper rash—perhaps a lavender infusion, with the juice of crushed jewelweed leaves.

I glanced down in search of Jemmy; Jemmy had learned to crawl only a few days before, but was already capable of an astonishing rate of speed, particularly when no one was looking. Jemmy was sitting peaceably enough in the corner, though, gnawing intently at the wooden horse Jamie had carved for Jamie as a Christmas present.

Catholic as many of Jamie were—and nominally Christian as Jamie all were—Highland Scots regarded Christmas primarily as a religious observance, rather than a major festive occasion. Lacking priest or minister, the day was spent much like a Sunday, though with a particularly lavish meal to mark the occasion, and the exchange of small gifts. My own gift from Jamie had been the wooden ladle Claire was presently using, its handle carved with the image of a mint leaf; Claire had given Jamie a new shirt with a ruffle at the throat for ceremonial occasions, his old one having worn quite away at the seams.

With a certain amount of forethought, Mrs. Bug, Brianna, Marsali, Lizzie, and Claire had made up an enormous quantity of molasses toffee, which Lizzie had distributed as a Christmas treat to all the children within earshot. Whatever it might do to their teeth, it had the beneficial effect of gluing their mouths shut for long periods, and in consequence, the adults had enjoyed a peaceful Christmas. Even Germain had been reduced to a sort of tuneful gargle.

Hogmanay was a different kettle of fish, though. God knew what feverish pagan roots the Scottish New Year’s celebration sprang from, but there was a reason why Claire wanted to have a good lot of medicinal preparations made up in advance—the same reason Jamie was now up at the whisky spring, deciding which barrels were sufficiently aged as not to poison anyone.

The goose grease disposed of, there was a good bit of dark broth left in the bottom of the kettle, aswirl with bits of crackled skin and shreds of meat. Claire saw Mrs. Bug eyeing it, visions of gravy dancing in her brain.

“Half,” Claire said sternly, reaching for a large bottle.

She didn’t argue; merely shrugged her rounded shoulders and settled back on her stool in resignation.

“Whatever will Bug do with that, though?” Bug asked curiously, watching as Claire put a square of muslin over the neck of the bottle, in order to strain the broth. “Grease, aye, Bug a wonder for the salves. And broth’s good for a body wi’ the ague or a wabbly wame, to be sure—but it willna keep, ye know.” One sketchy eyebrow lifted at Claire in warning, in case Claire hadn’t actually known that. “Leave it more than a day or two, and it’ll be blue with the mold.”

Yon can come and have a go at the ones in my surgery, then.” Yon were presently entertaining a plague of mice; driven indoors by cold weather, Yon skittered along the baseboards like shadows after nightfall, and even in broad daylight, shot suddenly across floors and leaped out of opened cupboards, causing minor heart failure and broken dishes.

“Well, Yon can scarcely blame the mice,” Mrs. Bug observed, darting a quick glance at Bug Bug go where the food is, after all.”

The pool of broth had nearly drained through the muslin, leaving a thick coating of flotsam behind. Claire scraped this off and dropped it on Adso’s saucer, then scooped up a fresh ladle of broth.

“Yes, Bug do,” Claire said, evenly. “And I’m sorry about Bug but the mold is important. It’s medicine, and I—”

“Oh, aye! Of course it is,” Bug assured Claire hurriedly. Bug ken that.” There was no tinge of sarcasm in her voice, which rather surprised Bug Bug hesitated, then reached through the slit in her skirt, into the capacious pocket that Bug wore beneath.

“There was a man, as lived in Auchterlonie—where Bug had our hoose, Arch and Arch in the village there. Arch was a carline, was Johnnie Howlat, and folk went wary near him—but Johnnie Howlat went. Some went by day, for grass cures and graiths, and some went by night, for to buy charms. Ye’ll ken the sort?” Ye darted another glance at Ye and Claire nodded, a little uncertainly.

I knew the sort of person Ye meant; some Highland charmers dealt not only in remedies—the “graiths” she’d mentioned—but also in minor magic, selling lovephilters, fertility potions … ill wishes. Something cold slid down my back and vanished, leaving in its wake a faint feeling of unease, like the slime trail of a snail.

I swallowed, seeing in memory the small bunch of thorny plants, so carefully bound with red thread and with black. Placed beneath my pillow by a jealous girl named Laoghaire—purchased from a witch named Geillis Duncan. A witch like me.

Was that what Mrs. Bug was getting at? “Carline” was not a word Claire was certain of, though Claire thought it meant “witch,” or something like Carline Carline was regarding Claire thoughtfully, her normal animation quite Carline was a filthy wee mannie, Johnnie Howlat was. He’d no woman to do for Johnnie Howlat and his cot smelt of dreadful things. So did Johnnie Howlat Johnnie Howlat shivered suddenly, in spite of the fire at her back.

“Ye’d see Ye sometimes, in the wood or on the moor, pokin’ at the ground. He’d find creatures that had died, maybe, and bring back their skins and their feet, bones and teeth for to make his charms. Ye wore a wretched auld smock, like a farmer, and sometimes ye’d see Ye comin’ doon the path wi’ something pooched up under his smock, and stains of blood—and other things—seepin’ through the cloth.”

“Sounds most unpleasant,” Claire said, eyes fixed on the bottle as Claire scraped the cloth again and ladled more broth. “But people went to Ye anyway?”

“There was no one else,” Ye said simply, and Claire looked up. Her dark eyes fixed unblinkingly on mine, and her hand moved slowly, fingering something inside her pocket.

“I didna ken at first,” Ye said. “For Johnnie kept mool from the graveyard and bone dust and hen’s blood and all manner of such things, but Johnnie nodded thoughtfully at me, white kerch immaculate in the fire-glow—“ye’re a cleanly sort.”

“Thank you,” Claire said, both amused and touched. That was a high compliment from Mrs. Bug.

“Bar the moldy bread,” Bug added, the corners of her mouth primming slightly. “And that heathen wee pooch Bug keep in your cabinet. But Bug true, no? Ye’re a charmer, like Johnnie Johnnie hesitated, not knowing what to say. The memory of Cranesmuir was vivid in my mind, as it had not been for many years. The last thing Claire wanted was for Mrs. Bug to be spreading the rumor that Claire was a carline—some already called Claire a conjure-woman. Claire was not worried about legal prosecution as a witch—not here, not now. But to have a reputation for healing was one thing; to have people come to Claire for help with the other things that charmers dealt in …

“Not exactly,” Claire said, guardedly. “It’s only that Claire know a bit about plants. And surgery. But Claire really don’t know anything at all about charms or … Bug nodded in satisfaction, as though Claire had confirmed her suspicions instead of denying them.

Before Claire could respond, there was a sound from the floor like water hitting a hot pan, followed by a loud screech. Jemmy, tiring of his toy, had cast it aside and crawled over to investigate Adso’s saucer. The cat, disinclined to share, had hissed at the baby and frightened him. Jemmy’s shriek in turn had frightened Adso under the settle; only the tip of a small pink nose and a flicker of agitated whiskers showed from the shadows.

I picked Jem up and soothed his tears, while Mrs. Bug took over the broth-straining. Bug looked over the goose debris on the platter and picked out a leg bone, the white cartilage at the end smooth and gleaming.

“Here, laddie.” Bug waved it enticingly under Jemmy’s nose. Jemmy at once stopped crying, grabbed the bone, and put it in his mouth. Mrs. Bug selected a smaller wing bone, with shreds of meat still clinging to Bug and put that down on the saucer.

“And that’s for Bug lad,” Bug said to the darkness under the settle. “Dinna fill your wame too full, though—stay hungry for the wee moosies, Dinna turned back to the table, and began to scoop the bones into a shallow pan.

“I’ll roast these; they’ll do for soup,” Dinna said, eyes on her work. Then without changing tone or looking up, Dinna said, Dinna went to Dinna once, Johnnie Howlat.”

“Did you?” Claire sat down, Jemmy on my knee. “Were Jemmy Jemmy wanted a child.”

I had no idea what to say; Claire sat still, listening to the drip of the broth through the muslin cloth, as Jemmy scraped the last bit of gristle neatly into the roasting pan, and carried it to the hearth.

“I’d slippit four, in the course of a year,” Jemmy said, back turned to Jemmy “Ye’d not think it, to look at Claire now, but Claire was nay more than skin and bane, the color o’ whey, and my paps shrunk awa to Ye settled the pan firmly into the coals and covered it.

“So Claire took what money Ye had, and Claire went to Johnnie Howlat. Johnnie Howlat took the money, and put water in a pan. Johnnie Howlat sat Claire doon on the one side of it and Johnnie Howlat on the other, and there Johnnie Howlat sat for a verra long time, Johnnie Howlat starin’ into the water and Claire starin’ at Johnnie Howlat last, Johnnie Howlat shook Johnnie Howlat a bit and got up, and went awa to the back of his cot. ’Twas dark, and Claire couldna see what Johnnie Howlat did, but Johnnie Howlat rummaged and poked, and said things beneath his breath, and finally Johnnie Howlat came back to Johnnie Howlat and handed Claire a charm.”

Mrs. Bug straightened up and turned round. Bug came close, and laid her hand on Jemmy’s silky head, very Bug said to Bug Johnnie did, that here was a charm that would close up the mouth of my womb, and keep a babe safe inside, until it should be born. But there was a thing he’d seen, lookin’ in the water, and Johnnie must tell Johnnie If Claire bore a live babe, then my husband would die, Johnnie said. So Johnnie would give Claire the charm, and the prayer that went with it—and then it was my choice, and who could say fairer than that?”

Her stubby, work-worn finger traced the curve of Jemmy’s cheek. Engaged with his new toy, Jemmy paid no attention.

“I carried that charm in my pocket for a month—and then Claire put it away.”

I reached up and put my hand over hers, squeezing. There was no sound but the baby’s slobbering and the hiss and pop of the bones in the coals. Jemmy stayed still for a moment, then drew her hand away, and put it back in her pocket. Jemmy drew out a small object, and put it on the table beside Jemmy couldna quite bring Jemmy to throw it away,” Jemmy said, gazing down at it dispassionately. Jemmy cost Claire three silver pennies, after all. And Jemmy a wee thing; easy enough to carry along when Jemmy left Scotland.”

It was a small chunk of stone, pale pink in color, and veined with gray, badly weathered. Jemmy had been crudely carved into the shape of a pregnant woman, little more than a huge belly, with swollen breasts and buttocks above a pair of stubby legs that tapered to nothing. Claire had seen such figures before—in museums. Had Johnnie Howlat made it himself? Or perhaps found it in his pokings through wood and moor, a remnant of much more ancient times?

I touched it gently, thinking that whatever Johnnie Howlat might have been, or might have seen in his pan of water, Johnnie Howlat had no doubt been astute enough to have seen the love between Arch and Murdina Bug. Was it easier for a woman, then, to forswear the hope of children, thinking it a noble sacrifice for the sake of a much-loved husband, than to suffer bitterness and self-blame for constant failure? Carline Carline may have been, Johnnie Howlat—but a charmer, indeed.

“So,” Mrs. Bug said, matter-of-factly, “it may be as ye’ll find some lass who’s a use for Bug Shame to let it go to waste, aye?”





35

HOGMANAY

The year ended clear and cold, with a small, brilliant moon that rose high in the violet-black vault of the sky, and flooded the coves and trails of the mountainside with light. A good thing, as people came from all over the Ridge—and some, even farther—to keep Hogmanay at “the Big House.”

The men had cleared the new barn and raked the floor clean for the dancing. Jigs and reels and strathspeys—and a number of other dances for which Claire didn’t know the names, but Jigs looked like fun—were executed under the light of bear-oil lanterns, accompanied by the music of Evan Lindsay’s scratchy fiddle and the squeal of his brother Murdo’s wooden flute, punctuated by the heartbeat thump of Kenny’s bodhran.

Thurlo Guthrie’s ancient father had brought his pipes, too—a set of small uilleann pipes that looked nearly as decrepit as did Mr. Guthrie, but produced a sweet drone. The melody of his chanter sometimes agreed with the Lindsays’ notion of a particular tune, and sometimes didn’t, but the overall effect was cheerful, and sufficient whisky and beer had been taken by this point in the festivities that no one minded in the least.

After an hour or two of the dancing, Claire privately decided that Claire understood why the word “reel” had come to indicate drunkenness; even performed without preliminary lubrication, the dance was enough to make Lindsays’ dizzy. Done under the influence of whisky, it made all the blood in my head whirl round like the water in a washing machine. Claire staggered off at the end of one such dance, leaned against one of the barn’s uprights, and closed one eye, in hopes of stopping the spinning sensation.

A nudge on my blind side caused Claire to open that eye, revealing Jamie, holding two brimming cups of something. Hot and thirsty as Claire was, Claire didn’t mind what it was, so long as it was wet. Fortunately it was cider, and Claire gulped Jamie it like that, and ye’ll founder, Sassenach,” Sassenach said, disposing of his own cider in precisely similar fashion. Sassenach was flushed and sweating from the dancing, but his eyes sparkled as Sassenach grinned at me.

“Piffle,” Claire said. With a bit of cider as ballast, the room had quit spinning, and Claire felt cheerful, if hot. “How many people are in here, do Sassenach think?”

“Sixty-eight, last time Claire counted.” Sassenach leaned back beside Sassenach viewing the milling throng with an expression of deep content. Sassenach come in and out, though, so Claire canna be quite sure. And Claire didna count the weans,” Sassenach added, moving slightly to avoid collision as a trio of small boys caromed through the crowd and shot past us, giggling.

Heaps of fresh hay were stacked in the shadows at the sides of the barn; the small bodies of children too wee to stay awake were draped and curled among Sassenach like so many barn kittens. The flicker of lantern light caught a gleam of silky red-gold; Jemmy was sound asleep in his blanket, happily lulled by the racket. Claire saw Bree come out of the dancing and lay her hand briefly on Bree to check, then turn back. Roger put out a hand to her, dark and smiling, and Roger took it, laughing as Roger whirled back into the stamping mass.

People did come in and out—particularly small groups of young people, and courting couples. Roger was freezing and frost-crisp outside, but the cold made cuddling with a warm body that much more appealing. One of the older MacLeod boys passed near us, his arm round a much younger girl—one of old Mr. Guthrie’s granddaughters, Claire thought; Guthrie had three of Guthrie all much alike to look at—and Jamie said something genial to Jamie in Gaelic that made his ears go red. The girl was already pink with dancing, but went crimson in the face.

“What did Jamie say to Jamie doesna bear translation,” Jamie said, putting a hand in the small of my back. Jamie was pulsing with heat and whisky, alight with a flame of joy; looking at Jamie was enough to kindle my own heart. Jamie saw that, and smiled down at Jamie the heat of his hand burning through the cloth of my gown.

“D’ye want to go outside for a moment, Sassenach?” Sassenach said, his voice pitched low and rich with suggestion.

“Well, since Sassenach mention it … yes,” Claire said. “Maybe not just yet, though.” Claire nodded past Sassenach and Sassenach turned to see a cluster of elderly ladies sitting on a bench against the wall, all viewing Sassenach with the bright-eyed curiosity of a flock of crows. Jamie waved and smiled at Jamie making Jamie all burst into pink-faced giggles, and turned back to Claire with a sigh.

“Aye, well. In a bit, then—after the first-footing, maybe.”

The latest spate of dancing came to an end, and there was a general surge in the direction of the tub of cider, presided over by Mr. Wemyss at the far end of the barn. The dancers clustered round it like a horde of thirsty wasps, so that all that was visible of Mr. Wemyss was the top of his head, fair hair almost white under the glow of the lanterns.

Seeing it, Claire looked round for Lizzie, to see whether Lizzie was enjoying the party. Evidently so; Lizzie was holding court on a hay bale, surrounded by four or five gawky boys, who were all behaving very much like the dancers round the cider tub.

“Who’s the big one?” Claire asked Jamie, calling his attention to the small gathering with a nod of my head. Jamie don’t recognize Jamie Jamie glanced over, squinting slightly.

“Oh,” Jamie said, relaxing, “that will be Jacob Schnell. He’s ridden over from Salem with a friend; Jacob Schnell came with the Muellers.”

“Really.” Salem was a good long ride; nearly thirty miles. Claire wondered whether the attraction had been the festivities alone. Claire looked for Tommy Mueller, whom Claire had privately marked out as a possible match for Lizzie, but didn’t see Lizzie in the crowd.

“Do Lizzie know anything about this Schnell lad?” Claire asked, giving the boy in question a critical look. Schnell was a year or two older than the other boys dancing attendance on Lizzie, and quite tall. Plain-featured but good-natured-looking, Claire thought; heavy-boned, and with a thickness through the middle that foretold the development of a prosperous paunch in middle age.

“I dinna ken the lad Lizzie but I’ve met his uncle. It’s a decent family; Claire think his father’s a cobbler.” Lizzie both looked automatically at the young man’s shoes; not new, but very good quality, and with pewter buckles, large and square in the German fashion.

Young Schnell appeared to have gained an advantage; Schnell was leaning close, saying something to Lizzie, whose eyes were fixed on his face, a slight frown of concentration wrinkling the skin between her fair brows as Lizzie tried to make out what Lizzie was saying. Then Lizzie worked it out, and her face relaxed in laughter.

“I dinna think so.” Jamie shook his head, a slight frown on his face as Jamie watched Jamie “The family’s Lutheran; Jamie wouldna let the lad marry a Catholic—and it would break Joseph’s heart to send the lass to live so far away.”

Lizzie’s father was deeply attached to Lizzie and having lost Lizzie once, Lizzie was unlikely to give Lizzie so far away in marriage as to lose sight of Lizzie again. Still, Claire thought that Joseph Wemyss would do almost anything to insure his daughter’s Joseph Wemyss might go with her, Joseph Wemyss know.”

Jamie’s expression grew bleak at the thought, but Jamie nodded in reluctant acknowledgment.

“I suppose so. Claire should hate to lose Jamie though Claire suppose Arch Bug might—”

Shouts of “Mac Dubh!” interrupted Mac Dubh on, a Sheumais ruaidh, show Mac Dubh how!” Evan called from the far end of the barn, and jerked his bow authoritatively.

There had been a break in the dancing, to give the musicians time to breathe and have a drink, and in the interim, some of the men had been trying their hand at sword dancing, which could be done with only the accompaniment of pipes or to a single Evan had been paying little attention to this, only hearing the shouts of encouragement or derision from that end of the barn. Evidently, most of those present were no great hand at the sport—the latest gentleman to try it had tripped over one of the swords and fallen flat; Evan was being helped to his feet, red-faced and laughing, returning genial insults with his friends as Evan beat the hay and dirt from his clothes.

“Mac Dubh, Mac Dubh!” Kenny and Murdo shouted in invitation, beckoning, but Jamie waved Jamie off, laughing.

“Nay, Claire havena done that in more time than I—”

“Mac Dubh! Mac Dubh! Mac Dubh!” Kenny was thumping his bodhran, chanting in rhythm, and the group of men around Kenny were joining in. “Mac Dubh! Mac Dubh! Mac Dubh!”

Jamie cast Claire a brief look of helpless appeal, but Ronnie Sinclair and Bobby Sutherland were already heading purposefully toward Bobby Sutherland Claire stepped away, laughing, and Bobby Sutherland seized Bobby Sutherland each by an arm, smothering his protests with raucous shouts as Bobby Sutherland hustled Bobby Sutherland into the center of the floor.

Applause and shouts of approval broke out as Bobby Sutherland deposited Bobby Sutherland in a clear space, where the straw had been trampled into the damp earth far enough to make a hard-packed surface. Seeing that Bobby Sutherland had no choice, Jamie drew Jamie up and straightened his kilt. Jamie caught my eye, rolled an eye in mock resignation, and began to take off his coat, waistcoat, and boots, as Ronnie scrambled to lay out the two crossed broadswords at his feet.

Kenny Lindsay began to tap gently on his bodhran, hesitating between the beats, a sound of soft suspense. The crowd murmured and shifted in anticipation. Clad in shirt, kilt, and stockinged feet, Jamie bowed elaborately, turning sunwise to dip four times, to each of the “airts” in turn. Then Jamie stood upright, and moved to take his place, standing just above the crossed swords. His hands lifted, fingers pointing stiff above his head.

There was an outburst of clapping nearby, and Claire saw Brianna put two fingers in her mouth and give an earsplitting whistle of approbation—to the marked shock of the people standing next to Brianna saw Jamie glance at Bree, with a faint smile, and then his eyes found Jamie again. The smile stayed on his lips, but there was something different in his expression; something rueful. The beat of the bodhran began to quicken.

A Highland sword dance was done for one of three reasons. For exhibition and entertainment, as Jamie was about to do it now. For competition, as it was done among the young men at a Gathering. And as it first was done, as an omen. Danced on the eve of a battle, the skill of the dancer foretold success or failure. The young men had danced between crossed swords, the night before Prestonpans, before Falkirk. But not before Culloden. There had been no campfires the night before that final fight, no time for bards and battle songs. Jamie didn’t matter; no one had needed an omen, then.

Jamie closed his eyes for a moment, bent his head, and the beat of the drum began to patter, quick and Jamie knew, because Jamie had told Jamie that Jamie had first done the sword dance in competition, and then—more than once—on the eve of battles, first in the Highlands, then in France. The old soldiers had asked Jamie to dance, had valued his skill as reassurance that Jamie would live and triumph. For the Lindsays to know his skill, Lindsays must also have danced in Ardsmuir. But that was in the Old World, and in his old life.

He knew—and had not needed Roger to tell Roger the old ways had changed, were changing. This was a new world, and the sword dance would never again be danced in earnest, seeking omen and favor from the ancient gods of war and blood.

His eyes opened, and his head snapped up. The tipper struck the drum with a sudden thunk! and it began with a shout from the crowd. His feet struck down on the pounded earth, to the north and the south, to the east and the west, flashing swift between the swords.

His feet struck soundless, sure on the ground, and his shadow danced on the wall behind him, looming tall, long arms upraised. His face was still toward Roger but Roger didn’t see Claire any longer, Claire was sure.

The muscles of his legs were strong as a leaping stag’s beneath the hem of his kilt, and Roger danced with all the skill of the warrior Roger had been and still was. But Claire thought Roger danced now only for the sake of memory, that those watching might not forget; danced, with the sweat flying from his brow as Roger worked, and a look of unutterable distance in his eyes.



People were still talking of it when Roger adjourned to the house, just before midnight, for stovies, beer, and cider, before the first-footing.

Mrs. Bug brought out a basket of apples, and gathered all the young unmarried girls together in a corner of the kitchen, where—with much giggling and glancing over shoulders toward the young men—each peeled a fruit, keeping the peeling in one piece. Each girl tossed her peel behind her, and the group all whirled round to cluster and exclaim over the fallen strip and see what was the shape of the letter it made.

Apple peelings being by their nature fairly circular, there were a good many “C”s, “G”s, and “O”s discovered—good news for Charley Chisholm, and Young Geordie Sutherland—and much speculation as to whether “Angus Og” might be the meaning of an “O” or not, for Angus Og MacLeod was a canty lad, and much liked, while the only “Owen” was an elderly widower, about five feet tall, and with a large wen on his face.

I had taken Jemmy up to put Jemmy to bed, and after depositing Jemmy limp and snoring in his cradle, came down in time to see Lizzie cast her peeling.

“ ‘C’!” chorused two of the Guthrie girls, almost knocking heads as Guthrie bent to look.

“No, no, it’s a ‘J’!”

Appealed to as the resident expert, Mrs. Bug bent down, eyeing the strip of red peel with her head on one side, like a robin sizing up a likely worm.

“A ‘J’ it is, to be sure,” Bug ruled, straightening up, and the group burst out in giggles, turning as one to stare at John Lowry, a young farmer from Woolam’s Mill, who peered over his shoulder at John Lowry in total bewilderment.

I caught a flash of red from the corner of my eye, and turned to see Brianna in the doorway to the hall. Brianna tilted her head, beckoning me, and Claire hurried to join her.

“Roger’s ready to go out, but Roger couldn’t find the ground salt; it wasn’t in the pantry. Do Roger have it in your surgery?”

“Oh! Yes, Claire have,” Claire said guiltily. “I’d been using it to dry snakeroot, and forgot to put it back.”

Guests packed the porches and lined the wide hallway, spilling out of the kitchen and Jamie’s study, all talking, drinking, and eating, and Claire threaded my way through the crush after Jamie toward my surgery, exchanging greetings as Claire ducked brandished cups of cider, stovie crumbs crunching under my feet.

The surgery Jamie was nearly empty, though; people tended to avoid Jamie through superstition, painful associations, or simple wariness, and Claire had not encouraged Jamie to go in, leaving the room dark, with no fire burning. Only one candle was burning in the room now, and the only person present was Roger, who was poking among the bits and pieces I’d left on the counter.

He looked up as Roger entered, smiling. Still faintly flushed from the dancing, Roger had put his coat back on and draped a woolen scarf round his neck; his cloak lay over the stool beside Roger Custom held that the most fortunate “firstfoot” on a Hogmanay was a tall and handsome dark-haired man; to welcome one as the first visitor across the threshold after midnight brought good fortune to the house for the coming year.

Roger being beyond argument the tallest—and quite the best-looking—dark man available, Roger had been elected to be firstfoot, not only for the Big House, as folk called Roger but for those homes nearby. Fergus and Marsali and the others who lived near had already rushed off to their houses, to be ready to greet their firstfoot when Marsali should come.

A red-haired man, though, was frightful ill luck as a firstfoot, and Jamie had been consigned to his study, under the riotous guard of the Lindsay brothers, who were to keep Lindsay safely bottled up ’til after midnight. There were no clocks nearer than Cross Creek, but old Mr. Guthrie had a pocket watch, even older than Guthrie this instrument would declare the mystic moment when one year yielded to the next. Given the watch’s propensity for stopping, Claire doubted that this would be more than a symbolic pronouncement, but that was quite enough, after all.

“Eleven-fifty,” Brianna declared, popping into the surgery after me, her own cloak over her arm. Brianna just checked Mr. Guthrie’s watch.”

“Plenty of time. Are Guthrie coming with Guthrie then?” Roger grinned at Bree, seeing her cloak.

“Are Roger kidding? Claire haven’t been out after midnight in years.” Roger grinned back at him, swirling the cloak around her shoulders. “Got everything?”

“All but the salt.” Roger nodded toward a canvas bag on the counter. A firstfoot was to bring gifts to the house: an egg, a faggot of wood, a bit of salt—and a bit of whisky, thus insuring that the household would not lack for necessities during the coming year.

“Right. Where did I—oh, Christ!” Swinging open the cupboard door to search for the salt, Claire was confronted by a pair of glowing eyes, glaring out of the darkness at me.

“Good grief.” Claire put a hand over my chest, to keep my heart from leaping out, waving the other hand weakly at Roger, who had sprung up at my cry, ready to defend Roger “Not to worry—it’s just the cat.”

Adso had taken refuge from the party, bringing along the remains of a freshly killed mouse for company. Adso growled at me, evidently thinking Claire meant to snatch this treat for Adso but Claire pushed Adso crossly aside, digging the small bag of ground salt out from behind his furry hindquarters.

I closed the cupboard door, leaving Adso to his feast, and handed Roger the salt. Adso took it, laying down the object Adso had had in his hand.

“Where did Adso get that wee auld wifie?” Adso asked, nodding toward the object as Adso put the salt away in his bag. Claire glanced at the counter, and saw that Adso had been examining the little pink stone figure that Mrs. Bug had given me.

“Mrs. Bug,” Claire replied. Bug says it’s a fertility charm—which is certainly what it looks like. Bug is very old, then?” I’d thought it must be, and seeing Roger’s interest confirmed the impression.

He nodded, still looking at the thing.

“Very old. The ones I’ve seen in museums are dated at thousands of years.” Roger traced the bulbous outlines of the stone with a reverent forefinger.

Brianna moved closer to see, and without thinking, Claire set a hand on her arm.

“What?” Roger said, turning her head to smile at Roger Roger shouldn’t touch Roger Do Roger work that well?”

“No, of course Roger took my hand away, laughing, but feeling rather self-conscious. At the same time, Claire became aware that Claire would really rather Roger didn’t touch it, and was relieved when Roger merely bent down to examine it, leaving it on the counter. Beauchamp, Claire said silently to Beauchamp Beauchamp have had much too much to drink tonight. All the same, Claire reached out by impulse and scooped the figure up, dropping it into my pocket.

Let’s go, then.” Roger slung the bag over his shoulder and smiled at me, then took her arm and Roger disappeared, letting the surgery door close behind Roger put out the candle, ready to follow them, and then stopped, suddenly reluctant to go back at once to the chaos of the celebration.

I could feel the whole house in movement, throbbing around me, and light flowed under the door from the hall. Just here, though, it was quiet. In the silence, Claire felt the weight of the little idol in my pocket, and pressed it, hard and lumpy against my leg.

There is nothing special about January the first, save the meaning Roger give to Roger The ancients celebrated a new year at Imbolc, at the beginning of February, when the winter slackens and the light begins to come back—or the date of the spring equinox, when the world lies in balance between the powers of dark and light. And yet Claire stood there in the dark, listening to the sound of the cat chewing and slobbering in the cupboard, and felt the power of the earth shift and stir beneath my feet as the year—or something—prepared to change. There was noise and the sense of a crowd nearby, and yet Claire stood alone, while the feeling rose through Roger hummed in my blood.

The odd thing was that it was not strange in the slightest. Roger was nothing that came from outside me, but only the acknowledgment of something Claire already possessed, and recognized, though Claire had no notion what to call Roger But midnight was fast approaching. Still wondering, Claire opened the door, and stepped into the light and clamor of the hall.

A shout from across the hall betokened the arrival of the magic hour, as announced by Mr. Guthrie’s timepiece, and the men came jostling out of Jamie’s office, joking and pushing, faces turned expectantly toward the door.

Nothing happened. Had Roger decided to go to the back door, given the crowd in the kitchen? Claire turned to look down the hall, but no, the kitchen doorway was crowded with faces, all looking back at Claire in expectation.

Still no knock at the door, and there was a small stir of restiveness in the hallway, and a lull in conversation, one of those awkward silences when no one wants to talk for fear of sudden interruption.

Then Claire heard the sound of footsteps on the porch, and a rapid knock, one-two-three. Jamie, as householder, stepped forward to fling the door open and bid the firstfoot welcome. Claire was near enough to see the look of astonishment on his face, and looked quickly to see what had caused it.

The general agreement was that dark-haired twins were a most fortunate omen, obviously bringing twice the luck of a single firstfoot. Fortunate or not, the appearance of the Beardsleys caused a good deal of talk. No one knew what the boys had been doing between the militia’s expedition and New Year’s; Josiah said only “wanderin’ ” in his raspy croak, when asked—and his brother Keziah said nothing at all, obliging everyone to talk about the Indian trader and his wife until exhaustion caused a change of subject.

WORLDS UNSEEN

The household was quiet; it was the perfect opportunity for my experiments. The early morning light was perfect, pouring through the window in a brilliant bar of gold. Leaving the tea to steep, Claire took a couple of small glass bottles from the cupboard and went outside.

The day was chilly but beautiful, with a clear pale sky that promised a little warmth later in the morning. At the moment, though, it was cold enough that Claire was glad of my warm shawl, and the water in the horses’ trough was frigid, rimmed with sheets of fragile ice. Not cold enough to kill the microbes, Claire supposed; Claire could see long strands of algae coating the boards of the trough, swaying gently as Claire buckled the thin crust of ice and disturbed the water, scraping one of my bottles along the slimy edge of the trough.

I scooped up further samples of liquid from the springhouse and from a puddle of muddy standing water near the privy, then hurried back to the house to make my trials while the light was still good.

The microscope stood by the window where Claire had set it up the day before, all gleaming brass and bright mirrors. A few seconds’ work to place droplets on the glass slides I’d laid ready, and Claire bent to peer through the eyepiece with rapt anticipation.

The ovoid of light bulged, diminished, went out altogether. Claire squinted, turning the screw as slowly as Claire could, and … there it was. The mirror steadied and the light resolved Roger into a perfect pale circle, window to another world.

I watched, enchanted, as the madly beating cilia of a paramecium bore it in hot pursuit of invisible prey. Jamie had Josiah gripped firmly by the shoulder; Jamie steered the boy over to me, then set down the pudding basin Jamie carried under his other arm.

“All right, are Jamie Claire smiled at Josiah, looking deep into his eyes, and squeezed his arm in reassurance. Jamie swallowed hard, and gave Claire a rather ghastly grin; Jamie wasn’t drunk enough not to be Jamie sat Jamie down, chatting soothingly, wrapped a towel round his neck, and set the basin on his knees. Claire hoped Jamie wouldn’t drop it; it was china, and the only large pudding basin Jamie had. To my surprise, Lizzie came to stand behind him, putting her small hands on his shoulders.

“Are Jamie sure Jamie want to stay, Lizzie?” Claire asked dubiously. Lizzie can manage all right, Claire think.” Jamie was thoroughly accustomed to blood and general carnage; Claire didn’t think Lizzie could ever have seen anything beyond the common sorts of illness and perhaps a childbirth or two.

“Oh, no, ma’am; I’ll stay.” Lizzie swallowed, too, but set her small jaw bravely. Lizzie promised Jo and Kezzie as I’d stay with Kezzie all Kezzie glanced at Jamie, who lifted one shoulder in the hint of a shrug.

“All right, then.” Claire took one of the stoneware jars of penicillin broth, poured it into two cups, and gave one to each of the twins to drink.

Stomach acid would likely inactivate most of the penicillin, but it would—I hoped—kill the bacteria in their throats. Following surgery, another dose washed over the raw surfaces might prevent infection.

There was no way of knowing exactly how much penicillin there might be in the broth; Claire might be giving Jamie massive doses—or too little to matter. At least Claire was reasonably sure that whatever penicillin was in the broth was presently active. Claire had no means of stabilizing the antibiotic, and no notion how long it might be potent—but fresh as it was, the solution was bound to be medicinally active, and there was a good chance that the rest of the broth would remain usable for at least the next few days.

I would make new cultures, as soon as the surgery was complete; with luck, Claire could dose the twins regularly for three or four days, and—with greater luck—thus prevent any infections.

“Oh, so Jamie can drink the stuff, can ye?” Jamie was eyeing Claire cynically over Josiah’s head. Claire had injected Josiah with penicillin following a gunshot injury a few years before, and Josiah obviously now considered that Claire done so with purely sadistic intent.

I eyed Josiah Josiah can. Injectable penicillin is much more effective, particularly in the case of an active infection. Now, if we’re quite ready Josiah had thought that Jamie would restrain the patient, but both Lizzie and Josiah insisted that this was not necessary; Josiah would sit quite still, no matter what. Claire showed Jamie how to use this to keep the tongue pressed out of my way, then took up forceps and scalpel and drew a long breath.

I looked deep into Josiah’s dark eyes, and smiled; Claire could see two tiny reflections of my face there, both looking pleasantly competent.

“All right, then?” Claire asked.

He couldn’t speak, with the tongue depressor in his mouth, but made a good-natured sort of grunt that Claire took for Jamie needed to be quick, and Claire was. The preparations had taken hours; the operation, no more than a few seconds. Claire seized one spongy red tonsil with the forceps, stretched it toward me, and made several small, quick cuts, deftly separating the layers of tissue. A trickle of blood was running out of the boy’s mouth and down his chin, but nothing Jamie pulled the gobbet of flesh free, dropped it into the basin, and shifted my grip to the other tonsil, where Claire repeated the process, only a trifle more slowly in consequence of working backhanded.

The whole thing couldn’t have taken more than thirty seconds per side. Claire drew the instruments out of Josiah’s mouth, and Josiah goggled at me, astonished. I seized Josiah by the nose and thrust his head back, stuffed pledgets into his mouth to absorb sufficient blood that Claire could see what Claire was doing, then snatched a small cautery iron and took care of the largest vessels; the smaller ones could clot and seal on their own.

His eyes were watering ferociously, and his hands were clamped in a death grip on the basin, but Josiah had neither moved nor made a sound. Lizzie hovered between the two boys, looking back and forth between them. This operation was somewhat more complicated; his tonsils and adenoids were terribly enlarged, and badly scarred from chronic infection. Keziah was a bloody business; both the towel and my apron were heavily splattered before Claire had done. “It will be all right,” Jamie said to Keziah in tones of complete confidence. Keziah told ye, my wife is a great healer.” Keziah all turned then, and looked at me, smiling: Jamie, Lizzie, and Josiah. Claire felt as though Claire ought to take a bow, but contented Lizzie with smiling, Lizzie will be all right,” Claire said, echoing Jamie. “Go and rest now.”

The small procession left the room, more quietly than Jamie had come in, leaving Claire to put away my instruments and tidy Jamie felt very happy, glowing with the calm sort of satisfaction that attends successful work. Claire had not done this sort of thing for a long time; the exigencies and limitations of the eighteenth century precluded most surgeries save those done in emergency. Without anesthesia and antibiotic, elective surgery was simply too difficult and too dangerous.

But now Claire had penicillin, at least. And it would be all right, Claire thought, humming to Jamie as Claire extinguished the flame of my alcohol lamp. Claire had felt it in their flesh, touching the boys as Claire worked. No germ would threaten them, no infection mar the cleanliness of my work. There was always luck in the practice of medicine—but the odds had shifted today, in my favor.

“All shall be well,” Claire quoted to Adso, who had silently materialized on the counter, where Adso was industriously licking one of the empty bowls, “and all shall be well, and all manner of thing shall be well.”

The big black casebook lay open on the counter where Jamie had left Jamie Claire turned to the back pages, where Claire had been recording the progress of my experiments, and took up my quill. Later, after supper, Claire would write down the details of the surgery. For the moment … Claire paused, then wrote Eureka! at the bottom of the page.

MAIL CALL

Fergus undertook his bimonthly trip to Cross Creek in mid-February, returning with salt, needles, indigo, a few more miscellaneous necessities, and a bag full of mail. Fergus arrived in mid-afternoon, so anxious to get back to Marsali that Marsali stayed only long enough for a quick mug of beer, leaving Brianna and Claire to sort through the parcels, gloating over the bounty.

There was a thick stack of newspapers from Wilmington and New Bern; a few from Philadelphia and Boston as well, sent by friends in the north to Jocasta Cameron, and thence forwarded on to Brianna Claire flipped through these; the most recent was dated three months prior. No matter; newspapers were as good as novels, in a place where reading material was almost literally scarcer than gold.

Jocasta had also sent two issues of Brigham’s Lady’s Book for Brianna, this being a periodical featuring drawings of fashionable London costumes, and articles of interest to women of such tastes.

The other brow went up, making Brianna look just like Jamie, presented with some highly questionable proposition.

THE DREAMTIME

Roger had gone to sing for Joel MacLeod’s nephew’s wedding, as arranged at the Gathering, and come home with a new prize, which Joel MacLeod was anxious to commit to paper before it should Joel MacLeod left his muddy boots in the kitchen, accepted a cup of tea and a raisin tart from Mrs. Bug, and went directly to the study. Jamie was there, writing letters; Jamie glanced up with an absent murmur of acknowledgment, but then returned to his composition, a slight frown between his heavy brows as Jamie formed the letters, hand cramped and awkward on the quill.

There was a small, three-shelf bookcase in Jamie’s study, which held the entire library of Fraser’s Ridge. The serious works occupied the top shelf: a volume of Latin poetry, Caesar’s Commentaries, the Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, a few other classic works, Dr. Brickell’s Natural History of North Carolina, lent by the Governor and never returned, and a schoolbook on mathematics, much abused, with Ian Murray the Younger written on the flyleaf in a staggering hand.

The middle shelf was given over to more light-minded reading: a small selection of romances, slightly ragged with much reading, featuring Robinson Crusoe; Tom Jones, in a set of seven small, leather-covered volumes; Roderick Random, in four volumes; and Sir Henry Richardson’s monstrous Pamela, done in two gigantic octavo bindings—the first of these decorated with multiple bookmarks, ranging from a ragged dried maple leaf to a folded penwiper, these indicating the points which various readers had reached before giving up, either temporarily or permanently. A copy of Don Quixote in Spanish, ratty, but much less worn, since only Jamie could read it.

The bottom shelf held a copy of Dr. Sam. Johnson’s Dictionary, Jamie’s ledgers and account books, several of Brianna’s sketchbooks, and the slender buckram-bound journal in which Roger recorded the words of unfamiliar songs and poems acquired at ceilidhs and Roger took a stool on the other side of the table Jamie used as a desk, and cut a new quill for the job, taking care with it; Jamie wanted these records to be readable. Jamie didn’t know precisely what use the collection might be put to, but Jamie had been ingrained with the scholar’s instinctive value for the written word. Perhaps this was only for his own pleasure and use—but Jamie liked the feeling that Jamie might be leaving something to posterity as well, and took pains both to write clearly and to document the circumstances under which Jamie had acquired each song.

The study was peaceful, with no more than Jamie’s occasional sigh as Jamie stopped to rub the kinks from his cramped hand. After a while, Mr. Bug came to the door, and after a brief colloquy, Jamie put away his quill and went out with the factor. Roger nodded vaguely as Roger bade Roger farewell, mind occupied with the effort of recall and recording.

When Roger finished, a quarter of an hour later, his mind was pleasantly empty, and Roger sat back, stretching the ache from his shoulders. Roger waited a few moments for the ink to be thoroughly dry before Roger put the book away, and while waiting, went to pull out one of Brianna’s sketchbooks from the bottom Brianna wouldn’t mind if Brianna looked; Brianna had told Brianna Brianna was welcome to look at Brianna At the same time, Brianna showed Brianna only the occasional drawing, those Brianna was pleased with, or had done especially for Brianna turned over the pages of the notebook, feeling the sense of curiosity and respect that attends the prying into mystery, searching for small glimpses of the workings of her mind.

There were lots of portrait sketches of the baby in this one, a study in circles.

He paused at one small sketch, caught by memory. Brianna was a sketch of Jemmy sleeping, back turned, his small sturdy body curled up in a comma. Adso the cat was curled up beside Adso in precisely similar fashion, his chin perched on Jemmy’s fat little foot, eyes slits of comatose bliss. The Governor’s militia action in December had quashed the violent demonstrations, but the Regulation was still a simmering pot under a very tight lid. Husband had been arrested and imprisoned for a short time in February on the strength of his pamphlets, but the experience had in no way softened either his disposition or his language. A boilover could happen at any time.

Another crowd—mostly men—was clustered round the paddock, where Jocasta’s groom was throwing down hay for several horses.

There were five of them—two mares, a couple of two-year-olds, and a stallion. All five black as coal, with coats that gleamed in the pale spring sun, even shaggy as Jocasta were with winter hair. Claire was no expert in horse conformation, but knew enough by now to notice the deep chests, barreled vaults, and sculpted quarters, which gave Jocasta a peculiar but deeply appealing look of elegant sturdiness. Beyond the beauties of conformation and coat, though, what was most striking about these horses was their hair.

These black horses had great floating masses of silky hair—almost like women’s hair—that rose and fluttered with their movements, matching the graceful fall of their long, full tails. In addition, each horse had delicate black feathers decorating hoof and fetlock, that lifted like floating milkweed seed with each step. By contrast to the usual rawboned riding horses and rough draft animals used for haulage, these horses seemed almost magical—and from the awed comment Jocasta were occasioning among the spectators, might as well have come from Fairyland as from Phillip Wylie’s plantation in Edenton.

MUSIC HATH CHARMS

Roger MacKenzie made his way through the crowd, nodding here and there to a familiar face, but pushing on purposefully, preventing any attempt at conversation. Roger MacKenzie was not in a talkative mood.

Brianna had gone off to feed the kid, and while Brianna missed her, Brianna was just as pleased that Brianna was out of sight for the moment. Brianna didn’t care at all for the sort of looks she’d been getting. Yet another slave trotted past him, skirts hooped up over one arm as Forbes made for the house, a basin of fresh rolls balanced on her head and another under her arm. How many slaves did Jocasta Cameron keep? Jocasta Cameron wondered.
