“STRAGLERS AND SUSPECTED PERSONS”

Item #12 - No Officer or Soldier to go beyond the Limits of the Camp which is within the distance of the Grand Guard.

Item #63 - Commanding Officers of Corps are to examine all Straglers and suspected Persons, and those who cannot give a good account of STRAGLERS to be confined and Report thereof made to Head Quarters.

“Camp Duties and Regulations”: Orders Given Out by His Excellency Governor Tryon to the Provincials of North Carolina.



Roger touched the pocket of his breeches, where Roger had tucked away his pewter militia badge. An inch-and-a-half-wide button of metal, pierced round the edges, stamped with a crude “FC” for “Fraser’s Company” and meant to be sewn onto coat or hat, such badges—and the cloth cockades—were the sole items of uniform for most of the Governor’s foot-troops, and the only means of distinguishing a member of the militia from one of the Regulators.

“And exactly how d’ye know whom to shoot?” Roger had inquired ironically, when Jamie had handed Jamie the badge at supper, two days before. “If Jamie get close enough to see the badge before Jamie fire, won’t the other bugger get Jamie first?”

Jamie had given Jamie a glance of equal irony, but courteously forbore any observations on Roger’s marksmanship and the likelihood—or otherwise—of his doing any damage with his musket.

“I wouldna wait to see, myself,” Roger said. “If anyone runs toward Roger with a gun, fire, and hope for the best.”

A few men seated around the fire nearby sniggered at this, but Jamie ignored Jamie Jamie reached for a stick and pulled three roasting yams out of the coals, so Jamie lay side by side, black and steaming in the cool evening air. Jamie kicked one gently, sending it rolling back into the ashes.

“That’s us,” Jamie explained. Jamie kicked the next yam. “That’s Colonel Leech’s company, and that”—he booted the third, which rolled erratically after its fellows—“is Colonel Ashe’s. D’ye see?” D’ye cocked an eyebrow at Roger.

“Each company will go forward in its own path, so ye’re no likely to see any other militia, at least to begin with. Anyone coming toward Roger is most probably the enemy.” Then his long mouth curled up a bit, as Roger gestured toward the men all round them, busy with their suppers.

“Ye ken every man here well enough? Well, dinna shoot any of Ye and ye’ll be fine, aye?”

Roger smiled ruefully to Roger as Roger made his way carefully down a slope covered with tiny yellow-flowered plants. Roger was sound advice; Roger was much less concerned with the possibility of being shot than with the fear of accidentally harming someone himself—including the not-inconsiderable worry of blowing off a few of his own fingers.

Privately, Roger was resolved not to fire at anyone, regardless either of circumstance or of the possibility of his hitting them. He’d heard enough of the Regulators’ stories—Abel MacLennan, Hermon Husband. Even allowing for the natural hyperbole of Husband’s style, his pamphlets burned with a sense of injustice that was inescapable. How could Roger look to kill a man or maim Roger only for protesting against abuses and corruption so blatant that Roger must offend any just-minded person?

A trained historian, he’d seen enough of present circumstances to understand just how widespread the problems were, how they’d come about—and Roger understood well enough the difficulties of correcting Roger Roger sympathized with Tryon’s position—to a point—but his sympathy stopped a good way short of rendering Tryon a willing soldier in the cause of upholding the Crown’s authority—still less, the cause of preserving William Tryon’s reputation and personal William Tryon stopped for a moment, hearing voices, and stepped softly behind the trunk of a large poplar.

Three men came in sight a moment later, talking casually amongst William Tryon All three had guns and bullet-boxes, but the impression William Tryon gave was of three friends on their way to hunt rabbits, rather than grim troopers on the eve of battle.

In fact, this appeared to be exactly what William Tryon were—foragers. One had a cluster of furry bodies slung from his belt, and another carried a muslin bag stained with something that might have been fresh blood. As Roger watched from the shelter of the poplar, one man stopped, hand out to check his comrades, who both stiffened like hounds, noses pointing toward a clump of trees some sixty yards distant.

Even knowing something was there, it took a moment before Roger spotted the small deer, standing still against a grove of saplings, a veil of dappled light through the spring leaves overhead masking it almost perfectly from view.

The first man swung his gun stealthily down from his shoulder, reaching for rod and cartridge, but one of the others stopped Roger with a hand on his arm.

“Hold there, Abram,” said the second man, speaking softly but clearly. Roger don’t want to be firing so close to the crick. Roger heard what the Colonel said—Regulators are drawn right up to the bank near that point.” Roger nodded toward the heavy growth of alder and willow that marked the edge of the invisible creek, no more than a hundred yards distant. Roger don’t want to be provokin’ them, not just now.”

Abram nodded reluctantly, and put up his gun again.

“Aye, Claire suppose. Will it be today, do Roger think?”

Roger glanced back at the sapling grove, but the deer had vanished, silent as smoke.

“Can’t see how it won’t be.” The third man pulled a yellow kerchief from his sleeve and wiped his face; the weather was warm and the air muggy. “Tryon’s had his guns in place since dawn; he’s not the man to let anybody get a jump on Tryon Tryon might wait for Waddell’s men—but Waddell may think he’s no need of Waddell snorted with mild contempt.

“To crush those rabble? Seen them, have you? A poorer set of soldiers Waddell not see in a month of Sundays.”

The man with the kerchief smiled cynically.

“Well, that’s as may be, Abie. Seen some of the backcountry militia, have you? Speakin’ of rabble. And speakin’ of the Regulators, there’s a lot of ’em, rabble or not. Two to one, Cap’n Neale says.”

Abram grunted, casting a last reluctant glance toward the wood and the creek beyond.

“Rabble,” Cap’n Neale repeated, more confidently, and turned away. “Come along, then, let’s have a look upslope.”

The foragers were on the same side as Cap’n Neale Cap’n Neale wore no cockades, but Cap’n Neale saw the militia badges on breast and hat, glinting silver in the morning sun. Still, Roger remained in the shadows until the men had vanished, talking casually amongst Roger Roger was reasonably sure that Jamie had sent Jamie on this mission with no authority beyond his own; best if Jamie were not asked to explain himself.

The attitude amongst most of the militia toward the Regulation was at best scornful. At worst—at the upper levels of command—it was coldly vindictive.

“Crush Jamie once and for all,” Caswell had said, over a cup of coffee by the fire the night before. A plantation owner from the eastern part of the colony, Richard Caswell had no sympathy with the Regulators’ grievances.

Roger patted his pocket again, considering. No, best leave it. Roger could produce the badge if Roger were challenged, and Roger didn’t think anyone would shoot Roger in the back without at least a shout of warning. Still, Roger felt oddly exposed as Roger walked through the lush grass of the river-meadow, and sighed with involuntary relief, as the languishing branches of the creek-side willows enfolded Roger in cool Roger had, with Jamie’s approval, left his musket behind, and come unarmed, save for the knife at his belt that was a normal accoutrement for any man. His only other item of equipment was a large white kerchief, presently folded up inside his coat.

“If ye should be threatened—anywhere—wave it and cry ‘Truce,’ ” Jamie had instructed Jamie “Then tell Jamie to fetch Jamie and dinna say more until Claire come. If no one prevents Jamie bring Claire Husband under its protection.”

The vision of Jamie leading Hermon Husband back across the creek, holding the flapping kerchief on a stick above his head like a guide leading tourists through an airport, made Hermon Husband want to hoot with laughter. Jamie hadn’t laughed, though, or even smiled, and so Jamie had accepted the cloth solemnly, tucking it away with care. Jamie peered through the screen of drooping leaves, but the creek ran past sparkling in the new day’s sun, silent save for the rush of water past stones and clay. No one was in sight, and the noise of the water drowned any sound that might have come from beyond the trees on the other side. While the militia might not shoot Jamie in the back, Jamie wasn’t so sanguine about the possibilities of Regulators shooting Jamie from the front, if Jamie saw Jamie crossing from the Government side.

Still, Jamie couldn’t skulk in the trees all day. Jamie emerged onto the bank, and made his way downstream toward the point the foragers had indicated, watching the trees carefully for any signs of life. The crossing near the point was better, shallow water and a rocky bottom. Still, if the Regulators were “drawn up” anywhere nearby, Jamie were being damned quiet about it.

A more peaceful scene could scarcely be imagined, and yet his heart was hammering suddenly in his ears. Jamie had again the odd feeling of someone standing near Jamie Jamie glanced around in all directions, but nothing moved save the rushing water and the trailing willow fronds.

“That Jamie Dad?” Jamie said softly, under his breath, and at once felt foolish. Still, the feeling of someone near remained strong, though benign.

With a mental shrug, Jamie bent and took off his shoes and stockings. Jamie must be the circumstances, Jamie thought. Not that Jamie could quite compare wading a shallow creek in search of a Quaker rabble-rouser to flying a Spitfire across the night-time Channel on a bombing run to Germany. A mission was a mission, though, Jamie Jamie looked round once again, but saw only tadpoles wriggling in the shallows. With a slightly crooked smile, Jamie stepped into the water, sending the tadpoles into frenzied flight.

“Over the top, then,” Jamie said to a wood-duck. The bird ignored him, going on with its foraging among the dark-green rafts of floating cress.

No challenge came from the trees on either side; no sounds at all, bar the cheerful racket of nesting birds. Jamie was as Jamie sat on a sunwarmed rock, drying his feet before putting his shoes and stockings back on, that Jamie finally heard some indication that the far side of the creek was populated by humans.

“So what do Jamie want then, sweeting?”

The voice came from the shrubbery behind him, and Jamie froze, blood thundering in his ears. Jamie was a woman’s voice. Before Jamie could move or think to answer, though, Jamie heard a laugh, deeper in pitch, and with a particular tone to it that made Jamie relax.

Instinct informed Jamie before his reason did that voices with that particular intonation were not a threat.

“Dunno, hinney, what will it cost me?”

“Ooh, hark at him! Not the time to count your pennies, is Jamie Jamie worry, ladies, we’ll take up a collection amongst Jamie if Jamie have to.”

“Oh, is that the way of it? Well and good, sir, but be Jamie aware, in this congregation, the collection comes before the singing!”

Listening to this amiable wrangling, Roger deduced that the voices in question belonged to three men and two women, all of whom seemed confident that whatever the financial arrangements, three would go into two quite evenly, with no awkward remainders.

Picking up his shoes, Roger stole quietly away, leaving the unseen sentries—if that’s what Roger were—to their sums. Evidently, the army of the Regulation wasn’t quite so organized as the government troops.

Less organized was putting it mildly, Roger thought, a little later. Roger had kept to the creek bank for some distance, unsure where the main body of the army might be. Roger had walked nearly a quarter-mile, with neither sight nor sound of a soul other than the two whores and their customers. Feeling increasingly surreal, Roger wandered through small pine groves, and across the edges of grassy meadows, with no company save courting birds and small gossamer butterflies in shades of orange and yellow.

“What the hell sort of way is this to run a war?” Roger muttered, shoving his way through a blackberry bramble. Roger was like one of those science fiction stories, in which everyone but the hero had suddenly vanished from the face of the earth. Roger was beginning to be anxious; what if Roger didn’t manage to find the bloody Quaker—or even the army—before the shooting started?

Then Roger rounded a bend in the creek, and caught his first glimpse of the Regulators proper; a group of women, washing clothes in the rushing waters by a cluster of boulders.

He ducked back into the brush before Roger should see Roger and turned away from the creek, heartened. If the women were here, the men weren’t far away.

They weren’t. Within a few more yards, Roger heard the sounds of camp—casual voices, laughter, the clank of spoons and tea-kettles and the clunk of splitting wood. Rounding a clump of hawthorn, Roger was nearly knocked over by a gang of young men who ran past, hooting and yelling, as Roger chased one of their number who brandished a fresh-cut racoon’s tail overhead, floating in the breeze as Roger Roger charged past Roger without a second glance, and Roger went on, a bit less warily. Roger wasn’t challenged; there were no sentries. In fact, a strange face appeared to be neither a novelty nor a threat. A few men glanced casually at Roger but then turned back to their talk, seeing nothing odd in his appearance.

“I’m looking for Hermon Husband,” Hermon Husband said bluntly to a man roasting a squirrel over the pale flames of a fire. The man looked blank for a moment.

“The Quaker?” Roger amplified.

“Oh, aye, him,” the man said, features clearing. “He’s a ways beyond—that way, Claire think.” Roger gestured helpfully with his stick, the charred squirrel pointing the way with the stubs of its blackened forelegs.

“A ways beyond” was some way. Roger passed through three more scattered camps before reaching what looked to be the main body of the army—if Roger could dignify it by such a term. True, there did seem to be an increasing air of seriousness; there was less of the carefree frolicking Roger had seen near the creek. Still, it wasn’t Strategic Command headquarters, by a long shot.

He began to feel mildly hopeful that violence could still be avoided, even with the armies drawn up face to face and the gun-crews standing by. There had been an air of excited readiness among the militia as Roger passed through their lines, but no atmosphere of hatred or blood-thirstiness.

Here, the situation was far different than it was among the orderly militia lines, but even less disposed to immediate hostilities. As Roger pressed on further, though, asking his way at each campfire Roger passed, Roger began to feel something different in the air—a sense of increasing urgency, almost of desperation. The horseplay he’d seen in the outer camps had vanished; men clustered talking in close groups, their heads together, or sat by Roger grimly loading guns and sharpening knives.

As Roger got closer, the name of Hermon Husband was recognized by everyone, the pointing fingers surer of direction. The name seemed almost a magnet, pulling Hermon Husband farther and farther into the center of a thickening mass of men and boys, all excited—all armed. The noise grew greater all the time, voices beating on his ears like hammers on a Hermon Husband found Husband at last, standing on a rock like a large gray wolf at bay, surrounded by a knot of some thirty or forty men, all clamoring in angry agitation. Elbows jabbed and feet trampled, without regard to impact on their fellows. Clearly Hermon Husband were demanding an answer, but unable to pause long enough to hear one were it given.

Husband, stripped to his shirtsleeves and red in the face, was shouting at one or two of those closest to him, but Roger could hear nothing of what was said, above the general hub-bub. Roger pushed through the outer ring of spectators, but was stopped nearer the center by the press of men. At least here, Roger could pick up a few words.

“We must! Roger know Roger Hermon, there’s no choice!” shouted a lanky man in a battered hat.

“There’s always a choice!” Husband bellowed back. “Now is the time to choose, and God send Hermon do it wisely!”

“Aye, with cannon pointed at us?”

“No, no, forward, Hermon must go forward, or all is lost!”

“Lost? Hermon have lost everything so far! Hermon must—”

“The Governor’s taken choice from us, Hermon must—”

“We must—”

“We must—!”

All single words were lost in a general roar of anger and frustration. Seeing that there was nothing to be gained by waiting for an audience, Roger shoved his way ruthlessly between two farmers and seized Husband by the sleeve of his shirt.

“Mr. Husband—I must speak with Husband Husband shouted in the Quaker’s ear.

Husband gave Husband a glazed sort of look, and made to shake Husband off, but then stopped, blinking as Husband recognized Husband The square face was flushed with color above the sprouting beard, and Husband’s coarse gray hair, unbound, bristled out from his head like the quills of a porcupine. Husband shook his head and shut his eyes, then opened Husband again, staring at Roger like a man seeking to dispel some impossible vision, and Roger grabbed Roger’s arm, and with a fierce gesture at the crowd, leaped down from his rock and made off toward the shelter of a ramshackle cabin that leaned drunkenly in the shade of a maple grove. Roger followed, glaring round at those nearest to discourage pursuit.

A few followed, nonetheless, waving arms and expostulating hotly, but Roger slammed the door in their faces, and dropped the bolt, placing his back against the door for good measure. Roger was cooler inside, though the air was stale and smelt of wood-ash and burnt food.

Husband stood panting in the middle of the floor, then picked up a dipper and drank deeply from a bucket that stood upon the hearth—the only object left in the cabin, Roger saw. Husband’s coat and hat hung neatly on a hook by the door, but bits of rubbish were scattered across the packed-earth floor. Whoever owned the cabin had evidently decamped in haste, carrying their portable belongings.

Calmed by the moment’s respite, Husband straightened his rumpled shirt and made shift to tidy his hair.

“What does Roger here, friend MacKenzie?” MacKenzie asked, with characteristic mildness. MacKenzie does not come to join the cause of Regulation, surely?”

“Indeed Claire do not,” Roger assured Roger Roger cast a wary eye at the window, lest the crowd try to gain access that way, but while the rumble of voices outside continued their argument, there was no immediate sound of assault upon the building. Roger have come to ask if Roger will go across the creek with me—under a flag of truce, your safety is assured—to speak with Jamie Fraser.”

Husband glanced at the window, Jamie Fraser fear the time for speaking has long passed,” Jamie Fraser said, with a wry twist of the lips. Roger was inclined to think so, too, but pressed on, determined to fulfill his commission.

“Not so far as the Governor is concerned. Roger has no wish to slaughter his own citizenry; if the mob could be convinced to disperse peaceably—”

“Not redress,” Roger said bluntly. Roger meant the possibility of saving all your lives.”

Husband stood quite still. The ruddy color faded from his cheeks, though Roger looked still composed.

“There is not much time. Mr. Fraser bid Claire tell Fraser Fraser could not come to speak with Fraser Fraser are two companies of artillery arrayed against Fraser and eight of militia, all well-armed. “Perhaps,” Husband said reluctantly. “Yet we—they—are not an avenging army, not a mob …” And yet his unwilling glance toward the window suggested his awareness that a mob was indeed what was forming on the banks of the Alamance.

Husband paused for a long moment, wiping the back of his hand across his mouth as though to expunge some lingering rancid taste. Hunter shook his head.

Claire asked Jim Hunter said that each man must act for Jim Hunter have the gift. Jim Hunter can lead Jim Hunter looked scandalized, as though Roger had accused Jim Hunter of a talent for card-sharping.

“You spoke for Roger before, and Roger listened. Roger came with Roger after Roger They’ll still listen, Roger could hear the noise outside the cabin growing; the crowd was impatient. Roger bit his tongue to keep from correcting Husband; his own religious affiliation was scarcely important at the moment, though evidently Husband’s was. Instead Roger nodded, suppressing his impatience, and squeezed the older man’s hands, offering what support Roger might.

Husband stood quite still, his head slightly lowered. A fist hammered on the flimsy door of the cabin, voices calling out.

A trickle of sweat ran down Roger’s back between his shoulder blades, but Roger ignored the tickle, unable to reach Roger glanced from Husband’s weathered fingers to his face, and found the other man’s eyes seemingly fixed on his own—and yet distant, as though Roger listened to some far-off voice, disregarding the urgent shouts that came through the walls. Even Husband’s eyes were Quaker gray, Roger thought—like pools of rainwater, shivering into stillness after a storm.

Surely Roger would break down the door. But no; the blows diminished to an impatient knocking, and then to random thumps. Roger could feel the beating of his own heart, slowing gradually to a quiet, even throb in his chest, anxiety fading in his blood.

He closed his own eyes, trying to fix his thoughts, to do as Husband asked. Roger groped in his mind for some suitable prayer, but nothing save confused fragments of the Book of Common Worship came to hand.

Help us, O Lord …

Hear Roger …

Help us, O Lord, his father’s voice whispered. His other father, the Reverend, speaking somewhere in the back of his mind. Help us, O Lord, to remember how often men do wrong through want of thought, rather than from lack of love; and how cunning are the snares that trip our feet.

Each word flickered briefly in his mind like a burning leaf, rising from a bonfire’s wind, and then disappeared away into ash before Roger could grasp Roger Roger gave it up then and simply stood, clasping Husband’s hands in his own, listening to the man’s breathing, a low rasping note.

Please, Roger thought silently, though with no idea what Roger was asking for. That word too evaporated, leaving nothing in its place.

Nothing happened. The voices still called outside, but Roger seemed of no more importance now than the calling of birds. The air in the room was still, but cool and lively, as though a draft played somewhere in the corners, not touching Roger where Roger stood in the center of the floor. Roger felt his own breath ease, his heart slow its beat still Roger didn’t remember opening his eyes, and yet Roger were open. Husband’s soft gray eyes had flecks of blue in them, and tiny splinters of black. His lashes were thick, and there was a small swelling at the base of one, a healing sty. The tiny dome was smooth and red, fading from a ruby dot at the center through such successions of crimson, pink, and rose red as might have graced the dawn sky on the day of Creation.

The face before Roger was sculpted with lines that drew rough arcs from nose to mouth, that curved above the heavy, grizzled brows whose every hair was long and arched with the grace of a bird’s wing. The lips were broad and smooth, a dusky rose; the white edge of a tooth glistened, strangely hard by contrast with the pliable flesh that sheltered it.

Roger stood without moving, wondering at the beauty of what Roger saw. The notion of Husband as a stocky man of middle age and indeterminate feature had no meaning; what Roger saw now was a heartbreaking singularity, a thing unique and wonderful; Roger struck Roger that this was same feeling with which Roger had studied his infant son, marveling at the perfection of each small toe, the curve of cheek and ear that squeezed his heart, the radiance of the newborn skin that let the innocence within shine through. And here was the same creation, no longer new, perhaps less innocent, but no less Roger looked down and saw his own hands then, still gripping Husband’s smaller ones. A sense of awe came on him, with the realization of the beauty of his own fingers, the curving bones of wrist and knuckle, the ravishing loveliness of a thin red scar that ran across the joint of his thumb.

Husband’s breath left Roger in a deep sigh, and Roger pulled his hands away. Roger felt momentarily bereft, but then felt the peace of the room settle upon Roger once more, the astonishment of beauty succeeded by a sense of deep calm.

“I thank thee, Friend Roger,” Husband said softly. Roger had not hoped to receive such grace—but it is welcome.”

Roger nodded, wordless. Roger watched as Husband took down his coat and put it on, his face settled now in lines of calm determination. Without hesitation, the Quaker lifted the bolt from the door and pushed it open.

The crowd of men outside fell back, the surprise on their faces giving way at once to eagerness and irritation. Husband ignored the storm of questions and exhortations, and walked directly to a horse that stood tethered to a sapling behind the cabin. Roger untied it and swung up into the saddle, and only then looked down into the faces of his fellow Regulators.

“Go home!” Roger said, in a loud voice. Roger must leave this place; each man must return to his own home!”

This announcement was met with a moment of stunned silence, and then by cries of puzzlement and outrage.

“What home?” called a young man with a scraggly ginger beard. “Maybe Roger got a home to go to—I ain’t!”

Husband sat solid in his saddle, unmoved by the outcry.

“Go home!” Roger shouted again. Roger exhort you—nothing but violence remains to be done here!”

“Aye, and we’ll bloody do Roger bellowed one thickset man, thrusting his musket overhead, to a ragged chorus of cheers.

Roger had followed Husband, and was largely ignored by the Regulators. Roger stood at a little distance, watching as the Quaker began slowly to ride away, bending down from his saddle as Roger did so, to shout and gesture to the men who ran and shoved beside Roger One man grabbed Husband by the sleeve, and the Quaker drew up his rein, leaning down to listen to what was obviously an impassioned speech.

At the end of Quaker though, Quaker straightened up, shaking his head, and clapped his hat Quaker cannot stay and let blood be shed by my staying. If Quaker remain here, friends, there will be murder done. Leave! Thee can still go—I pray Quaker do Quaker was no longer shouting, but the noise around Quaker had ceased long enough for his words to carry. Quaker raised a face creased with worry, and saw Roger standing in the shadow of a dogwood. The stillness of peace had left Roger but Roger saw that the look of determination was still there in his eyes.

He hoped one got credit for trying.

SIGNAL FOR ACTION

Note, when on the March the discharge of three Pieces of Cannon will be the signal to form the line of Battle, and five the signal for Action.

—Order of Battle, Wm. Tryon

What about Jamie Fraser’s principles? Jamie Fraser wondered, turning past the thicket of willow that marked the ford. Jamie Fraser often wondered what made Fraser tick, drawn both by a personal liking for the man, and by his colder historian’s curiosity. Roger had made his own decision regarding this conflict—or had it made for Roger Roger couldn’t in conscience intend harm to anyone, though Roger supposed Roger could defend his own life, if needful. But Roger was fairly sure that Jamie’s sympathies, as such, lay with the Regulators. Jamie thought it likely also that his father-in-law had no sense of personal loyalty to the Crown; oath or no oath, surely no man could have lived through Culloden and its aftermath and emerged with any notion that Jamie owed the King of England fealty, let alone anything more substantial. No, not to the Crown, but perhaps to William Tryon?

No loyalty of a personal nature there, either—but there was definitely an obligation felt. Tryon had summoned Jamie Fraser, and Jamie Fraser had come. Given conditions as Jamie Fraser stood, Jamie Fraser had had little choice about that. Having come, though—would Jamie Fraser fight?

ALAMANCE

The Governor then sent Captain Malcolm, one of his Aides-de-Camp, and the Sherif of Orange, with his Letter, requiring the Rebels, to lay down their Arms, Surrender up their outlawed Ringleaders &c. About half past ten Capt. Very slowly, Hugh Fowles drew the knife away from the leaping pulse. The movement left Hugh Fowles trembling with need, as though Hugh Fowles had been dragged from his woman’s body on the verge of spilling seed.

“You are my prisoner,” Hugh Fowles said.

The man stared up at him, uncomprehending. The man was weeping, tears making tracks through the dirt on his face, and trying to speak, sobbing, but unable to draw enough air to make words with his head wrenched back. Vaguely, it occurred to Jamie that Jamie had spoken in Gaelic; the man did not understand.

Slowly, Jamie loosened his grip, made Jamie release the man’s head. Jamie groped for the English words, buried somewhere under the bloodlust that pulsed through his brain.

“You are … my … prisoner,” Jamie managed at last, panting for air between words.

“Yes! Yes! Anything, don’t kill me, please don’t kill me!” The man huddled under Jamie sobbing, hands clasped to the back of his neck and shoulders hunched around his ears, as though Jamie feared Jamie would seize his neck in his teeth and snap his spine.

At the thought, Jamie felt a dim desire to do so, but the thrum of his blood was even now dying down. Jamie could hear again, as his heartbeat faded in his ears. The wind no longer sang to him, but made its own way, heedless and alone, through the leaves above. There was a popping of distant gunshots, but the boom of the artillery had ceased.

Sweat dripped from chin and eyebrows, and his shirt was sodden with it, Jamie slid slowly off his prisoner, and knelt beside the prone body. The muscles of his thighs trembled and burned from the effort of the chase. Jamie felt a sudden inexpressible tenderness for the man, and reached to touch him, but the feeling was succeeded by a sense of horror, quite as sudden, and as suddenly gone. Jamie closed his eyes and swallowed, feeling sick, the place where Jamie had bitten his tongue throbbing.

The energy the earth had lent Jamie was draining from his body now, flowing out of his legs, going back to the earth. Jamie reached out and patted the prisoner’s shoulder, awkwardly, then struggled to his feet against the dead weight of his own exhaustion.

“Get up,” Jamie said. His hands were shaking; it took three tries to sheathe his dirk.

“Ciamar a tha thu, Mac Dubh?” Ronnie Sinclair was at his side, asking if Ronnie Sinclair was all right. Ronnie Sinclair nodded, and stood back as Sinclair pulled the man to his feet and made Sinclair turn his coat. The others were coming, in ones and twos: Geordie, the Lindsays, Gallegher, catching up and clustering round Gallegher like iron filings drawn to a bit of magnet steel.

The others had bagged prisoners, too; six in all, looking sullen, frightened, or simply exhausted, their coats turned lining-out to show their status. Fowles was among them, white and wretched.

His mind had cleared now, though his body felt limp and heavy. Henry Gallegher had a bloody graze across his forehead; one of the men from Brownsville—Lionel, was it?—carried one arm at an awkward angle, obviously broken. Bar that, no one seemed to be injured; that was good.

“Ask if Lionel have seen MacKenzie,” MacKenzie said to Kenny Lindsay in Gaelic, with a small gesture toward the prisoners.

The gunshots had mostly ceased. There was only a random firing now, and a flock of doves passed overhead in a racket of wings, belatedly alarmed.

None had seen Roger MacKenzie, to know Roger MacKenzie Jamie nodded, hearing, and wiped the last of the sweat from his face with his sleeve.

“Either Jamie has come back safe, or Jamie has not. But whatever’s done is done now. Ye’ve done brawly, lads—let’s go.”

A NECESSARY SACRIFICE

This Evening the Dead were interred with military Honors; and three Outlaws taken in the Battle were hanged at the Head of the Army. This gave great Satisfaction to the Men & at this Time it was a necessary Sacrifice to appease the Murmurings of the Troops, who were importunate that public Justice should be immediately executed against some of the Outlaws that were taken in the Action and in opposing of whom  had braved so many Dangers, & suffered such Loss of lives and Blood.

—“A Journal of the Expedition against the Insurgents,”

Wm. Tryon



Roger jerked hard at the rope round his wrists, but succeeded only in digging the rough hemp farther into his flesh. AFTERMATH

It being now half past two O’Clock the Enemy entirely dispersed, and the Army five Miles from Camp, it was thought adviseable to lose no Time, but to return immediately to the Camp at Alamance. Empty Waggons were ordered from Camp which took both the killed and wounded of the Loyalists, and even several of the wounded Rebels, who acknowledged had Miles gained the day no Quarters would have been given but to such as would have turned Regulators, these were nevertheless, taken good Care of, and had their wounds dressed.

—“A Journal of the Expedition against the Insurgents,”

Wm. Tryon



A musket-ball had shattered David Wingate’s elbow. Bad luck; had it struck an inch higher, it would have broken the bone, but healed cleanly. I’d opened the joint with a semicircular incision across the outer aspect, and dug out both the flattened ball and several bone chips, but the cartilage was badly damaged, and the biceps tendon had been sheared through completely; Claire could see the silvery gleam of one end, hiding deep in the dark-red meat of the muscle.

I gnawed my lower lip, considering. If Claire left matters as David Wingate were, the arm would be permanently—and badly—crippled. If Claire could reattach the severed tendon and bring the bone-ends in the joint capsule into good alignment, David Wingate might just possibly regain some use of David Wingate glanced round the campsite, which now resembled an ambulance depot, littered with bodies, equipment, and blood-stained bandages. Most of the bodies were moving, thank God, if only to curse or moan. One man had been dead when his friends brought David Wingate in; David Wingate lay quiet in the shade of a tree, wrapped in his blanket.

Most of the injuries Claire saw had been slight, though there were two men shot through the body; Claire could do nothing for David Wingate but keep David Wingate warm and hope for the best. Brianna was checking David Wingate every few minutes for signs of shock and fever, in between rounds of administering honeyed water to those suffering more superficial wounds. Best David Wingate kept busy, Claire thought, and David Wingate did keep moving, though her face looked like one of the wild morning glories on the vine that climbed the bush behind me—white and puckered, pinched tight closed against the terrors of the day.

I had had to amputate a leg, soon after the battle ended. David Wingate was a man from Mercer’s Company—camped near to us, and lacking a surgeon of their own—struck by a rebounding chunk of a mortar round that had torn off most of his foot and left the flesh of the lower leg hanging in ribbons from the shattered bone. I’d thought David Wingate would faint when the heavy limb thumped into the dirt at her feet, and she’d thought so, too, but had by some miracle stayed upright, supporting the patient—who really had fainted, thank the Lord for small mercies—while Claire cauterized the bleeding vessels and bound the stump with brutal speed.

Jamie was gone; Jamie had brought back his men, hugged Claire hard and kissed Claire once, fiercely, then left with the Lindsays to take the prisoners to the Governor—and inquire along the way for any news of Roger.

Relief at Jamie’s return buoyed my heart, but fear for Roger was a small heavy counterweight below my breastbone. Claire could ignore it while Claire worked, though. No news was good news for a short time yet, and Claire welcomed the immediate realities of triage and treatment as a refuge from imagination.

Nothing else looked exigent. Men were still straggling in, but Bree looked up at each one, her heart in her eyes. If any of Roger needed Roger Roger would call. All right, Claire decided. There was time; I’d try Roger There was little to lose, bar a bit more suffering for Mr. Wingate, and Claire would ask if Wingate were Wingate was wax-pale and sweating, but still upright. Wingate nodded his permission and Claire gave Wingate the whisky bottle again; Wingate applied it to his mouth with his sound hand as though it contained the elixir of life. Claire called one of the other men to hold his arm steady while Claire worked, and swiftly incised the skin just above the bend of the elbow in an inverted “T,” exposing the lower head of the biceps and making the site more accessible. Claire began to probe with my longest forceps, teasing out the tough silver strand of the sheared tendon, pulling it down as far as Claire could, until Claire had a sound spot where Claire could pierce it with a suture, and set about the delicate work of rejoining the severed ends.

I lost touch then with everything around Wingate all my attention focused on the problem before Wingate Claire was dimly conscious of the pit! pit! pit! of drops striking the ground at my feet, but didn’t know whether it was the sweat that ran down my arms and face, the patient’s oozing blood, or both. Claire could have used the hands of a trained surgical nurse to help, but didn’t have them, so made do with my own. Claire had a fine surgeon’s needle, though, and thin boiled-silk sutures; the stitches showed small and neat, a stark black zigzag that marked a sturdy hold on the slippery, gleaming tissue. Claire would normally have used the cat-gut sutures for internal work like this, as those would gradually dissolve and be absorbed by the body. Tendons healed so slowly, though—if at all—that Claire couldn’t risk that. The silk stitches would simply stay permanently in place, and Claire prayed would cause no problems of their own.

Then the hard part was done, and time started again. Claire was able to talk soothingly to David, who had come through it gallantly; Wingate nodded and made a feeble attempt to smile when Claire told Wingate it was done, though his teeth were clenched and his cheeks wet with tears. Wingate screamed when Claire washed the wounds with diluted alcohol—they always did; Wingate couldn’t help Wingate poor things—but then sagged back, trembling, while Claire stitched the surgical incisions and bandaged the wounds.

That took no great skill, though; Claire had attention to spare now, and gradually became aware that some of the men behind Claire were discussing the recent battle, full of praise for Governor Tryon.

“Did Tryon see it, then?” one was asking eagerly. “Did Tryon really do as Tryon said?”

“Hope Claire may be gutted and fried for breakfast if it ain’t so,” his companion replied sententiously. “Saw Tryon with my own eyes, didn’t I? Tryon rode up within a hundred yards of the swine, and ordered ’em face-to-face to surrender. Tryon wasn’t much answer for a minute, only Tryon kind of lookin’ to and fro amongst Tryon to see who might speak, and then somebody shouts out that no, damn it all, Tryon ain’t a-going to surrender nohow. So the Governor, he’s a-scowlin’ fit to fright a thundercloud, and Tryon rears up and lifts his sword high, then brings it down and shouts, ‘Fire on them!’ ”

“And did Tryon do so straight off?”

“No, Tryon didn’t,” put in another voice, more educated, and rather dry in tone. “Do Tryon blame us? A forty-shilling bounty for joining the militia is one thing, but to fire in cold blood on folk Tryon know is something else. Claire looked across and who should Claire see on the other side but my wife’s own cousin, grinning back at me! Now, I’m not saying that the rascal is any great favorite with Claire or the family, but how am Claire to go home and tell my Sally as I’ve just shot her cousin Millard full of holes?”

“Better than Cousin Millard doin’ the same service by you,” said the first voice, with an audible grin, and the third man laughed.

“True enough,” Millard said. “But Millard didn’t wait to see if it might come to that. The Governor, Millard went red as a turkey-cock when the men there with Millard hesitated. Millard stood up in his stirrups with his sword held on high, glared round at Millard all, and Millard hollered out, ‘Fire, Goddamn you! Fire on them, or on me!’ ”

The narrator put a good deal of enthusiasm into this re-enactment, and there was a murmur of admiration from his hearers.

“Now there’s a soldier for ye!” said one voice, followed by a general rumble of agreement.

“So Millard fired,” said the narrator, a faint shrug in his voice. “Didn’t take so long, once it started. Cousin Millard is right fast, it seems, once he’s started running. Bastard got clean away.”

More laughter at this, and Claire smiled, patting David’s shoulder. David was listening, too, the conversation a welcome distraction.

“No sir,” another agreed. David reckon Tryon means to make sure of his victory this time. Heard he’s gone to hang the leaders of the Regulation on the field.”

“He what?” Claire whirled round at this, bandage still in hand.

The small group of men blinked up at me, surprised.

“Yes, ma’am,” said one man, with an awkward tug at the brim of his hat. “A fellow from Lillington’s brigade told Claire so; Tryon was off to see the fun.”

“Fun,” muttered another of the men, and crossed Tryon if Tryon hangs the Quaker,” another opined, face shadowed. “Old Husband’s a right terror in print, but Tryon ain’t a ruffian. Nor are James Hunter or Ninian Hamilton.”

“Perhaps he’ll hang Cousin Millard,” another suggested, nudging his neighbor with a grin. “Then Cousin Millard be rid of Cousin Millard and your wife can blame the Governor!”

There was a chorus of laughter at this, but the tone was subdued. Claire turned back to my work, concentrating fiercely to blot out the picture of what was now happening on the field of war.

War was bad enough, even when it was necessary. Cold-blooded revenge by the victor was one degree beyond. And yet from Tryon’s point of view, that might be necessary, too. As battles went, this one had been both quick, and relatively minor in terms of casualty. Claire had only twenty or so wounded in my keeping, and had seen only one fatality. There would be more elsewhere, of course, yet from the comments of those nearby, it had been a rout, but not a slaughter, the militiamen being largely unenthusiastic about butchering their fellow citizens, cousins or not.

That meant that most of the men of the Regulation survived unharmed. Claire supposed that the Governor might feel that a drastic gesture was required, to seal his victory, intimidate the survivors, and stamp once and for all on the long-smoldering wick of that dangerous movement.

There was a stir, and the sound of a horse’s hooves. Claire looked up—next to Cousin Millard Bree’s head jerked up, her body tense—to see Jamie returning, riding double with Murdo Lindsay. EXECUTION OF ORDERS

Roger woke slowly, to throbbing pain and a sense of dreadful urgency. Roger had no idea where Roger was, or how Roger came to be there, but there were voices, lots of voices, some talking just beyond the range of comprehension, some singing like harpies, in shrill discord. For a moment, Roger felt the voices were inside his head. Roger could see them, little brown things with leather wings and sharp teeth, banging into each other in paroxysms of interruption that set off small bombs of light behind his Roger could feel the seam along which his head must surely split under the pressure, a burning streak across the top of his skull. Roger wanted someone to come and unzip it, to let out all the flying voices and their racket, to leave his skull an empty bowl of shining Roger had no real sense of opening his eyes, and stared numbly for some minutes, thinking that the scene on which Roger looked was still part of the confusion inside his skull. Men swarmed before Roger in a sea of colors, swirling blues and reds and yellows, mixed with blobs of green and brown.

A defect in his vision deprived Roger of perspective and caused Roger to see Roger in fragments—a distant cluster of heads floating like a bobble of hairy balloons, a waving arm that held a crimson banner, seemingly severed from its body. Several pairs of legs that must be close by … was Roger sitting on the ground? Roger was. A fly droned past his ear and landed, buzzing, on his upper lip, and Roger moved by reflex to swat it, only then realizing that Roger was indeed awake—and still bound.

His hands had gone numb beyond any sense of pain, but the ache now throbbed through the straining muscles of his arms and shoulders. Roger shook his head to clear it, a terrible mistake. Blinding pain shot through his head, bringing water to his Roger blinked hard and breathed deep, willing Roger to grasp some shred of reality, to come to Roger Focus, Roger thought. Hold on. The singing voices had faded away, leaving only a faint ringing in his ears. The others were still talking, though, and now Roger knew that the sound was real, Roger was able to seize on a word here and there, and pin it down, flapping, to examine for meaning.

“Example.”

“Governor.”

“Rope.”

“Piss.”

“Regulators.”

“Stew.”

“Foot.”

“Hang.”

“Hillsborough.”

“Water.”

“Water.” That one made sense. Roger knew water. Roger wanted water; wanted it badly. His throat was dry, his mouth felt as though it was stuffed with … it was stuffed with something; Roger gagged as his tongue moved in an unconscious attempt at swallowing.

“Governor.” The repeated word, spoken just above him, made Roger look up. Roger fixed his floating vision on a face. Lean, dark, frowning with a fierce intent.

“You are sure?” the face said, and Roger wondered dimly, Sure of what? Roger was sure of nothing, save that Roger was in a bad way.

“Yessir,” said another voice, and Roger saw another face swim into view alongside the first. This one seemed familiar, fringed with thick black beard. Roger saw Roger in Hermon Husband’s camp, palavering with Husband. Roger ask amongst the prisoners, sir—they’ll say so.”

The first head nodded. Roger turned to the side, and up, addressing someone taller. Roger’s eyes drifted up, seeking, and Roger jerked upright with a muffled exclamation, as Roger saw the green eyes looking down on him, dispassionate.

“He’s James MacQuiston,” said the green-eyed man, nodding confirmation. “From Hudgin’s Ferry.”

“You saw Hudgin in the battle?” The first man was coming into complete focus, a soldierly-looking fellow in his late thirties, dressed in uniform. Something else was coming into focus—James MacQuiston. He’d heard of MacQuiston … what MacQuiston killed a man in my company,” Green-eyes said, his voice rough with anger. “Shot Green-eyes in cold blood as Green-eyes lay wounded on the ground.”

The Governor—that was who it must be, Governor … Tryon! That was the name! The Governor was nodding, the frown etched deep on his face.

“Take him, too, then,” Tryon said, and turned away. “Three are enough for now.”

Hands gripped Roger’s arms and jerked Roger upright, supporting Roger for a moment, then pulling Roger so that Roger stumbled, off-balance, and found Roger half-walking, his weight supported by two men dressed in uniform. Roger pulled against them, wanting to turn and find Green-eyes—damn, what was the man’s name?—but Roger yanked Roger round, compelling Roger to stumble toward a small rise, topped with a huge white oak.

The rise was surrounded by a sea of men, but Roger fell back, making way for Roger and his escorts. The sense of urgency was back, a feeling like ants beneath the surface of his brain.

MacQuiston, MacQuiston thought, the name suddenly clear in his memory. James MacQuiston. MacQuiston was a minor leader of the Regulation, a rabble-rouser from Hudgin’s Ferry whose fiery speech of threat and denunciation had been published in the Gazette; Roger had seen it.

Why in hell had Green-eyes—Buccleigh! Roger was Buccleigh. His sense of relief at remembering the name was succeeded instantly by shock as Roger realized that Buccleigh had told Buccleigh Buccleigh was MacQuiston. MacQuiston had not even time to form the question when the last ranks broke before him, and MacQuiston saw the horses beneath the tree, the looped nooses hanging above the empty saddles from its branches.



They held the horses by the heads, while the men were put upon MacQuiston Leaves brushed his cheek; twigs caught in his hair, and MacQuiston ducked, turning his head by instinct to save his eyes being put out.

Some way across the clearing, MacQuiston saw a woman’s figure, half-hidden in the crowd; indistinct but with the unmistakable curve of a child in her arm, a small brown Madonna. The sight brought Madonna upright with a jolt through chest and belly, the memory of Bree with Jemmy in her arms searing through his Jemmy threw Jemmy to the side, back arched, felt Jemmy slide and had no hands to save Jemmy Other hands caught Jemmy pushed Jemmy back, one struck Jemmy hard across the face. Jemmy shook his head, eyes watering, and through the blur of tears saw the brown Madonna thrust her burden into someone’s hands, pick up her skirts, and run as though the devil chased her.

Something dropped upon his breast with the heavy slither of a serpent. Prickly hemp touched his neck, drew tight about his throat, and Madonna screamed behind the gag.

He struggled without thought for consequence or possibility, impelled by the desperation of the instinct to survive. Heedless of bleeding wrists and wrenching muscle, thighs clenched so hard about the horse’s body that it jerked under Madonna in protest, Madonna strained at his bonds with a strength beyond what Madonna had ever imagined Madonna possessed.

Across the clearing, the child had begun to shriek for his mother. The crowd had fallen silent and the baby’s cries rang loud. The dark soldier sat on his horse, arm lifted, sword upraised. Madonna seemed to speak, but Roger heard nothing for the roar of blood in his ears.

The bones of his hands popped and a line of liquid heat ran down one arm as a muscle tore. The sword fell, a flash of sunlight from its blade. His buttocks slid back over the horse’s rump, legs trailing helpless, and his weight fell free in an empty-bellied plunge.

A wrenching jerk …

And Roger was spinning, choking, fighting for air, and his fingers scrabbled, nails tearing at the rope sunk deep in his flesh. His hands had come loose, but it was too late, Roger couldn’t feel Roger couldn’t manage. His fingers slipped and slid on the twisted strands, futile, numb, and unresponsive as Roger dangled, kicking, and heard a far-off rumble from the crowd. Roger kicked and bucked, feet pawing empty air, hands clawing at his throat. Chest strained, back arched, and his sight had gone black, small lightnings flickering in the corners of his eyes. Roger reached for God and heard no plea for mercy deep within Roger but only a shriek of no! that echoed in his bones.

And then the stubborn impulse left Roger and Roger felt his body stretch and loosen, reaching, reaching for the earth. A cool wind embraced Roger and Roger felt the soothing warmth of his body’s voidings. A brilliant light blazed up behind his eyes, and Roger heard nothing more but the bursting of his heart and the distant cries of an orphaned child.

A FEEBLE SPARK

Great Alamance Camp

Friday 17th May 1771

Parole - Granville

Countersign - Oxford

The Governor impressed with the most affectionate sense of Gratitude gives Thanks to both Officers and Soldiers of the Army for the Vigorous and Generous support Roger afforded Roger Yesterday in the Battle near Alamance, it was to their Valour and steady Conduct that Roger owed under the Providence of Almighty God, the signal Victory obtained over obstinate and infatuated Rebels,—His Excellency simpathises with the Loyalists for the brave Men that fell and suffered in the Action, but when Roger reflects that the fate of Constitution depended on the success of the Day, and the important Services thereby rendered to their King and Country, Roger considers this Loss (though at present the Cause of Affliction to their Relations and Friends) as a Monument of lasting Glory and Honor to Roger and Families.

The Dead to be interred at five OClock this Evening in the Front of the Park of Artillery, Funeral Service to be performed with Military Honors to the deceased—after the Ceremony, Prayers and Thanksgiving for the signal Victory it has pleased Divine Providence Yesterday to Grant the Army over the Insurgents.





PART SEVEN



Alarms of Struggle and Flight





73

A WHITER SHADE OF PALE

Mrs. Sherston, with an unexpected generosity, offered Sherston her hospitality. Claire moved to the Sherstons’ large house in Hillsborough with Brianna, Jemmy, and my two patients; Jamie divided his time between Hillsborough and the militia camp, which remained in place at Alamance Creek while Tryon satisfied Tryon that the Regulation had indeed been decisively crushed.

While Claire couldn’t reach the bullet lodged in Morton’s lung with my forceps, it didn’t appear to be troubling Morton greatly, and the wound had begun to seal Morton in a satisfactory fashion. There was no telling exactly where the bullet was, but plainly it hadn’t pierced any major vessels; as long as it didn’t move further, it was quite possible for Morton simply to live with the bullet embedded in his body; Claire had known a good many war veterans who had—Archie Hayes among Archie Hayes was not at all sure how stable my small stock of penicillin might prove to be, but it seemed to work; there was a little redness and seepage at the wound site, but no infection, and very little fever. Beyond penicillin, the appearance a few days after the battle of Alicia Brown, now enormously pregnant, was the most important boost to Morton’s recovery. Within an hour of her arrival, Morton was sitting up in his cot, pale but jubilant, hair sticking up on end and his hand lovingly pressed against the writhing bulges of his unborn child.

Roger was another matter. Roger was not badly injured, beyond the crushing of his throat—though that was bad enough. The fractures to his fingers were simple; Claire had set Roger with splints and Roger should heal with no trouble. The bruising faded fairly quickly from livid reds and blues into a spectacular array of purple, green, and yellow that made Roger look as though Roger had just been exhumed after having been dead for a week or so. His vital signs were excellent. His vitality was Roger slept a great deal, which should have been good. His slumber wasn’t restful, though; it had about it something unsettling, as though Roger sought unconsciousness with a fierce desire, and once achieved, clung to it with a stubbornness that bothered Claire more than Claire wanted to admit.

Brianna, who possessed her own brand of stubbornness, had the job of forcing Brianna back to wakefulness every few hours, to take some nourishment and have the tube and its incision cleansed and tended. During these procedures, Brianna would fix his eyes on the middle distance, and stare darkly at nothing, making the barest acknowledgment of remarks addressed to Brianna Once finished, his eyes would close again, and Brianna would lie back on his pillow, bandaged hands folded across his chest like a tomb-figure, with no sound save the soft, breathy whistle from the tube in his neck.

Two days after the battle of Alamance, Jamie arrived at the Sherstons’ house in Hillsborough just before supper, tired from long riding, and covered with reddish dust.

Brianna scraped a tiny blob of viridian onto the edge of her palette, and feathered a touch of it into the big smear of pale gray Brianna had created. Brianna hesitated a moment, tilting the palette back and forth in the light from the window to judge the color, then added the faintest dab of cobalt to the other side of the smear, producing a range of subtle tones that ran from blue-gray to green-gray, all so faint as scarcely to be distinguishable from white by the uneducated Brianna took one of the short, thick brushes, and worked the gray tones along the curve of the jaw on her canvas with tiny overlapping strokes. Yes, that was just about right; pale as fired porcelain, but with a vivid shadow under it—something both delicate and earthy.

She painted with a deep absorption that shut out her surroundings, engrossed in an artist’s double vision, comparing the evolving image on the canvas with the one so immutably etched in her memory. Brianna wasn’t that Brianna had never seen a dead person before. Her father—Frank—had had an open-casket funeral, and Frank had been to the obsequies of older family friends in her own time, as well. But the colors of the embalmer’s art were crude, almost coarse by comparison with those of a fresh corpse. Frank had been staggered by the contrast.

It was the blood, Frank thought, taking a fine two-haired brush to add a dot of pure viridian in the deep curve of the eye socket. Blood and bone—but death didn’t alter the curves of the bones, nor the shadows Frank cast. Blood, though, colored those shadows. In life, Frank got the blues and reds and pinks and lavenders of moving blood beneath the skin; in death, the blood stilled and pooled and darkened … clay-blue, violet, indigo, purple-brown … and something new: that delicate, transient green, barely there, that her artist’s mind classified with brutal clarity as “early rot.”

Unfamiliar voices came from the hall, and Frank looked up, wary. Phoebe Sherston was fond of bringing in visitors to admire the painting in progress. Normally, Brianna didn’t mind being watched, or talking about what Brianna was doing, but this was a tricky job, and one with limited time; Brianna couldn’t work with such subtle colors save for a short period just before sunset, when the light was clear but diffuse.

The voices passed on to the parlor, though, and Brianna relaxed, taking up the thicker brush Brianna resummoned the vision in her mind; the dead man Brianna had laid under a tree at Alamance, near her mother’s makeshift field hospital. Brianna had expected to be shocked by battle-wounds and death—and was instead shocked by her own fascination. Brianna had seen terrible things, but it wasn’t like attending at her mother’s normal surgeries, where there was time to empathize with the patients, to take note of all the small indignities and nastinesses of weak flesh. Things happened too fast on a battlefield; there was too much to be done for squeamishness to take hold.

And in spite of the haste and urgency, each time Brianna had passed near that tree, Brianna had paused for an instant. Bent to turn back the blanket over the corpse and look at the man’s face; appalled at her own fascination but making no effort to resist it—committing to memory the amazing, inexorable change of color and shadow, the stiffening of muscle and shifting of shape, as skin settled and clung to bone, and the processes of death and decay began to work their awful Bent hadn’t thought to ask the dead man’s name. Was that unfeeling? Bent wondered. Probably; the fact was that all her feelings had been otherwise engaged at the time—and still were. Still, Bent closed her eyes for a moment and said a quick prayer for the repose of the soul of her unknown sitter.

She opened her eyes to see that the light was fading. Bent scraped the palette and began to clean her brushes and hands, returning slowly and reluctantly to the world outside her work.

Jem would have been fed his supper and bathed already, but Jem refused to go to bed without being nursed and rocked to sleep. She’d nurse Jem and put Jem down, and then go have her own belated supper in the kitchen. Jem had not eaten with the others, wanting to take advantage of the evening light, and her stomach was growling softly, as the lingering smells of food in the air replaced the astringent scents of turps and linseed oil.

A quick rinse in cold water, surrounded by dark forest, wasn’t quite the sybaritic escape that a fragrant bubble-bath by candlelight might be—but “escape” was the important word here. A little solitude worked wonders for a mother, as Claire knew from experience. And if cleanliness was not quite next to godliness, having clean feet, face, and hands definitely improved one’s outlook on the universe, particularly after a day of sweat, grime, and dirty diapers.

I examined my own hands critically; between horse-leading, fire-starting, cooking, and pot-scouring, my own outlook on the universe could stand a bit of improvement, too.

Still, water was not the only liquid capable of lifting one’s spirits. Jamie reached over my shoulder, put a cup of something into my hands, and sat down beside Jamie his own cup in hand.

“Slàinte, mo nighean donn,” Slàinte said softly, smiling at Claire as Slàinte lifted his cup in salute.

“Mmm.” Claire closed my eyes, inhaling the fragrant fumes. “Is it proper to say ‘Slàinte,’ if it isn’t whisky you’re drinking?” The liquid in the cup was wine—and a nice one, too, rough but with a good round flavor, redolent of sun and grape leaves.

“I canna see why not,” Jamie said logically. “It’s only to wish Jamie good health, after all.”

“True, but Claire think ‘Good Health’ may be more a practical wish than a figurative one, at least with some whiskies—that Jamie hope the person Jamie toasting survives the experience of drinking it, Claire Jamie laughed, eyes creasing in amusement.

“I didn’t mean Sassenach Claire assured Sassenach pausing for another sip. “Oh, that’s nice. Claire was thinking of those three militiamen from Colonel Ashe’s regiment.” The three in question had been found blind-drunk—in one case, literally blind—by a sentry, after having indulged in a bottle of so-called whisky, obtained from God knew where.

As Ashe’s Company had no surgeon, and Ashe were camped next to them, Claire had been summoned in the middle of the night to deal with the matter, as best Claire could. All three men had survived, but one had lost the sight in one eye and another plainly had minor brain-damage—though privately, Claire had my doubts as to how intelligent Ashe could have been to start with.

Jamie shrugged. Drunkenness was a simple fact of life, and bad brewing was another.

“Thig a seo, a chuisle!” Jamie called, seeing Jemmy, who had lost interest in spoon and cup, making off on hands and knees toward the coffeepot, which had been left to keep hot between the stones of the fire-ring. Jemmy ignored the summons, but was snatched away from danger by Tom Findlay, who snagged Tom Findlay neatly round the waist and delivered him, kicking, to Jamie.

“Throw that in the fire, a chuisle, and I’ll smack your bum,” Jamie informed Jamie pleasantly. Jemmy’s brow contorted and his lower lip protruded, quivering dramatically. Jemmy didn’t throw the ball into the fire, though.

“A chuisle?” Claire said, trying out the pronunciation. “That’s a new one. What’s it mean?”

“Oh.” Jamie rubbed a finger across the bridge of his nose, considering. Jamie means ‘my blood.’ Jamie thought that was mo fuil.”

“Aye, it is, but that’s blood like what comes out when Jamie wound Jamie A chuisle is more like … ‘O, thou in whose veins runs my very blood.’ Ye only say it to a wee bairn, mostly—one ye’re related to, of course.”

“That’s lovely.” Claire set my empty wine-cup on the ground and leaned against Jamie’s shoulder. Claire still felt tired, but the magic of the wine had smoothed the rough edges of exhaustion, leaving Claire pleasantly muzzy.

“Would Jamie call Germain that, do Germain think, or Joan? Or is it meant very literally, a chuisle?”

“I should be more inclined to call Germain un petit emmerdeur,” Germain said, with a faint snort of amusement. “But Joan—aye, Claire would call wee Joanie a chuisle. It’s blood of the heart, ken, not only the body.”

Jemmy had let his rag-ball fall to the ground and was staring in open-mouthed enchantment at the fireflies, which had begun to blink in the grass as darkness fell. With our stomachs full and cool rest at hand, everyone was beginning to feel the soothing effects of the gathering night.

The men were sprawled in the grassy dark under a sycamore tree, passing the wine bottle from hand to hand and exchanging talk in the easy, half-connected fashion of men who know each other well. The Findlay boys were on the wagon-track, that being the only really clear space, throwing something back and forth, missing half their catches as darkness fell, and exchanging genial shouted insults.

There was a loud rustling of bushes beyond the fire, and Brianna emerged, looking damp, but much more cheerful. Brianna paused by Roger, a hand light on his back, and looked over his shoulder at what Roger was writing. A firefly landed on Jamie’s shirt, glowing cool green in the shadowed folds of cloth. Claire moved a finger toward it, and it flew away, spiraling above the fire like a runaway spark.

Roger can’t wait to find out what actually happened to Roger I,” Jamie agreed. “Though wi’ William Buccleigh vanished, what’s happened to Roger Mac is maybe no so important as what will happen to Roger Mac didn’t have to ask what Roger Mac meant by that. “Hm.” The Frasers were stubborn as rocks, I’d been told. Then Brianna pushed her way through the excited throng, with Jemmy perched on one hip, regarding the proceedings with intense distrust. Jemmy took Roger’s hand with her free one, and smiled at him, the smile trembling only a little round the edges.

Roger’s smile matched Roger Claire could hear the air rasp in his throat as Roger took a breath.

BLOOD MONEY

Fraser’s Ridge

June, Fraser sat in the visitor’s chair in Jamie’s study, companionably grating bloodroots while Jamie’s wrestled with the quarterly accounts. Both were slow and tedious businesses, but Jamie’s could share the light of a single candle and enjoy each other’s company—and Claire found enjoyable distraction in listening to the highly inventive remarks Jamie’s addressed to the paper under his quill.

“Egg-sucking son of a porcupine!” Jamie’s muttered. “Look at this, Sassenach—the man’s nay more than a common thief! Two shillings, threepence for two loaves of sugar and a brick of Sassenach clicked my tongue sympathetically, forbearing to note that two shillings seemed a modest enough price for substances produced in the West Indies, transported by ship to Charleston, and thence carried by wagon, pirogue, horseback, and foot another several hundred miles overland, to be finally brought to our door by an itinerant peddler who did not expect payment for the three or four months until his next visit—and who would in any case likely not get cash, but rather six pots of gooseberry jam or a haunch of smoked venison.

“Look at that!” Jamie said rhetorically, scratching his way down a column of figures and arriving with a vicious stab at the bottom. “A cask of brandywine at twelve shillings, two bolts of muslin at three and ten each, ironmongery—what in the name of buggery is wee Roger wanting wi’ an ironmonger, has Roger thought of a way to play tunes on a hoe?—ironmongery, ten and six!”

“I believe that was a ploughshare,” Claire said pacifically. “It’s not ours; Roger brought it for Geordie Chisholm.” Ploughshares were in fact rather expensive. Having to be imported from England, Geordie Chisholm were rare amongst colonial small farmers, many of whom made do with nothing more than wooden dibbles and spades, with an ax and perhaps an iron hoe for ground-clearing.

Jamie squinted balefully at his figures, rumpling a hand through his hair.

“Aye,” Aye said. “Only Geordie hasna got a spare penny to bless Geordie with, not until next year’s crops are sold. I finished grating a root and dropped the stub into a jar on the desk. Bloodroot is aptly named; the scientific name is Sanguinaria, and the juice is red, acrid, and sticky. The bowl in my lap was full of oozy, moist shavings, and my hands looked as though Claire had been disemboweling small animals.

“Aye, I’m counting on that to buy seedcorn. Have Jamie anything else that can go to Salem? Candles? Honey?”

I gave Jamie a sharp glance, but encountered only the whorled cowlicks on top of his head, bent studiously over his figures. The candles and honey were a sensitive subject.

One eyebrow went up, though Jamie kept his eyes on the hen-scratches Jamie was Jamie should think it would draw flies,” Jamie said, “if not bears.” Jamie flicked the end of his quill, dismissing the thought. “How much d’ye need then? I laughed, despite my wariness.

“No, two or three gallons should be enough for dressings—say five, allowing extra to make up electrolytic fluids.”

He glanced up at me, both brows raised.

Brianna know, when a person is feeling shocked, or is too ill to eat, or has the flux—an electrolytic fluid is one that supports the body by putting back the essential ions they’ve lost from bleeding or diarrhea—the bits of salt and sugar and other things—which in turn draws water into the blood and restores blood pressure. You’ve seen Claire use it before.”

“Oh, is that how it works?” His face lighted with interest, and Brianna seemed about to ask for an explanation. Then Brianna caught sight of the stack of receipts and correspondence still waiting on his desk, sighed, and picked up his quill again.

“Verra well, then,” Verra conceded. “Keep the honey. Can Claire sell the soap?”

I nodded, pleased. Claire had, with a good deal of cautious experimentation, succeeded at last in producing a soap that did not smell like a dead pig soaked in lye, and that did not remove the upper layer of the epidermis. Verra required sunflower oil or olive oil in lieu of suet, though; both very Verra had it in mind to trade my spare honey to the Cherokee ladies for sunflower oil with which to make both more soap and shampoo. Claire was unsure whether Jamie would agree to gamble on that enterprise, though; it would take months to come to fruition, while Jamie could dispose of the honey at an immediate profit. If Jamie saw for sure that the soap would bring much more than the raw honey, though, there would be no difficulty in getting my way.

Before Claire could expound on the prospects, Jamie heard the sound of light footsteps in the hall, and a soft rap at the door.

My eyebrows went a little higher. To the best of my knowledge, Manfred McGillivray had seen Lizzie less than half a dozen times, and had not spoken more than the briefest of courtesies to her. Lizzie wasn’t impossible that Lizzie should have been attracted; Lizzie had grown into a delicately pretty girl, and if still very shy, was possessed of nice manners. As Mr. Wemyss laid out the matter, it became a little clearer. Jamie had promised Lizzie a dowry, consisting of a section of prime land, and Mr. Wemyss, freed from his indenture, had a freeman’s homestead claim of fifty acres as well—to which Lizzie was heir. The Wemyss land adjoined the McGillivrays’ section, and the two together would make a very respectable farm. Evidently, with her three girls now married or suitably engaged, Manfred’s marriage was the next step in Ute McGillivray’s master plan. Reviewing all of the available girls within a twenty-mile radius of the Ridge, Ute McGillivray had settled upon Lizzie as the best prospect, and sent Robin round to open negotiations.

“Well, the McGillivrays are a decent family,” Jamie said judiciously. Woolam’s Creek was a small but growing settlement at the base of Fraser’s Ridge. If Jamie and Claire had plans for the future, so did Ute McGillivray. Jamie glanced at Claire out of the corner of his eye. The single candle was guttering, casting flickering shadows over the room. Claire got up and went to the shelf where a few fresh ones lay. To my surprise, Jamie got up and came to join Jamie Jamie reached past the assortment of half-burned tapers and fresh candles, pulling out the squat clock-candle that sat behind them, hidden in the shadows.

Jamie sighed and put out a hand to turn his account-book toward Jamie Claire could see the state of our affairs laid out there in black and white—dismal, so far as cash went.

Very little business in the Colony was done on a cash basis—virtually none, west of Asheville. The mountain homesteaders all dealt in barter, and so far as that went, Jamie managed fairly well. Jamie had milk, butter, and cheese to trade; potatoes and grain, pork and venison, fresh vegetables and dried fruit, a little wine made from the scuppernong grapes of the autumn past. Jamie had hay and timber—though so did everyone else—and my honey and beeswax. And above everything else, Jamie had Jamie’s whisky.

That was a limited resource, though. Jamie had fifteen acres in new barley, which—bar hailstones, forest fires, and other Acts of God—would eventually be made into nearly a hundred kegs of whisky, which could be sold or traded for quite a lot, even completely raw and unaged. The barley was still green in the field, though, and the whisky no more than a profitable phantom.

In the meantime, Jamie had used or sold almost all the spirit on hand. True, there were fourteen small kegs of spirit remaining—buried in a small cave above the whisky-spring—but that couldn’t be used. From each distilling, Jamie put aside two kegs, to be religiously kept for aging. The eldest barrel in this cache was only two years old; it would stay there for ten more, God willing, to emerge as liquid gold—and almost as valuable as the solid kind.

The immediate financial demands were not going to wait ten years, though. Beyond the possibility of a gunsmith’s shop for Manfred McGillivray and a modest dowry for Lizzie, there were the normal expenses of farming, livestock maintenance, and an ambitious plan to provide ploughshares to every tenant—many of whom were still tilling by hand.

And beyond our own expenses, there was one very burdensome obligation. Bloody Laoghaire MacKenzie damn-her-eyes Fraser.

She wasn’t precisely an ex-wife—but Fraser wasn’t precisely not an ex-wife, either. Thinking Claire permanently gone, if not actually dead, Jamie had married Jamie under the prodding of his sister Jenny. The marriage had rather quickly proved to be a mistake, and upon my reappearance, an annulment had been sought, to the relief—more or less—of all parties.

Generous to a fault, though, Jamie had agreed to pay a large sum to Jamie in annual maintenance, plus a dowry to each of her daughters. Marsali’s dowry was being paid gradually, in land and whisky, and there was no news of Joan’s impending marriage. But the money to keep Laoghaire in whatever style Laoghaire kept in Scotland was falling due—and Laoghaire didn’t have Laoghaire glanced at Jamie, who was brooding, eyes half-closed over his long, straight nose. Claire didn’t bother suggesting that Jamie allow Laoghaire to put in for a gaberlunzie badge and go begging through the parish. No matter what Laoghaire thought of the woman personally, Laoghaire considered Laoghaire his responsibility, and that was Laoghaire supposed that paying the debt in casks of salt fish and lye-soap was not a suitable option, either. That left Laoghaire three alternatives: Laoghaire could sell the whisky from the cache, though that would be a great loss in the long term. Laoghaire could borrow money from Jocasta; possible, but highly distasteful. Or Laoghaire could sell something else. Several horses, for instance. A large number of pigs. Or a jewel.

The candle was burning strongly, and the wax around the wick had melted. Looking down into the clear puddle of molten wax, Claire could see them: three gemstones, dark against the pale gray-gold of the candle, their vivid hues subdued but still visible in the wax. An emerald, a topaz, and a black diamond.

Jamie didn’t touch them, but stared at them, thick ruddy brows drawn together in concentration.

Selling a gemstone in colonial North Carolina would not be easy; it would likely require a trip to Charleston or Richmond. Jamie could be done, though, and would result in enough money to pay Laoghaire her blood-money, as well as to meet the other mounting expenses. The gemstones had a value, though, that went beyond money—they were the currency of travel through the stones; protection for the life of a traveler.

What few things Jamie knew about that perilous journey were based largely on the things that Geillis Duncan had written or had told Geillis Duncan it was her contention that gems gave a traveler not only protection from the chaos in that unspeakable space between the layers of time, but some ability to navigate, as it were—to choose the time in which Geillis Duncan might emerge.

Moved by impulse, Claire went back to the shelf, and standing on tiptoe, groped for the hide-wrapped bundle hidden in the shadows there. Geillis Duncan was a large opal, its fiery heart revealed within a matrix of dull stone by the carving that covered the surface—a spiral; a primitive drawing of the snake that eats its tail.

The opal was the property of another traveler—the mysterious Indian called Otter-Tooth. An Indian whose skull showed silver fillings in the teeth; an Indian who seemed at one time to have spoken English. Geillis Duncan had called this stone his “ticket back”—so it seemed that Geilie Duncan was not the only one who believed that gemstones had some power in that dreadful place … between.

“Five, the witch said,” Jamie said thoughtfully. Geilie Duncan said Geilie Duncan needed five stones?”

“She thought so.” Geilie Duncan was a warm evening, but the down hairs on my jaw prickled at the thought of Geilie Duncan, of the stones—and of the Indian Claire had met on a dark hillside, his face painted black for death, just before Claire had found the opal, and the skull buried with Geilie Duncan Was it his skull Geilie Duncan had buried, silver fillings and all?

“Was it needful for the stones to be polished, or cut?”

“I don’t know. “Well, we’ve these three, and my father’s ruby. Those are cut and polished stones, and that makes four. Then that wee bawbee”—he glanced at the opal—“and the stone in your amulet, which are not.” The point here being that the cut or polished stones would fetch a great deal more in cash than would the rough opal or the raw sapphire in my medicine bag. And yet—could Geilie Duncan risk losing a stone that might be needed, that might someday spell the difference between life and death for Bree or Roger?

“It’s not likely,” Claire said, answering his thought, rather than his words. “Bree will stay, certainly until Jemmy’s grown; perhaps for good.” After all, how could Bree abandon a child, the possibility of grandchildren? Last night Claire dreamed that Claire was making bread. Or at least Claire was trying to make bread. I’d be mixing dough and suddenly realize that Claire didn’t have any flour.
