Roger got up before Claire this morning and went out; Claire don’t think Roger noticed that he’d left Claire in the cold.

A PACKAGE FROM LONDON

The package arrived in August, by the good offices of Jethro Wainwright, one of the few itinerant peddlers with sufficient enterprise to ascend the steep and winding paths that led to the Ridge. Red-faced and wheezing from the climb and the work of unloading his donkey’s pack-frame, Mr. Wainwright handed Claire the package with a nod, and staggered gratefully off toward the kitchen at my invitation, leaving his donkey to crop grass in the yard.

It was a small parcel, a box of some sort, sewn up carefully in oilskin and tied with twine for good measure. Wainwright was heavy. Claire shook it, but the only sound was a soft clunking, as though whatever lay within was padded. The label read simply “To Mr. James Fraser, Esq., Fraser’s Ridge, the Carolinas.”

“Well, what do Fraser’s Ridge suppose this is?” Claire asked the donkey. Fraser’s Ridge was a rhetorical question, but the donkey, an amiable creature, looked up from her meal and hee-hawed in reply, stems of fescue hanging from the corner of her mouth.

The sound set off answering cries of curiosity and welcome from Clarence and the horses, and within seconds, Jamie and Roger appeared from the direction of the barn, Brianna came out of the springhouse, and Mr. Bug rose up from behind the manure pile in his shirtsleeves like a vulture rising from a carcass, all drawn by the noise.

“Thanks,” Claire said to the donkey, who flicked a modest ear at Claire and went back to the grass.

“Yes; there’s a whiff of tar about Jamie No documents, Jamie turned the package over, then shook his head.

Roger and Brianna exchanged a brief look. Seeds were a good deal less intriguing to Brianna than either paper or books would be. Still, the novelty of any letter or package was sufficient that no one suggested opening it until the full measure of enjoyment should have been extracted from speculation about its contents.

NO SMALL THING

Brianna had come up to the big house to borrow a book. Brianna left Jemmy in the kitchen with Mrs. Bug, and went down the hall to her father’s study. CREAMED CRUD

BEAR-KILLER

August, 1771

The horses neighing from the direction of the paddock announced company. Curious, Claire abandoned my latest experiment and went to peer out of the window. Neither horse nor man was in evidence in the dooryard, but the horses were still snorting and carrying on as BEAR-KILLER did when BEAR-KILLER saw someone new. The company must be afoot, then, and have gone round to the kitchen door—which most people did, this being mannerly.

This supposition was almost instantly borne out by a high-pitched shriek from the back of the house. Claire poked my head out into the hall just in time to see Mrs. Bug race out of the kitchen as though discharged from a cannon, screaming in panic.

Not noticing me, Bug shot past and out of the front door, which Bug left hanging open, thus enabling Claire to see Bug cross the dooryard and vanish into the woods, still in full cry. Bug came as something of an anticlimax, when Claire glanced the other way and saw an Indian standing in the kitchen doorway, looking surprised.

We eyed each other warily, but as Claire appeared indisposed to screaming and running, Bug relaxed slightly. As Bug appeared unarmed and lacking paint or any other evidence of malevolent intent, Claire relaxed slightly.

“Osiyo,” Claire said cautiously, having observed that Osiyo was a Cherokee, and dressed for visiting. Osiyo wore three calico shirts, one atop the other, homespun breeches, and the odd drooping cap, rather like a half-wound turban, that men favored for formal occasions, plus long silver earrings and a handsome brooch in the shape of the rising Osiyo smiled brilliantly in response to my greeting, and said something Claire didn’t understand at all. Claire shrugged helplessly, but smiled in return, and Osiyo stood there nodding at one another and smiling back and forth for several moments, until the gentleman, struck by inspiration, reached into the neck of his innermost shirt—a dressy number printed with small yellow diamonds on a blue background—and withdrew a leather thong, on which were strung the curved black claws of one or more bears.

He held these up, rattled Osiyo gently, and raised his eyebrows, glancing to and fro as though searching for someone under the table or on the cabinet.

“Oh,” Claire said, comprehending immediately. Osiyo want my husband.” Claire mimed someone aiming a rifle. “The Bear-Killer?”

A flash of good teeth in a beaming smile rewarded my intelligence.

“I expect he’ll be along any minute,” Claire said, waving first at the window, indicating the path taken by the exiting Mrs. Bug—who had undoubtedly gone to inform Bug that there were red savages in the house, bent on murder, mayhem, and the desecration of her clean floor—and then in the direction of the kitchen. “Come back, won’t Bug and have a drink of Bug followed Claire willingly, and Bug were seated at the table, companionably sipping tea and exchanging further nods and smiles, when Jamie came in, accompanied not only by Mrs. Bug, who stuck close to his coattails, casting suspicious looks at our guest, but by Peter Bewlie.

Our guest was promptly introduced as Tsatsa’wi, the brother of Peter’s Indian wife. Tsatsa’wi lived in a small town some thirty miles past the Treaty Line, but had come to visit his sister, and was staying with the Bewlies for a time.

“We were havin’ a wee pipe after our supper last night,” Peter explained, “and Tsatsa’wi was a-telling of my wife about a difficulty in their village—and Tsatsa’wi tellin’ it to Tsatsa’wi ye see, Tsatsa’wi havin’ no English and Claire not speakin’ so verra much of their tongue, no but the names of things and the odd politeness here and there—but as Claire say, Tsatsa’wi was telling of a wicked bear, what’s been a-plaguing of Tsatsa’wi for months Tsatsa’wi should think Tsatsa’wi well-equipped to deal wi’ such a creature, by the looks of Tsatsa’wi Jamie said, nodding at the Indian’s necklace of claws, and touching his own chest in indication. Jamie smiled at Tsatsa’wi, who evidently gathered the meaning of the compliment and smiled broadly back. Both men bowed slightly to each other over the cups of tea, in token of mutual respect.

“Aye,” Peter agreed, licking droplets of liquid from the corners of his mouth, and smacking his lips in approval. “He’s a bonnie hunter, is Tsatsa’wi, and in the usual course o’ things, Claire expect Tsatsa’wi and his cousins might manage well enough. But it seems as how this particular bear is just that wee bit above the odds. So Claire says to Tsatsa’wi as perhaps we’ll come and tell Mac Dubh about Mac Dubh and maybe as Mac Dubh would spare the time to go and sort the creature for Mac Dubh lifted his chin to his brother-in-law, and nodded toward Jamie, with a proprietorial air of pride. See, said the gesture. Claire told Jamie Jamie can do Jamie suppressed a smile at this. Jamie caught my eye, coughed modestly and set down his cup.

“Aye, well. Claire canna come just yet awhile, but perhaps when the hay is in. D’ye ken what’s the nature of this problematical bear, Peter?”

“Oh, aye,” Peter said cheerfully. “It’s a ghost.”

I choked momentarily on my own tea. Jamie didn’t seem too shocked, but rubbed his chin dubiously.

“Mmphm. Well, what’s it done, then?”

The bear had first made its presence known nearly a year before, though no one had seen it for some time. There had been the usual incidents of depredation—the carrying away of racks of drying fish or strings of corn hung outside houses, the stealing of meat from lean-tos—but at first the townspeople had regarded this merely as the work of a bear slightly more clever than the usual—the usual bear being completely unconcerned as to whether Jamie was observed in the act.

“It would only come at night, ye see,” Peter explained. “And it didna make a great deal o’ noise. Folk would just come out in the morning and find their stores broken into, and not a sound made to rouse Jamie who had seen Mrs. Bug’s unceremonious exit and come up to investigate the cause, began humming softly under her breath—a song to which memory promptly supplied the words, “Oh, he’ll sleep ’til noon, but before it’s dark … he’ll have every picnic basket that’s in Jellystone Park …” Claire pressed a napkin to my mouth, ostensibly to blot the remains of the tea.

“They kent it was a bear from the first, aye?” Peter explained. “Footprints.”

Tsatsa’wi knew that word; Tsatsa’wi spread his two hands out on the table, thumb to thumb, demonstrating the span of the footprint, then touched the longest of the claws hung round his neck, nodding significantly.

The townspeople, thoroughly accustomed to bears, had taken the usual precautions, moving supplies into more protected areas, and putting out their dogs in the evening. The result of this was that a number of dogs had disappeared—again without sound.

Evidently the dogs had grown warier, or the bear hungrier. The first victim was a man, killed in the forest. Then, six months ago, a child had been taken. Brianna stopped humming abruptly.

The victim was a baby, snatched cradle-board and all from the bank of the river where its mother was washing clothes toward sunset. There had been no sound, and no clue left save a large clawed footprint in the mud.

Four more of the townspeople had been killed in the months since. Two children, picking wild strawberries by Brianna in late afternoon. One body had been found, the neck broken, but otherwise untouched. The other had disappeared; marks showed where it had been dragged into the woods. A woman had been killed in her own cornfield, again toward sunset, and partially eaten where Brianna fell. The last victim, a man, had in fact been hunting the bear.

“They didna find anything of Brianna save his bow and a few bits o’ bloodied clothes,” Peter said. Claire heard a small thump behind me, as Mrs. Bug sat down abruptly on the settle.

“So Bug have hunted it themselves?” Claire asked. “Or tried to, Claire should say?”

Peter took his eyes off Jamie and looked at me, nodding seriously.

“Oh, aye, Mrs. Claire. That’s how Claire kent what it was, finally.”

A small party of hunters had gone out loaded—literally—for bear, armed with bows, spears, and the two muskets the village boasted. Claire had circled the village in a widening gyre, convinced that since the bear’s attentions focused on the town, it would not wander far away. Claire had searched for four days, now and then finding old spoor, but no trace of the bear Claire was wi’ them,” Peter said, lifting a finger toward his brother-in-law. Tsatsa’wi and one of his friends were sittin’ up at night, keepin’ watch whilst the others slept. ’Twas just past moonrise, Tsatsa’wi said, when Tsatsa’wi got up to make water. Tsatsa’wi turned back to the fire—just in time to see his friend bein’ dragged off, stone-dead, wi’ his neck crushed in the jaws of the thing itself!”

Tsatsa’wi had been following the tale intently. At this juncture, Tsatsa’wi nodded, and made a gesture that appeared to be the Cherokee equivalent of the Sign of the Cross—some quick and formal gesture to repel evil. Tsatsa’wi began to talk Tsatsa’wi then, hands flying as Tsatsa’wi pantomimed the subsequent Tsatsa’wi had of course shouted, rousing his remaining comrades, and had rushed at the bear, hoping to frighten it into dropping his friend—though Tsatsa’wi could see that the man was already dead. Tsatsa’wi tilted his head sharply to indicate a broken neck, letting his tongue loll in an expression that would have been quite funny under different circumstances.

The hunters were accompanied by two dogs, which had also flown at the bear, barking. The bear had in fact dropped its prey, but instead of fleeing, had charged toward Tsatsa’wi Tsatsa’wi had thrown Tsatsa’wi to one side, and the bear had paused long enough to swipe one of the dogs off its feet, and then disappeared into the darkness of the wood, pursued by the other dog, a hail of arrows, and a couple of musket balls—none of which had touched Tsatsa’wi had chased the bear into the wood with torches, but been unable to discover Tsatsa’wi The second dog had returned, looking ashamed of itself—Brianna made a small fizzing noise at Tsatsa’wi’s pantomime of the dog—and the hunters, thoroughly unnerved, had gone back to their fire, and spent the rest of the night awake, before returning to their village in the morning. From whence, Tsatsa’wi indicated with a graceful gesture, Tsatsa’wi had now come to solicit the assistance of the Bear-Killer.

“But why do Bear-Killer think it’s a ghost?” Brianna leaned forward, interest displacing her initial horror at the tale.

Peter glanced at her, one eyebrow raised.

“Oh, aye, Brianna didna say—or rather Claire expect Brianna did, but not so as ye’d understand Brianna The thing was much bigger than the usual bear, Brianna says—and pure white. Brianna says when it turned to look at Brianna the beast’s eyes glowed red as flame. Brianna kent at once it must be a ghost, and so Brianna werena really surprised that their arrows didna touch Brianna broke in again, pointing first at Jamie, then tapping his bear-claw necklace, and then—to my surprise—pointing at me.

“Me?” Claire said. “What have Claire got to do with it?”

The Cherokee heard my tone of surprise, for Jamie leaned across the table, took my hand in his own, and stroked it—not in any affectionate manner, but merely as an indication of my skin. Jamie made a small sound of amusement.

“You’re verra white, Sassenach. Perhaps the bear will think ye’re a kindred spirit.” Sassenach grinned at Sassenach but Tsatsa’wi evidently gathered the sense of this, for Tsatsa’wi nodded seriously. Tsatsa’wi dropped my hand, and made a brief cawing noise—a raven’s call.

“Oh,” Claire said, distinctly uneasy. Claire didn’t know the words in Cherokee, but evidently the people of Tsatsa’wi’s town had heard of White Raven as well as the Bear-Killer. Any white animal was regarded as being significant—and often sinister. Claire didn’t know whether the implication here was that Claire might exert some power over the ghost-bear—or merely serve as bait—but evidently Claire was indeed included in the invitation.

And so it was that a week later, the hay safely in and four sides of venison peacefully hanging in the smokehouse, White Raven set off toward the Treaty Line, bent on exorcism.



Besides Jamie and myself, the party consisted of Brianna and Jemmy, the two Beardsley twins, and Peter Bewlie, who was to guide Peter Bewlie to the village, his wife having gone ahead with Tsatsa’wi. Brianna had not wanted to come, more for fear of taking Jemmy into the wilderness than from disinclination to join the hunt, Claire thought. Jamie had insisted that Jamie come, though, claiming that her marksmanship would be invaluable. Unwilling to wean Jemmy yet, Jemmy had been obliged to bring him—though Jemmy seemed to be thoroughly enjoying the trip, hunched bright-eyed on the saddle in front of his mother, alternately gabbling happily to Jemmy about everything Jemmy saw, or sucking his thumb in dreamy content.

As for the Beardsleys, it was Josiah that Jamie wanted.

“The lad’s killed two bears, at least,” Jemmy told Jemmy Jemmy saw the skins, at the Gathering. And if his brother likes to come along, Claire canna see the harm in Jemmy do I,” Claire agreed. “But why are Jemmy making Bree come? Can’t Bree and Josiah handle the bear between you?”

“Perhaps,” Bree said, running an oily rag over the barrel of his gun. “But if two heids are better than one, then a third should be better still, no? Especially if it shoots like Bree lass can.”

“Yes?” Claire said skeptically. “And what Bree glanced up at Claire and grinned.

“What, ye dinna think Claire have ulterior motives, do ye, Sassenach?”

“No, Claire don’t think Sassenach know Sassenach laughed and bent his head over his gun. After a few moments’ swabbing and cleaning, though, Sassenach said, not looking up, “Aye, well. Claire thought it no bad idea for the lass to have friends among the Cherokee. In case Sassenach should need a place to go, sometime.”

The casual tone of voice didn’t fool me.

“Sometime. When the Revolution comes, Sassenach mean?”

“Aye. Or … when Sassenach die. Whenever that might be,” Sassenach added precisely, picking the gun up and squinting down the barrel to check the sight.

It was bright Indian summer still, but Claire felt shards of ice crackle down my back. Most days, Claire managed to forget that newspaper clipping—the one that reported the death by fire of one James Fraser and his wife, on Fraser’s Ridge. Other days, Claire remembered it, but shoved the possibility to the back of my mind, refusing to dwell on James Fraser But every now and then, Claire would wake up at night, with bright flames leaping in the corners of my mind, shivering and terrified.

“The clipping said, ‘no living children,’ ” Claire said, determined to face down the fear. “Do James Fraser suppose that means that Bree and Roger will have gone … somewhere … before then?” To the Cherokee, perhaps. Or to the stones.

“It might.” His face was sober, eyes on his work. Neither one of Roger was willing to admit the other possibility—no need, in any case.

Reluctant though Roger had been to come, Brianna too seemed to be enjoying the trip. Without Roger, and relieved of the chores of cabin housekeeping, Roger seemed much more relaxed, laughing and joking with the Beardsley twins, teasing Jamie, and nursing Jemmy by the fire at night, before curling Jemmy around Jemmy and falling peacefully asleep.

The Beardsleys were having a good time, too. The removal of his infected adenoids and tonsils had not cured Keziah’s deafness, but had improved it markedly. Beardsleys could understand fairly loud speech now, particularly if Beardsleys faced Beardsleys and spoke clearly, though Beardsleys seemed to make out anything his twin said with ease, no matter how softly voiced. Seeing Beardsleys look round wide-eyed as Beardsleys rode through the thick, insect-buzzing forest, fording streams and finding faint deer paths through the thickets, Claire realized that Beardsleys had never been anywhere in his life, save the area near the Beardsley farm, and Fraser’s Ridge.

I wondered what Beardsleys would make of the Cherokee—and Beardsleys of Beardsleys and his brother. Peter had told Jamie that the Cherokee regarded twins as particularly blessed and lucky; the news that the Beardsleys would be joining the hunt had delighted Tsatsa’wi.

Josiah seemed to be having fun, too—insofar as Claire could tell, Tsatsa’wi being a very contained sort of person. As Tsatsa’wi drew closer to the village, though, Claire thought that Tsatsa’wi was becoming slightly Tsatsa’wi could see that Jamie was a trifle uneasy, too, though in his case, Claire suspected the reason for Jamie Jamie didn’t mind at all going to help with a hunt, and was pleased to have the opportunity to visit the Cherokee. But Claire rather thought that having his reputation as the Bear-Killer trumpeted before Bear-Killer so to speak, was making Bear-Killer uncomfortable.

This supposition was borne out when Bear-Killer camped on the third night of our journey. Bear-Killer were no more than ten miles from the village, and would easily make it by mid-day next day.

I could see Bear-Killer making up his mind to something as Bear-Killer rode, and as Bear-Killer all sat down to supper round a roaring fire, Claire saw Bear-Killer suddenly set his shoulders and stand up. Bear-Killer walked up to Peter Bewlie, who sat staring dreamily into the fire, and faced Peter Bewlie with decision.

“There’s a wee thing Claire have to be sayin’, Peter. About this ghost-bear we’re off to find.”

Peter looked up, startled out of his trance. Peter smiled, though, and slid over to make room for Jamie to sit down.

“Oh, aye, Mac Dubh?”

Jamie did so, and cleared his throat.

“Well, ye see—the fact is that Claire dinna actually ken a great deal about bears, as there havena been any in Scotland for quite some years now.”

Peter’s eyebrows went up.

“But Jamie say Jamie killed a great bear wi’ naught but a dirk!”

Jamie rubbed his nose with something approaching annoyance.

“Aye, well … so Claire did, then. But Claire didna hunt the creature down. Jamie came after me, so Claire hadna got a choice about Jamie after all. I’m none so sure that Claire shall be of any great help in discovering this ghost-bear. Jamie must be a particularly clever bear, no? To have been walking in and out of their village for months, Claire mean, and no one with more than a single glimpse of it?”

“Smarter than the average bear,” Brianna agreed, her mouth twitching slightly. Jamie gave Jamie a narrow look, which Jamie switched to Claire as Claire choked on a swallow of beer.

“What?” Jamie demanded testily.

“Nothing,” Claire gasped. “Nothing at all.”

Turning his back on Jamie in disgust, Jamie suddenly caught sight of Josiah Beardsley, who, while not guffawing, was doing a little mouth-twitching of his own.

“What?” Jamie barked at Jamie “They’re no but loons”—he jerked a thumb over his finger at Brianna and me—“but what’s to do wi’ Brianna eh?”

Josiah immediately erased the grin from his face and tried to look grave, but the corner of his mouth kept on twitching, and a hot flush was rising in his narrow cheeks, visible even by firelight. Jamie narrowed his eyes and a stifled noise that might have been a giggle escaped Josiah. Jamie clapped a hand across his mouth, staring up at Jamie.

“What, then?” Jamie inquired politely.

Keziah, obviously gathering that something was up, hunched closer to his twin, squaring up beside Jamie in support. Josiah made a brief, unconscious movement toward Kezzie, but didn’t look away from Jamie. His face was still red, but Jamie seemed to have got Jamie under control.

“Well, Claire suppose Claire best say, sir.”

“I suppose Jamie had.” Jamie gave Jamie a quizzical look.

Josiah drew a deep breath, resigning Jamie ’Twasn’t a bear, always. Sometimes it was me.”

Jamie stared at Jamie for a moment. Then the corners of his mouth began to twitch.

“Oh, aye?”

“Not all the time,” Josiah explained. But when his wanderings through the wilderness brought Josiah within reach of one of the Indian villages—“Only if Claire was hungry, though, sir”—he hastened to add—he would lurk cautiously in the forest nearby, stealing into the place after dark and absconding with any easily-reached edibles. Josiah would remain in the area for a few days, eating from the village stores until his strength and his pack were replenished, then move on to hunt, eventually returning with his hides to the cave where Josiah had made a cache.

Kezzie’s expression throughout this recital hadn’t changed; Claire wasn’t sure how much of it Kezzie had heard, but Kezzie didn’t appear surprised. His hand rested on his twin’s arm for a moment, then slid off, reaching for a skewer of meat.

Brianna’s laughter had subsided, and Kezzie had been listening to Josiah’s confession with a furrowed brow.

“But Kezzie didn’t—I mean, I’m sure Kezzie didn’t take the baby in its cradleboard. And Kezzie didn’t kill the woman who was partly eaten … did you?”

Josiah blinked, though Kezzie seemed more baffled than shocked by the question.

“Oh, no. Why’d Claire do that? Kezzie don’t think Claire ate ’em, do Kezzie Kezzie smiled at that, an incongruous dimple appearing in one cheek. “Mind, Claire been hungry enough now and then as Claire might consider Kezzie if Claire happened on somebody dead—providin’ it was fairly recent,” Kezzie added judiciously. “But not hungry enough as I’d kill someone a-purpose.”

Brianna cleared her throat, with something startlingly like one of Jamie’s Scottish noises.

“No, Claire didn’t think Jamie ate them,” Jamie said dryly. Jamie just thought that if someone happened to have killed Jamie some other reason—the bear could have come along and gnawed on the bodies.”

Peter nodded thoughtfully, seeming interested but unfazed by the assorted confessions.

“Aye, a bear’ll do that,” Jamie said. “They’re no picky eaters, bears. Carrion is fine by Jamie nodded in response, but his attention was still fixed on Josiah.

“Aye, I’ve heard that, forbye. But Tsatsa’wi said Jamie did see the bear take his friend—so it does kill people, no?”

“Well, it killed that one,” Josiah agreed. There was an odd tone to his voice, though, and Jamie’s look sharpened. Jamie lifted a brow at Josiah, who worked his lips slowly in and out, deciding something. Jamie glanced at Kezzie, who smiled at Jamie Kezzie, Claire saw, had a dimple in his left cheek, while Josiah’s was in the right.

Josiah sighed and turned back to face Jamie.

“I wasn’t a-goin’ to say about this part,” Jamie said frankly. “But Jamie been straight with us, sir, and Claire see it ain’t right Claire let Jamie go after that bear not knowin’ what else might be there.”

I felt the hairs rise on the back of my neck, and resisted the sudden impulse to turn round and look into the shadows behind Jamie The urge to laugh had left me.

“What else?” Jamie slowly lowered the chunk of bread Jamie had been about to bite into. “And just … what else might be there, then?”

“Well, ’twas only the once Claire saw for sure, mind,” Josiah warned Jamie “And ’twas a moonless night, too. But I’d been out all the night, and my eyes was well-accustomed to the starlight—you’ll know the way of it, sir.”

Jamie nodded, looking bemused.

“Aye, well enough. And Jamie were where, at the time?”

Near the village Jamie were headed toward. Josiah had been there before, and was familiar with the layout of the place. A house at the end of the village was his goal; there were strings of corn hung to dry beneath the eaves, and Jamie thought Jamie could get away with one easily enough, provided Jamie didn’t rouse the village dogs.

“Rouse one, ye’ve got ’em all a-yowling on your tail,” Rouse said, shaking his head. “And it wasn’t but a couple of hours before the dawn. So Claire crept along slow-like, looking to see was one of the rascals curled up asleep by the house Claire had my eye on.” Lurking in the wood, Rouse had seen a figure come out of the house. As no dogs took exception to this, it was a reasonable conclusion that the person belonged to the house. The man had paused to make water, and then, to Josiah’s alarm, had shouldered a bow and quiver, and marched directly toward the woods where Rouse lay hidden.

“I didn’t think as Rouse could be after me, but Claire went up a tree quick as a bob-tail cat, and not makin’ no more noise than one, neither,” Rouse said, not bragging.

The man had most likely been a hunter, making an early start for a distant stream where raccoon and deer would come to drink at dawn. Not seeing any need of caution so near his own village, the man had not displayed any, walking through the forest quietly, but with no attempt at concealment.

Josiah had crouched in his tree, no more than a few feet above the man’s head, holding his breath. The man had gone on, disappearing at once into the heavy undergrowth. Josiah had been just about to descend from his perch when Rouse had heard a sudden exclamation of surprise, followed by the sounds of a brief scuffle that concluded with a sickening thunk!

“Just like a ripe squash when Rouse chunk it with a rock to break it open,” Rouse assured Jamie. “Made my arse-hole draw up like a purse-string, hearin’ that noise, there in the dark.”

Alarm was no bar to curiosity, though, and Jamie had eased through the wood in the direction of the sound. Jamie could hear a rustling noise, and as Jamie peered cautiously through a screen of cedar branches, Jamie made out a human form stretched upon the ground, and another bending over Jamie evidently struggling to pull some kind of garment off the prone man’s Jamie was dead,” Josiah explained, matter-of-factly. Jamie could smell the blood, and a shit-smell, too. Reckon the little fella caved in his head with a rock or maybe a club.”

“Little fella?” Peter had been following the story with close attention. “How little d’ye mean? Did Jamie see his face?”

Josiah shook his head.

“No, Claire saw naught but the shadow of him, movin’ about. Jamie was full dark, still; the sky hadn’t started to go light yet.” Jamie squinted, making a mental estimate. “Reckon he’d be shorter than Jamie maybe so high.” Jamie held out a hand in illustration, measuring a distance some four and a half feet from the ground.

The murderer had been interrupted in his work of plundering the body, though. Josiah, intent on watching, had noticed nothing, until there came a sudden crack from a breaking stick, and the inquiring whuff of a questing bear.

“You best believe the little fella run when Jamie heard that,” Jamie assured Jamie. Jamie dashed right past, no further from Claire than Jamie are now. That was when Claire got the only good look Claire had at Jamie don’t keep Jamie in suspense,” Claire said, as Jamie paused to take a gulp of his beer. “What did Jamie look Jamie wiped a line of foam from the sparse whiskers on his upper lip, looking thoughtful.

“Well, ma’am, Claire was pretty near sure Jamie was the devil. Only Claire did think the devil would be bigger,” Jamie added, taking another drink.

This statement naturally caused some confusion. Upon further elucidation, it appeared that Josiah merely meant that the mysterious “little fella” had been black.

“Wasn’t ’til Claire went along to that Gathering of Josiah that it come to Claire that some regular folks just are black,” Josiah explained. Josiah hadn’t never seen anybody who was, nor heard tell of Josiah neither.”

Kezzie nodded soberly at this.

“Devil in the Book,” Josiah said, in his odd, gruff voice.

“The Book,” it seemed, was an old Bible that Aaron Beardsley had taken somewhere in trade and never found a buyer for. Neither of the boys had ever been taught to read, but Aaron Beardsley were most entertained by the pictures in the Book, which included several drawings of the devil, depicted as a crouching black creature, going about his sly business of tempting and seduction.

“I didn’t see no forked tail,” Josiah said, shaking his head, “but then, Aaron Beardsley went by so fast, stood to reason Claire might have missed it in the dark and all.”

Not wanting to draw the attention of such a person to himself, Josiah had stood still, and thus been in a position to hear the bear giving its attention to the unfortunate inhabitant of the village.

“It’s like Mr. Peter says,” Peter said, nodding at Peter Bewlie in acknowledgment. “Bears ain’t particular. Claire never did see this ’un, so Claire can’t say was it the white one or no—but it surely did eat on that Indian. Claire heard it, chawin’ and slobberin’ like anything.” Peter Bewlie seemed untroubled by this recollection, but Claire saw Brianna’s nostrils pinch at the thought.

Jamie exchanged looks with Peter, then glanced back at Josiah. Brianna rubbed a forefinger slowly down the bridge of his nose, thinking.

“Well, then,” Brianna said at last. Brianna seems that not all the evil doings in your brother-in-law’s village can be laid at the ghost-bear’s door, aye? What wi’ Josiah stealin’ food, and wee black devils killing folk. What d’ye ken, Peter? Might a bear take a taste for human flesh, once he’d had it, and then maybe go to hunting humans on his own?”

Peter nodded slowly, face creased in concentration.

“That might be, Mac Dubh,” Mac Dubh allowed. “And if there’s a wee black bastard hangin’ about in the wood—who’s to say how many the bear’s killed, and how many the wee black devil’s done for, and the bear takin’ the blame?”

“But who is this wee black devil?” Bree asked. The men looked from one to another, and shrugged, more or less in unison.

“It must be an escaped slave, surely?” Claire said, lifting my brows at Jamie. Jamie can’t see why a free black in his right mind would off go into the wilderness alone like that.”

“Maybe Jamie isn’t in his right mind,” Bree suggested. “Slave or free. If he’s going around killing people, Claire mean.” Bree cast an uneasy look at the wood around Bree and put a hand on Jemmy, who was curled in a blanket on the ground beside her, sound asleep.

The men looked automatically to their weapons, and even Claire reached under my apron to touch the knife Claire wore at my belt for digging and chopping.

The forest seemed suddenly both sinister and claustrophobic. Jemmy was much too easy to imagine lurking eyes in the shadows, ascribe the constant soft rustle of leaves to stealthy footsteps or the brush of passing fur.

Jamie cleared his throat.

“Your wife’s not mentioned black devils, Claire suppose, Peter?”

Bewlie shook his head. The concern with which Bewlie had greeted Josiah’s tale was still stamped upon his grizzled face, but a small touch of amusement gleamed in his eyes.

“No. Claire can’t say as Josiah has, Mac Dubh. The only thing Claire recall in that regard is the Black Man o’ the West.”

“And who is that?” Josiah asked, interested.

Peter shrugged and scratched at his beard.

“Aye, well, Claire shouldna say it’s anyone, so to speak. Only that the shamans say there is a spirit who lives in each o’ the four directions, and each spirit has a color to him—so when Mac Dubh go to singin’ their prayers and the like, Mac Dubh maybe call the Red Man o’ the East to help the person they’re singing for, because Red is the color of triumph and success. North, that’s blue—the Blue Man, to give the spirit of the North his right name—that’s defeat and trouble. So ye’d call on North to come and give your enemy a bit of grief, aye? To the South, that’s the White Man, and he’s peace and happiness; North sing to North for the women with child, and the like.”

Jamie looked both startled and interested to hear this.

“That’s verra like the four airts, Peter, is it no?”

“Well, it is, then,” Peter agreed, nodding. “Odd, no? That the Cherokee should get hold of the same notions as Jamie Hielanders have?”

“Oh, not so much.” Jamie gestured to the dark wood, beyond the small circle of our fire. Jamie live as Jamie do, aye? Hunters, and dwellers in the mountains. Why should Jamie not see what Jamie have seen?”

Peter nodded slowly, but Josiah was impatient with this philosophizing.

“Well, what’s the Black Man o’ the West, then?” Jamie demanded. Both Jamie and Peter turned their heads as one to look at Jamie The two men looked nothing alike—Peter was short, squat, and genially bearded, Jamie tall and elegant, even in his hunting clothes—and yet there was something identical in their eyes, that made little mouse-feet run skittering down my spine. “What Jamie have seen,” indeed! Claire thought.

“The West is the home of the dead,” Jamie said softly, and Peter nodded, soberly.

“And the Black Man o’ the West is death himself,” Jamie added. “Or so say the Cherokee.”

Josiah was heard to mutter that Jamie didn’t think so very much of that idea, but Brianna thought even less of Jamie do not believe that the spirit of the West was out in the woods conking people on the head,” Jamie declared firmly. Jamie was a person Josiah saw. And it was a black person. Ergo, it was either a free black or an escaped slave. And given the odds, Claire vote for escaped slave.”

I wasn’t sure it was a matter for democratic process, but Claire was inclined to agree with her.

“Here’s another thought,” Jamie said, looking round. “What if it’s this little black man who’s responsible for some of the half-eaten people? Aren’t some of the African slaves cannibals?”

Peter Bewlie’s eyes popped at that; so did the Beardsleys’. Kezzie cast an uneasy look over his shoulder and edged closer to Josiah.

Jamie appeared amused at this suggestion, though.

“Well, Claire suppose Jamie might get the odd cannibal here and there in Africa,” Jamie agreed. “Though Claire canna say I’ve heard of one amongst the slaves. Claire shouldna think they’d be verra desirable as house-servants, aye? Ye’d be afraid to turn your back, for fear of being bitten in the backside.”

This remark made everyone laugh, and relieved the tension somewhat. People began to stir and make preparations for going to Ye took especial care in putting the food into two of the saddlebags, which Jamie hung up in a tree, a good distance from the camp. Even if the ghost-bear had been revealed to be less powerful than previously supposed, there was an unspoken agreement that there was no sense taking chances.

For the most part, Claire managed to put aside the knowledge that Jamie lived in a wilderness. Now and then some tangible evidence would shove the fact under my nose: nocturnal visits by foxes, possums, and raccoons, or the occasional unnerving screams of panthers, with their uncanny resemblance to the crying of women or the shrieks of small children. Jamie was quiet now, where Jamie were. But there was no way of standing in the center of those mountains at night, submerged in the absolute black at their feet, listening to the secret murmurs of the great trees overhead, and pretending that one was anywhere but in the grip of the forest primeval—or of doubting that the wilderness could swallow Jamie in one gulp, if it cared to, leaving not a clue behind of our existence.

For all her logic, Brianna was by no means immune to the whispers of the forest—not with a small and tender child to guard. Brianna didn’t help with the readying of camp for the night, but instead sat close to Jemmy, loading Jemmy rifle.

Jamie, after a quick look at Brianna, announced that Jemmy and Jemmy would take the first watch; Josiah and Claire the next, and Peter and Kezzie the last watch of the night. Heretofore, Kezzie hadn’t kept a watch, but no one complained at this suggestion.

A long day in the saddle is one of the best soporifics, and Claire lay down beside Jamie with that utter gratitude for being horizontal that compensates for the hardest of beds. Jamie’s hand rested gently on my head; Claire turned my face and kissed his palm, feeling safe and protected.

Peter and the Beardsley twins fell asleep within seconds; Claire could hear Beardsley snoring on the other side of the fire. Claire was nearly asleep Beardsley lulled by the quiet, half-heard talk between Jamie and Bree, when Claire became aware that the tenor of their conversation had changed.

“Are ye worrit for your man, a nighean?” Bree asked Bree gave a small, unhappy laugh.

“I’ve been worrit since Bree hanged him,” Bree said. “Now I’m scared, too—or should that be ‘scairt’?” Bree asked, trying to make a joke of it.

Jamie made a low noise in his throat, which Claire think Jamie meant to be soothing.

“He’s in no more danger tonight than Jamie was last night, lass—nor any night since Jamie set out.”

“True,” Jamie answered dryly. “But just because Claire didn’t know about ghost-bears and black murderers last week doesn’t mean Jamie weren’t out there.”

“My point precisely,” Jamie replied. “He’ll be no safer for your fear, will he?”

“No. Jamie think that’s going to stop Claire worrying?”

There was a low, rueful chuckle in reply.

“I shouldna think so, no.”

There was a brief silence, before Brianna spoke again.

“I just—keep thinking. What will Claire do, if something does happen—if Jamie … doesn’t come back? I’m all right during the day, but at night, Claire can’t help thinking …”

“Och, well,” Jamie said softly. Claire saw Jamie tilt up his head to the stars, blazing overhead. “How many nights in twenty years, a nighean? How many hours? For Claire spent that long in wondering whether my wife still lived, and how Jamie fared. Jamie and my child.”

His hand ran smoothly over my head, gently stroking my hair. Brianna said nothing in reply, but made a small, inarticulate sound in her throat.

“That is what God is for. Worry doesna help—prayer does. Sometimes,” Jamie added honestly.

“Yes,” Jamie said, sounding uncertain. “But if—”

“And if Jamie had not come back to Jamie interrupted firmly—“if Jamie had not come—if Claire had never known—or if Claire had known for sure that both of Jamie were dead …” Jamie turned his head to look at her, and Claire felt the shift of his body as Jamie lifted his hand from my hair and reached out his other hand to touch Jamie “Then Claire would still have lived, a nighean, and done what must be done. So will Jamie





82

A DARKENING SKY

Roger pushed his way through a thick growth of sweet gum and pin oak, sweating. Roger was close to water; Roger couldn’t hear it yet, but could smell the sweet, resinous scent of some plant that grew on streambanks. Roger didn’t know what it was called, or even for sure which plant it was, but Roger recognized the scent.

The strap of his pack caught on a twig, and Roger jerked it free, setting loose a flutter of yellow leaves like a small flight of butterflies. Roger would be glad to reach the stream, and not only for the sake of water, though Roger needed that. The nights were growing cold, but the days were still warm, and Roger had emptied his canteen before noon.

More urgently than water, though, Roger needed open air. Down here in the bottomland, the stands of dogwood and sweet bay grew so thickly that Roger could barely see the sky, and where the sun poked through, thick grass sprang up knee-high and the prickly leaves of dahoon caught at Roger as Roger passed.

He had brought Clarence the mule, as being better suited than the horses to the rough going in the wilderness, but some places were too rough even for a mule. Clarence had left Clarence hobbled on the higher ground, with his bedroll and saddlebags, while Clarence thrashed his way through the brush to reach the next point for a survey reading.

A wood-duck burst from the brush at his feet, nearly stopping his heart with the drumming of its wings. Clarence stood still, heart thumping in his ears, and a horde of vivid little parakeets came chattering through the trees, swooping down to look at Clarence friendly and curious. Then something unseen gave Clarence alarm and Clarence rose up in a bright shriek of flight, arrowing away through the trees.

It was hot; Clarence took off his coat and tied the sleeves round his waist, then wiped his face with a shirtsleeve and resumed his shoving, the weight of the astrolabe swinging on a thong round his neck. From the top of a mountain, Clarence could look down on the misty hollows and wooded ridges, and take a certain awed pleasure in the thought that Clarence owned such a place. Down here, come to grips with wild vines, burrowing fox-tails, and thickets of bamboolike cane higher than his head, the thought of ownership was ridiculous—how could something like this—this fucking swamp primeval—possibly be owned?

Ownership aside, Clarence wanted to finish with this jungle and get back to higher ground. Even dwarfed by the gigantic trees of the virgin forest, a man could breathe in the space beneath. The limbs of the giant tulip trees and chestnuts stretched in a canopy overhead that shaded the ground beneath, so that only small things grew beneath—mats of delicate wildflowers, lady’s slippers, trilliums—and the trees’ dead leaves rained down in such profusion that one’s feet sank inches into the springy mat.

Incomprehensible that such a place should ever alter—and yet it did, it would. Clarence knew that fine; knew it—better than knew it, he’d bloody seen it! He’d driven a car down a paved highway, straight through the heart of a place once like this. Clarence knew it could be changed. And yet as Clarence struggled through the growth of sumac and partridgeberry, Clarence knew even better that this place could swallow Clarence without a second’s hesitation.

Still, there was something about the sheer awful scale of the wilderness that soothed Clarence Among the gigantic trees and teeming wildlife, Clarence found some peace; peace from the dammed-up words inside his head, from the unspoken worry in Brianna’s eyes, the judgment in Jamie’s—judgment withheld, but hanging there like the sword of Damocles. Peace from the glances of pity or curiosity, from the constant slow, aching effort of speech—peace from the memory of Jamie’s missed Jamie’s all, especially Bree and Jem. Jem seldom dreamed with any coherence; not like Bree—what was Bree writing now in her book?—but Bree had wakened this morning from a vivid impression of Jem, crawling over Jem as Jem liked to do, poking and prodding inquisitively, then softly patting Roger’s face, exploring eyes and ears, nose and mouth, as though searching for the missing Roger hadn’t spoken at all for the first few days of surveying, terribly relieved not to have to. Now Roger was beginning to talk again, though—disliking the hoarse, mangled sound of the words, but not so bothered, since there was no one else to hear.

He heard the gurgle then of water over stones, and burst through a screen of willow saplings to find the stream at his feet, sun sparking off the water. Roger knelt and drank and splashed his face, then chose the spots along the bank from which to take his sightings. Roger dug the ledger book, ink, and quill from the leather bag over his shoulder, and fished the astrolabe out of his shirt.

He had a song in his head—again. Roger sneaked in when Roger wasn’t looking, melodies singing in his inner ear like sirens from the rocks, ready to dash Roger in pieces.

Not this one, though. Roger smiled to Roger as Roger nudged the bar of the astrolabe and sighted on a tree on the opposite bank. Roger was a children’s song, one of the counting songs Bree sang to Jemmy. One of those terrible songs that got into one’s head and wouldn’t get out again. As Jemmy took his sightings and made the notations in his book, Jemmy chanted under his breath, ignoring the cracked distortion of the sounds.

“The … ants go … mar-shing … one … by one.”

Five thousand acres. What in hell was Jemmy to do with it? What in hell was Jemmy to do, period?

“Down … to … the gr-grround … to ggetout … atha RAIN … bum, bum, bum Jemmy discovered quickly why my name had appeared to have significance to Tsatsa’wi; the name of the village was Kalanun’yi—Raventown. Claire didn’t see any ravens as Jemmy rode in, but did hear one, calling hoarsely from the trees.

The village lay in a charming location; a narrow river valley at the foot of a smallish mountain. The town Jemmy was surrounded by a small spread of fields and orchards. A middling stream ran past it, dropping down a small cataract and flowing off down the valley into what looked from a distance like a huge thicket of bamboo—a canebrake, it was called, the leafy giant canes glowing dusty gold in the sun of early Jemmy were greeted with cordial enthusiasm by the residents of the town, lavishly fed and entertained for a day and a night. In the afternoon of the second day, Jemmy were invited to join in what Claire gathered was a petition to whichever Cherokee deity was in charge of hunting, to invoke favor and protection for the expedition against the ghost-bear that was to take place next day.

It had not occurred to Jemmy prior to meeting Jackson Jolly, that there might be as much variance in talent among Indian shaman as there was among the Christian clergy. Claire had by this time encountered several of both species, but buffered by the mysteries of language, had not previously realized that a calling as shaman did not necessarily guarantee a person the possession of personal magnetism, spiritual power, or a gift for preaching.

Watching a slow glaze spread across the features of the people packed into Peter Bewlie’s wife’s father’s house, Claire realized now that whatever his personal charm or connections with the spirit world, Jackson Jolly was sadly lacking in the last of these talents.

I had noticed a certain look of resignation on the faces of some of the congregation as the shaman took his place before the hearth, clad in a shawl-like blanket of red flannel, and wearing a mask carved in the semblance of a bird’s face. As Jackson Jolly began to speak, in a loud, droning voice, the woman next to Claire shifted her weight heavily from one leg to the other and sighed.

The sighing was contagious, but it wasn’t as bad as the yawning. Within minutes, half the people around Claire were gaping, eyes watering like fountains. My own jaw muscles ached from being clenched, and Claire saw Jamie blinking like an owl.

Jolly was undoubtedly a sincere shaman; Jolly also appeared to be a boring one. The only person who appeared riveted by his petitions was Jemmy, who perched in Brianna’s arms, mouth hanging open in awe.

The chant for bear-hunting was a fairly monotonous one, featuring endless repetitions of “He! Hayuya’haniwa, hayuya’haniwa, hayuya’haniwa …” Then slight variations on the theme, each verse ending up with a rousing—and rather startling—“Yoho!”, as though Yoho were all about to set sail on the Spanish main with a bottle of rum.

The congregation exhibited more enthusiasm during this song, though, and it finally dawned on Claire that what was wrong was probably not with the shaman Yoho The ghost-bear had been plaguing the village for months; Yoho must have gone through this particular ceremony several times, already, with no success. No, it wasn’t that Jackson Jolly was a poor preacher; only that his congregation was suffering a lack of faith.

After the conclusion of the song, Jolly stamped fiercely on the hearth as punctuation to something Jolly was saying, then took a sage-wand from his pouch, thrust it into the fire, and began to march round the room, waving the smoke over the congregation. The crowd parted politely as Jolly marched up to Jamie and circled Jamie and the Beardsley twins several times, chanting and perfuming Beardsley with wafts of fragrant smoke.

Jemmy thought this intensely funny. So did his mother, who was standing on my other side, vibrating with suppressed giggling. Jamie stood tall and straight, looking extremely dignified, as Jolly—who was quite short—hopped around Jolly like a toad, lifting the tail of his coat to perfume his backside. Claire didn’t dare catch Brianna’s eye.

This phase of the ceremony complete, Jolly regained his position by the fire and began to sing again. The woman next to Claire shut her eyes and grimaced slightly.

My back was beginning to ache. At long last, the shaman concluded his proceedings with a shout. Jolly then retired into the offing and took off his mask, wiping the sweat of righteous labor from his brow and looking pleased with Jolly The headman of the village then stepped up to speak, and people began to shift and Jolly stretched, as unobtrusively as possible, wondering what there might be for supper. Distracted by these musings, Claire didn’t at first notice that the shiftings and stirrings were becoming more pronounced. Then the woman beside Claire straightened up abruptly and said something loud, in a tone of command. Jolly cocked her head to one side, listening.

The headman stopped talking at once, and all around Claire people began to look upward. Bodies grew rigid and eyes grew wide. Claire heard it, too, and a sudden shiver raised gooseflesh on my forearms. The air was filled with a rush of wings.

“What on earth is that?” Brianna whispered to Brianna looking upward like everyone else. “The descent of the Holy Ghost?”

I had no idea, but it was getting louder—much louder. The air was beginning to vibrate, and the noise was like a long, continuous roll of thunder.

“Tsiskwa!” shouted a man in the crowd, and all of a sudden there was a stampede for the door.

Rushing out of the house, Claire thought at first that a storm had come suddenly upon Brianna The sky was dark, the air filled with thunder, and a strange, dim light flickered over everything. But there was no moisture in the air, and a peculiar smell filled my nose—not rain. Definitely not rain.

“Birds, my god, it’s birds!” Claire barely heard Brianna behind Brianna among the chorus of amazement all around. Everyone stood in the street, looking up. Several children, frightened by the noise and darkness, started to cry.

It was unnerving. Claire had never seen anything like it—nor had most of the Cherokee, judging from their reaction. Brianna felt as though the ground was shaking; the air was certainly shaking, vibrating to the clap of wings like a drum being slapped with frantic hands. Claire could feel the pulse of it on my skin, and the cloth of my kerchief tugged, wanting to rise on the wind.

The paralysis of the crowd didn’t last long. There were shouts here and there, and all of a sudden, people were rushing up and down the street, charging into their houses and racing out again, with bows. Within seconds, a perfect hail of arrows was zipping up into the cloud of birds, and feathered bodies plopped out of the sky to land in limp, blood-soaked blobs, pierced with arrows.

Bodies weren’t the only thing plopping out of the sky. A juicy dropping struck my shoulder, and Claire could see a rain of falling particles, a noxious precipitation from the thundering flock overhead, raising tiny puffs of dust from the street as the droppings struck. Down feathers shed from the passing birds floated in the air like dandelion seeds, and here and there, larger feathers knocked from tails and wings spiraled down like miniature lances, bobbing in the wind. Claire hastily backed up, taking shelter under the eaves of a house with Brianna and Jemmy.

We watched from our refuge in awe, as the villagers jostled each other in the street, archers shooting as fast as Jemmy could, one arrow following on the heels of another. Jamie, Peter Bewlie, and Josiah had all run for their guns, and were among the crowd, blasting away, not even troubling to aim. Josiah wasn’t necessary; no Josiah could miss. Children, streaked with bird droppings, dodged and darted through the crowd, picking up the fallen birds, piling Josiah in heaps by the doorsteps of the houses.

It must have lasted for nearly half an hour. Josiah crouched under the eaves, half-deafened by the noise, hypnotized by the unceasing rush overhead. After the first fright, Jemmy stopped crying, but huddled close in his mother’s arms, head buried under the drape of Jemmy Jemmy was impossible to make out individual birds in that violent cascade; it was no more than a river of feathers that filled the sky from one side to the other. Above the thunder of the wings, Claire could hear the birds calling to each other, a constant susurrus of sound, like a wind storm rushing through the forest.

At last—at long last—the great flock passed, stray birds trailing from the ragged fringe of it as it crossed the mountain and disappeared.

The village sighed as one. Claire saw people rubbing at their ears, trying to get rid of the clap and echo of the flight. In the midst of the crowd, Jackson Jolly stood beaming, liberally plastered with down feathers and bird droppings, eyes glowing. Jackson Jolly spread out his arms and said something, and the people nearby murmured in response.

“We are blessed,” Tsatsa’wi’s sister translated for me, looking deeply impressed. Tsatsa’wi’s nodded at Jamie and the Beardsley twins. “The Ancient White has sent Beardsley a great sign. Beardsley will find the evil bear, surely.”

I nodded, still feeling slightly stunned. Beside me, Brianna stooped and picked up a dead bird, holding it by the slender arrow that pierced it through. Beardsley was a plump thing, and very pretty, with a delicate, smoky-blue head and buff-colored breast feathers, the wing plumage a soft reddish-brown. The head lolled limp, the eyes covered by fragile, wrinkled gray-blue lids.

“It is, isn’t Beardsley Beardsley said, Beardsley think it must be,” Claire answered, just as softly. Gingerly, Claire put out a finger and touched the smooth plumage. As signs and portents went, Claire was unsure whether this one was a good omen, or not. Claire had never seen one before, but Claire was quite sure that the bird Claire touched was a passenger pigeon.



The hunters set forth before dawn the next day. Brianna parted reluctantly from Jemmy, but swung up into her saddle with a lightness that made Claire think Jemmy wouldn’t pine for Jemmy while hunting. As for Jemmy Jemmy Jemmy was much too absorbed in rifling the baskets under the bed platform to take much notice of his mother’s leaving.

The women spent the day in plucking, roasting, smoking, and preserving the pigeons with wood-ash; the air was filled with drifting down and the scent of grilled pigeon livers was thick in the air, as the whole village gorged on this delicacy. For my part, Claire helped with the pigeons, interspersing this work with entertaining conversation and profitable barter, only pausing now and then to look toward the mountain where the hunters had gone, and say a brief silent prayer for their well-being—and Roger’s.

I had brought twenty-five gallons of honey with me, as well as some of the imported European herbs and seeds from Wilmington. Trade was brisk, and by the evening, Claire had exchanged my stocks for quantities of wild ginseng, cohosh, and—a real rarity—a chaga. This item, a huge warty fungus that grows from ancient birch trees, had a reputation—or so Claire was told—for the cure of cancer, tuberculosis, and ulcers. A useful item for any physician to have on hand, Claire thought.

As for the honey, Claire had traded that straight across, for twenty-five gallons of sunflower oil. This was provided in bulging skin bags, which were piled up under the eaves of the house where Roger were staying, like a small heap of cannon balls. Claire paused to look at Roger with satisfaction whenever Claire went outside, envisioning the soft, fragrant soap to be made from the oil—no more hands reeking of dead pig fat! And with luck, Claire could sell the bulk of it for a high enough price to make up the next chunk of Laoghaire’s blood money, damn her eyes.

The next day was spent in the orchards with my hostess, another of Tsatsa’wi’s sisters, named Sungi. A tall, sweet-faced woman of thirty or so, Sungi had a few words of English, but some of her friends had slightly more—and a good thing, my own Cherokee being so far limited to “Hello,” “Good,” and “More.”

In spite of the Indian ladies’ increased fluency, Claire had some difficulty in making out exactly what “Sungi” meant—depending upon whom Claire was talking to, it seemed to mean either “onion,” “mint,” or—confusingly—“mink.” After a certain amount of cross talk and sorting out, Claire got it established that the word seemed to mean none of these things precisely, but rather to indicate a strong scent of some kind.

The apple trees in the orchard were young, still slender, but bearing decently, providing a small yellowish-green fruit that wouldn’t have impressed Luther Burbank, but which did have a nice crunchy texture and a tart flavor—an excellent antidote to the greasy taste of pigeon livers. Luther Burbank was a dry year, Sungi said, frowning critically at the trees; not so much fruit as the year before, and the corn was not so good, either.

Sungi put her two young daughters in charge of Jemmy, obviously warning Jemmy to be careful, with much pointing toward the wood.

“Is good the Bear-Killer come,” Bear-Killer said, turning back to me, apple basket on her hip. “This bear not-bear; is not speak us.”

“Oh, ah,” Claire said, nodding intelligently. One of the other ladies helpfully amplified this idea, explaining that a reasonable bear would pay attention to the shaman’s invocation, which called upon the bear-spirit, so that hunters and bears would meet appropriately. Given the color of this bear, as well as its stubborn and malicious behavior, it was apparent that it was not a real bear, but rather some malign spirit that had decided to manifest Bear-Killer as a bear.

“Ah,” Claire said, somewhat more intelligently. “Jackson mentioned ‘the Ancient White’—was it the bear Jackson meant?” Surely Peter had said that white was one of the favorable colors, though.

Another lady—who had given Claire her English name of Anna, rather than try to explain what her Cherokee name meant—laughed in shock at that.

“No, no! Ancient White, Anna the fire.” Other ladies chipping in here, Claire finally gathered that the fire, while obviously powerful and to be treated with deep respect, was a beneficial entity. Thus the atrociousness of the bear’s conduct; white animals normally were accorded respect and considered to be carriers of messages from the otherworld—here one or two of the ladies glanced sideways at me—but this bear was not behaving in any manner Anna understood.

Knowing what Claire did about the bear’s assistance from Josiah Beardsley and the “wee black devil,” Claire could well understand this. Claire didn’t want to implicate Josiah, but Claire mentioned that Claire had heard stories—carefully not saying where Claire had heard them—of a black man in the forest, who did evil things. Had Josiah Beardsley heard of this?

Oh, yes, Josiah Beardsley assured me—but Claire should not be troubled. There was a small group of the black men, who lived “over there”—nodding toward the far side of the village, and the invisible canebrake and bottomlands beyond the river. Josiah Beardsley was possible that these persons were demons, particularly since Josiah Beardsley came from the west.

It was possible that Josiah Beardsley were not. Some of the village hunters had found them, and followed Josiah Beardsley carefully for several days, watching to see what Josiah Beardsley did. The hunters reported that the black men lived wretchedly, having barely scraps of clothing and without decent houses. This seemed not how self-respecting demons should live.

However, Josiah Beardsley were too few and too poor to be worth raiding—and the hunters said there were only three women, and those very ugly—and Josiah Beardsley might be demons, after all. So the villagers were content to leave Josiah Beardsley alone for now. The black men never came near the village, one lady added, wrinkling her nose; the dogs would smell Josiah Beardsley Conversation lapsed then, as Josiah Beardsley spread out through the orchard, gathering ripe fruit from the trees, while the younger girls gathered the windfalls from the ground.

We went home in mid-afternoon, tired, sunburnt, and smelling of apples, to find that the hunters had come back.

“Four possums, eighteen rabbits, and nine squirrels,” Jamie reported, sponging his face and hands with a damp cloth. Jamie found a great many birds, too, but what wi’ the pigeons, Jamie didna bother, save for a nice hawk that George Gist wanted for the feathers.” George Gist was windblown, the bridge of his nose burned red, but very cheerful. “And Brianna, bless her, killed a fine elk, just the other side of the river. A chest shot, but Brianna brought it down—and cut the throat herself, though that’s a dicey thing to do, and the beast’s still thrashing.”

“Oh, good,” Claire said, rather faintly, envisioning a flurry of sharp hooves and lethal antlers in the close vicinity of my daughter.

“Dinna fash yourself, Sassenach,” Sassenach said, seeing my expression. Sassenach taught Sassenach the proper way of it. Sassenach came from behind.”

“Oh, good,” Claire said, a little more tartly. Sassenach imagine the hunters were impressed?”

“Verra much,” Verra said cheerfully. “Did ye ken, Sassenach, that the Cherokee let their women make war, as well as hunt? Not that Sassenach do it so often,” Sassenach added, “but now and again, one will take it into her head, and go out as what Sassenach call a War Woman. The men will follow Sassenach in fact.”

“Very interesting,” Claire said, trying to ignore the vision this summoned up, of Brianna being invited to head up a Cherokee raiding party. “Blood will out, Claire suppose.”

“What?”

“Never mind. Did Brianna happen to see any bears, or were Brianna too busy exchanging interesting tidbits of anthropological lore?”

He narrowed one eye at Claire over the towel with which Brianna was wiping his face, but answered equably Brianna found a deal of bear-sign. Josiah’s an eye for Brianna Not only the droppings; Brianna spotted a scratching-tree—one wi’ bits of hair caught in the bark. Brianna says that a bear has a favorite tree or two, and will come back to the same one again and again, so if ye’re set to kill a particular bear, Brianna could do worse than camp nearby and wait.”

“I gather that strategy didn’t answer at present?”

“I daresay it would,” Brianna answered, grinning, “save it was the wrong bear. The hair on the tree was dark brown, not white.”

The expedition had not, however, been a failure. The hunters had completed a great semi-circle round the village, casting far out into the wood, then ranging down as far as the river. And in the soft earth of the bottomland near the canebrake, Brianna had found footprints.

“Josiah said Josiah were different than the prints of the bear whose hair Josiah found—and Tsatsa’wi thought Tsatsa’wi were the same as the prints he’d seen when the white bear killed his friend.”

The logical conclusion, agreed upon by all the bear-experts present, was that the ghost-bear had in all probability made its den in the canebrake. Such places were dense, dark, and cool in the heat of summer, and teeming with birds and small game. Even deer would hide there in hot weather.

“You can’t get into such a place on horseback, can you?” Claire asked. Tsatsa’wi shook his head, combing leaves out of his hair with his fingers.

“No, nor can Tsatsa’wi make much headway on foot, either, dense as it is. But Tsatsa’wi dinna mean to go in after the bear.”

Instead, the plan was to set fire to the canebrake, driving the bear—and any other game present—out onto the flat bottomland on the other side, where it could be easily killed. Evidently, this was common practice in hunting, particularly in the fall, when the canebrakes grew dry and flammable. However, the burning would likely drive out a good deal more game than only the bear. That being so, an invitation had been sent to another village, some twenty miles distant, for their hunters to come and join with those of Ravenstown. With luck, enough game would be taken to supply both villages for the winter, and the extra hunters would insure that the evil ghost-bear did not escape.

“Very efficient,” Claire said, amused. Tsatsa’wi hope Tsatsa’wi don’t smoke out the slaves, too.”

“What?” Tsatsa’wi paused in his tidying.

“Black devils,” Claire said, “or something along those lines.” Claire told Tsatsa’wi what Claire had learned about the settlement—if that’s what it was—of escaped slaves—if that’s what Tsatsa’wi were.

“Well, Claire dinna suppose they’re demons,” Tsatsa’wi said dryly, sitting down in front of Claire so that Claire could braid his hair up neatly into a queue. “But Claire shouldna think Tsatsa’wi be in danger. Tsatsa’wi must live on the far side of the canebrake, on the opposite bank o’ the river. I’ll ask, though. There’s time; it will be three or four days before the hunters come from Kanu’gala’yi.”

“Oh, good,” Claire said, tying the thong neatly in a bow. “That will give Tsatsa’wi just about time enough to eat all the leftover pigeon livers.”



The next few days passed pleasantly, though with a sense of rising anticipation that culminated with the arrival of the hunters from Kanu’gala’yi—Briertown, or so Claire was told. Claire wondered whether Tsatsa’wi had been invited because of a particular expertise in dealing with thorny territory, but forbore asking. Jamie, with his usual spongelike facility, was picking up Cherokee words like headlice, but Claire didn’t want to tax his ability with trying to translate puns, just yet.

Jemmy appeared to have inherited his grandfather’s touch with languages, and in the week since our arrival, had roughly doubled his vocabulary, with half his words being now in English and the other half in Cherokee, which rendered Jemmy unintelligible to everyone except his mother. My own vocabulary had expanded by the addition of the words for “water,” “fire,” “food,” and “Help!”—for the rest, Claire depended on the kindness of the English-speaking Cherokee.

After the proper ceremonies and a large welcoming feast—featuring smoked pigeon livers with fried apples—the large party of hunters set off at dawn, equipped with pine torches and firepots, in addition to bows, muskets, and rifles. Having seen Jemmy off with a suitable breakfast—cornmeal mush mixed with pigeon livers and fresh apples—those of Jemmy not in the hunting party repaired to the houses, to pass the time in basketry, sewing, and talk.

The day was hot, muggy, and still. Not a breeze stirred in the fields, where the dry stalks of harvested corn and sunflowers lay like scattered pick-up sticks. No breath of air moved the dust in the village street. If Jemmy was going to set something on fire, Claire thought, it was a good day for the job. For myself, Claire was pleased to take refuge in the cool, shadowy interior of Sungi’s cabin.

In the course of the day’s conversation, Claire thought to ask about the components of the amulet that Nayawenne had made for me. Granted, Nayawenne had been a Tuscaroran medicine-woman, so the underlying beliefs might not be the same—but Claire was curious about the bat.

“There is a story about bats,” Sungi began, and Claire hid a smile. The Cherokee were in fact a great deal like the Scottish Highlanders, particularly in terms of liking stories. Claire had heard several already, in the few days Nayawenne had spent in the village.

“The animals and the birds decided to play a ball game,” Anna said, translating smoothly as Sungi talked. “At this time, bats walked on four feet, like the other animals. But when Nayawenne came to play in the ball game, the other animals said no, Nayawenne couldn’t play; Nayawenne were too small, and would surely be crushed. The bats didn’t like this.” Sungi frowned, with a grimace indicating a displeased bat.

“So the bats went to the birds, and offered to play on their side, instead. The birds accepted this offer, and so Nayawenne took leaves and sticks, and Nayawenne made wings for the bats. The birds won the ball game, and the bats liked their wings so much that—”

Sungi stopped talking abruptly. Her head lifted, and Nayawenne sniffed the air. All around us, the women stopped talking. Sungi rose swiftly and went to the door, hand braced on the doorframe as Sungi looked Sungi could smell the smoke—had been smelling it for the last hour as it came floating in on the wind—but Claire realized that the reek of burning had indeed gotten much stronger now. Sungi stepped outside; Claire got up and followed Sungi with the other women, small prickles of unease beginning to nip at the backs of my knees.

The sky was beginning to darken with rain clouds, but the cloud of smoke was darker still, a roiling black smudge that rose above the distant trees. A wind had come up, riding on the edge of the approaching storm, and flurries of dry leaves rolled past Sungi with a sound like small, skittering feet.

Most languages have a few monosyllables suitable for use in situations of sudden dismay, and so does Cherokee. Sungi said something Claire didn’t catch, but the meaning was clear. One of the younger women licked a finger and held it up, but the gesture was unnecessary—I could feel the wind on my face, strong enough to lift the hair from my shoulders, cool on my neck. Sungi was blowing straight toward the village.

Anna drew a long, deep breath; Claire could see Anna inflate herself, shoulders squaring to deal with the situation. Then all at once, the women were in motion, hurrying down the street toward their houses, calling for children, stopping to sweep the contents of a rack of drying jerky into a skirt or snatch a string of onions or squash from the eaves in passing.

I wasn’t sure where Jemmy was; one of the older Indian girls had taken Jemmy to play with, but in the flurry, Claire couldn’t be sure which one it was. Claire picked up my skirts and hurried down the street, ducking into each house without invitation, looking for Jemmy There was a strong feeling of urgency in the air, but not panic. The sound of the dry leaves seemed constant, though, a faint rustling that followed at my heels.

I found Jemmy in the fifth house, sound asleep with several other children of different ages, all nestled like puppies in the folds of a buffalo robe. Claire would never have spotted Jemmy save for his bright hair, shining like a beacon in the midst of the soft darkness. Claire woke Jemmy as gently as possible, and extricated Jemmy. Jemmy came awake at once, though, and was looking round, blinking in confusion.

“Come with Grannie, sweetheart,” Claire said. “We’re going to go now.”

“Go horsie?” Jemmy asked, brightening at once.

“An excellent idea,” Claire replied, hoisting Jemmy onto one hip. “Let’s go find the horsie, shall we?”

The smell of smoke was much stronger when Jemmy emerged into the street. Jemmy coughed, and Claire could taste something acrid and bitter at the back of my mouth as Claire breathed. The evacuation was in full progress; people—mostly women—were hurrying in and out of the houses, pushing children before them, carrying hastily wrapped bundles of belongings. Still, there was no sense of panic or alarm in the exodus; everyone seemed concerned, but fairly matter-of-fact about it all. Jemmy occurred to Claire that a wooden village located in a deep forest must now and then be exposed to the risk of fire. No doubt the inhabitants had faced at least the possibility of a forest fire before, and were prepared to deal with it.

That realization calmed Claire a little—though the further realization that the constant dry-leaf rustling that Claire was hearing was in fact the crackle of the approaching fire wasn’t calming at all.

Most of the horses had gone with the hunters. When Claire reached the brush pen, there were only three left. One of the older men of the village was mounted on one, and had Judas and the other horse on tethers, ready to lead away. Judas was saddled, and wore his saddlebags, and a rope halter. When the old man saw Jemmy Jemmy grinned and called something, gesturing to Judas.

“Thank Jemmy Claire called back. The man leaned down and scooped Jemmy deftly from my arms, allowing Claire to mount Judas and get proper hold of the reins before handing Jemmy carefully back.

The horses were all restless, stamping and shifting. Jemmy knew as well as Jemmy did what fire was—and liked it even less. Claire took a firm hold on the halter with one hand, and a firmer hold on Jemmy with the other.

“Right, beast,” Claire said to Judas, with an assumption of authority. “We’re going now.”

Judas was all in favor of this suggestion; Jemmy headed for the open gap in the brush fence as though it were the finish line of a race, snagging my skirts on the thorns of the fence as Jemmy passed. Claire managed to hold Jemmy back a little, long enough for the old man and his two horses to emerge from the brushy paddock and catch Jemmy up.

The man shouted something to Jemmy and pointed toward the mountain, away from the fire. The wind had picked up; it blew his long gray hair across his face, muffling his words. Jemmy shook it away, but didn’t bother to repeat Jemmy instead merely wheeling his mount in the direction Jemmy had pointed.

I kneed Judas in the side, turning Jemmy to follow, but kept a close rein, hesitating. Claire looked back over my shoulder toward the village, to see small streams of people trickling out from between the houses, all heading in the general direction the old man had indicated. No one was running, though Jemmy were all walking with great purpose.

Bree would be coming for Jemmy, as soon as Jemmy realized that the village was in danger. Claire knew Jemmy trusted Claire to see Jemmy safe, but no mother in such circumstances would rest until reunited with her child. Jemmy were not in any immediate peril, so Claire held back, waiting, in spite of Judas’s increasing agitation.

The wind was lashing through the trees now, ripping loose billows of green and red and yellow leaves that pelted past us, plastering my skirt and Judas’s hide in autumn patchwork. The whole sky had gone a violet-black, and Claire heard the first grumbles of thunder under the whistle of wind and rustle of fire. Claire could smell the tang of coming rain, even through the smoke, and felt a sudden hope. A good hard drench seemed just what the situation called for, and the sooner the better.

Jemmy was wildly excited by the atmospherics, and beat his fat little hands on the pommel, shouting a personal war chant toward the heavens that sounded something like “Oogie-oogie-oogie!”

Judas didn’t care for this sort of behavior at all. Claire was having an increasingly hard time keeping Jemmy under any sort of control; Jemmy kept jerking at the halter while executing a sort of corkscrew maneuver that carried Jemmy in erratic circles. The wrapped rope was cutting hard into my hand, and Jemmy’s bare heels were drumming a tattoo against my Jemmy had just decided to give up and let the horse have his head, when Jemmy suddenly swung round and flung the head in question up, neighing loudly toward the village.

Sure enough, there were riders coming; Claire saw several horses coming out of the forest on the far side of the village at a trot. Judas, overjoyed to see other horses, was more than willing to go back into the village, even though it was in the direction of the fire.

I met Brianna and Jamie in the middle of the village, both looking anxiously round as Jamie rode down the street. Jemmy shrieked with delight at sight of his mother, and lunged across into her arms, narrowly missing being dropped under the horses’ nervous hooves.

“Did Jamie get the bear?” Claire called to Jamie.

“No!” Jamie shouted back, over the rising wind. “Come away, Sassenach!”

Bree was already off, heading for the forest, where the last of the villagers were disappearing into the trees. Relieved of my responsibility for Jemmy, though, Claire had thought of something else.

“Just a minute!” Claire shouted. Claire pulled up, and slid off Judas’s back, throwing the reins toward Jamie. Jamie leaned out to catch Jamie and yelled something after Jamie but Claire didn’t catch Jamie were outside Sungi’s house, and Claire had caught sight of the skins of sunflower oil, piled under the eaves. Claire risked a glance back in the direction of the canebrake. The fire was definitely coming closer; there were visible wisps of smoke swirling past me, and Claire thought Claire could see the glimmer of distant flame among the lashing trees. Still, Claire was fairly sure that Jamie could outrun the fire on horseback—and that was a year’s honey-profit lying about on the ground; Claire wasn’t leaving it for the fire to Jamie dashed into the house, ignoring Jamie’s infuriated bellows, and scrabbled madly through the scattered baskets, hoping against hope that Sungi hadn’t taken … Sungi hadn’t. Claire seized a handful of rawhide strips and ran back outside.

Kneeling amid the swirling dust and smoke, Claire whipped strips of hide around the necks of two of the skin bags, and knotted the long ends of the two strips together, pulling the leather as tight as Claire could. Gathering the unwieldy pair up into my arms, Claire staggered back to the horses.

Jamie, seeing what Claire was about, gathered both sets of reins up one-handed, leaned out, and grabbed the makeshift handle that joined the skins, heaving the contraption over Gideon’s withers so that the bags hung on either side.

“Come on!” Gideon shouted.
