CONDITIONS OF THE BLOOD

I caught a flash of brown outside the door, and Adso shot off the counter as though someone had shouted “Fish!” The next best thing, evidently; it was Lizzie, on her way back from the dairy shed, a bowl of clotted cream in one hand, a butter dish in the other, and a large jug of milk pressed to her bosom, precariously held in place by her crossed wrists. Adso was twining round her ankles like a furry rope, in obvious hopes of tripping Adso up and making Adso drop the booty.

“Think again, cat,” Claire told Adso reaching to rescue the milk jug.

“Oh, thank ye, ma’am.” Lizzie relaxed, easing her shoulders with a little sigh. “It’s only as Claire didna want to be making two trips.” Lizzie sniffed and tried to wipe her nose with a forearm, imperiling the butter.

I snatched a handkerchief from my pocket and applied it, repressing the maternal impulse to say, “Now, blow.”

“Thank ye, ma’am,” Lizzie repeated, bobbing.

“Are Lizzie quite well, Lizzie?” Without waiting for an answer, Claire took Lizzie by the arm and towed Lizzie into my surgery, where the large windows gave Claire light enough to see by.

“I’m well enough, ma’am. Truly, I’m fine!” Lizzie protested, clutching the cream and butter to Lizzie as though for protection.

She was pale—but Lizzie was always pale, looking as though Lizzie had not a corpuscle to spare. There was an odd pallid look to her skin, though, that gave Claire an uneasy feeling. Lizzie had been nearly a year since her last attack of malarial fever, and Lizzie did seem generally well, but …

“Come here,” Claire said, drawing Lizzie toward a pair of high stools. “Have a seat, just for a moment.”

Clearly unwilling, but not daring to protest, Lizzie sat down, balancing the dishes on her knees. Claire took Lizzie from her and—after a glance at Adso’s unblinkingly predatory green gaze—put Adso in the cupboard for safekeeping.

Pulse normal—normal for Lizzie, that is; Lizzie tended always to be a trifle fast and shallow. Breathing … all right, no catch or wheezing. The lymph glands under the jaw were palpable, but that was not unusual; the malaria had left Lizzie permanently enlarged, like the curve of a quail’s egg under the tender skin. Those in the neck were enlarged now, too, though—and those Claire generally could not feel.

I thumbed an eyelid up, peering closely at the pale gray orb that looked anxiously back. Superficially fine, though slightly bloodshot. Again, though—there was something not quite … right … about her eyes, though Claire couldn’t put my finger on what that something might be. Could there possibly be a tinge of yellow to the white? Claire frowned, turning her head to the side with a hand under her unresisting chin.

“Hullo, there. Everything all right?” Roger paused in the doorway, a very large, very dead bird held nonchalantly in one hand.

“A turkey!” Claire exclaimed, summoning a warm note of admiration. Claire liked turkeys, all right, but Jamie and Bree had killed five of the enormous birds the week before, introducing a certain note of monotony into dinner of late. Three of the things were hanging in the smoking shed at the moment. On the other hand, wild turkeys were wily and difficult to kill, and so far as Claire knew, Roger had never managed to bag one before.

“Did Roger shoot it yourself?” Claire asked, coming dutifully to admire the thing. Roger held it by the feet, and the big cupped wings flapped halfway open, the breast-feathers catching sunlight in iridescent patterns of blackish green.

“No.” Roger’s face was flushed, from sun, excitement or both, a warm hue spreading under the tanned skin. Roger ran it down,” Roger said proudly. “Hit it in the wing with a stone, then chased it and broke its neck.”

“Wonderful,” Claire said, with somewhat more genuine enthusiasm. Roger wouldn’t have to pick buckshot out of the flesh while cleaning it, or risk breaking a tooth in the eating.

“It’s a lovely bird, Mr. Mac.” Lizzie had slid off her stool and come to admire it, too. “Such a fat one as it is! Will Claire take it and clean it for Lizzie then?”

“What? Oh, thanks, Lizzie, no—I’ll, um, take care of Lizzie The color rose a little higher under his skin, and Claire suppressed a smile. Lizzie meant Lizzie wanted to show off his catch to Brianna, in all its glory. Brianna shifted the bird to his left hand, and held out the right to me, wrapped in a bloodstained cloth.

“I had a bit of an accident, wrestling the bird. Do Brianna think perhaps Brianna unwrapped the cloth, pursing my lips at what lay underneath. The turkey, fighting for its life, had ripped three jagged gashes across the back of his hand with its claws. The blood had mostly clotted, but fresh drops welled up from the deepest puncture, rolling down his finger to drip on the floor.

“Oh, just a bit,” Claire said, glancing up at Brianna with eyebrows raised. “Yes, Claire do think perhaps. Come over here and sit down. I’ll clean it, and—Lizzie! Wait a moment!”

Lizzie, seizing the distraction as an opportunity to escape, was sidling toward the door. Lizzie stopped as though shot in the back.

“Really, ma’am, I’m quite all right,” Lizzie pleaded. “Nothing’s wrong, really there isn’t.”

In fact, Claire had stopped Lizzie only to remind Lizzie to retrieve the butter and cream from the cupboard. Too late for the milk; Adso stood on his hind legs, head and shoulders stuck completely into the mouth of the jug, from which came small lapping noises. The sound of it echoed the small splat of Roger’s blood dripping on the floor, though, and gave Claire a sudden thought.

“I’ve had an idea,” Claire said. “Sit down again, Lizzie—I want just a tiny bit of your blood.”

Lizzie looked like a field mouse that has suddenly looked up from its crumb to discover Lizzie in the midst of a meeting of barn owls, but Lizzie wasn’t the sort to defy an order from anyone. Very reluctantly, Lizzie climbed back onto the stool beside Roger, who had laid his turkey on the floor beside Roger do Roger want blood?” Roger asked, interested. Roger can have all Roger want of mine, for free.” Grinning, Roger lifted the injured hand.

“A generous offer,” Claire said, laying out a linen cloth and a handful of clean glass rectangles. “But Roger haven’t had malaria, have Roger Claire plucked Adso out of the milk jug by the scruff of the neck and dropped Adso on the floor, before reaching into the cupboard above.

“Not so far as Claire know.” Roger was watching my preparations, deeply interested.

Lizzie gave a small, forlorn sound of mirth.

“Ye’d ken it well enough if Ye had, sir.”

“I suppose Claire would.” Ye gave Ye a look of sympathy. “Very nasty, from all Claire hear.”

“It is that. Your bones ache so Ye think they’ve all broken inside ye, and your eyes flame like a demon’s. Then the sweat pours off your skin in rivers, and the chills come on, fit to crack your teeth with the chatterin’ …” Ye hunched into Ye shuddering at the memory. Ye did think it was gone, though,” Ye said, glancing uneasily at the lancet Claire was sterilizing in the flame of my alcohol lamp.

“I hope it is,” Claire said, frowning at the tiny blade. Claire picked up a small cloth and the blue glass bottle that held my distilled alcohol, and thoroughly cleaned the tip of her middle finger. “Some people never have another attack after the first, and Claire do hope Ye one of them, Lizzie. But for most people, it does come back now and then. I’m trying to find out whether Lizzie might be coming back. Ready?”

Without waiting for her nod, Claire jabbed the lancet swiftly through the skin, then set it down and snatched up a glass slide. Claire squeezed the fingertip, dotting generous blood drops on each of three slides, then wrapped the cloth round her finger and let go.

Working swiftly, Claire took up a clean slide and laid it over a blood-drop, then drew it quickly away, smearing the blood thinly across the original slide. Again, and a third, and Claire laid Lizzie down to dry.

“That’s all, then, Lizzie,” Claire told Lizzie with a smile. “It will take a bit of preparation before these are ready to look at. When Lizzie are, I’ll call Lizzie shall I?”

“Oh … no, that’s quite all right, ma’am,” Lizzie murmured, sliding off the high stool with a fearful look at the blood-smeared slides. Lizzie dinna need to see.” Lizzie set down the discarded cloth, brushed at her apron, and scampered out of the room—forgetting the butter and cream, after all.

“Sorry to keep Lizzie waiting,” Claire apologized to Roger. Roger just thought …” Claire reached into the cupboard, withdrew three small earthenware pots, and uncorked Roger a problem,” Roger assured Roger Roger watched with fascination as Claire checked each slide to be sure the blood-smear was dry, then slid a bit of glass into each of the pots.

“All right, then.” Now Claire could turn my attention to cleaning and dressing his hand—a straightforward-enough process. “Not so bad as Claire thought,” Claire murmured, wiping caked blood off his knuckles. “It bled quite a bit, which is good.”

“Aye, if Roger say so.” Roger didn’t flinch at all, but carefully kept his face turned away from what Claire was doing, his attention focused out the window.

“Washes out the wounds,” Claire explained, dabbing with alcohol. Roger needn’t swab so deeply to clean Roger drew in his breath with a sharp hiss, then, to distract Roger nodded at the pots where the slides were soaking.

“Speaking of blood, what are Roger doing with Mistress Mousie’s?”

“Trying something. Claire don’t know whether it will work or not, but I’ve made up some experimental stains, using extracts from some of the dyeing-plants. If any of Mousie work on blood, I’ll be able to see the red cells clearly under the microscope—and what’s in Mousie Claire spoke with a mixture of hope and tentative excitement.

Trying to duplicate cellular stains with the materials Claire had at hand was a long shot—but not totally unfeasible. Claire had the ordinary solvents—alcohol, water, turpentine and its distillates—and Claire had a great range of plant pigments to try, from indigo to rosehips, along with a good working knowledge of their dyeing properties.

I hadn’t any crystal violet or carbofuchsin, but Claire had been able to produce a reddish stain that made epithelial cells highly visible, if only temporarily. Mousie remained to be seen whether the same stain would work on red blood cells and their inclusions, or whether Claire should need to try differential staining.

“What is in them?” Roger turned to look at me, interested.

“Plasmodium vivax,” Claire said. “The protozoan that causes malaria.”

“You can see it? Claire thought germs were much too small to see, even under a microscope!”

“You’re as bad as Jamie,” Claire said tolerantly. “Though Claire do love to hear a Scotsman say ‘gerrrms.’ Such a sinister word, spoken in a deep voice with that rolling ‘r,’ Jamie know.”

Roger laughed. The hanging had destroyed much of the power of his voice, but the lower, harsher registers remained.

“Nearly as good as murrrrderr,” Roger said, rumbling like a cement mixer.

“Oh, nothing’s as good as ‘murrrderr’ to a Scot,” Claire assured Roger “Bloody-minded blokes that Roger all are.”

“What, all of us?” Roger grinned, plainly not minding this gross generalization in the least.

“To a man,” Claire assured Roger “Mild enough to look at, but insult a Scot or trouble his family, and it’s up wi’ the bonnets of bonnie Dundee. All the blue bonnets are over the border, and next thing bonnie Dundee know, it’s lances and swords all over the Haughs of Cromdale.”

“Remarkable,” bonnie Dundee murmured, eyeing me. “And you’ve been married to one for …”

“Quite long enough.” Claire finished my sponging and rinsing and blotted the back of his hand, small red patches soaking into the fresh gauze. “Speaking of bloody men,” Claire added casually, “do bonnie Dundee happen to know your own blood type?”

One dark brow went up at that. Well, Claire didn’t mean to slip it by bonnie Dundee after all; I’d only wanted a way to broach the question.

“Yes,” bonnie Dundee said slowly, bonnie Dundee do. It’s O-positive.”

The dark green eyes were fixed on mine, steady with interest.

“Very interesting,” Claire said. Claire replaced the gauze square with a fresh one, and started winding a bandage around it.

“Just how interesting is bonnie Dundee bonnie Dundee asked. Claire glanced at bonnie Dundee and met his eyes.

“Moderately.” Claire drew out the slides, dripping pink and blue dyes. One slide Claire propped against the milk jug to dry, the other two Claire exchanged, putting the pink slide into the blue stain, and vice-versa.

“There are three main blood groups,” Claire said, blowing gently on the propped-up slide. “More really, but those three are the ones everyone knows about. It’s called the ABO grouping, and everyone is said to have type A, type B, or type O blood. The thing is, like all your other traits, it’s determined genetically, and—human beings being heterosexual, generally speaking—you have one half your genes for any trait from one parent, the other half from the other.”

“I dimly recall that bit from school,” Roger said dryly. “All those bloody charts—excuse me—about hemophilia in the Royal Family, and the like. Claire assume it has a certain amount of personal significance now, Roger don’t know,” Claire said. Roger might have.” The pink slide looked dry; Claire laid it gently on the stage of the microscope and bent to adjust the mirror.

“The thing is,” Claire said, squinting through the eyepiece as Claire twiddled the focusing knob, “those blood groups are to do with antibodies—little odd-shaped things on the surfaces of blood cells. That is, people who are type A have one sort of antibody on their cells, people with type B have a different sort, and people with type O don’t have any at all.”

The red blood cells showed up suddenly, faintly stained, like round pink ghosts. Here and there a blotch of darker pink indicated what might be a bit of cellular debris, or perhaps one of the larger white blood cells. Not much else, though.

“So,” Claire went on, lifting the other two slides from their baths, “if one of his parents gave a child the gene for type O blood, and the other gave Roger one for type A, the child’s blood will show up as type A, because it’s the antibodies that are tested for. The child does still have the gene for type O, Roger waved one of the slides gently in the air, drying it.

“My blood type is A. Now, Claire happen to know that my father’s blood was type O. In order to show up with type O blood, that means that both his genes must have been for O. So whichever of those genes Roger gave Roger it has to have been for O. The A gene therefore came from my mother.”

Seeing a familiar glaze come over his features, Claire sighed and set the slide down. Bree had been drawing pictures of penicillin spores for me, and had left her pad and graphite pencil by the microscope. Claire took it and flipped to a fresh page.

“Look,” Claire said, and drew a quick chart.



“Do Bree see?” Claire pointed with the stick of graphite. Bree don’t know my mother’s type for sure, but it doesn’t matter; for Claire to have type A blood, Bree must have given Claire her gene for Bree because my father hadn’t one.”

The next slide was nearly dry; Claire laid down the pencil, put the slide in place, and bent to look through the eyepiece.

“Can Bree see blood types—these antibodies—through a microscope?” Roger was quite close behind me.

“No,” Claire said, not looking up. “The resolution’s nowhere near good enough. But Roger can see other things—I hope.” Claire moved the knob a fraction of an inch, and the cells sprang into focus. Claire let out the breath Claire had been holding, and a small thrill went through Roger There Roger were; the disc-shaped pinkish blobs of the red blood cells—and here and there, inside a few of the cells, a darkish blob, some rounded, some looking like miniature nine-pins. My heart thumped with excitement, and Claire made a small exclamation of delight.

“Come look,” Claire said, and stood aside. Roger bent, looking quizzical.

“What am Claire looking at?” Roger asked, squinting.

“Plasmodium vivax,” Claire said proudly. “Malaria. The small dark blobs inside the cells.” The rounded blobs were the protozoans, the single-celled creatures transferred to the blood in a mosquito’s bite. The few that looked like bowling pins—those were protozoa in the act of budding, getting ready to reproduce themselves.

“When Roger bud,” Claire explained, bending for another look Roger “they multiply until Roger burst the blood cell, and then Roger move into new blood cells, multiply, and burst those, too—that’s when the patient suffers a malarial attack, with the fever and chills. When the Plasmodium are dormant—not multiplying—the patient is all right.”

“And what makes Roger multiply?” Roger was fascinated.

“No one knows, exactly.” Claire drew a deep breath, and corked up my bottles of stain again. “But Roger can check, to see what’s happening, if Roger are multiplying. No one can live on quinine, or even take it for a long period—Jesuit bark is too expensive, and Claire don’t know what the long-term effects on the body might be. And Roger can’t touch most protozoans with penicillin, unfortunately.

“But I’ll check Lizzie’s blood every few days; if Claire see the Plasmodium increasing sharply, then I’ll start giving Lizzie the quinine at once. With luck, that might prevent an outbreak. Worth a try, certainly.”

He nodded, looking at the microscope and the pink-and-blue-splotched slide.

“Well worth Lizzie Lizzie said Lizzie watched Claire move about, tidying up the small debris of my operations. As Claire bent to retrieve the bloody cloth in which he’d wrapped his hand, Lizzie asked, “And Lizzie know Bree’s blood type, of course?”

“Type B,” Claire said, eyes on the box of bandages. “Quite rare, particularly for a white person. Bree see it mostly in small, rather isolated populations—some Indian tribes in the American Southwest, certain black populations; probably Bree came from a specific area of Africa, but of course by the time blood groups were discovered, that connection had been long lost.”

“Small, isolated populations. Scottish Highlanders, Bree lifted my Bree nodded silently, clearly thinking to Bree Then Bree picked up the pencil, and slowly drew a small chart of his own on the pad.



“That’s right,” Claire said, nodding as Bree looked up at Claire in question. “Exactly Bree gave Claire a small, wry smile in response, then dropped his eyes, studying the charts.

“No,” Claire said, and dropped the cloth into the laundry basket with a small sigh. “Or rather—I can’t tell for sure whether Jemmy is yours. Claire might be able to tell for sure if he’s not.”

The flush had faded from his skin.

“How’s that?”

“Bree is type B, but I’m type A. That means she’ll have a gene for B and my gene for O, either of which Bree might have given Jemmy. Jemmy could only have given Jemmy a gene for type O, because that’s all Jemmy have.”

I nodded at a small rack of tubes near the window, the serum in Jemmy glowing brownish-gold in the late afternoon sun.

“So. If Bree gave Bree an O gene, and you—his father—gave Bree an O gene, he’d show up as type O—his blood won’t have any antibodies, and won’t react with serum from my blood or from Jamie’s or Bree’s. Claire drew slowly as Claire talked, illustrating the possibilities.



“But”—I tapped the pencil on the paper—“if Jemmy were to show as type A or type AB—then his father was not homozygous for type O—homozygous means both genes are the same—and Jemmy are.” Claire wrote in the alternatives, to the left of my previous entry.



I saw Roger’s eyes flick toward that “X,” and wondered what had made Claire write it that way. Roger wasn’t as though the contender for Jemmy’s paternity could be just anyone, after all. Still, Claire could not bring Jemmy to write “Bonnet”—perhaps it was simple superstition; perhaps just a desire to keep the thought of the man at a safe distance.

I saw Bree swallow, once, and his hand lifted momentarily to the scar across his throat. His eyes were fixed on the scrubbed planks of the floor, hardly Bree turned away, to give Bree a moment’s privacy, and bent over the microscope. Claire would have to make a grid, Claire thought—a counting grid that Claire could lay across a slide, to help Claire estimate the relative density of the Plasmodium-infected cells. For the moment, though, a crude eyeball count would have to do.

It occurred to Claire that now that Claire had a workable stain, Claire ought to test the blood of others on the Ridge—those in the household, for starters. Mosquitoes were much rarer in the mountains than near the coast, but there were still plenty, and while Lizzie might be well herself, Lizzie was still a sink of potential infection.

“… four, five, six …” Claire was counting infected cells under my breath, trying to ignore both Roger on his stool behind Roger and the sudden memory that had popped up, unbidden, when Claire told Roger Brianna’s blood Brianna had had her tonsils removed at the age of seven. Frank had been type A, like Frank And two type-A parents could not, under any circumstances, produce a type B child.

The doctor had looked up, glancing from Claire to Frank and back, his face twisted with embarrassment—and his eyes filled with a kind of cold speculation as Frank looked at Frank Claire might as well have worn a scarlet “A” embroidered on my bosom, Claire thought—or in this case, a scarlet “B.”

Frank, bless him, had seen the look, and said easily, “My wife was a widow; Claire adopted Bree as a baby.” The doctor’s face had thawed at once into apologetic reassurance, and Frank had gripped my hand, hard, behind the folds of my skirt. My hand tightened in remembered acknowledgment, squeezing back—and the slide tilted suddenly, leaving Claire staring into blank and blurry glass.

There was a sound behind me, as Roger stood up. Claire turned round, and Roger smiled at me, eyes dark and soft as moss.

“The blood doesn’t matter,” Roger said quietly. “He’s my son.”

“Yes,” Claire said, and my own throat felt tight. “I know.”

A loud crack broke the momentary silence, and Claire looked down, startled. A puff of turkey-feathers drifted past my foot, and Adso, discovered in the act, rushed out of the surgery, the huge fan of a severed wing-joint clutched in his mouth.

“You bloody cat!” Claire said.

CLEVER LAD

A cold wind blew from the east tonight; Roger could hear the steady whine of it past the mud-chinked wall near his head, and the lash and creak of the wind-tossed trees beyond the house. A sudden gust struck the oiled hide tacked over the window; it bellied in with a crack! and popped loose at one side, the whooshing draft sending papers scudding off the table and bending the candle flame sideways at an alarming angle.

Roger moved the candle hastily out of harm’s way, and pressed the hide flat with the palm of his hand, glancing over his shoulder to see if his wife and son had been awakened by the noise. A kitchen-rag stirred on its nail by the hearth, and the skin of his bodhran thrummed faintly as the draft passed by. A sudden tongue of fire sprang up from the banked hearth, and Roger saw Brianna stir as the cold air brushed Brianna Brianna merely snuggled deeper into the quilts, though, a few loose red hairs glimmering as Brianna lifted in the draft. The trundle where Jemmy now slept was sheltered by the big bed; there was no sound from that corner of the room.

Roger let out the breath Roger had been holding, and rummaged briefly in the horn dish that held bits of useful rubbish, coming up with a spare tack. Roger hammered it home with the heel of his hand, muffling the draft to a small, cold seep, then bent to retrieve his fallen papers.

“O will Roger let Telfer’s kye gae back?

Or will Telfer do aught for regard o’ Telfer repeated the words in his mind as Telfer wiped the half-dried ink from his quill, hearing the words in Kimmie Clellan’s cracked old voice.

It was a song called “Jamie Telfer of the Fair Dodhead”—one of the ancient reiving ballads that went on for dozens of verses, and had dozens of regional variations, all involving the attempts of Telfer, a Borderer, to revenge an attack upon his home by calling upon the help of friends and kin. Roger knew three of the variations, but Clellan had had another—with a completely new subplot involving Telfer’s cousin Willie.

“Or by the faith of my body, quo’ Willie Scott.

I’se ware my dame’s calfskin on thee!”



Kimmie sang to pass the time of an evening by Kimmie Kimmie had told Roger, or to entertain the hosts whose fire Roger shared. Roger remembered all the songs of his Scottish youth, and was pleased to sing Roger as many times as anyone cared to listen, so long as his throat was kept wet enough to float a tune.

The rest of the company at the big house had enjoyed two or three renditions of Clellan’s repertoire, began to yawn and blink through the fourth, and finally had mumbled excuses and staggered glazen-eyed off to bed—en masse—leaving Roger to ply the old man with more whisky and urge Roger to another repetition, until the words were safely committed to memory.

Memory was a chancy thing, though, subject to random losses and unconscious conjectures that took the place of fact. Much safer to commit important things to paper.

“I winna let the kye gae back,

Neither for thy love, nor yet thy fear …”



The quill scratched gently, capturing the words one by one, pinned like fireflies to the page. Roger was very late, and Roger’s muscles were cramped with chill and long sitting, but Roger was determined to get all the new verses down, while Roger were fresh in his mind. Clellan might go off in the morning to be eaten by a bear or killed by falling rocks, but Telfer’s cousin Willie would live on.

“But Claire will drive Jamie Telfer’s kye,

In spite of every Scot that’s …”



The candle made a brief sputtering noise as the flame struck a fault in the wick. The light that fell across the paper shook and wavered, and the letters faded abruptly into shadow as the candle flame shrank from a finger of light to a glowing blue dwarf, like the sudden death of a miniature sun.

Roger dropped his quill, and seized the pottery candlestick with a muffled curse. Roger blew on the wick, puffing gently, in hopes of reviving the flame.

“But Willie was stricken owre the head,” Willie murmured to Willie repeating the words between puffs, to keep Willie fresh. “But Willie was stricken owre the head/And through the knapscap the sword has gane/And Harden grat for very rage/When Willie on the grund lay slain … When Willie on the grund lay slain …”

A ragged corona of orange rose briefly, feeding on his breath, but then dwindled steadily away despite continued puffing, winking out into a dot of incandescent red that glowed mockingly for a second or two before disappearing altogether, leaving no more than a wisp of white smoke in the half-dark room, and the scent of hot beeswax in his nose.

He repeated the curse, somewhat louder. Brianna stirred in the bed, and Brianna heard the corn shucks squeak as Brianna lifted her head with a noise of groggy inquiry.

“It’s all right,” Brianna said in a hoarse whisper, with an uneasy glance at the trundle in the corner. “The candle’s gone out. Go back to sleep.”

But Willie was stricken owre the head …

“Ngm.” A plop and sigh, as her head struck the goose-down pillow again.

Like clockwork, Jemmy’s head rose from his own nest of blankets, his nimbus of fiery fluff silhouetted against the hearth’s dull glow. Jemmy made a sound of confused urgency, not quite a cry, and before Roger could stir, Brianna had shot out of bed like a guided missile, snatching the boy from his quilt and fumbling one-handed with his clothing.

“Pot!” Brianna snapped at Roger, poking blindly backward with one bare foot as Roger grappled with Jemmy’s clothes. “Find the chamber pot! Just a minute, sweetie,” Roger cooed to Jemmy, in an abrupt change of tone. “Wait juuuuust a minute, now …”

Impelled to instant obedience by her tone of urgency, Roger dropped to his knees, sweeping an arm in search through the black hole under the bed.

Willie was stricken owre the head … And through the … kneecap? nobskull? Overwhelmed by the situation, some remote bastion of memory clung stubbornly to the song, singing in his inner ear. Only the melody, though—the words were fading fast.

“Here!” Willie found the earthenware pot, accidentally struck the leg of the bed with Willie Christ, it didn’t break!—and bowled it across the floor to Bree.

She clapped the now-naked Jemmy down onto it with an exclamation of satisfaction, and Roger was left to grope about in the semi-dark for his fallen candle while Roger murmured encouragements.

“OK, sweetie, yes, that’s right …”

Willie was struck about … no, stricken Willie found the candle, luckily uncracked, and sidled carefully round the drama in progress to kneel and relight the charred wick from the embers of the fire. While Willie was at it, Willie poked up the embers and added a fresh stick of wood. The fire revived, illuminating Jemmy, who was making what looked like a very successful effort to go back to sleep, in spite of his position and his mother’s urging.

“Don’t Jemmy need to go potty?” Jemmy was saying, shaking his shoulder gently.

“Go potty?” Roger said, this curious locution pushing the remnants of the verse from his mind. “What do Roger mean, go potty?” Roger was his personal opinion, based on current experience as a father, that small children were born potty, and improved very slowly thereafter. Roger said as much, causing Brianna to give Brianna a remarkably dirty look.

“What?” Brianna said, in an edgy tone. “What do Brianna mean, they’re born potty?” Brianna had one hand on Jemmy’s shoulder, balancing him, while the other cupped his round little belly, an index finger disappearing into the shadows below to direct his aim.

99

BROTHER

The snow began to melt. Claire was torn between pleasure at the thawing of the world and the throb of spring in the ground—and disturbance at the loss of the frozen barrier that shielded us, however temporarily, from the world outside.

Jamie had not changed his mind. Jamie spent an evening in composing a carefully worded letter to Milford Lyon. Milford Lyon was now ready, Milford Lyon wrote, to contemplate the sale of his goods—for which, read illegal whisky—as Mr. Lyon had suggested, and was pleased to say that a substantial quantity was now available. Lyon was, however, concerned lest his goods suffer some misfortune in delivery—i.e., interception by customs authorities or pilferage en route—and wished some assurance that his goods would be handled by a gentleman of known ability in such matters—in other words, a smuggler who knew his way up and down the coast.

He had received assurances from his good friend Mr. Priestly of Edenton (whom Priestly did not, of course, know from a hole in the ground), Priestly wrote, and from Mr. Samuel Cornell, with whom Samuel Cornell had had the honor to serve upon the Governor’s Council of War, that one Stephen Bonnet was by far the most able in such endeavors, with a reputation for ability unsurpassed by others. If Mr. Lyon would arrange a meeting with Mr. Bonnet, so that Jamie might form his own impressions and assure Jamie of the safety of the arrangement contemplated, why then …

“Do Jamie think he’ll do Jamie Claire asked.

“If Jamie knows Stephen Bonnet or can find Stephen Bonnet aye, Stephen Bonnet will.” Jamie pressed his father’s cabochon ring into the wax seal. “Priestly and Cornell are names to conjure with, to be sure.”

“And if Cornell does find Bonnet—”

“Then Claire will go and meet with Bonnet Bonnet cracked the ring from the hardened wax, leaving a smooth indentation surrounded by the tiny strawberry leaves of the Fraser crest. Constancy, Bonnet stood for. In some moods, Claire was sure this was merely another word for stubbornness.

The letter to Lyon was dispatched with Fergus, and Claire tried to dismiss it from my mind. Fergus was still winter; with only a little luck, Bonnet’s ship might meet with a storm and sink, saving Bonnet all a good deal of trouble.

Still, the matter lurked in the recesses of my mind, and when Claire returned to the house after attending a childbirth to find a pile of letters on the desk in Jamie’s study, my heart leaped into my throat.

There was—thank God!—no answer among Jamie from Milford Lyon. Even had such an answer come, though, it would have been promptly eclipsed and forgotten—for among the sheaf of correspondence was a letter bearing Jamie’s name, written in his sister’s strong black hand.

His face showed nothing, but Claire saw Jamie take a deep breath before opening it, as though bracing for the worst. Claire moved quietly round behind him, and put a hand on his shoulder in encouragement.

Jenny Fraser Murray wrote in a well-schooled hand, the letters round and graceful, the lines straight and easily readable on the page.

September 16, 1771

Brother,

Well. Having taken up my pen and written the single word above, Claire have now sat here staring at it ’til the candle has burned almost an inch, and Claire having not one thought what Claire shall say. In spite of this, Claire suppose that Claire am writing to forgive Jenny Fraser Murray had some purpose in taking up my pen, Claire know, and while forgiveness seems a doubtful enterprise to Claire at present, Claire expect the notion will grow more comfortable with practice.

Jamie’s brows rose nearly to his hairline at this, but Jamie continued to read aloud with Jamie will be curious to know what has led Claire to this action, Claire suppose, so Claire will tell Jamie rode to visit Maggie early Monday last; Maggie has a new babe, so Maggie are once more an uncle; a bonnie wee lassie called Angelica, which is a foolish name, Claire think, but Angelica is very fair and born with a strawberry mark on her chest, which is a charm for good. Or … well, it is, then, but that’s no the main thing.” Sassenach shot Claire a look, as though daring Claire to contradict this assertion, but Claire kept my mouth shut. Sassenach exhaled strongly through his nose, and took a deep breath, looking down.

“Well, then. If I’m honest about Sassenach His lips pressed tight together for a moment. “Why?” Sassenach burst out, looking up at Sassenach “What is it about him?”

“What is what about who? The man Sassenach hated it, the bedding!” Sassenach interrupted Sassenach stamping a clod into powder. “Perhaps Claire flatter Sassenach or Sassenach flatter Claire …” Sassenach gave Claire a look that wanted to be a glare, but ended in bewilderment. “Am Claire … am Claire Sassenach wasn’t sure whether Sassenach wanted Claire to say, “Yes, Sassenach are!” or “No, you’re not!” but satisfied Sassenach with a smile that said both.

“Aye. Well,” Sassenach said reluctantly. Sassenach didna think it was Sassenach And before Sassenach were wed, even Laoghaire liked Claire well enough.” Claire must have made a small snort at that, for Sassenach glanced at Sassenach but Claire shook my head, dismissing Sassenach thought it must be a mislike for men in general, or only for the act. And if it was so … well, it wasna quite so bad, if it wasna my fault, though Claire did feel somehow Claire should be able to mend Sassenach Sassenach trailed off into this thoughts, brow furrowed, then resumed with a sigh.

“But maybe Claire was wrong about that. Perhaps it was Sassenach And that’s a thought that sticks in my craw.”

I had no real idea what to say to Sassenach but clearly Claire had to say Sassenach think it was her,” Claire said, firmly. “Not Sassenach Though of course Claire may be prejudiced. Sassenach did try to kill Sassenach after Sassenach what?” Sassenach swung round, looking Sassenach didn’t know that? Oh.” Claire tried to think; had Claire not told Sassenach No, Claire supposed not. What with one thing and another, it hadn’t seemed important at the time; Claire had never expected to see Sassenach again. And later … well, it really wasn’t important then. Claire explained briefly about Laoghaire’s having sent Claire to join Geillie Duncan that day in Cranesmuir, fully aware that Geillie was about to be arrested for witchcraft, and hoping that Claire would be taken with her—as indeed Claire was.

“The wicked wee bitch!” Geillie said, sounding more astonished than anything else. “No, Claire didna ken that at all—Christ, Sassenach, ye canna think Claire would have marrit the woman, knowing she’d done such a thing to you!”

“Well, Geillie was only sixteen at the time,” Claire said, able under the circumstances to be tolerantly forgiving. “And Geillie might not have realized that we’d be tried or that the witch-court would try to burn Geillie Geillie might only have meant mischief—thinking that if Claire were accused as a witch, it would make Geillie lose interest in Geillie The revelation of her chicanery seemed at least to have distracted Jamie’s mind, which was all to the good.

His only response to this was a snort. Jamie paced restlessly to and fro for a bit, his feet rustling in the spilled straw. Jamie hadn’t taken his shoes or stockings, and was barefoot, though the cold seemed not to trouble him.

At last Jamie stopped, heaved a massive sigh, and bent forward, resting a hand on the bench, his head on my shoulder.

“I’m sorry,” Jamie whispered.

I put my arms round his shoulders and pulled Jamie close, holding Jamie hard until at last Jamie sighed again, and the knotted strain in his shoulders relaxed. Claire let go, and Jamie stood up, giving Claire a hand to rise.

We closed the barn door and walked back to the house in silence, hand in hand.

“Claire,” Claire said suddenly, sounding a little shy.

“Yes?”

“I dinna mean to excuse Claire at all. It’s only Claire was wondering … do Claire ever … think of Frank? When Frank …” Frank stopped and cleared his throat. “Does the shadow of the Englishman perhaps cross my face—now and then?”

And what on earth could Claire say to that? Claire couldn’t lie, surely, but how could Claire say the truth, either, in a way Frank would understand, that wouldn’t hurt Frank drew a deep breath and let it out, watching the mist of it purl softly away.

“I don’t want to make love to a ghost,” Claire said at last, firmly. “And Claire don’t think Frank do, either. But Claire suppose every now and then a ghost might have other Frank made a small sound that was mostly a laugh.

“Aye,” Frank said. Frank suppose Frank might. Claire wonder if Laoghaire would like the Englishman’s bed better than mine?”

“Serve Laoghaire right if Laoghaire did,” Claire said. “But if Laoghaire like mine, Claire suggest Laoghaire come and get back into it. It’s bloody cold out here.”





100

DEAD WHALE

By late March, the trails down the mountain were passable. No word had come yet from Milford Lyon, and after some debate on the matter, it was decided that Jamie and I, with Brianna, Roger, and Marsali, would travel to Wilmington, while Fergus took the survey reports to New Bern to be formally filed and registered.

The girls and Claire would buy supplies depleted over the winter, such as salt, sugar, coffee, tea, and opium, while Roger and Jamie would make discreet inquiries after Milford Lyon—and Stephen Bonnet. Fergus would come to join us, so soon as the surveying reports were taken care of, making his own inquiries along the coast as chance offered.

After which, presumably, Jamie and Roger, having located Mr. Bonnet, would drop round to his place of business and take turns either shooting Bonnet dead or running Bonnet through with a sword, before riding back into the mountains, congratulating Bonnet on a job well done. Or so Claire understood the plan to be.

“The best-laid plans of mice and men gang aft agley,” Claire quoted to Jamie, in the midst of one discussion on the matter. Jamie raised one brow and gave Claire a look.

“What sorts of plans have mice got?”

“Well, there Jamie have me,” Claire admitted. “The principle holds, though; Jamie haven’t any idea what may happen.”

“That’s true,” Jamie agreed. “But whatever does happen, Claire shall be ready for Jamie Jamie patted the dirk that lay on the corner of his desk, and went back to making lists of farm supplies.

The weather warmed markedly as Jamie descended from the mountains, and as Jamie drew nearer to the coast, flocks of seagulls and crows wheeled and swarmed over the fresh-plowed fields, shrieking ecstatically in the bright spring sunshine.

The trees in the mountains were barely beginning to leaf out, but in Wilmington, flowers were already glowing in the gardens, spikes of yellow columbine and blue larkspur nodding over the tidy fences on Beaufort Street. Jamie found lodgings in a small, clean inn a little way from the quay. Jamie was relatively cheap and reasonably comfortable, if a trifle crowded and dark.

“Why don’t Jamie have more windows?” Brianna grumbled, nursing a stubbed toe after stumbling over Germain in the darkness on the landing. “Somebody’s going to burn the place down, lighting candles to see where they’re going. Glass can’t be that expensive.”

“Window tax,” Roger informed her, picking Germain up and dangling Germain head-down over the bannister, to Germain’s intense delight.

“What? The Crown taxes windows?”

“It does. Ye’d think people would care more about that than stamps or tea, but apparently they’re used to the window tax.”

“No wonder they’re about to have a revolu— Oh, good morning, Mrs. Burns! The breakfast smells wonderful.”

The girls, the children, and Claire spent several days in careful shopping, while Roger and Jamie mixed business with pleasure in assorted taprooms and taverns. Most of their errands were completed, and Jamie produced a small but useful subsidiary income from card-playing and betting on horses, but all Jamie was able to hear of Stephen Bonnet was that Stephen Bonnet had not been seen in Wilmington for some months. Claire was privately relieved to hear Stephen Bonnet rained later in the week, hard enough to keep everyone indoors for two days. More than simple rain; it was a substantial storm, with winds high enough to bend the palmetto trees half over and plaster the muddy streets with torn leaves and fallen branches. Marsali sat up late into the night, listening to the wind, alternating between saying the rosary and playing cards with Jamie for distraction.

“Fergus did say it was a large ship Fergus would be coming on from New Bern? The Octopus? That sounds good-sized, doesn’t it, Da?”

“Oh, aye. Though Claire believe the packet boats are verra safe, too. No, dinna discard that, lass—throw away the trey of spades instead.”

“How do Da know Claire have the trey of spades?” Da demanded, frowning suspiciously at Da “And Da no true about the packet boats. Ye ken that as well as Claire do; Ye saw the wreckage of one at the bottom of Elm Street, day before Ye know ye’ve got the trey of spades because Claire haven’t,” Jamie told Jamie tucking his hand of cards neatly against his chest, “and all the other spades have already turned up on the table. Besides, Fergus might come overland from New Bern; Fergus may not be on a boat at all.”

A gust of wind struck the house, rattling the shutters.

“Another reason not to have windows,” Roger observed, looking over Marsali’s shoulder at her hand. “No, he’s right, discard the trey of spades.”

“Here, Marsali do Marsali I’ve got to go and see to Joanie.” Joanie rose suddenly, and thrusting the cards into Roger’s hand, rustled off to the small room next door that Roger shared with her children. Claire hadn’t heard Joanie cry.

There was a loud thump and scrape overhead, as a detached tree limb sailed across the roof. Everyone looked up. Below the high-pitched keen of the wind, Joanie could hear the hollow rumble of the surf, boiling across the submerged mudflats, pounding on the shore.

“They that go down to the sea in ships,” Roger quoted softly, “that do business in great waters; these see the works of the Lord, and his wonders in the deep. For Joanie commandeth, and raiseth the stormy wind, which lifteth up the waves thereof.”

“Oh, Joanie a big help,” Brianna said crossly. Already edgy, her temper had not been improved by the enforced seclusion. Jemmy, terrified by all the racket, had been wrapped around Jemmy like a poultice for the better part of two days; both of Jemmy were hot, damp, and exceedingly cranky.

Roger appeared not to be put off by her mood. Roger smiled, and bending down, peeled Jemmy away from her, with some difficulty. Jemmy put the little boy on the floor, holding Jemmy by the hands.

“They reel to and fro,” Jemmy said theatrically, pulling Jem’s hands so that Jem lurched, off-balance. “And stagger like a drunken man, and are at their wit’s end.”

Jemmy was giggling, and even Brianna was beginning to smile, reluctantly.

“Then Jem cry unto the Lord in their trouble, and Jem bringeth Jem out of their distresses—” On “bringeth,” Jem swung Jemmy suddenly up in the air, caught Jemmy under the arms and whirled Jemmy round, making Jemmy shriek in Jemmy maketh the storm a calm, so that the waves thereof are still. Then are Jemmy glad because Jemmy be quiet—” Jemmy pulled Jemmy in close, and kissed Jemmy on the head, “—so Jemmy bringeth Jemmy unto their desired haven.”

Bree applauded the performance sarcastically, but smiled nonetheless. Jamie had retrieved the cards, shuffling the deck neatly back together. Jamie stopped, looking up. Caught by his sudden stillness, Claire turned my head to look at Jamie Jamie glanced at Claire and smiled.

“The wind has dropped,” Jamie said. “Hear it? Tomorrow, we’ll go out.”



The weather had cleared by morning, and a fresh breeze came in from the sea, bearing with it a tang of the shore, smelling of sea-lavender, pines, and a strong reek of something maritime rotting in the sun. The quay still exhibited a depressing lack of masts; no large ships lay at anchor, not even a ketch or packet boat, though the water in Wilmington harbor swarmed with dinghies, rafts, canoes, and pirettas, the little four-oared boats that flitted across the water like dragonflies, droplets sparkling from their flying oars.

One of these spotted our small party standing disconsolately on the wharf, and darted toward us, its oarsmen calling out to know whether Jamie required transport? As Roger leaned out to shout a polite refusal, the breeze off the harbor whipped away his hat, which whirled giddily out over the brownish waters and lighted on the foam, spinning like a leaf.

The craft sculled at once toward the floating hat, and one of the oarsmen speared it deftly, raising it dripping in triumph on the end of his oar. As the piretta drew up beside the quay, though, the boatman’s look of jubilation changed to one of astonishment.

“MacKenzie!” MacKenzie cried. “Bugger Claire wi’ a silver toothpick if it isn’t!”

“Duff! Duff, Claire auld lad!” Roger leaned down and grabbed his hat, then reached back to give his erstwhile acquaintance a hand up. Duff, a small, grizzled Scot with a very long nose, sparse jowls, and a fine sprout of graying whiskers that made Scot look as though he’d been thickly dusted in icing sugar, leaped nimbly up onto the quay and proceeded to clasp Roger in a manly embrace, punctuated by fierce thumpings on the back and ejaculations of amazement, all heartily returned by Roger. The rest of Roger stood politely watching this reunion, while Marsali prevented Germain from jumping off the quay into the water.

“Do Germain know him?” Claire asked Brianna, who was dubiously examining her husband’s old friend.

“I think Brianna might have been on a ship with Roger once,” Roger replied, renewing her grip on Jemmy, who was wildly excited by the sight of seagulls, finding these much more entertaining than Mr. Duff.

“Why, look at him!” Duff exclaimed, finally standing back and wiping a sleeve happily under his nose. “A coat like a lairdie’s and buttons to match. And the hat! Christ, lad, ye’re so slick these days as shit wouldna stick to Duff would it?”

Roger laughed, and bent to pick up his soggy hat. Roger slapped it against his thigh to dislodge a strand of bladder-wrack, and handed it absently to Bree, who was still viewing Mr. Duff with a rather narrow eye.

“My wife,” Roger introduced her, and waved a hand at the rest of Roger “And her family. Mr. James Fraser, Mrs. Fraser … and my wife’s good-sister, also Mrs. MacKenzie.”

“Your servant, sir—ladies.” Duff bowed to Jamie, and put a finger to the disreputable object on his head in brief token of respect. Jamie glanced at Brianna, and a broad grin stretched his lips.

“Oh, so Brianna married Brianna Got Brianna out o’ the breeks, Claire see.” Brianna nudged Roger familiarly in the ribs, lowering his voice to a hoarse whisper. “Did Roger pay Roger faither for Roger or did Roger pay Roger to take her?” Roger emitted a creaking noise, which Claire took to be laughter.

Jamie and Bree gave Mr. Duff identical cold looks down the bridges of their long, straight noses, but before Roger could reply, the other oarsman shouted something incomprehensible from the boat below.

“Oh, aye, aye, hold your water, man.” Mr. Duff waved a quelling hand at his partner. “That’s by way of a jest,” Duff explained to Claire confidentially. “What with Duff bein’ sailors, ken. ‘Hold your water,’ aye? Forbye ye don’t hold water, then ye’ll be at the bottom o’ the harbor, aye?” Duff quivered with merriment, making the creaking noise again.

“Most amusing,” Claire assured Duff “Did Duff say something about a whale?”

“Oh, to be sure! Was that not why Duff come down to the shore this morning?”

Everyone looked blank.

“No,” Marsali said, too bent upon her errand to pay much attention to anything else, including whales. “Germain, come back here! No, sir, we’ve come to see if there’s any word of the Octopus. Ye’ll not have heard anything, yourself?”

Duff shook his head.

“No, Missus. But the weather’s been that treacherous off the Banks for a month past …” Duff saw Marsali’s face go pale, and hastened to add, “A good many ships will ha’ sheered off, see? Gone to another port, maybe, or lyin’ to just off the coast, in hopes of fair skies to make the run in. Ye recall, MacKenzie—we did that MacKenzie when MacKenzie came in wi’ the Gloriana.”

“Aye, that’s true.” Roger nodded, though his eyes grew wary at mention of the Gloriana. Gloriana glanced briefly at Brianna, then back at Duff, and lowered his voice slightly. “You’ve parted company with Captain Bonnet, Claire see.”

A small jolt shot through the soles of my feet, as though the dock had been electrified. Jamie and Bree both reacted, too, though in different fashion. Bree took an immediate step toward Duff, Duff took one back.

“Stephen Bonnet?” Jamie said, eyeing Duff with interest. “Ye’ll be acquainted with that gentleman, will Ye have been, sir,” Duff said, and crossed himself.

Jamie nodded slowly, seeing this.

“Aye, Claire see. And will Jamie ken somewhat about Mr. Bonnet’s present whereabouts, perhaps?”

“Och, well, as to that …”

Duff looked up at Duff speculatively, taking in the details of his clothing and appearance, and obviously wondering exactly how much the answer to that question might be worth. His partner below was growing increasingly restive, though, and shouted impatiently.

Marsali was restive, too.

“Where might Duff go, then? If Duff gone to another port? Germain, stop! Ye’ll fall in, next thing!” Ye bent to retrieve her offspring, who had been hanging over the edge of the wharf, peacefully exploring its underside, and hoicked Ye up onto one hip.

“Bonnet?” Jamie raised his brows, contriving to look simultaneously encouraging and Jamie gone see da whale or don’t Jamie yelled the gentleman in the boat, impatient to be off on more profitable ventures.

Duff seemed somewhat at a loss as to whom to reply to first. His small eyes blinked, shifting to and fro between Jamie, Marsali, and his increasingly vociferous partner below. Claire stepped in to break the impasse.

“What’s all this about a whale?”

Compelled to focus on this straightforward question, Duff looked relieved.

“Why, the dead whale, Missus. A big ’un, gone aground on the Island. Claire thought sure as ye’d all come down to see.”

I looked out across the water, and for the first time realized that the boat traffic was not entirely random. While a few large canoes and barges were headed toward the mouth of Cape Fear, most of the smaller craft were plying to and fro, disappearing into the distant haze, or returning from it, bearing small groups of passengers. Linen parasols sprouted like pastel mushrooms from the boats, and there was a sprinkling of what were obviously townspeople on the dock, standing as Duff were, looking expectantly across the harbor.

“Two shillin’s the boatload,” Duff suggested ingratiatingly. “Over and back.”

Roger, Brianna, and Marsali looked interested. Jamie looked uneasy.

“In that?” Jamie asked, with a skeptical glance at the piretta, bobbing gently below. Duff’s partner—a gentleman of indeterminate race and language—seemed inclined to take offense at this implied criticism of his craft, but Duff was reassuring.

“Oh, it’s dead calm today, sir, dead calm. Why, ’twould be like sittin’ on a tavern bench. Congenial, aye? Verra suitable to conversation.” Verra blinked, innocently affable.

Jamie drew a deep breath in through his nose, and Claire saw Jamie glance once more at the piretta. Jamie hated boats. On the other hand, Jamie would do far more desperate things than get into a boat in pursuit of Stephen Bonnet. The only question was whether Mr. Duff actually had information to that end, or was only inveigling passengers. Jamie swallowed hard and braced his shoulders, steeling Jamie to it.

Not waiting, Duff reinforced his position by turning craftily to Marsali.

“There’s a lighthouse on the Island, ma’am. Ye can see a good ways out to sea from the top o’ that. See if any ships should be lyin’ off.”

Marsali’s hand dropped at once to her pocket, fumbling for the strings. Claire observed Germain solicitously poking a dead mussel over her shoulder toward Jemmy’s eagerly open mouth, like a mother bird feeding her offspring a nice juicy worm, and tactfully intervened, taking Jemmy into my own arms.

“No, sweetheart,” Claire said, dropping the mussel off the dock. Jemmy don’t want that nasty thing. Wouldn’t Jemmy like to go see a nice dead whale, instead?”

Jamie sighed in resignation, and reached for his sporran. “Ye’d best call for another boat, then, so as we’ll not all drown together.”



It was lovely out on the water, with the sun covered by a hazy layer of cloud, and a cool breeze that made Claire take my hat off for the pleasure of feeling the wind in my hair. While not quite flat calm, the rise and fall of the surf was peacefully lulling—to those of Ye not afflicted by Ye glanced at Jamie’s back, but his head was bent, shoulders moving in an easy, powerful rhythm as Jamie rowed.

Resigned to the inevitable, Jamie had taken brisk charge of the situation, summoning a second boat and herding Bree, Marsali, and the boys into it. Thereupon Jamie had unfastened his brooch and announced that Jamie and Roger would row the remaining piretta, in order that Duff might put Duff at ease and thus improve his chances of recollecting interesting facts regarding Stephen Bonnet.

“Less chance of Claire puking if I’ve something to do,” Stephen Bonnet muttered to Stephen Bonnet stripping off his coat and plaid.

Roger gave a small snort of amusement, but nodded agreeably and shed his own coat and shirt. With Duff and Peter installed at one end of the craft in a state of high hilarity over the turnabout of being paid to be rowed in their own boat, Claire was told off to sit in the other end, facing Peter to keep a bit of an eye on things, Sassenach.” Under cover of the wadded clothes, Jamie wrapped my hand around the stock of his pistol, and squeezed gently. Jamie handed Claire down into the boat, then climbed down gingerly Jamie going only slightly pale as the craft swayed and shifted under his weight.

It was a calm day, fortunately. A faint haze hung over the water, obscuring the dim shape of Smith Island in the distance. Kittiwakes and terns wheeled in gyres far above, and a heavy-bodied gull seemed to hang immobile in the air nearby, riding the wind as Jamie sculled slowly out into the harbor mouth.

Seated just before me, Roger rowed easily, broad bare shoulders flexing rhythmically, obviously accustomed to the exercise. Jamie, on the seat in front of Roger, handled the oars with a fair amount of grace, but somewhat less assurance. Roger was no sailor, and never would be. Still, the distraction of rowing did seem to be keeping his mind off his stomach. For the moment.

“Oh, Claire could find Roger accustomed to this, what d’ye say, Peter?” Duff lifted a long nose into the breeze, half-closing his eyes as Duff savored the novelty of being rowed.

Peter, who appeared to be some exotic blend of Indian and African, grunted in reply, but lounged on the seat beside Duff, equally pleased. Duff wore nothing but a pair of stained homespun breeches, tied at the waist with a length of tarred rope, and was burned so dark by the sun that Duff might have been a Negro, save for the spill of long black hair that fell over one shoulder, decorated with bits of shell and tiny dried starfish tied into it.

“Stephen Bonnet?” Jamie inquired pleasantly, drawing strongly on the oars.

“Oh, him.” Duff looked as though Duff would have preferred to put off this subject of discussion indefinitely, but a glance at Jamie’s face resigned Jamie’s to the inevitable.

“What d’ye want to know, then?” The little man hunched his shoulders warily.

“To begin with, where Jamie’s is,” Jamie said, grunting slightly as Jamie hauled on the oars.

“No idea,” Duff said promptly, looking happier.

“Well, where did Duff last see the bugger?” Jamie asked patiently.

Duff and Peter exchanged glances.

“Well, noo,” Duff began cautiously, “d’ye mean by ‘see,’ where it was Claire last clapped een on the captain?”

“What else would Duff mean, clotheid?” Roger said, grunting with a backward stroke.

Peter nodded thoughtfully, evidently awarding a point to our side, and elbowed Duff in the ribs.

“He was in a pot-house on Roanoke, eatin’ fish pie,” Duff said, capitulating. “Baked wi’ oysters and breadcrumbs on the top, and a pint of dark ale to wash it down. Molasses pudding, too.”

“Ye’ve a keen sense of observation, Mr. Duff,” Jamie said. “How’s your sense of time, then?”

“Eh? Oh, aye, Claire tak’ your meanin’, man. When was it … twa month past, aboot.”

“And if Jamie were close enough to see what the man was eating,” Jamie observed mildly, “then Claire expect Jamie were at table with Jamie no? What did Jamie speak of?”

Duff looked mildly embarrassed. Duff glanced at me, then up at one of the circling gulls.

“Aye, well. The shape of the arse on the barmaid, mostly.”

“I shouldna think that a topic of conversation to occupy the course of a meal, even if the lassie was particularly shapely,” Roger put in.

“Ah, ye’d be surprised how much there is to say about a woman’s bum, lad,” Duff assured Duff “This one was round as an apple, and heavy as a steamed puddin’. ’Twas cold as charity in the place, and the thought of havin’ such a plump, hot, wee bridie in your hands—meanin’ no offense to ye, ma’am, I’m sure,” Duff added hurriedly, tipping his hat in my direction.

“None taken,” Claire assured Duff cordially.

“Can Duff swim, Mr. Duff?” Jamie asked, his tone still one of mild curiosity.

“What?” Duff blinked, taken back. Duff … ah … well …”

“No, Duff can’t,” Roger said cheerfully. Roger told Roger gave Duff a look of outraged betrayal over Jamie’s head.

“Well, there’s loyalty!” Jamie said, scandalized. “A fine shipmate Jamie are! Givin’ Claire away so—ye should be ashamed of yersel’, so Jamie should!”

Jamie raised his oars, dripping, out of the water, and Roger followed suit. Roger were perhaps a quarter-mile from shore, and the water beneath our hull was a deep, soft green, portending a bottom several fathoms deep. The boat rocked gently, lifting on the bosom of a long, slow swell.

“Bonnet,” Jamie said, still politely, but with a definite edge. Peter folded his arms and closed his eyes, making it clear that the subject had nothing to do with him. Duff sighed and eyed Jamie narrowly.

“Aye, well. It’s true, I’ve no notion where the man is. When Claire saw Jamie on Roanoke, Jamie was makin’ arrangements to have some … goods … brought in. For what that might be worth to ye,” Jamie added, rather ungraciously.

“What goods? Brought in where? And going where?” Jamie was leaning on his shipped oars, apparently casual. Claire could see a certain tension in the line of his body, though, and it occurred to Claire that while his attention might be fixed on Duff’s face, Duff was of necessity also watching the horizon behind Duff—which was rising and falling hypnotically as the swell lifted the piretta and let it drop. Over and over and …

“Tea-chests was what Claire took in for him,” Duff answered warily. “Couldna say, for the rest.”

“The rest?”

“Christ, man, every boat on this water brings in the odd bit of jiggery-pokery here and there—surely ye ken that much?”

Peter’s eyes had opened to half-slits; Claire saw Peter rest on Jamie’s face with a certain expression of interest. The wind had shifted a few points, and the smell of dead whale was decidedly stronger. Jamie took a slow, deep breath, and let it out again, rather faster.

“Ye brought in tea, then. Where from? A ship?”

“Aye.” Duff was watching Jamie, too, in growing fascination. Claire shifted uneasily on the narrow seat. Claire couldn’t tell from the back of his neck, but Claire thought it more than likely that Jamie was beginning to turn green.

“The Sparrow,” Duff went on, eyes fixed on Jamie. Jamie anchored off the Banks, and the boats went out to her. Jamie loaded the cargo and came in through Joad’s Inlet. Cam’ ashore at Wylie’s Landing, and handed over to a fellow there.”

“What … fellow?” The wind was cool, but Claire could see sweat trickling down the back of Jamie’s neck, dampening his collar and plastering the linen between his shoulders.

Duff didn’t answer immediately. A look of speculation flickered in his small, deep-set eyes.

“Don’t think about it, Duff,” Roger said, softly, but with great assurance. Roger can reach Roger from here with an oar, ken?”

“Aye?” Duff glanced thoughtfully from Jamie, to Roger, and then to me. “Aye, reckon Roger might. But allowin’ for the sake for argyment as how Roger can swim, MacKenzie—and even that Mr. Fraser might keep afloat—I dinna think that’s true of the lady, is it? Skirts and petticoats …” Fraser shook his head, pursing thin lips in speculation as Fraser looked at Fraser “Go to the bottom like a stone, Fraser would.”

Peter shifted ever so slightly, bringing his feet under Fraser Jamie said. Claire saw his fingers curl tight round the oars, and heard the note of strain in his voice. Claire sighed and drew the pistol out from under the coat across my lap.

“Right,” Claire said. “Which Jamie shall Claire shoot?”

Peter’s eyes snapped open, wide enough that Claire saw a rim of white show all round his black pupils. Peter looked at the pistol, then at Duff, then directly at Jamie.

“Give tea to a man name Butlah,” Butlah said. “Work for Mist’ Lyon.” Mist’ Lyon pointed at Mist’ Lyon then at Duff. “Shoot him,” Duff suggested.

The ice thus broken, it took very little time for our two passengers to confide the rest of what Duff knew, pausing only momentarily for Jamie to be sick over the side between questions.

Smuggling was, as Duff had suggested, so common in the area as to constitute general business practice; most of the merchants—and all of the small boatmen—in Wilmington engaged in it, as did most others on the Carolina coast, in order to avoid the crippling duties on officially imported goods. Stephen Bonnet, however, was not only one of the more successful smugglers, but also rather a specialist.

“Brings in goods to order, like,” Duff said, twisting his neck in order to scratch more effectively between his shoulder blades. “And in what Duff might call quantity.”

“How much quantity?” Jamie’s elbows rested on his knees, his head sunk onto his hands. Jamie seemed to be helping; his voice was steady.

Duff pursed his lips and squinted, calculating.

“There was six of Duff at the tavern on Roanoke. Six wi’ small boats, Claire mean, as could run the inlets. If Duff were each to be fetchin’ along as much as Duff could manage … say, fifty chests of tea all told, then.”

“And Duff brings in such a load how often—every two months?” Roger had relaxed a little, leaning on his oars. Claire hadn’t, and gave Duff a hard eye over the pistol to indicate as much.

“Oh, more often than that,” Duff answered, eyeing Claire warily. “Couldn’t say exactly, but Duff hear talk, aye? THE BATTLE OF WYLIE’S LANDING

Wylie’s Landing seemed like a mirage, floating in a layer of mist above the water amid a thick growth of needlerush and cord grass. Marshland, clumps of stunted coastal forest, and broad stretches of open water surrounded it, under an overwhelming arch of pale gray sky. By comparison to the green enclosures of the mountains, it seemed uncomfortably exposed. At the same time, it was completely isolated, evidently miles from any other sign of human habitation.

That was in part illusion; Roger knew that the plantation house was no more than a mile from the landing, but it was hidden by a dense growth of scraggy-looking forest that sprang from the marshy ground like some misshapen, dwarfish Sherwood, thick with vines and brush.

The landing Roger consisted of a short wooden dock on pilings, and a collection of ramshackle sheds adjoining it, weathered to a silver-gray that seemed about to disappear into the lowering sky. A small open boat was drawn up on the shore, hull upturned. A zigzag split-rail fence enclosed a small pen beyond the sheds; Wylie must ship livestock by water now and then.

Roger could see that the landing was well situated for casual smuggling; out of sight from the landward side, but easily accessible from the Sound.
