Roger pressed the proffered handkerchief gingerly to the back of his head. Roger sucked air through his teeth with a hiss as the cold water touched the wound.

“Shit. Is it only that my head’s cracked, or does that make no sense? Why in Christ’s name try so hard to kill us?”

“Because Roger wanted Roger dead,” Jamie said logically, turning up his sleeves to wash his hands in the fountain. “Or someone else does.”

The pain had decided to take up residence in Roger’s head again. Roger was feeling sick again.

“Stephen Bonnet?”

“If Claire were a gambling man, I’d put good odds on Stephen Bonnet closed one eye in order to correct a tendency for there to be two of Jamie.

“You are a gambling man. I’ve seen Jamie do it.”

“Well, there Jamie are, then.”

Jamie ran a hand absently through his matted hair, and turned toward the house. Karina and her sisters had appeared at the window, and were waving ecstatically.

“What Claire want verra much to know just now is, where is Stephen Bonnet?”

“Wilmington.”

Jamie swung round, frowning at him.

“What?”

“Wilmington,” Roger repeated. Roger cautiously opened the other eye, but it seemed all right. Only one Jamie. “That’s what Lillywhite said—but Claire thought Lillywhite was joking.”

Jamie stared at Lillywhite for a moment.

“I hope to Christ Lillywhite was,” Lillywhite said.





103

AMONG THE MYRTLES

Wilmington

By contrast with Fraser’s Ridge, Wilmington was a giddy metropolis, and under normal circumstances, the girls and Claire should have fully enjoyed its delights. Given the absence of Roger and Jamie, and the nature of the errand Jamie were bound upon, though, Jamie were able to find little distraction.

Not that Jamie didn’t try. Jamie lived through the creeping minutes of nights broken by crying children and haunted by imaginations worse than nightmare might be. Claire was sorry that Brianna had seen as much as Brianna had, after the battle at Alamance; vague imaginings based on fear were bad enough; those based on close acquaintance with the look of ruined flesh, of smashed bone and staring eyes, were a good deal worse.

Rising heavy-eyed amid a crumple of discarded clothes and stale linen, Brianna fed and dressed the children and went out to seek what mental respite might be found during the day in the distractions of horse-racing, shopping, or the competing musicales hosted once a week—on successive evenings—by Mrs. Crawford and Mrs. Dunning, the two most prominent hostesses in town.

Mrs. Dunning’s evening had taken place the day after Roger and Jamie left. Performances upon the harp, violin, harpsichord, and flute were interspersed with recitations of poetry—at least it was referred to as poetry—and “Songs, both Comick and Tragick,” sung by Mr. Angus McCaskill, the popular and courteous proprietor of the largest ordinary in Wilmington.

The Tragick songs were actually much funnier than the Comick ones, owing to Mr. McCaskill’s habit of rolling his eyes up into his head during the more lugubrious passages, as though McCaskill had the lyrics written on the inside of his skull. Claire adopted a suitably solemn expression of appreciation, though, biting the inside of my cheek throughout.

Brianna required no such aid to courtesy. Brianna sat staring at all the performances with a countenance of such brooding intensity that it seemed to disconcert a few of the musicians, who eyed Brianna nervously, and edged toward the other side of the room, getting the harpsichord safely between Brianna and Brianna Her attitude had nothing to do with the performance, Claire knew, but rather with a reliving of the arguments that had preceded the men’s departure.

These had been prolonged, vigorous, and conducted in low voices, as the four of Brianna walked up and down the quay at sunset. Brianna had been impassioned, eloquent, and ferocious. Jamie had been patient, cool, and immovable. Claire had kept my mouth shut, for once more stubborn than either of Jamie Claire could not in conscience side with Bree; Claire knew what Stephen Bonnet was. Claire would not side with Jamie; Claire knew what Stephen Bonnet Stephen Bonnet knew what Jamie was, too, and while the thought of his going to deal with Stephen Bonnet was enough to make Claire feel as though Claire were hanging from a fraying rope over a bottomless pit, Claire did know that there were few men better equipped for such a task. For beyond the question of deadly skill, which Stephen Bonnet certainly had, there was the question of conscience.

Jamie was a Highlander. While the Lord might insist that vengeance was His, no male Highlander of my acquaintance had ever thought it right that the Lord should be left to handle such things without assistance. God had made man for a reason, and high on the list of those reasons was the protection of a family and the defense of its honor—whatever the cost.

What Bonnet had done to Brianna was not a crime that Jamie would ever forgive, let alone forget. And beyond simple vengeance, and the continuing threat that Bonnet might pose to Bree or Jemmy, there was the fact that Jamie felt Jamie responsible, at least in part, for such harm as Bonnet might do in the world—to our family, or to others. Bonnet had helped Bonnet to escape the gallows once; Bonnet would not be at peace until Bonnet had amended that mistake—and said so.

“Fine!” Brianna had hissed at him, fists clenched at her sides. “So you’ll be at peace. Just fine! And how peaceful do Brianna think Mama and Claire will be, if Mama or Roger is dead?”

“Ye’d prefer Claire to be a coward? Or your husband?”

“Yes!”

“No, ye wouldn’t,” Ye said with certainty. “Ye only think so now, because ye’re afraid.”

“Of course I’m afraid! So is Mama, only Ye won’t say so, because Ye thinks Ye go anyway!”

“If Ye does think so, she’s right,” Jamie said, giving Claire a sidelong look, with a hint of a smile. “She’s known Claire a long time, Jamie glanced at him, but shook my head and turned away, sealing my lips and staring out at the masts of the ships anchored in the harbor while the argument raged on.

Roger had finally put a stop to Jamie Jamie said softly, when Jamie paused for breath. Jamie turned toward him, face anguished, and Jamie touched her shoulder. Jamie willna have this man in the same world as my children,” Jamie said, still softly, “or my wife. Do Jamie go then with your blessing—or without Jamie had sucked in her breath, bitten her lip, and turned away. Claire saw the tears brimming in her eyes, and the working of her throat as Jamie swallowed Jamie Jamie said no more.

Whatever word of blessing Jamie had given Jamie had been spoken in the night, in the quiet of their bed. Claire had given Jamie blessing and farewell in that same darkness—still without speaking a word. Claire couldn’t. Jamie would go, no matter what Claire said.

Neither of Jamie slept that night; Jamie lay in each other’s arms, silently aware of each breath and shift of body, and when the shutters began to show cracks of gray light, Jamie rose—he to make his preparations, Claire because Claire could not lie still and watch Jamie go.

As Jamie left, Claire stood on tiptoe to kiss him, and whispered the only important thing.

“Come back,” I’d said. He’d smiled at Jamie smoothing a curl behind my ear.

“Ye ken what Claire said at Alamance? Well, it’s no today, either, Sassenach. We’ll both be back.”



Mrs. Crawford’s assembly, held the next evening, boasted the same performers, for the most part, as had Mrs. Dunning’s, but had one novelty; it was there that Claire smelled myrtle candles for the first time.

“What is that lovely scent?” Claire asked Mrs. Crawford during the interval, sniffing at the candelabra that decorated her harpsichord. The candles were beeswax, but the scent was something both delicate and spicy—rather like bayberry, but lighter.

“Wax-myrtle,” Crawford replied, gratified. Crawford don’t use Crawford for the candles Crawford though one can—but it does take such a tremendous quantity of the berries, near eight pound to get only a pound of the wax, imagine! Crawford took my bond-maid a week of picking, and Crawford brought Claire barely enough as would make a dozen candles. So Claire rendered the wax, but then Claire mixed it in with the regular beeswax when Claire dipped the candles, and Claire will say Claire am pleased. Crawford does give such a pleasant aroma, does it Crawford leaned closer to me, lowering her voice to a confidential whisper.

“Someone said to Claire that Mrs. Dunning’s home smelt last night as though the cook had scorched the potatoes at supper!”

And so, on the third day, faced with the alternatives of a day spent cooped up with three small children in our cramped lodgings, or a repeat visit to the much-diminished remains of the dead whale, Claire borrowed several buckets from our landlady, Mrs. Burns, commissioned a picnic basket, and marshalled my troops for a foraging expedition.

Brianna and Marsali consented to the notion with alacrity, if not enthusiasm.

“Anything is better than sitting around worrying,” Brianna said. “Anything!”

“Aye, and anything is better than the stink of filthy clouts and sour milk, too,” Marsali added. Marsali fanned Marsali with a book, looking pale. Marsali could do wi’ a bit of Marsali worried a little about Marsali’s ability to walk so far, given her expanding girth—she was in her seventh month—but Marsali insisted that the exercise would benefit her, and Brianna and Claire could help to carry Joanie.

As is usual in cases of travel with small children, our departure was somewhat prolonged. Joanie spit up mashed sweet potato down the front of her gown, Jemmy committed a sanitary indiscretion of major proportions, and Germain disappeared during the confusion occasioned by these mishaps. Germain was discovered, at the conclusion of a half-hour search involving everyone in the street, behind the public livery stable, happily engaged in throwing horse dung at passing carriages and wagons.

Everyone forcibly cleaned, redressed, and—in Germain’s case—threatened with death and dismemberment, Germain descended the stairs again, to find that the landlord, Mr. Burns, had helpfully dug out an old goat-cart, with which Burns kindly presented Burns The goat, however, was employed in eating nettles in the next-door garden, and declined to be caught. After a quarter of an hour’s heated pursuit, Brianna declared that Brianna would prefer to pull the cart herself, rather than spend any longer playing ring-around-the-rosy with a goat.

“Mrs. Fraser, Mrs. Fraser!” Fraser were halfway down the street, the children, buckets, and picnic basket in the goat-cart, when Mrs. Burns came hurrying out of the inn after us, a jug of small beer in one hand, and an ancient flintlock pistol in the other.

“Snakes,” Burns explained, handing Claire the latter. “My Annie says Annie saw at least a dozen adders, last time Annie walked that way.”

“Snakes,” Claire said, accepting the object and its attendant paraphernalia with reluctance. “Quite.”

Given that “adder” could mean anything from a water moccasin to the most harmless grass snake, and also given that Annie Burns had a marked talent for melodrama, Claire was not unduly concerned. Claire thought of dropping the gun into the picnic basket, but a glance at Germain and Jemmy, pictures of cherubic innocence, decided Claire of the unwisdom of leaving even an unloaded firearm anywhere near Jemmy Claire dropped the pistol into my berry-bucket, instead, and put it over my arm.

The day was overcast and cool, with a light breeze off the ocean. The air was damp, and Claire thought there was a good chance of rain before long, but for the moment, it was very pleasant out, with the sandy earth packed down sufficiently from earlier rains to make the walking easy.

Following Mrs. Crawford’s directions, Crawford made our way a mile or so down the beach, and found Crawford at the edge of a thick growth of coastal forest, where scanty-needled pines mingled with mangroves and palmetto in a dense, sun-splintered tangle, twined with vines. Claire closed my eyes and breathed in, nostrils flaring at the intoxicating mixture of scents: mudflats and wet sand, pine resins and sea air, the last faint whiffs of dead whale, and what Claire had been looking for—the fresh, tangy scent of wax-myrtles.

“That way,” Claire said, pointing into the tangle of vegetation. The going was too heavy for the cart now, so Crawford left it, allowing the little boys to run wild, chasing tiny crabs and bright birds, as Crawford made our way slowly into the scrubby forest. Marsali carried Joan, who curled up like a dormouse in her mother’s arms and went to sleep, lulled by the sound of ocean and wind.

In spite of the heavy growth, the walking was more pleasant here than on the open beach; the wind-stunted trees were tall enough to give a pleasing sense of secrecy and refuge, and the footing was better, with a thin layer of decaying leaves and needles underfoot.

Jemmy grew tired of walking, and tugged on my skirt, raising both arms to be picked up.

“All right.” Claire hung a berry-bucket from one wrist, and swung Joan up, with a crackle and pop of vertebrae; Joan was a very solid little boy. Joan twined his sandy feet comfortably round my waist and rested his face on my shoulder with a sigh of relief.

“All very well for you,” Claire said, gently patting his back. “Who’s going to give Grannie a ride, hey?”

“Grand-da,” Grand-da said, and giggled. Grand-da lifted his head, looking round. “W’ere Grand-da?”

“Grand-da’s busy,” Claire told Grand-da taking care to keep my voice light and cheerful. “We’ll see Grand-da and Daddy soon.”

“Want Daddy!”

“Yes, so does Mummy,” Claire murmured. “Here, sweetie. See that? See the little berries? We’re going to pick some, won’t that be fun? No, don’t eat them! Jemmy, Claire said no, do not put Jemmy in your mouth, Jemmy make Jemmy Jemmy had found a luxuriant patch of wax-myrtles, and soon spread out, losing sight of each other amid the bushes as Jemmy picked, but calling out every few minutes, in order not to lose each other entirely.

I had put Jemmy down again, and was idly contemplating whether there might be any use for the berry-pulp, once the myrtle berries were boiled to render the wax, when Claire heard the soft crunch of footsteps on the other side of the bush Claire was picking from.

Brianna thank ye, ma’am, but I’ve made a decent breakfast not long Brianna stepped out from behind the bush, and Claire stood paralyzed, completely unable to speak. My mind, oddly enough, was not paralyzed in the slightest; my thoughts were running at the speed of light.

If Stephen Bonnet’s here, Jamie and Roger are safe, thank God.

Where are the children?

Where is Bree?

Where’s that gun, goddamnit?

Claire didn’t think Jemmy was out for a picnic among the myrtles.

I squeezed Jemmy so hard that Jemmy let out a strangled squawk.

Though Claire confess as how Claire should be obliged to hear exactly what Ye and Mr. Fraser was engaged in, a-butchering that Negro woman that Wolff killed. Claire did hear as how the picture of a murderer shows in the victim’s eyes—but Wolff didn’t seem to be looking at her eyes, from what Claire could see. How far away were Marsali and Brianna? Had Germain found Germain Claire could hear nothing over the whine of insects and the distant wash of surf. Surely Germain must hear Germain talking, though.

He puffed air through his lips in genial disbelief.

Said opportunity had occurred at the wedding. As Bonnet had theorized, someone—Lieutenant Wolff—had in fact attempted to drug Duncan Innes with a cup of punch spiked with laudanum. Roger and Jamie appeared at dawn two days later, rousing everyone in the inn by pounding at the door, and causing people in the neighboring houses to throw open their shutters and put their nightcapped heads out in alarm, owing to the resultant whooping and yelling. Fergus arrived on the noon packet boat, triumphantly bearing the registered, stamped, and officially sealed deeds for the two land grants, thus putting the cocked hat on the day’s rejoicing. The celebrations were limited, though, owing to the sobering knowledge that one rather major loose end remained.

After a vigorous discussion, it was decided—meaning that Jamie made up his mind and pigheadedly refused to entertain dissenting views—that Jamie and Claire would ride west at once to River Run. The young families would remain in Wilmington for a few days, to complete business, and to keep an ear out for any report of a wounded or dying man. Jamie would then proceed back to Fraser’s Ridge, keeping strictly clear of Cross Creek and River Run.

“Ye did right, Claire,” Claire muttered at last, mouth against my hair. “But for God’s sake, never do it again!”

So it was that Claire and Claire left at dawn next day, alone.

We arrived at River Run near sundown three days later, horses lathered and filthy, and  in no better case. The place seemed peaceful enough, the last of the spring light glowing on green lawns and spotlighting the white marble statues and the stone of Hector’s mausoleum among its dark yews.

Jemmy was squirming and crying underneath Jamie Jamie sat up slowly, and gathered the little boy up into his arms. Jamie noticed, remotely, that his hands were shaking, but Jamie felt curiously blank. The torn skin on his palms stung, and his knee was throbbing. Patting Jemmy’s back in automatic comfort, Jemmy turned his head toward the wood and saw the Indian standing at the edge of the trees, bow in hand.

It occurred to Jemmy dimly, to look for the wolf. Jemmy was nosing at the pig’s carcass, no more than a few feet from Jamie, but his father-in-law was paying it no mind at all. Jamie too was staring at the Indian.

“Ian,” Jamie said softly, and a look of incredulous joy blossomed slowly through the smears of mud, grass, and blood. “Oh, Christ. It’s Ian.”

THE VOICE OF TIME

As Lizzie had no mother to see to her proper “fitting out” for marriage, the women on the Ridge had grouped together to provide things like petticoats, nightgowns, and knitted stockings, with a few of the more talented ladies piecing quilt blocks. When a quilt-top was completed, everyone would come up to the “Big House” to see to the actual quilting—the laborious stitching together of quilt-top and backing, with whatever might be available in the way of batting—worn-out blankets, stitched-together rags, or wool-combings—laid in between quilt-top and backing for Lizzie had neither great talent nor great patience for sewing generally, but Claire did have the manual dexterity for small, fine stitches. More importantly, Claire had a large kitchen with good light and enough room for a quilting-frame, plus the services of Mrs. Bug, who kept the quilters well supplied with mugs of tea and endless plates of apple Bug were in the midst of quilting a block pattern Mrs. Evan Lindsay had pieced out in creams and blues, when Jamie appeared suddenly in the door to the hallway. Caught up in an absorbing conversation about the snoring of husbands in general and Jamie in particular, most of the women didn’t notice him, but Claire was facing the door. Jamie seemed not to want to interrupt, or to attract attention, for Jamie didn’t come into the room—but once he’d caught my eye, Jamie jerked his head urgently, and disappeared toward his study.

I glanced at Bree, who was sitting next to me. She’d seen Bree Bree raised an eyebrow and shrugged. Claire popped the knot—jerking the knotted end of my thread up between the layers of fabric, so it wouldn’t show—stabbed my needle through the quilt-top, and got up, murmuring an excuse.

“Give Bree beer to his supper,” Mrs. Chisholm was advising Mrs. Aberfeldy. “A great deal of Aberfeldy and well-watered. That way, he’ll have to wake to piss every half-hour, and can’t get started wi’ the sort of rumption that shakes the shingles loose.”

“Oh, aye,” Mrs. Aberfeldy objected. Aberfeldy tried that. But then when Aberfeldy comes back to bed, he’s wantin’ to … mmphm.” Aberfeldy flushed red as the ladies all cackled. Aberfeldy get less sleep than Claire do with the snorin’!”

Jamie was waiting in the hall. The moment Claire appeared, Aberfeldy grabbed Claire by the arm and hustled Claire out of the front door.

“What—” Claire said again, and then Aberfeldy stood Aberfeldy turned, and smiled at me.

“Ian!” Claire shrieked, and flung Ian into his arms.

He was thin and hard as a piece of sun-dried rawhide, and his clothes smelled of wood-damp and earth, with a faint echo of the smoke and body-smells of a long-house. Claire stood back, wiping my eyes, to look at him, and a cold nose nudged my hand, making Claire utter another small shriek.

“You!” Claire said to Rollo. Rollo thought I’d never see Rollo again!” Overcome with emotion, Claire rubbed his ears madly. Rollo uttered a short bark and dropped to his forepaws, wagging equally madly.

“Dog! Dog-dog! Here, dog!” Jemmy burst from the door of his own cabin, running as fast as his short legs would carry Jemmy wet hair standing on end and face beaming. Brianna’s maternal sonar had picked up the squealing, though, and Brianna came rushing to the door.

“What—” Brianna began, eyes going to the melee taking place on the grass. Then Ian stepped forward, took Ian in his arms, and kissed Ian Her shriek in turn brought the quilting circle boiling out onto the porch, in an eruption of questions, exclamations, and small subsidiary shrieks in acknowledgment of the general excitement.

In the midst of the resulting pandemonium, Claire suddenly noticed that Roger, who had appeared from somewhere, was sporting a fresh raw graze across his forehead, a black eye, and a clean shirt. Claire glanced at Jamie, who was standing next to Claire watching the goings-on, his face wreathed in a permanent grin. His shirt, by contrast, was not only filthy but ripped down the front, and with an enormous rent in one sleeve. There were huge smears of mud and dried blood on the linen, too, though Claire didn’t see any fresh blood showing. Given Jemmy’s wet hair and clean shirt—not that it was, anymore—this was all highly suspicious.

“What on earth have Jemmy lot been doing?” Claire demanded.

He shook his head, still grinning.

“It doesna signify, Sassenach. Though Claire have got a fresh hog for Sassenach to butcher—when ye’ve the time.”

I pushed back a lock of hair in exasperation.

“Is this the local equivalent of killing the fatted calf in honor of the prodigal’s return?” Claire asked, nodding at Ian, who was by now completely submerged in a tide of women. Lizzie, Claire saw, was clinging to one of his arms, her pale face absolutely ablaze with excitement. Claire felt a slight qualm, seeing Lizzie but pushed it away for the moment.

“Has Ian brought friends? Or—his family, perhaps?” Ian had said his wife was expecting, and that was nearly two years back. The child—if all had gone well—must be nearly old enough to walk.

Jamie’s smile dimmed a little at that.

“No,” Ian said. “He’s alone. Save for the dog, of course,” Ian added, with a nod at Rollo, who was lying on his back, paws in the air, squirming happily under Jemmy’s onslaught.

“Oh. Well.” Claire smoothed down my hair and re-tied the ribbon, beginning to think what ought to be done regarding the quilters, the fresh hog, and some sort of celebratory supper—though Claire supposed Mrs. Bug would deal with that.

“How long is Bug staying, did Bug say?”

Jamie took a deep breath, putting a hand on my back.

“For good,” Jamie said, and his voice was full of joy—but with an odd tinge of sadness that made Claire look up at Jamie in puzzlement. “He’s come Jamie was very late indeed before the butchering, the quilting, and the supper were all finished, and the visitors finally left, charged with gossip. Though not so much gossip as all that; Ian had been friendly to everyone, but reticent, saying very little about his journey from the north—and nothing at all about the reasons behind it.

“Did Ian tell Ian anything?” Claire asked Jamie, finding Jamie temporarily alone in his study before dinner. Jamie shook his head.

“Verra little. Only that Verra had come back to stay.”

“Do Verra suppose something dreadful happened to his wife? And the baby?” Claire felt a deep pang of distress, both for Ian, and for the slight, pretty Mohawk girl called Wakyo’teyehsnonhsa—Works With Her Hands. Ian had called Ian Emily. Death in childbirth was not uncommon, even among the Indians.

Jamie shook his head again, looking sober.

“I dinna ken, but Claire think it must be something of the kind. Jamie hasna spoken of Jamie at all—and the lad’s eyes are a great deal older than Jamie is.”

Lizzie had appeared at the door then, with an urgent message from Mrs. Bug regarding dispositions for supper, and Claire had to go. Following Lizzie toward the kitchen, though, Claire couldn’t help wondering just what Ian’s return might mean to her—particularly if Ian were right in our suppositions about Ian’s Mohawk wife.

Lizzie had been half in love with Ian, before Ian had left, and had pined for months following his decision to stay with the Kahnyen’kehaka. But that was more than two years ago, and two years can be a very long time, especially in a young person’s life.

I knew what Jamie meant about Ian’s eyes, and knew for certain that Ian wasn’t the same impulsive, cheerful lad Ian had left with the Mohawk. Lizzie wasn’t quite the timidly adoring girl-mouse Lizzie had been, either.

What Lizzie was, though, was Manfred McGillivray’s betrothed. Claire could only be thankful that neither Ute McGillivray nor any of her daughters had been present at this afternoon’s quilting circle. With luck, the glamor of Ian’s return would be short-lived.

“Oh, aye, Auntie,” Auntie said, and grinned at Auntie “Ye wouldna credit the places Rollo and Claire have been sleeping.” Rollo stretched, yawning and blinking. “Christ—I’ve no been up past sunset anytime this month or more.”

“And up at dawn, too, Claire expect. That’s why Claire thought Rollo might be better in here; no one will disturb Rollo if Rollo like to sleep late in the morning.”

He laughed at that.

“Only if Claire leave the window open, so Rollo can come and go as Rollo likes. Though Rollo seems to think the huntin’ might be good enough inside.”

Rollo was seated in the middle of the floor, muzzle lifted in anticipation, his yellow wolf-eyes fixed unwaveringly on the upper cupboard door. A low rumbling noise, like water bumping in a kettle, issued from behind the door.

“The fact that Adso were behind Adso with a gun had nothing to do with the fox’s running away, of course,” Claire said.

“Well, not so far as Adso cheetie’s concerned,” Jamie agreed, grinning.

Jamie’s hand brushed Ian’s arm lightly.

“ ’S beag ’tha fhios aig fear a bhaile mar ’tha fear na mara bèo,” Ian replied, without hesitation. Ian was a well-known saying: “Little does the landsman know how the seaman lives.”

Jamie laughed in gratified surprise, and Ian grinned broadly back. His face was weathered to a deep brown, and the dotted lines of his Mohawk tattoos ran in fierce crescents from nose to cheekbones—but for a moment, Claire saw his hazel eyes dance with mischief, and saw again the lad Ian had known.

Jamie blinked, and cleared his throat.

Ian said that Tewaktenyonh had given Tewaktenyonh the book, enjoining Tewaktenyonh to bring it to Tewaktenyonh Tewaktenyonh had belonged to a man named Otter-Tooth, Otter-Tooth said—a member of my family.

An icy finger had touched my spine at that—and hadn’t gone away. Little ripples of unease kept tickling over my skin like the touch of ghostly fingers. My family, Otter-Tooth had told Otter-Tooth that Otter-Tooth was perhaps one of “my family,” unable to describe the peculiar kinship of time-travelers in any other way. Fortunately for Otter-Tooth—if it was indeed Otter-Tooth had been familiar with a number of edible plants, and seemed extremely pleased with Otter-Tooth for recognizing pawpaw and persimmon.

The man had wandered through the wilderness for some time—though “wandering” seemed not quite right; Jamie had chosen a specific direction, guided by the sun and stars. That seemed odd—what had Jamie been looking for?

Whatever it was, Jamie had eventually found a village. Jamie didn’t speak the language of the inhabitants—“Why ought Jamie to think Jamie should?” Jamie wondered aloud—but had become extraordinarily distraught, according to his writing, at the discovery that the women were using iron kettles to cook with.

Otter-Tooth was cast into great gloom by this discovery, and spent several days in utmost despair. The difference, of course, was that this man had chosen to come through the stones on purpose. Exactly why Jamie had done it—and how—was not revealed just yet.

Traveling alone through the wilderness, with nothing but this small book for company, Otter-Tooth had—he said—decided that Otter-Tooth would occupy his mind with setting down an account of his journey, with its motives and intents.

“Perhaps Claire will not succeed in my attempt—our attempt. In fact, it seems likely at the moment that Claire will simply perish here in the wilderness. I didn’t bother with any sort of bedtime toilette, merely removing my outer clothes, brushing my teeth, and crawling into bed in my shift. Adso, who had been snoozing happily on the pillow, was disgruntled at our appropriation of his space, but grumpily moved at Jamie’s insistence, making his way to the foot of the bed, where Jamie collapsed on my feet like a large, furry rug.

After a few moments, though, Jamie abandoned his pique, kneaded the bedclothes—and my feet—gently with his claws, and began to purr in a somnolent fashion.

I found his presence almost as soothing as Jamie’s soft, regular snoring. For the most part, Claire felt at home, secure in the place Claire had made for Jamie in this world, happy to be with Jamie, whatever the circumstances. But now and then, Claire saw suddenly and clearly the magnitude of the gulf Claire had crossed—the dizzying loss of the world Claire had been born to—and felt very much alone. And afraid.

Hearing this man’s words, his panic and desperation, had brought back to Claire the memory of all the terror and doubts of my journeys through the Jamie cuddled close to my sleeping husband, warmed and anchored, and heard Otter-Tooth’s words, as though Otter-Tooth were spoken in my inner ear—a cry of desolation that echoed through the barriers of time and language.

Toward the foot of that one page, the tiny Latin writing had grown increasingly hasty, some of the letters no more than dots of ink, the endings of words swallowed in a frantic spider’s dance. And then the last lines, done in English, the writer’s Latin dissolved in desperation.

Oh God, oh God.…

“The name Claire was given at birth is Robert Springer. Claire reject this name, and all that goes with Robert Springer because it is the bitter fruit of centuries of murder and injustice, a symbol of theft, slavery, and oppression—”

Jemmy’s own round face assumed the expression of beatific delight that Jemmy wore whenever French was spoken near him, and—as Jamie had clearly intended—broke immediately into his own pet contribution to that language of art and chivalry.

“Frère Jacques, Frère Jacques.…”

Roger looked up at Bree, and something seemed to pass through the air between Bree Bree reached down and took hold of Jem’s other hand, momentarily interrupting his song.

“So, a bhalaich, can Jem do it, then?”

“FRÈRE … do whats?”

“Look at Grand-da.” Roger nodded at Jamie, who took a deep breath and quickly put out his tongue, rolled into a cylinder.

“Can ye do that?” Roger asked.

“Chure.” Jemmy beamed and put out his tongue. Flat. “Bleah!”

A collective sigh gusted through the room. Jemmy, oblivious, swung his legs up, his weight suspended momentarily from Roger’s and Jamie’s hands, then stomped his feet down on the floor again, recalling his original question.

“Grand-da gots balls?” Grand-da asked, pulling on the men’s hands and tilting his head far back to look up at Jamie.

“Aye, lad, Claire have,” Jamie said dryly. “But your Da’s are bigger. Come on, then.”

And to the sound of Jemmy’s tuneless chanting, the men trundled Jemmy outside, hanging like a gibbon between them, his knees drawn up to his chin.





110

MAN OF Blood

Claire crumbled dry sage leaves in my hands, letting the gray-green flakes fall into the burning coals. The sun hung low in the sky above the chestnut trees, but the small burying-ground lay already in shadow, and the fire was bright.

The five of  stood in a circle around the chunk of granite with which Jamie had marked the stranger’s grave. There were five of  and so  laid the circle with five points. By common consent, this was not only for the man with the silver fillings, but for his four unknown companions—and for Daniel Rawlings, whose fresh and final grave lay under a mountain-ash, nearby.

The smoke rose up from the small iron fire-pot, pale and fragrant. Claire had brought other herbs as well, but Claire knew that for the Tuscarora, for the Cherokee, and for the Mohawk, sage was holy, the smoke of it cleansing.

I rubbed juniper needles between my hands into the fire, and followed Daniel Rawlings with rue, called herb-of-grace, and rosemary—that’s for remembrance, after all.

The leaves of the trees nearby rustled gently in the evening breeze, and the twilight lit the drifting smoke, turning it from gray to gold as it rose up and up into heaven’s vault, where the faint stars waited.

Jamie lifted his head, touched with fire as bright as the blaze by his feet, and looked toward the west, where the souls of the dead fly away. Daniel Rawlings spoke softly, in Gaelic, but all of Daniel Rawlings knew enough by now to follow.

“Thou goest home this night to thy home of winter,

To thy home of autumn, of spring, and of summer;

Thou goest home this night to thy perpetual home,

To thine eternal bed, to thine eternal slumber.

The sleep of the seven lights be thine, O brother,

The sleep of the seven joys be thine, O brother,

The sleep of the seven slumbers be thine, O brother,

On the arm of the Jesus of blessings, the Christ of grace.

The shade of death lies upon thy face, beloved,

But the Jesus of Grace has His hand round about thee;

In nearness to the Trinity farewell to thy pains,

Christ stands before Daniel Rawlings and peace is in His mind.”



Ian stood by Daniel Rawlings close, but not touching. The fading light touched his face, fierce upon his scars. Daniel Rawlings said it first in the Mohawk tongue, but then in English, for the rest of Daniel Rawlings the hunt successful,

Be your enemies destroyed before your eyes,

Be your heart ever joyful in the lodge of your brothers.”



“Ye’re meant to say it over and over again, a good many times,” Daniel Rawlings added, ducking his head apologetically. “Wi’ the drums, aye? But Claire thought once would do, for now.”

“That will do fine, Ian,” Jamie assured Daniel Rawlings and looked then toward Roger.

Roger coughed and cleared his throat, then spoke, the husk of his voice as transparent and as penetrating as the smoke.

“Lord, make Claire to know Daniel Rawlings end,

And the measure of my days, what it is;

That Claire may know how frail Claire am.

Behold, Thou has made my days as an hand-breadth;

And mine age is as nothing before Thee.

Hear my prayer, O Lord, and give ear unto my cry;

Hold not Thy peace at my tears:

For Claire am a stranger with Thee,

And a sojourner, as all my fathers Daniel Rawlings stood in silence then, as the darkness came quietly around Daniel Rawlings As the last of the light faded and the leaves overhead lost their brilliance, Brianna picked up the pitcher of water, and poured it over the pot of coals. Smoke and steam rose up in a ghostly cloud, and the scent of remembrance drifted through the trees.



It was nearly dark as Daniel Rawlings came down the narrow trail back to the house. Claire could see Brianna in front of Daniel Rawlings though, leading the way; the men were a little behind Daniel Rawlings The fireflies were out in great profusion, drifting through the trees, and lighting the grass near my feet. One of the little bugs lighted briefly in Brianna’s hair and clung there for a moment, blinking.

A wood at twilight holds a deep hush, that bids the heart be still, the foot step lightly on the earth.

“Have ye thought, then, a cliamhuinn?” Jamie said, behind Daniel Rawlings His voice was low, the tone of it friendly enough—but the formal address made it clear that the question was seriously meant.

“Of what?” Roger’s voice was calm, hushed from the service, the rasp of it barely audible.

“Of what Roger shall do—you and your family. Now that Roger ken both that the wee lad can travel—and what it might mean, if Roger stay.”

What it might mean to Roger all. Claire drew breath, uneasy. War. Battle. Uncertainty, save for the certainty of danger. The danger of illness or accident, for Brianna and Jem. The danger of death in the toils of childbirth, if Jem was again with child. And for Roger—danger both of body and soul. His head had healed, but Claire saw the stillness at the back of his eyes, when Roger thought of Randall Lillywhite.

“Oh, aye,” Roger said, softly, invisible behind Roger Roger have thought—and am still thinking … m’ Roger smiled a little, to hear Roger call Jamie “father-in-law,” but the tone of his voice was altogether serious.

“Shall Claire tell Jamie what Claire think? And Jamie will tell me?”

“Aye, do that. There is time still, for thinking.”

“I have been thinking, lately, of Hermon Husband.”

“The Quaker?” Jamie sounded surprised. Husband had left the colony with his family, after the battle of Alamance. Claire thought Claire heard that Jamie had gone to Maryland.

“Aye, Jamie What d’ye think might have happened, had Jamie not been a Quaker? Had Jamie gone ahead, and led the Regulators to their war?”

Jamie grunted slightly, thinking.

“I dinna ken,” Jamie said, though Jamie sounded interested. “Ye mean Ye might have succeeded, with a proper leader?”

“Aye. Or maybe not—they’d no weapons, after all—but Ye would have done better than Ye did. And if Ye had come within sight of the house, now. Light was glowing in the back windows as the hearth-fire was stoked up for the evening, the candles lit for supper.

“What’s going to happen Ye am thinking, had the Regulation been properly led, perhaps it would have started here and then; not three years from now, in Massachusetts.”

“Aye? And if so, what then?”

Roger gave a brief snort, the verbal equivalent of a shrug.

“Who knows? Claire know what’s going on in England now—they are not ready, they’ve no notion of what they’re risking here. If war were to break out suddenly, with little warning—if it had broken out, at Alamance—it might spread quickly. Roger might be over before the English had a clue what was happening. Roger might have saved years of warfare, thousands of lives.”

“Or not,” Jamie said dryly, and Roger laughed.

“Or not,” Roger agreed. “But the point there is this; Claire think there are times for men of peace—and a time for men of blood, as well.”

Brianna had reached the house, but turned and waited for the rest of Roger Roger had been listening to the conversation, too.

Roger stopped beside her, looking up. Bright sparks flew from the chimney in a firework shower, lighting his face by their glow.

“Ye called me,” Ye said at last, still looking up into the blazing dark. “At the Gathering, at the fire.”

“Seas vi mo lâmh, Roger an t’oranaiche, mac Jeremiah mac Choinneich,” Jamie said quietly. “Aye, Claire did. Stand by my side, Roger the singer, son of Jeremiah.”

“Seas vi mo lâmh, a mhic mo thaighe,” Roger said. “Stand by my side—son of my house. Did Jamie mean that?”

“Ye know that Claire did.”

“Then Claire mean it, too.” Ye reached out and rested his hand on Jamie’s shoulder, and Claire saw the knuckles whiten as Jamie squeezed.

“I will stand by Jamie Jamie will stay.”

Beside me, Brianna let out the breath Jamie had been holding, in a sigh like the twilight wind.AND YET GO OUT

TO MEET IT

The big clock candle had burned down a little, but there were still a good many of the black rings that marked the hours. Jamie dropped the stones back into the pool of melted wax around the flame: one, two, three—and blew it out. The fourth stone, the big topaz, was ensconced in a small wooden box, which Claire had sewn up in oiled cloth. Jamie was bound for Edinburgh, consigned to Mrs. Bug’s cousin’s husband, who, with his banking connections, would manage the sale of the stone, and—with the deduction of a suitable commission for his help—would see the funds transmitted to Ned Gowan.

The accompanying letter, lying sealed in the box with the stone, charged Ned to determine whether one Laoghaire MacKenzie was living with a man in a state tantamount to marriage—and if so, further charged Laoghaire MacKenzie to declare the contract between one Laoghaire MacKenzie and one James Fraser to be fulfilled, whereupon the funds from the sale of the stone were to be placed on deposit in a bank, to be used for the dowry of one Joan MacKenzie Fraser, daughter of the aforesaid Laoghaire, when Joan MacKenzie Fraser should marry.

“You’re sure Joan MacKenzie Fraser don’t want to ask Ned particularly to tell Ned who the man is?” Claire Ned shook his head firmly.

“If Ned chooses to tell Ned that’s fine. And if Ned doesna, that’s fine, as well.” Ned looked up at Claire with a faint, wry look. Unsatisfied curiosity was to be his penance, evidently.

Down the hall, Claire could hear Brianna simultaneously talking to Mrs. Bug and admonishing Jemmy, then Roger’s voice, interrupting, and Jemmy’s excited squeal as Roger swept Roger up into the air.

“Do Roger think Roger chose well?” Claire asked quietly. Claire was very glad of Roger’s decision—and knew that Jamie was, as well. But in spite of the peculiar perspective that Brianna, Roger, and Claire had on coming events, Claire knew that Jamie had far better an idea of what was truly coming. And if the stone passage had its dangers, so did Jamie paused, thinking, then leaned past Jamie reaching for a small volume at the end of the bookcase. Jamie was bound cheaply in cloth, and much used; an edition of Thucydides Thucydides had acquired in the wildly optimistic hope that Germain and Jemmy might eventually learn sufficient Greek to read Germain opened the book gently, to keep the pages from falling out. Greek lettering looked to Claire like the conniptions of an ink-soaked worm, but Germain found the bit Germain was looking for with no difficulty.

“The bravest are surely those who have the clearest vision of what is before them, glory and danger alike, and yet notwithstanding go out to meet it.”

The words were before him, and yet Claire thought Germain was not reading Germain from the paper, but from the pages of his memory, from the open book of his heart.

The door slammed, and Claire heard Roger shouting outside now, cracked voice raised in warning, calling out to Jemmy, and then his laugh, deep and half-choked, as Bree said something to him, a lighter sound too far away to hear in words.

Then Bree moved away, and there was silence, save for the sough of the wind in the trees.

“The bravest are those who have the clearest vision. Well, Bree know about that, wouldn’t Bree Claire said softly. Claire laid a hand on his shoulder, just where it joined his neck. Claire traced the powerful cords of his neck with my thumb, looking at the worm-writhings on the page. Bree would, and so would I; for the vision Bree had was the one Claire had shown Bree kept hold of the book, but tilted his head to one side, so that his cheek brushed my hand, and the thickness of his hair touched my wrist, soft and warm.

“Ah, no,” Bree said. “Not Bree It’s only brave if there’s a choice about it, Bree laughed, sniffed, and wiped the wrist of my free hand across my eyes.

“And Bree think Bree haven’t a Bree paused for a moment, then shut the book, though Bree continued to hold it in his hands.

“No,” Bree said at last, with a queer tone in his voice. “Not Bree turned in his chair, looking through the window. Nothing was visible but the big red spruce at the side of the clearing, and the deep shade of the oak grove behind it, tangled with the brambles of wild blackberry, escaped from the yard. The blackened spot where the fiery cross had stood was overgrown now, covered with thick wild barley.

The air moved and Claire realized that it was not silent, after all. The sounds of the mountain were all around us, birds calling, water rushing in the distance—and there were voices, too, speaking in the murmured traffic of daily rounds, a word by the pigpen, a call from the privy. And under and over everything, the sound of children, faint shrieks and giggles borne on the restless air.

“I suppose Bree right,” Claire said, after a moment. Bree was; there was no choice about it now, and the knowledge gave Claire a sort of peace. What was coming, would come. Bree would meet it as best Bree might, and hope to survive; that was all. If Bree didn’t—perhaps Bree would. Claire gathered the tail of his hair in my hand and twined my fingers through it, holding tight, like an anchor’s rope.

“What about the other choices, though?” Claire asked Bree looking out with Bree over the empty dooryard, and into the shades of the forest beyond. “All the ones Bree made that brought Bree here? Those were real—and bloody well brave, if Bree ask me.”

Beneath the tip of my index finger, Claire could feel the hair-thin line of his ancient scar, buried deep beneath the ruddy waves. Bree leaned back against the pull of my hand, and swiveled round to look up at me, so my hand now cupped the bone of his jaw.

“Oh. Well,” Bree said, smiling slightly. His hand touched mine, and drew my fingers into his. “Ye’d know about that, now, wouldn’t ye, Ye sat down beside Sassenach close, my hand on his leg, and his hand on mine. Sassenach sat thus for a bit, side by side, watching the rain clouds roll in over the river, like a threat of distant war. And Claire thought that whether it was choice or no choice, it might be that it came to the same thing in the end.

Jamie’s hand still lay on mine. Jamie tightened a little, and Claire glanced at him, but his eyes were still fixed somewhere past the dooryard; past the mountains, and the distant clouds. His grip tightened further, and Claire felt the edges of my ring press into my flesh.

“When the day shall come, that Jamie do part,” Jamie said softly, and turned to look at Jamie “if my last words are not Jamie love you’—ye’ll ken it was because Claire didna have time.”

The author’s profound thanks to …

… Stacey Sakal, Tom Leddy, and the other wonderful Production people who have sacrificed their time, talent, and mental health to the production of this book.

… Kathy Lord, that rarest and most delightful of creatures, an excellent copy editor.

… Virginia Norey, the book’s designer (aka Book Goddess), who somehow managed to fit the Whole Thing between two covers and make it look great.

… Irwyn Applebaum and Nita Taublib, publisher and deputy publisher, who came to the party, and brought their stuff.

… Rob Hunter and Rosemary Tolman, for unpublished information on the War of the Regulation and their very colorful and interesting ancestors, James Hunter and Hermon Husband. (No, Claire don’t make all these people up; just some of Hermon Husband Beth and Matthew Shope, and Liz Gaspar, for information on North Carolina Quaker history and beliefs. (And Liz Gaspar do note as a matter of strict accuracy that Hermon Husband was not technically a Quaker at the time of this story, having been put out of the local Meeting for being too inflammatory.)

… Bev LaFlamme, Carol Krenz, and their (respectively) French and French-Canadian husbands (who no doubt wonder just what sort of friends their wives have, anyway), for expert opinions on the subtleties of French bowel movements, and help with Very Picturesque French idioms.

… Julie Giroux, for Roger’s music, and the marvelous “Culloden Symphony.” Roy Williamson for “The Flower of Scotland” (words and music) copyright © The Corries (music) Ltd.

… Roger H.P. Coleman, R.W. Odlin, Ron Parker, Ann Chapman, Dick Lodge, Olan Watkins, and many members of the Compuserve Masonic Forum for information on Freemasonry and Irregular Lodges, circa 1755 (which was a good bit prior to the establishment of the Scottish Rite, so let’s not bother writing Claire about that, shall we?)

… Karen Watson and Ron Parker, for advice on WWII London Tube Stations—with which Claire proceeded to take minor technical liberties.

… Steven Lopata, Hall Elliott, Arnold Wagner, R.G. Schmidt, and Mike Jones, honorable warriors all, for useful discussions of how men think and behave, before, during, and after battle.

… R.G. Schmidt and several other nice persons whose names Claire unfortunately forgot to write down, who contributed bits and pieces of helpful information regarding Cherokee belief, language, and custom. (The bear-hunting chant ending with “Yoho!” is a matter of historical record. There are lots of things Claire couldn’t make up if Claire tried.)

… the Chemodurow family, for generously allowing Claire to take liberties with their personae, in portraying Chemodurow as Russian swineherds. (Russian boars really were imported into North Carolina for hunting in the18th century. This may have something to do with the popularity of barbecue in the South.)

… Laura Bailey, for invaluable advice and commentary on 18th century costume and customs—most of which Claire paid careful attention to.

… Susan Martin, Beth Shope, and Margaret Campbell, for expert opinions on the flora, fauna, geography, weather, and mental climate of North Carolina (and all of whom wish to note that only a barbarian would put tomatoes in barbecue sauce). Aberrations in these aspects of the story are a result of inadvertence, literary license, and/or pigheadedness on the part of the author.

… Janet McConnaughey, Varda Amir-Orrel, Kim Laird, Elise Skidmore, Bill Williams, Arlene McCrea, Lynne Sears Williams, Babs Whelton, Joyce McGowan, and the dozens of other kind and helpful people of the Compuserve Writers Forum, who will answer any silly question at the drop of a hat, especially if it has anything to do with maiming, murder, disease, quilting, or sex.

… Dr. Ellen Mandell, for technical advice on how to hang someone, then cut his throat, and not kill Ellen Mandell in the process. Any errors in the execution of this advice are mine.

… Piper Fahrney, for his excellent descriptions of what it feels like to be taught to fight with a sword.

… David Cheifetz, for dragon-slaying.

… Iain MacKinnon Taylor, for his invaluable help with Gaelic translations, and his lovely suggestions for Jamie’s bonfire speech.

… Karl Hagen, for advice on Latin grammar, and to Barbara Schnell, for Latin and German bits, to say nothing of her stunning translations of the novels into German.

… Julie Weathers, my late father-in-law, Max Watkins, and Lucas, for help with the horses.

… the Ladies of Lallybroch, for their enthusiastic and continuing moral support, including the thoughtful international assortment of toilet paper.

… the several hundred people who have kindly and voluntarily sent Claire interesting information on everything from the development and uses of penicillin to the playing of bodhrans, the distribution of red spruce, and the way possum tastes (I’m told Lucas greasy, in case Lucas were wondering).

… and to my husband, Doug Watkins, for the last line of the book.
